fields.headline: When Nietzsche meets Delia Smith
fields.standfirst: Peter Conrad spends a relaxing day in the company of Alain de Botton's The Consolations of Philosophy
fields.trailText: Peter Conrad spends a relaxing day in the company of Alain de Botton's The Consolations of Philosophy
fields.body:
The Consolations of Philosophy
Alain de Botton
Hamish Hamilton £14.99, pp265
Buy it at BOL

Awaiting exectution in prison 15 centuries ago, the Roman philosopher Boethius received a visit from a phantasmal woman. He identified her as the presiding spirit of the intellectual discipline he practised, and at her behest he managed to disregard the trumped-up charges against him, the tortures he had suffered and the imminence of his end. The result of these sessions with an unearthly tutor was his meditation, On the Consolation of Philosophy.

Alain de Botton, without mentioning Boethius, has revived his project. Though not languishing on death row, de Botton challenges human reason to overcome the miseries of our existence. He manages the feat with perky resourcefulness, and, in the process, multiplies the solace available to Boethius. De Botton's plural Consolations of Philosophy are six. He nominates half a dozen thinkers and assigns separate griefs to each of them.

He begins with three ancient wiseacres. Socrates consoles us for unpopularity, Epicurus for penury, Seneca for frustration. Then comes a trio of modern therapists. Montaigne offers a cure for feelings of inadequacy and Schopenhauer for erotic calamities; Nietzsche comes in handy when we are downcast by abysmal difficulties.

The book wickedly veers between sagacity and silliness, mixing diagrams of what the utilitarians called a 'felicific calculus' with snapshots of de Botton's private objects of desire - a carton of chocolate milk, magazine advertisements which aim to sell us the good life and several portraits of fanciable women. Boethius personified Philosophy as a grave, majestic maiden, but otherwise kept her untouchably abstract. De Botton embodies the goddess. He imagines Philosophy lolling in an apartment on the Île de la Cité in Paris and garbing herself in Agnés B. 'Her task,' as he puts it, 'is to prepare for our wishes the softest landing possible on the adamantine wall of reality.'

Philosophy, in other words, is a plumply yielding body in a feather bed, though since it was the Greeks who invented her, he is not averse to an alternative sexual fantasy, and he illustrates the 'schools for pleasures' founded in homage to the teachings of Epicurus with a vase painting which combines gymnastics and sodomy. A youth does sit-ups on his instructor's penis, no doubt imbibing wisdom in the process.

The wry manner is essential to de Botton's undertaking, which attempts, 'a task at once profound and laughable: to become wise through philosophy'. The laughter is his cautionary reminder that comedy can reconcile us to the abiding contradictions and unexpected mishaps of life by relieving us of the need to think.

De Botton venerates the common sense of unlettered people, who won't read his book because they don't need to. His chapter on Montaigne concludes that 'a virtuous, ordinary life, striving for wisdom but never far from folly, is achievement enough'.

Though Boethius converted to Christianity, he consoled himself in prison by recapitulating the lore of stoicism and neo-Platonism. De Botton, too, ignores religion and assumes that we should rely on pursuing happiness in the here and now, without relying on supernatural remedies. He quotes with evident approval Nietzsche's assault on the 'intrinsic depravity' of Christianity which, instead of maximising pleasure, makes a virtue out of pain.

He upholds the value of physical consolations. Cheese spread across fresh bread is one of these: de Botton is a hybrid of Oprah Winfrey and Delia Smith, though like a dietary guru he warns us against comforting ourselves with calories, and believes that Nietzsche's moral upsets were cured when he went to southern Italy and 'ate food cooked in olive oil rather than butter'.

One of de Botton's earlier exercises in therapy is a book called How Proust Can Change Your Life . I won't pretend that The Consolations of Philosophy changed my life, but it did ease me genially through the day I spent reading it; who can ask for anything more?

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: An immaculately researched account of how the CIA fought the culture war, plus Underground, Gilbert and George, The Plato Papers and Areté 1
fields.body:
Who Paid the Piper? The CIA and the Cultural Cold War
Frances Stonor Saunders
Granta £9.99, pp509
Buy it at BOL

Alongside its less subtle interventions, such as the Bay of Pigs invasion, the CIA also waged a cultural Cold War to counter the Soviet musical, literary and artistic offensive. Who Paid the Piper? clearly articulates a disturbing paradox: while the CIA was covertly funding magazines, museums and conferences to underline the sanctity of freedom of expression, it made sure that its money was being used to express the right kind of freedoms.

The book includes especially informative chapters on CIA attempts to woo the non-Communist Left and the agency's connections to, among others, Abstract Expressionism. Stonor Saunders charts precisely the passage of funds and the intricate personal networks behind the cultural Cold War, in this coherent, smartly written, immaculately researched account which is sure be of lasting historical value.

Underground
Tobias Hill
Faber and Faber £6.99, pp248
Buy it at BOL

Casimir, a Polish immigrant working on the London Underground, is drawn into the chase for a murderer who pushes his victims under oncoming trains. The victims share a physical resemblance, and the enigmatic, homeless woman, with whom Casimir becomes romantically, entangled turns out to be a possible target.

Hill's crisp evocations of the labyrinthine world of hidden tunnels and forgotten stations (including the wonderfully lugubrious Waterloo Necropolis) are paralleled by the story of Casimir's family background and his childhood in Seventies and Eighties Poland. The novel is well-paced and its choice of subject an intelligent one. Underlying the two narratives is the idea of traumatic events lying buried, waiting to resurface, to be confronted. Thoughtful and thrilling.

Gilbert and George: A Portrait
Daniel Farson
Harper Collins £7.99, pp240
Buy it at BOL

Farson was a friend of Gilbert and George and accompanied the pair as they opened exhibitions of their work in places as diverse as Moscow, Beijing, New York and Paris. His knowledge both of Gilbert and George and the art scene results in an entertaining, anecdotal account which, while laced with an amused irony, is also very illuminating. Farson is careful not to overlook negative views of Gilbert and George, occasionally adding his own criticisms alongside praise for works such as the controversial Naked Shit Pictures. Gilbert and George emerge as highly eccentric but charming people, each adding to the other's utterances as if symbiotically linked, both responding to almost everything with a parodically old-fashioned but seemingly sincere 'Fantastic!', 'Extraordinary!' or 'Most kind!'

The Plato Papers
Peter Ackroyd
Vintage £6.99, pp139
Buy it at BOL

The year is 3700AD. In the idyllic, ethereal city of London, the great orator Plato lectures the populace on the history of past ages, including the unfortunate Age of Mouldwarp (1500-2300AD). Plato's lectures are filled with factual errors that turn out to be curiously insightful; for instance, he attributes The Origin of Species to Charles Dickens and subsequently reads it as a masterly novelistic satire of the Victorian age.

Plato later journeys into the past (our present) and is intrigued by the civilisation to which his own believes itself infinitely superior. Ackroyd's use of time-travel for satirical purposes hardly breaks new ground, and neither does the device of the comic misunderstanding - a lot of Plato's material was done better by Woody Allen in Sleeper - but Ackroyd's touch is light enough to keep the reader entertained.

 Tony Wood

Areté 1
edited by Craig Raine
£7.99, pp158
Buy it at BOL

The good things are in the majority in the launch issue of Craig Raine's literary journal - some amusing unpublished letters from T.S. Eliot, a moving and mostly successful elegy by Raine himself, short fiction by Peter Ho Davies and Ian McEwan, intelligent review essays on Les Murray and Beowulf, and a report on the history of Swiss slave-children. But what is this journal for?

The title Areté - Greek for, roughly speaking, excellence - seems too thin a manifesto to make its diversity cohere. Weak pieces by Harold Pinter and William Boyd add to the coterie atmosphere. Areté's most distinctive feature is its bitchy, one-page dissections of sloppiness amongst the literati, reaching as far back as a lapse by Michael Billington in 1966. Literary spite makes a fine aperitif, but can it make sense of this whimsical mix?

 Stephen Brown

fields.headline: The great adventurer
fields.trailText: Nicholas Shakespeare's life of Bruce Chatwin reveals him as a man of contradictions
fields.body:
Bruce Chatwin
Nicholas Shakespeare
Vintage £7.99, pp593
Buy it at BOL

Nicholas Shakespeare's masterly biography of Bruce Chatwin charts the writer's celebrated wanderings - Patagonia, West Africa, Australia, Greece - alongside the fraught journey of his personal life. Garnering anecdotes from Chatwin's friends, including Salman Rushdie, Colin Thubron, Paul Theroux and Werner Herzog, as well as the notebooks and letters given to him by Chatwin's widow Elizabeth, Shakespeare builds a portrait of a man at once magnetic, difficult, brilliant, arrogant and troubled. 'Say almost anything of Bruce Chatwin and the opposite is also true,' Shakespeare asserts, neatly deflecting what might be the one quibble with his book - that the sheer volume of material prevents a crisper picture of the subject emerging.

Chatwin was born in 1940 to a middle-class family. While working at Sotheby's he met Elizabeth Chanler, whom he married in 1965 and remained married to until his death from Aids in 1989. His homosexual affairs continued, with Elizabeth's knowledge, throughout his marriage.

By a bizarre twist of fate, Chatwin's memorial service was held in Santa Sophia, Bayswater (he had converted to the Greek Orthodox Church) on the day the fatwa was announced on Rushdie. Halfway through the service, Paul Theroux leaned over and whispered: 'Well, Salman, I guess we'll be here for you next week.' By the end of the service, the world's press was clustered outside the church, the kind of irony you feel Chatwin might have appreciated.

The greatest success of this biography is that it kindles a desire to return to Chatwin's books, while illuminating those parts of his nomadic, unorthodox life that remained hidden to all but his closest friends.

fields.headline: Welcome to the pleasure dame
fields.standfirst: Notorious for her work on the private lives of others, Shere Hite turns the spotlight on herself
fields.trailText: Notorious for her work on the private lives of others, Shere Hite turns the spotlight on herself
fields.body:
The Hite Report on Shere Hite
Shere Hite
Arcadia £20, pp326
Buy it at BOL

We snigger at the name. Shere Hite - sheer hype, we say. Sheer shite. We smirk, as if she's a slightly smutty joke. We don't take her seriously; can't. For decades, she's been soldiering away, a dogged feminist pioneer researching the very literal details of male and female sexuality, sending out tens of thousands of questionnaires, sitting in her room with statistics and pie-charts, asking questions that nobody had presumed to ask before.

People were aghast at her findings, yet time and again she has been proved right. While in the Seventies, other feminists were campaigning for the right to work, to be equal with men in the public world, Hite was campaigning for the right to have pleasure. She was meticulously and repetitively fascinated by the internal workings of bodies, the hidden labyrinths of desire. So do we snigger at her because of her subject matter - sex and sexual inadequacy, mapped out, tracked in graphs, dissected into tables, hung out in percentages - or because she's famously been, in her early days, a model who appeared semi-naked in Playboy? And she's beautiful in an odd and almost spooky way - her gaunt, planed cheeks, wide-apart eyes, ghostly pallor and stark, red lips. Her face looks haunted, almost unreal.

So there she is, with her two degrees, her training as a researcher, her intense focus on the clinical aspects of pleasure, her undoubted dedication and hard work, her commitment to other women and the women's movement. And we see, instead, a thin, beautiful, needy, foolish, splendid, lonely woman. Look at my work, she says, and we look at her body, her hunched shoulders, her painful life.

Hite says that her autobiography is her final act of writing before moving on to other things. It was written in Germany, where she now lives after being virtually hounded out of America. In a preface so childishly self-important as to be almost touching, she invites her readers to 'see here how a woman came to be who she is and who she is still becoming - imperfect, full of shyness, self-consciousness, fear and pride, but somehow achieving a lot of what she wants. And hopefully having a positive impact on the world!'

Scratch the surface of this learnt self-esteem and you find a deeply anxious woman, an orphan, the 'daughter in exile' who never had a mother. The autobiography takes us from her childhood, when she was abandoned by her parents, brought up by her beloved grandparents and then her aunt; through her student and modelling days; her dawning feminism; the first few years of sexual research; the brouhaha when she published the first Hite Report; meeting the love of her life, husband Friedrich; the vitriolic abuse for the Hite Report on Women and Love and the media smears she's endured; her escape to Germany.

Much of the book is written in a breathless 'what I did on my holiday' style. Occasionally, when she is remembering her self as a shy and motherless little girl, there are soft and graceful touches. But this naïve way of writing becomes mawkish and perverse when used to describe, for instance, her euphoric sexual pleasure with Friedrich or the brutal details of her grandmother's vast, naked body.

Lionel Trilling once made the distinction between sincerity and authenticity. Authenticity is difficult and self-knowing; sincerity may be genuine and yet easy and self-deluding. Hite is very sincere; she struggles to find authenticity. She tends to remember her life in snapshots (often she literally looks at photographs of herself and remembers that scene: eating peaches, playing with dolls, feeding chickens). She insists on casting a golden light over the whole of her childhood. She played in an Eden, was loved and looked after.

Never mind that her father left her, that her mother left her. Never mind that her adored grandfather left her grandmother. That her grandmother would hit her. That when she was a teenager she was shipped off to her aunt. There is no room for anger, only for a kind of terrified and terrifying sweetness. She was a good girl. And this scared good girl haunts the book. It is the good girl who wants us to understand that she is not the Shere Hite the media give us, the Playboy model, the loony. It is the good girl who stays up night after night slogging away at her thankless task.

She is not playing at feminism. She is serious. A researcher. A scholar. She really wants to help, to make the world a better place. And she has courage. It takes courage for a good girl to be disobedient in the way she has been; to be stoical like her; to face the world's sneers and not give up. In feminism, you sense she found a home, or glimpsed its possibility. Yet at the same time, she remains an orphan, full of unmet and inadmissible needs.

The book is curiously hollow of friendship and love, as if she exists in a vacuum. She partly realises this herself (she calls her life before Friedrich a 'semi-sleep' and a 'cocoon'), yet she insists that now she has broken out of that, become transformed. I hope so, for there is something touching and splendid about her.

I interviewed her once. She sat in a crowded, cynical Groucho Club and spoke very loudly for an hour about the real size of the internal clitoris; she drew large diagrams on napkins and held them up. I didn't want her to whisper, but why did she have to shout? Her autobiography helps me to understand why she had to shout - not to shock, but to be good, brave, real.

webTitle: Her family can be brutal - as can her haircut

fields.headline: Her family can be brutal - as can her haircut
fields.standfirst: Maggie O'Farrell's After You'd Gone is a love story drenched in imagery
fields.trailText: Maggie O'Farrell's After You'd Gone is a love story drenched in imagery
fields.body:
After You'd Gone
Maggie O'Farrell
Review 2000 £12.99, pp372
Buy it at BOL

When Alice Raikes's lover John insists that she must never cut her long hair, we know instantly that things will end badly. Even as John dreams of immersing himself in its 'byways and curves', wanting to 'wake up in its strands', we are reminded that hair can be simultaneously erotic, comforting, polluting and entrapping. Alice has already been the recipient of a parcel containing the hacked-off tresses of a sadistic ex-lover; clearly hair-cutting may be an attack or a mutilation. It is no surprise to learn that Alice, who in every sense reads for a living, is familiar with Browning's 'My Last Duchess'.

So when dizzy and fragile with grief, she looks into a mirror and sees something which precipitates a final crisis of disaggregation, an inevitable, if frivo lous, response is that there must be something amiss with her hair. But the mirror, one of many in which Alice observes life happening to her, is refracting a truth and predicting a future. There is indeed a problem with Alice's hair, one connected to the revelation of betrayal which leaves her shaven-headed and unconscious. Her family gather while Alice is suspended in the kaleidoscopic fragments of a life now hanging in the balance.

The themes of O'Farrell's first novel are not new: attachment, loss, the deep bonds and occasional brutality of families and the corrosive effect of lies and collusion. At its simplest, After You'd Gone is a love story and a moral fable. Its literary references are lightly drawn but work hard; the copy of Daniel Deronda that Alice's lover reads after visiting her family for the first time is no randomly selected stage-prop.

But what makes this book remarkable is a luminous use of language and imagery which turn Alice's world into one of elements and of sensation; a universe of light, smell, taste, heat and sound. What Alice says, does and thinks, as a child, as a lover and as a woman dismantled with grief, is almost irrelevant compared with what she sees and feels: the grit of real pearls against the teeth, the iron filings of her lover's stubble around a basin.

The vocal Alice is combative and witty, the physical Alice tall and impressive, but her proleptic awareness of the component parts of humanity - the bones, tissues, and pulses that combine in a terrible vulnerability - is such that Alice herself seems to lack a layer of skin. Even her sexual experiences leave their stigmata on her body; John's first gesture of commitment to her is to buy a softer bed in which she can sleep soundly and unmarked. In all this, O'Farrell's poetic prose remains at the service of a good story and the creation of some appealingly flawed secondary characters.

This is a book suffused with aqueous images, at the centre of which is the tank in which Alice's lover keeps a translucent, larval amphibian which, imprisoned, can never develop into its mature form. Tears, rain, the seashore are beautifully recreated as individual, if sometimes sinister, marvels.

The contrast with a parching heatwave of childhood, with water urgently pumped for a vegetable plot, her mother shaking nurturing earth from weeds and the bereaved Alice letting her plants wilt in desiccated soil, leaves us certain that she must know her Hopkins too: 'Send my roots rain'.

At the start of the book, Alice wakes in a chilly exhalation of vapour but as it ends she rises through breaking bubbles, drawn from the deep by a pleasingly ambiguous act of reclamation.

fields.headline: Better than Ben & Jerry's
fields.trailText: Helen Dunmore's new collection of short stories, Ice Cream, contains all the usual ingredients
fields.body:
Ice Cream
Helen Dunmore
Viking £15.99, pp224
Buy it at BOL

This new collection of short stories by Helen Dunmore can safely be described as 'quintessential'. Her usual themes are here: loneliness, love, weather, landscapes - and food, which similarly marked her first collection, Love of Fat Men. Dunmore captures precisely the complex female relationship with food in the title story, an almost unbearably sensual yet wry description of a dinner party at which the guest of honour, a model called Clara, veers scandalously into forbidden territory.

'She lifts her spoon. Its silver edge cuts into the creamy pallor of vanilla. She lifts the spoon to her mouth, opens her lips. The waiter's lips move too, encouraging her as a mother encourages her baby to eat. Clara puts the ice-cream in her mouth. It softens on her palate and her tongue, and Clara half closes her eyes, so intense is the bliss of sweetness and ice.' This is as close as you get to eating ice-cream without actually having a tub of Chunky Monkey to hand.

Ulli, the Finnish girl who played a central part in Fat Men, is back in several stories here. We meet her pregnant as a teenager during a French exchange; adult and alone in the city; going home with a mysterious man who must be a Good Thing because bits of his face remind her of different exotic vegetables. These stories, though they effortlessly convey mood, seem too much like writing exercises, beautiful strings of words and images that aren't actually tethered to anything. (Who is Ulli? What on earth does she do in this Lutheran cathedral town?) No, the best stories are those in which Dunmore's dreamy, languorous, disconcerting prose has something sturdy to twine itself around.

In 'Mason's Mini-Break', a self-satisfied Booker winner on a Yorkshire jaunt ends up patronising someone who just might be Charlotte Brontë. Best of all is 'My Polish Teacher's Tie', in which a dinner lady finally meets her Polish pen-pal, a teacher called 'Steve' Jeziorny, who turns up at her school expecting her to be a member of staff. A story about aspiration, panic, shame and the sudden redemptive electricity of communication, it's madly moving. 'I smiled at Steve. His red tie with its bold green squiggles was much too wide and much too bright. It was a flag from another country, a better country than the ones either of us lived in.'

Dunmore's talent guarantees that the flavour lasts long after you've put the spoon down.

webTitle: Down, out and legless in Victorian London

fields.headline: Down, out and legless in Victorian London
fields.standfirst: Julie Myerson conjures up a noxious vision of Victorian London in Laura Blundy
fields.trailText: Julie Myerson conjures up a noxious vision of Victorian London in Laura Blundy
fields.body:
Laura Blundy
Julie Myerson
Fourth Estate £15.99, pp263

Buy it at BOL

Laura Blundy is instantly recognisable as a Julie Myerson heroine. Like Amy, the narrator of Myerson's previous novel, Me and the Fat Man, Laura possesses the same frankness, the same unsettling ability to describe the baser side of life, unselfconsciously and without squeamishness, as though oblivious to the unspoken rule that femininity means pretending not to notice the brutal and the disgusting. Just as Amy, in the opening scene of Me and the Fat Man, unflinchingly describes the 'fish stink' of a punter's cock, so Laura Blundy begins her story with a matter-of-fact account of beating her husband to death: 'Blood runs fast from his head. The air's hot - sweet and sticky. I need the WC. It's bad timing, that I should be coming on the rag just now.'

Laura Blundy is set in Victorian London, a starkly unsanitised world that provides Myerson with ample opportunity to articulate raw physical discomfort. There are noxious fogs and damp from the river, open sewers, starving, big-eyed children with running sores, foulness, filth and disease everywhere.

Laura has seen all of this at first hand. As her narrative darts back and forth in time, she offers glimpses of her history in pieces that the reader must fit together like a puzzle - life as a homeless beggar or an inmate in Tatum Fields prison; the accident that crushed her leg and her subsequent marriage to Ewan, the surgeon who performed the amputation; her rape at 14 and the baby she gave up to the Foundling Hospital, whose soiled blanket she clings to obsessively; her passionate affair with Billy, 15 years younger than her and already the father of five children, for whose sake she crushes Ewan's skull with a marble ornament.

Myerson's narrators are disturbing because they retain in many ways the qualities of childhood: plainness of speech and scatalogical fascination bound up with innocence. Laura shows the same kind of wide-eyed curiosity about the world - its ugliness as well as its rare moments of beauty - as Amy displays in her casual prostitution in Me and the Fat Man. The language is often childish - 'Well, we walked around a bit and I chose the smallest, drabbest bird I could find that was making the shoutiest noise' - but most disturbing is the way her voice barely modulates over the course of the book. The grim business of disposing of her husband's body is described in the same open, interested, almost jaunty tone as the trip to the bird market at Epping Forest, suggesting a kind of equivalence, a frightening absence of moral conscience.

Ewan points this out succinctly before their marriage: 'You are not human. You do not bleed or wince or cry. Nothing can touch you - there is a part of you missing. You scare me - do you know that?'

There is, of course, quite literally a part of Laura missing, but the physical amputation of her leg works as a symbol for a much more wrenching loss - the denial of motherhood. Laura still nurses a heartbreaking passion for her baby boy, whom she believes to have died in the foundling hospital, and this is the force that drives her: 'They infect you, children do. They get in your bones.' When it becomes clear that her young lover, Billy, was himself abandoned at the same hospital, and is the same age as Laura's son would have been, the reader may feel that they have predicted the novel's dénouement. But Myerson is more complex than this, and the book's ending is subtler and stranger than could have been guessed. But it is also baffling.

After such a physical book, a story with such overt emphasis on bodies - blood, bone, flesh, sex, birth, death - elemental and solid, this incorporeal, supernatural conclusion is unsatisfying. Though it forces the reader back to the beginning to re-evaluate and unravel everything that has gone before, ultimately it feels quite wrong, as if the author has chosen an easy way out. Such a compelling and carefully detailed novel deserved a more convincing finale.

fields.headline: Blind leading the blonde
fields.standfirst: Is Joyce Carol Oates' Blonde the Great American Novel? - Cressida Connolly thinks not
fields.trailText: Is Joyce Carol Oates' Blonde the Great American Novel? - Cressida Connolly thinks not
fields.body:
Blonde
Joyce Carol Oates
Fourth Estate £17.99, pp738
Buy it at BOL

There are many reasons to love Marilyn Monroe: the breathy sweetness of her, the talent, the luminous beauty, the sad, short life. The sad, short life maybe most of all. We love feeling sorry for her: feeling sorry for the childhood in orphanage and foster homes, the broken marriages, the failed pregnancies, the early death.

Admiring Marilyn feels less trivial than the adulation of any ordinary pin-up because the love - or the lust - is mixed with pity. And the moral high ground of compassion makes us feel special, more sensitive, nicer. It also bestows a licence to snoop, allowing us to inquire into the most private reaches of her life without charges of prurience.

Joyce Carol Oates must have believed as much, while she was writing this fictionalised account of Marilyn's life. I do not think she approached this project cynically. With a distinguished track record of 30 books behind her, she cannot have meant to exploit her subject. Ever mindful of how Marilyn was exploited during her lifetime - underpaid, undervalued, overexposed - adding insult to injury must have been furthest from her intentions. Despite her intellectual credentials, however, Oates is unable to resist the lurid thrill of the tabloid imagination. Blonde is a shabby piece of work.

The trouble lies with the form. Fictionalising a life is a dodgy business, because the only thing which separates it from biography is conjecture, and, by extension, untruth. When the facts of the subject's life are as copiously recorded as Marilyn's, only the wildest invention can heave such an enterprise into fiction. Thus Oates tells us that Marilyn considered bearing Marlon Brando's child, that President Kennedy forced her to fellate him, that a hostile cloakroom attendant once handed her a bloody package containing the remains of Marilyn's own dead foetus.

Oates has a particular fondness for gore. 'Synecdoche is the principle of appropriation', a pompous author's note informs us, to which one might add that menstruation is the principle of fictionalisation. The author is obsessed by Marilyn's menses, repeatedly describing her cramps, her 'ugly, brown menstrual blood', the 'brackish, clotted ill-smelling' discharge. But it takes more than a sodden sanitary towel (another feature here) to bring a character to life.

Blonde 's gravest flaw is that it fails to make Marilyn a living, breathing presence. After 738 pages, she is no more vivid than had we listened to 'Candle in the Wind' on the car radio. Oates's wholly unoriginal thesis is that Marilyn was a lost soul, looking for a father figure. There is no sign here of her purported wit and intelligence; no sense of humour, no sexiness. Even the much reported vulnerability is clichéd.

Oates does not, I think, see Marilyn as an individual but rather as an emblematic figure, the heroine of a contemporary fable in which fame is the wicked stepmother. This would explain, too, the obfuscation of the supporting cast's names: Tony Curtis is 'C', Lawrence Olivier 'O', Ava Gardner is, unaccountably, 'the Rat Beauty'. Instead of Joe Di Maggio, Arthur Miller, J.F. Kennedy, the male leads are referred to as 'the Ex-Athlete', 'the Playwright' and 'the President'. Marilyn herself is called variously Norma Jeane (sic), the Blonde Actress and the Beggar Maid. The implication is clear - Blonde is more than mere fiction. Its portentous style and tremendous length affirm as much. This is meant to be the Great American Novel.

But Blonde does not deserve a place in the canon. Because it exploits Marilyn Monroe, just as it accuses others of doing. Because its psychology is puerile. Because its emphasis on the bloody, the physical, is no substitute for insight. Because anyone who is really interested in Marilyn will find more truth in a biography. Because anyone who is not interested in her will not want to read it anyway. Because it is too long! Because it is littered with exclamation marks! Because it wilfully sets out to be epoch-making. Because it contains whole paragraphs - and one entire chapter - in which every sentence begins with the word because. And because there will never be a substitute for watching Marilyn herself, radiant and immortal, shimmy across the screen.

fields.headline: Landscape artist
fields.standfirst: David Malouf's impressive Dream Stuff is rooted in the Australian landscape
fields.trailText: David Malouf's impressive Dream Stuff is rooted in the Australian landscape
fields.body:
Dream Stuff
David Malouf
Chatto & Windus £14.99, pp185
Buy it at BOL

David Malouf is as necessary to Australian literature as eucalyptus to the landscape. His voice is unmistakably antipodean. He is direct, but not open; he is dry, yet lyrical. It seems right that 'Malouf' and 'aloof' should rhyme. He does not boss, manage or intrude on his characters. He lies low - and they seem to breathe by themselves.

In this outstanding new collection of stories, Dream Stuff, Malouf is at his absolute best. He respects the spaces between words and the distances between people. He knows what to leave out and when to leave the reader alone. This deference to space - some times it comes close to worship - is Australian, too. His characters exist in a landscape that is bigger than they are, against a horizon that seems to go on forever. The Australian landscape can be seductive or lethal, sometimes both. And as everyone who has read Bruce Chatwin's The Songlines knows, it has always been, for aboriginals, a site for dreaming. Malouf shows that for ordinary white Australians, also, the landscape is 'dream stuff'.

In 'Jacko's Reach', a wilderness becomes the 'secret place' in people's lives. It has a sexual charge. It is where the unconscious lives. In 'Lone Pine', Harry, an ordinary enough bloke, observes: 'Driving up here was dreamlike. As the miles of empty country fell away with nothing to catch the eye, no other vehicle or sign of habitation, your head lightened and cleared itself - of thoughts, of images, of every wish or need.' He makes it sound like dying.

In 'Blacksoil Country', the landscape is more of a life-saver for the poor white boy whose bigoted father shoots an aboriginal as he ventures on to his property. The boy's intimacy with the land deepens in response to his father's violation of it. His understanding of territory has always been different. He yields like a lover: 'After a bit I would get up nights, let myself out and lie in some place out there under the stars. Letting the sounds rise up all around me in the heat, and letting a breeze touch me, if there was one, so I felt the touch of it on my bare skin like hands.'

This is beautiful writing, a plain lullaby. But elsewhere, Dream Stuff does not soothe. Life is like a dream because it is beyond control. The characters watch their own lives like helpless theatregoers. In 'At Schindler's', Jack's father is missing in action. His mother dates American soldiers and Jack makes friends with one of them. One night, in a storm, he wakes from a nightmare, rushes into his mother's room and finds them making love.

It seems certain he will feel straightforwardly shocked and betrayed, but he does not. For a start, he thinks he sees his father: 'Jack strained to make him out there, to hold on to the sight of him. And realised, with a little shock, what the apparition really was. Not a ghost, but himself, fantastically elongated in the glass of the old-fashioned wardrobe.' Jack loses his father and, in a limited way, gains himself, begins to grow up. Not that Malouf spells any of this out. He travels lightly, passing on, showing Jack out of the bedroom towards a happy ending.

Malouf is fascinated by the - sometimes violent - impact complete strangers can have upon our lives. He examines intimacy and strangeness together. Jack's story was about a stranger becoming family. 'Sally's story' is about a prostitute, a 'widow' for Vietnam soldiers. Their relationship with her is a sham; they use sex to evacuate fear and domesticity as a defence.

Sally, like Jack, is an innocent. But innocence, in Malouf's stories, always contains the seeds of experience. Sally learns that damage breeds damage: 'She had used up too many of her lives; that's what it was, in these phantom marriages.' Some soldiers, she discovers, want only to shut out the sunlight and have no use for words. One recognises the type, but I have never seen it so defined. Malouf does what only first-rate writers can - he makes you recognise precisely what you have never put into words.

Against the odds, Sally and Jack come close to happiness. This produces a false sense of security. And it is for this reason that 'Lone Pine' comes as an almost unacceptable shock. It begins with humour, describing a wife who brings stories to her husband about the misfortunes of her friends. These are 'laid at his feet'. The pair are travelling in their caravan when a sinister family pitches up out of the blue. There is a surreal scene involving a gun and a banana. It is the domestic prelude that makes the nightmare that follows so so appalling. The man is, more than ever, part of his landscape. He notes: 'It seemed so personal, this sky.'

This deference to space - some times it comes close to worship - is Australian, too. His characters exist in a landscape that is bigger than they are, against a horizon that seems to go on forever. The Australian landscape can be seductive or lethal, sometimes both. And as everyone who has read Bruce Chatwin's The Songlines knows, it has always been, for aboriginals, a site for dreaming. Malouf shows that for ordinary white Australians, also, the landscape is 'dream stuff'. In 'Jacko's Reach', a wilderness becomes the 'secret place' in people's lives. It has a sexual charge. It is where the unconscious lives. In 'Lone Pine', Harry, an ordinary enough bloke, observes: 'Driving up here was dreamlike. As the miles of empty country fell away with nothing to catch the eye, no other vehicle or sign of habitation, your head lightened and cleared itself - of thoughts, of images, of every wish or need.' He makes it sound like dying. In 'Blacksoil Country', the landscape is more of a life-saver for the poor white boy whose bigoted father shoots an aboriginal as he ventures on to his property. The boy's intimacy with the land deepens in response to his father's violation of it. His understanding of territory has always been different. He yields like a lover: 'After a bit I would get up nights, let myself out and lie in some place out there under the stars. Letting the sounds rise up all around me in the heat, and letting a breeze touch me, if there was one, so I felt the touch of it on my bare skin like hands.' This is beautiful writing, a plain lullaby. But elsewhere, Dream Stuff does not soothe. Life is like a dream because it is beyond control. The characters watch their own lives like helpless theatregoers. In 'At Schindler's', Jack's father is missing in action. His mother dates American soldiers and Jack makes friends with one of them. One night, in a storm, he wakes from a nightmare, rushes into his mother's room and finds them making love. It seems certain he will feel straightforwardly shocked and betrayed, but he does not. For a start, he thinks he sees his father: 'Jack strained to make him out there, to hold on to the sight of him. And realised, with a little shock, what the apparition really was. Not a ghost, but himself, fantastically elongated in the glass of the old-fashioned wardrobe.' Jack loses his father and, in a limited way, gains himself, begins to grow up. Not that Malouf spells any of this out. He travels lightly, passing on, showing Jack out of the bedroom towards a happy ending. Malouf is fascinated by the - sometimes violent - impact complete strangers can have upon our lives. He examines intimacy and strangeness together. Jack's story was about a stranger becoming family. 'Sally's story' is about a prostitute, a 'widow' for Vietnam soldiers. Their relationship with her is a sham; they use sex to evacuate fear and domesticity as a defence. Sally, like Jack, is an innocent. But innocence, in Malouf's stories, always contains the seeds of experience. Sally learns that damage breeds damage: 'She had used up too many of her lives; that's what it was, in these phantom marriages.' Some soldiers, she discovers, want only to shut out the sunlight and have no use for words. One recognises the type, but I have never seen it so defined. Malouf does what only first-rate writers can - he makes you recognise precisely what you have never put into words. Against the odds, Sally and Jack come close to happiness. This produces a false sense of security. And it is for this reason that 'Lone Pine' comes as an almost unacceptable shock. It begins with humour, describing a wife who brings stories to her husband about the misfortunes of her friends. These are 'laid at his feet'. The pair are travelling in their caravan when a sinister family pitches up out of the blue. There is a surreal scene involving a gun and a banana. It is the domestic prelude that makes the nightmare that follows so so appalling. The man is, more than ever, part of his landscape. He notes: 'It seemed so personal, this sky.'

fields.headline: Fables and foibles
fields.standfirst: Philip Hensher considers the short story as he dips into The Art of the Story and The Oxford Companion to Fairy Tales
fields.trailText: Philip Hensher considers the short story as he dips into The Art of the Story and The Oxford Companion to Fairy Tales
fields.body:
The Art of the Story
Edited by David Halpern
Viking £20, pp688
Buy it at BOL

The Oxford Companion to Fairy Tales
Edited by Jack Zipes
Oxford £35, pp601
Buy it at BOL

What is a short story, anyway? It's even more of a bastard form than the novel, and makes its way in life as best it can, without anything much in the way of respectable forebears. It's somehow appropriate that the greatest master of the form, Chekhov, came from a lower middle-class family. If he knew nothing much about his roots, literary or social, he could hardly care less.

The short story just arrived at some point in the nineteenth century, called into being by the demands of mass-circulation journals. Since then, and despite the effective disappearance of such journals, it has stuck in there. Is it a form, like a sonnet? Is it a genre, like tragedy? Is there, even, as Harold Brodkey intimated, a 'classical mode' for the short story? Is there a difference, as Conrad seems to have thought, between the 'tale' and the 'story'? Surely not. No one has ever managed to understand Conrad's distinction. Surely it is nothing more than an arena, like the novel, dictating nothing more than scale. Into such an arena, anything may enter; within its flexible bounds, anything may happen.

When you add to that the fact that short stories are hardly confined by the dictates of scale, it is easy to see that this is the most difficult of forms to generalise about. There are short stories by Henry James, or Chekhov, which are twice as long as whole novels by Firbank; there are others, by Kafka, which run their length in a few lines. Calvino used to cite, with great glee, a minuscule Uruguayan short story. In its entirety, it runs thus: 'When he awoke, the dinosaur was still there.'

But, on the whole, the classic short story runs from 5,000-10,000 words, and prefers the single situation to plot-and-subplot entrelacement. Beyond that, it is difficult to generalise. Perhaps, right now, genre has a weaker hold on the short story than it does on the novel; there are fewer writers now producing ghost stories, detective stories, horror stories than there were 50 years ago. Perhaps it has become a more literary form, with the decline of the popular magazine. I think that's a great shame; some of the masterpieces of the English short story are 'genre pieces' - J.G. Ballard's science fiction or M.R. James's ghost stories (not to mention Henry James's).

Who, now, is writing anything resembling the sublime genre pieces of Conan Doyle or Chesterton's wonderfully off-the-leash Father Brown stories? But, on the whole, it's impossible to diagnose the state of the short story, make any suggestion where it might be going, since it's impossible to say where it has come from.

That doesn't stop people trying and The Art of the Story, an enormous anthology, clearly has big ideas. It presents itself as a snapshot of the short story across the world, as produced by writers born after 1938. It is predominantly American and, since it only includes work published in America, is much more parochial than it looks at first sight - a really interesting writer such as Judith Hermann, whose Sommerhaus Spaeter was a big success in Europe last year, can't be included, since no American editor would have understood it. For my taste, there are far too many weedy creative writing teachers producing limp imitations of a Raymond Carver. Many, if not most of the non-American writers included, seem to be offering palatable, summary accounts of their own culture, which have no virtue except exoticism.

Exoticism, however, is a quality which has settled over the short story, and many writers have started matching the mysterious brevity of the story to a mysterious treatment of the alien. Whether it's a tiny talent such as Nathan Englander, flailing around in an utterly unconvincing account of Stalin's Russia, or a major one such as Ingo Schulze in a dreamlike St Petersburg, writers are starting to feel the necessity to look outwards. The sharp response to the old creative writing injunction to 'write what you know' has come, and it is 'write what you don't know'.

There's no harm in that and, as time goes on, some of these writers will start to understand the foreign cultures they write about and stop treating them as merely colourful or exotic. What is slightly harmful is the tendency of writers to write about their own cultures with the exotic tone, to make it palatable to the American reader.

The anthology has no place for a writer such as Javier Marias, whose excellent stories never flirt with the ignorant foreigner, but write about the concrete and shared culture. There is something deeply deplorable about Junot Diaz, who writes about the Dominican Republic in a daft, macaronic English, scattered with harmless Spanish words to remind the dumb American reader that he isn't reading about Wisconsin - 'We were on our way to the colmado for an errand, a beer for my tio'. You know, I think 'uncle' would have done perfectly well.

In the end, the more promising writer is someone such as the Vietnamese Duong Thu Huong, whose story won't go into English at all. When she specifies what her characters eat - 'country rice pies, sticky rice cakes, rice wafers' - the English reader glimpses a sort of specificity which isn't aiming at him, and has no need to explain.

Daniel Halpern opines in his introduction that the primary influence on these writers is no longer Chekhov. That may be the case, though if a writer is any good he will always see something usable in the great master. What is pretty clear, too, is that the influence of Raymond Carver has come and gone. The only stories here using that stripped-down domestic tone are abject imitations. The best writers in America now, such as Lorrie Moore, have a warmer sense of absurdity, a keen appreciation of the little, inexplicable knots around which people try to steer their lives. Where his influence may prove most productive and interesting is on European writers. A writer such as Andrea De Carlo, learning from Carver's brevities, brought a beautiful new noise into Italian fiction.

But the biggest and most fundamental influence on the short story over the past 20 years is almost not a literary one. Plenty of writers have turned away from the marvellous subtleties of Pritchett and Faulkner and drawn inspiration from the roots of narrative in the folk tale and the beast fable. Fifty years ago, it would have seemed pretty odd to have reviewed a companion to fairy tales along with this anthology; now, it seems a natural thing to do. That wonderful, odd volume, Angela Carter's The Bloody Chamber, started something rather marvellous with its Phallus-in-Wonderland retellings of the great folk tales. Since then, writers as diverse as Donald Barthelme and A.S. Byatt have returned to the roots of narrative, and produced versions of familiar folk tales as well as entirely new folk tales.

Jack Zipes's intelligent and useful companion guide ranges widely - I can't see the Alice books as 'fairy tales' in any sense and yet it is interesting to place them in this context. It doesn't, however, have any convincing explanations for the phenomenon of the new literary folk tale. Perhaps the fascination never went away. After all, the most relaxed realist fictions may be shown at root, to be profound variations on Cinderella, as in all of Jane Austen. As absurdist and surreal tendencies came into literature, the idea of the folk tale became more marked. There is an excellent story in Halpern's anthology by the wonderful Victor Pelevin, seen from the point of view of a shed, which can hardly do anything but recall Baba Yaga's hut on hen's legs.

Perhaps, too, the new and rejuvenating interest in the folk tale isn't as anti-literary as it might seem; to me, A.S. Byatt's beautiful and surprising fairy tales draw strength from the narrative inventiveness of Tolstoy's late fables quite as much as from recorded folklore.

Whether the marriage of folk tale and short story represents a brief interest, or something more lasting, remains to be seen. Fortunately, we don't have to choose and it's helpful to remind oneself that there are fairy stories even by Chekhov.

It's a difficult form to do well. I never understood why inexperienced writers of fiction are advised to write stories, since they are so much more difficult to get right. Even Tolstoy took years of practice before he started to get them anywhere near the level of his novels. At best, there are probably a dozen really accomplished living practitioners of the art living today; everyone else, one feels, is living in hope.

fields.headline: Publishing in the internet age
fields.trailText: The reaction to Dr Mark Hogarth, the website 'entrepreneur' from Cambridge who has been merrily appropriating literary website names like vsnaipaul.com and martinamis.com, has run the gamut of emotions from A to B, from outrage to hysteria.
fields.body:
The reaction to Dr Mark Hogarth, the website 'entrepreneur' from Cambridge who has been merrily appropriating literary website names like vsnaipaul.com and martinamis.com, has run the gamut of emotions from A to B, from outrage to hysteria.

What's generally been overlooked in the commentary about the 'cybersquatting' Dr Hogarth is the extent to which every aspect of the world of books has become transformed by the Internet. Most professional writers today work at a computer, and probably communicate with their fellows by e-mail. Writers with established publishing relationships will soon be dispatching their work straight to the printer down an ISDN line.

That's one scenario, unfolding beneath the proscenium arch of traditional publishing. But there's a more radical drama being acted out in anoraks and trainers in a Portakabin across the street. This is a heavily improvised show starring Stephen King who, pursuing the logic of the available technology, last month published his novella Riding the Bullet straight on to the Net - with outstanding success.

Publishers will object that King, the world's top-selling novelist, is an exception. That's not the point. After King, there is now absolutely no reason why any established writer should not take on the commercial risk for themselves and follow his example. In other words, thanks to the Internet, writers can now become their own publishers, marketing and finally distributing their work to the reading public.

If Internet publishing threatens the old-fashioned book trade, back in the traditional marketplace the traditional role of the publisher is being further squeezed. Take, for instance, Dave Eggers's bestselling Californian memoir, A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius. This newspaper has already written about Mr Eggers and his amazing overnight success. But if you actually want to buy his book here, incredible as this may seem, you will have to wait until January 2001, when Picador will publish the British edition and The Observer, in turn, will review it.

This quaint procedure is the upshot of the traditional division of the English-speaking world into British and American publishing territories. But for how much longer? Thanks to Amazon.com, it is now perfectly possible to buy a copy of any book published in the United States at the click of a mouse. Gone are the days - remember Spycatcher ? - when hot, even libellous, books published abroad had to be smuggled in through Heathrow by globetrotting friends.

Thanks to Internet bookselling (and Dave Eggers is pre-eminently an Internet phenomenon), it hardly matters that Simon & Schuster and Picador have come to an agreement to sell this enthralling volume in separate markets. If consumers want this book in a hurry - and there's every sign that they do - then they will go to the supplier who can provide. This is the age-old imperative of the marketplace.

So why, then, is The Observer not reviewing Dave Eggers this week? It's a good question. In common with all other literary pages, we are part of a delicate ecosystem which has evolved over generations. The conventional wisdom says that we should not review a book until it has been published in the UK and is available in the shops. But if publication happens out in cyberspace, in the unruly tracts roamed by Dr Hogarth and his ilk, and the bookshops are virtual ones operated by Amazon, who's to say that the conventional wisdom is right?

robertmccrum@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Angus MacFadyen, the man who plays the stars

fields.headline: Angus MacFadyen, the man who plays the stars
fields.trailText: Angus MacFadyen, the man who plays the stars
fields.body:
Angus MacFadyen's CV looks like the celebrity section of Who's Who: his roles include Richard Burton, Rat Pack fixer Peter Lawford and Orson Welles. But what is his most memorable role? That would be freedom-fighter Robert the Bruce in Braveheart.

The irony is that MacFadyen himself hasn't found the role which will make him famous. In Cradle Will Rock, Tim Robbins's hyperactive, Depression-era comedy based on Welles's real-life struggles to stage an agitprop musical, MacFadyen gives a fine performance. The 36-year-old shed 20lb and 15 years to play the theatre wunderkind as a breathless opportunist wrapped in hubris. It's a winningly exuberant performance, yet stardom is likely to remain elusive.

Unlike Magnolia where Tom Cruise's battle-scarred misogyny 'Respect the cock' took the acting honours for pure brio, it's harder to choose a performance from Cradle Will Rock. The impressive ensemble cast - Susan Sarandon, John Tuturro, Bill Murray, Vanessa Redgrave, John Cusack, Joan Cusack, Emily Watson and Hank Azaria - perform as well as you expect; MacFadyen is good, not outstanding.

His low profile meant he wasn't an automatic choice to play the celebrated maverick. He pursued the part for six months, as Robbins even toyed with playing Welles himself. Finally, his agent rang to say, 'Well, they've seen everybody else in town and they haven't found Welles, so here's your shot.' He didn't miss. After securing the role, MacFadyen spent a month immersed in all things Wellesian: his films, biographies and radio work.

Playing such a figure is bound to provoke dissenting voices. 'I just don't think about that,' he argues. 'You're never going to please everyone. You just have to do your best and walk away from it. And at the end of the day, it's just a movie.'

Of course, he's been here before. He played Richard Burton in the US television movie Destiny: The Elizabeth Story and Peter Lawford in HBO's The Rat Pack. The Scottish-born actor facilitated his move to Hollywood with the success of Braveheart, although without the requisite square-jawed handsomeness he cuts an incongruous figure in Los Angeles.

But the actor has always fought lazy typecasting. After graduating from the Central School of Speech and Drama he quickly decided heritage drama wasn't his métier. Following a couple of 'Agatha Christie-type whodunits' he opted out. He initially turned down the chance to play the weak-willed Prince Edward in Braveheart . The actor met the cast ing agent but refused to read or even talk about the role, instead making his case for Robert the Bruce. He got his chance when the first-choice actor pulled out at the last minute.

His bullish attitude has also earned him the chance to rewrite his own scenes, a privilege on some of the obscure indie films he has made between biopics. This year his recognition factor should rise. Aside from Cradle Will Rock , he stars in Titus , Julie Taymor's visceral adaptation of Shakespeare's Titus Andronicus, co-starring Anthony Hopkins and Jessica Lange. He is Lucius, son of Hopkins's vengeful character. He apparently took the role so he could watch the Welsh actor work at close range. Perhaps he hopes to play him one day.

Five things you should know about Angus MacFadyen

1: He has written a play called 1905, a sequel to Chekhov's Uncle Vanya set in the First Russian Revolution.

2: His favourite actor is Gerard Depardieu.

3: When the shooting schedule for Titus stretched from three to five months, he relaxed and spent time 'soaking up the sights and sounds of Rome'.

4: He stuffed himself on steaks, red wine and chocolate to pile on the pounds for Cradle Will Rock.

5: He is the son of a doctor in the World Health Organisation.

 Cradle Will Rock opens on 21 April

Finally, his agent rang to say, 'Well, they've seen everybody else in town and they haven't found Welles, so here's your shot.' He didn't miss. After securing the role, MacFadyen spent a month immersed in all things Wellesian: his films, biographies and radio work. Playing such a figure is bound to provoke dissenting voices. 'I just don't think about that,' he argues. 'You're never going to please everyone. You just have to do your best and walk away from it. And at the end of the day, it's just a movie.' Of course, he's been here before. He played Richard Burton in the US television movie Destiny: The Elizabeth Story and Peter Lawford in HBO's The Rat Pack. The Scottish-born actor facilitated his move to Hollywood with the success of Braveheart, although without the requisite square-jawed handsomeness he cuts an incongruous figure in Los Angeles. But the actor has always fought lazy typecasting. After graduating from the Central School of Speech and Drama he quickly decided heritage drama wasn't his métier. Following a couple of 'Agatha Christie-type whodunits' he opted out. He initially turned down the chance to play the weak-willed Prince Edward in Braveheart . The actor met the cast ing agent but refused to read or even talk about the role, instead making his case for Robert the Bruce. He got his chance when the first-choice actor pulled out at the last minute. His bullish attitude has also earned him the chance to rewrite his own scenes, a privilege on some of the obscure indie films he has made between biopics. This year his recognition factor should rise. Aside from Cradle Will Rock , he stars in Titus , Julie Taymor's visceral adaptation of Shakespeare's Titus Andronicus, co-starring Anthony Hopkins and Jessica Lange. He is Lucius, son of Hopkins's vengeful character. He apparently took the role so he could watch the Welsh actor work at close range. Perhaps he hopes to play him one day. Five things you should know about Angus MacFadyen 1: He has written a play called 1905, a sequel to Chekhov's Uncle Vanya set in the First Russian Revolution. 2: His favourite actor is Gerard Depardieu. 3: When the shooting schedule for Titus stretched from three to five months, he relaxed and spent time 'soaking up the sights and sounds of Rome'. 4: He stuffed himself on steaks, red wine and chocolate to pile on the pounds for Cradle Will Rock. 5: He is the son of a doctor in the World Health Organisation.  Cradle Will Rock opens on 21 April

fields.headline: Mafia's £2.5bn smoke ring
fields.standfirst: Nick Paton Walsh, Young Journalist of the Year, reveals how organised crime has muscled in on a lucrative tobacco smuggling trade that offers easy profits at low risk and cheats the chancellor out of millionsSmoking: special report
fields.trailText: Nick Paton Walsh, Young Journalist of the Year, reveals how organised crime has muscled in on a lucrative tobacco smuggling trade that offers easy profits at  low risk and cheats the chancellor out of millions.
fields.body:
At 3am on Friday, Martin and Sam sat shrouded in smoke at the bar of a P&O ferry returning from Calais to Dover. It had been a good night's work. On the car deck below, hidden among crates of beer in Martin's dilapidated Rover, were 10,000 cigarettes for bootleg sale in Britain.

'I can make at least £100 a day clear profit,' crowed Martin, draining his second pint as he drew on a Marlboro taken from his cargo. He and Sam are part of an illicit trade that cost the Exchequer £2.5 billion last year in lost revenue. Every time the chancellor puts cigarette prices up in the Budget - to £4.20 a packet last month - the trade in bootleg cigarettes and tobacco from the Continent gets a boost.

The likes of Martin and Sam are just small fry. Tobacco smuggling is a ruthlessly efficient, highly organised trade that now involves some of Britain's most vicious criminal gangs, as well as the so-called Red Mafia from eastern Europe and, more recently, Italy's own mobsters.

Police believe Italian gangs in Dover now account for 15 per cent of the cross-Channel trade that supplies one-fifth of cigarettes smoked in Britain.'The Italians have been pushed out of the drug trade by violent Eastern gangs,' explained one officer. 'They're moving into cigarettes as there's so much money to be made for such a low risk.'

Eastern European gangs from Moscow, St Petersburg and the Baltic states have muscled in on a further 10 per cent of the operation, and Europol believes violent confrontations are likely as the gangs compete for control.

The ferocity of the competition underlines how attractive and simple the trade is: brand-name cigarettes cost £2.10 a packet in France, or £19.20 for 200. Martin will sell his for £3 a packet in Dover, £1.20 below the retail price, giving him roughly £350 profit, after overheads, for every 10,000 he sells.

But there are ways of bringing the product to the market even more cheaply - The Observer bought a packet of Marlboro reds in a well-known London market for £2.

Martin admits there are more cost-effective methods than his. 'Eighteen months ago a group of Geordies started taking coach rides to Luxembourg where cigarettes are £8 for 200,' he says. 'They put us out of business for a while.'

A former nursery worker, Martin earns £20,000 a year from tobacco smuggling. The risks are slight. Police believe runners can lose one in three shipments to Customs and still make a healthy profit.

Martin and Sam face plenty of competition in the cross-Channel tobacco trade. Every night a stream of vans and cars passes through Dover Customs, thickening between 4am and 6am. The distribution networks are sophisticated, often beginning in the Far East or Eastern Europe. 'The whole process is normally controlled by the same individual,' says one senior officer with the National Investigations Service (NIS), the Customs unit responsible for tracking the bootleggers around the globe.

'The cigarettes may be bought in Penang in Malaysia for £7 a carton, and then shipped to a distributor who will take them into the UK and sell each carton for £15. When it's on the street that carton can fetch at least £20.'

The criminals even know the shift patterns of Customs and Excise. When the night shift ends, at around 6.30am, foot passengers and vans flood through the nothing-to-declare channels. Pick-ups are now the favoured vehicle as they can carry the load of a van but get on the ferry with a cheap car ticket. Bootleg gers stack beer cans around their cigarettes but often find their illicit loads are obvious because of the way their vehicles dip and lurch as they cross the speed ramps at Customs. In the past week, Customs officers say, smugglers have begun welding their suspension systems so that there is no movement.

'For every action on our part, there's a reaction from the runners,' says senior officer Phil Thomas. 'In February we were given the power to confiscate a bootlegger's vehicle. As a result, they went out and bought old cars with a few months left on their MoT. If they get caught, they abandon the car as well as the goods.' Customs have already filled a field near Dover with abandoned vehicles.

The first signs of the Italian Mafia's arrival in Dover came in February last year. A new lorry, registered to a fake German company but with the markings of a reputable Italian haulage firm, was stopped at Dover Customs. Inside were innocuous boxes of pasta - hiding four million Regal cigarettes. The driver had recently been released from a Naples jail where he was doing time for cigarette smuggling.

At the same time, two Italian men flew into London Gatwick, intent on meeting the lorry-load and, detectives believe, arranging the distribution. These three were arrested for conspiracy to evade duty at an industrial unit near Hythe.

Bail for the three Italians was set at £68,000 each and a total of £204,000 was paid directly to Kent Crown Courts the same day.

There is little difference between the transcontinental route a bag of heroin and a packet of cigarettes might take. Both end up in more or less the same place; both exploit the disadvantaged before their sale. Near the fashionable Brick Lane market in London's East End, a man stands next to an exhausted blue transit van, holding out packets of cigarettes to passers by. '£2 each' he says in his limited English. A carton? '£20'.

He nods to his wife across the road who opens the boot of a car. The carton is brought across the road by his son, the person on the bottom rung of this billion pound trade: a nine-year-old boy.

fields.headline: Now we're comrades again
fields.standfirst: But this time round, unions are more likely to be fighting for influence in the company than striking for pay rises. Nick Gillies reports
fields.trailText: Peter Sellers was an actor of genius - and that has caused a 50-year problem in this country: deep down, many people still think unions are run by the shop steward in I'm All Right, Jack. Yes, there are still Fred Kites to be found, but when a leading lawyer for employers says 'Frankly, shop stewards are more used to negotiating than many line managers', and the boss of the print', union says, 'we recruit a lot of our organisers straight from university', you realise the world has moved on.
fields.body:
Peter Sellers was an actor of genius - and that has caused a 50-year problem in this country: deep down, many people still think unions are run by the shop steward in I'm All Right, Jack. Yes, there are still Fred Kites to be found, but when a leading lawyer for employers says 'Frankly, shop stewards are more used to negotiating than many line managers', and the boss of the print', union says, 'we recruit a lot of our organisers straight from university', you realise the world has moved on.

This is important because after 1 May you may become part of collective bargaining by a union. That is when the Employment Relations Act 1999 comes into force as part of European legislation designed to give a level playing field across Europe, for employers as well as employees.

If 50 per cent plus one of the workforce wants a union, then that union must be recognised by the management. An employee can be accompanied to disciplinary hearings by his or her chosen union rep, even where that union isn't recognised. And for businesses with 1,000 employees in one country in Europe, including the UK, and 150 of them in a second EU country, there will be a hybrid beast called a Works Council which management will have to consult.

The enormous number of mergers, and the transfer of workers from the public to the private sector, has created fertile ground for unions, says Sarah Veale, senior policy officer at the TUC. And this is not caused just by insecurity among employees. Multinationals and companies which are going to be affected by the Works Council rules 'can be persuaded it will cost them nothing, in fact they will save money by having centralised bargaining'.

What do people want unions to do for them? The answer is quite interesting, according to a survey of 3,065 members of the Communication Workers Union (53 per cent responded). Job security was rated as a'crucial' concern by 77 per cent. This was by far the largest response: even preserving pay and pension conditions only rated 62 per cent. Increasing pay (which many people believe is the reason for having a trade union) was picked by little over half, and better pensions by exactly 50 per cent.

Another interesting figure came out of the survey: 42 per cent put 'union influence' as the next most important thing Ð higher than health and safety (37 per cent) or shorter hours (27 per cent). Unison's television adverts about the power of the little ants when they stand together against the big bears has struck a deep chord.

There were 75 recognition deals in the first 10 months of 1999, according to the TUC. Two of the possible reasons are that employers recognise the logistical benefit of collective bargaining, and the benefits of a 'partnering' approach; and that with the coming of the Employment Relations Act they see the need to work with the unions.

It is not surprising then that Tony Burke, deputy general secretary of the GPMU (Graphical, Print and Media Union) feels he is on a roll. He quotes another figure from the TUC survey - that 5 million people would like to belong to a union - and says that in 12 months his union has got 27 recognition deals. He is also venturing into areas traditionally hard to recruit in, white collar staff in small units.

'We have a special section for e-workers - CMS On-line,' he says, meaning clerical, managerial and sales. 'They can go online and get quick advice on contracts, job security and dignity at work- there is a lot of bullying and harassment in e-commerce.' The GPMU has trained 35 organisers in the past year, and recruited four more from Australia: 'They are very experienced at campaigning, at being inclusive,' says Burke. 'We are trying to put back the smile on the face of trade unionism. It has been a dreadful 20 years, but I say we're trying to win in a new way, not lose in the old way.' But David Bradley, national head of the Human Resources Legal Group at Dibb Lupton Alsop, is still to be convinced. 'The senior people in trade unions talk a business language, but when you get on the ground they haven't carried their shop stewards with them.' In its 1999 Industrial Relations Survey, Dibb Lupton discussed the idea of 'partnering' between unions and management and mentioned that there is 'some nervousness at the altar'.

Bradley says 'It is about communicating, and that is something a lot of enterprises have only done in times of crisis. At the moment it's rather as if you were standing in the street trying to give away 10-pound notes. You would get a lot of scepticism, even cynicism. But it will change - it has to.'

Roll your own union

 At this stage be very discreet: it still happens that employers fire people seeking to recruit for a trade union, even though those people could claim unfair dismissal. Sound out a few colleagues on why a union might be needed. Don't write anything on your computer at work: management can read it.

 Comparison shop: you want a union which has experience of helping people in your field, but there is often more than one. What benefits do they offer? Legal reps, for example, are sometimes poorly trained shop stewards. You may want a specialist lawyer to fight a personal injury claim: is this permitted? Look at the subscription fees as well: high subs will act as a disincentive to recruitment.

 It's not your baby: don't get upset if the union sends down a full-time organiser to leaflet and train recruiters. The TUC has set up an American-style Organisers Academy. They tend to send 'like for like' says Tony Burke, chair of the Academy. 'If, for example, the workforce is largely female we'll send a woman.'

webTitle: How to... thrive in an open-plan office

fields.headline: How to... thrive in an open-plan office
fields.trailText: 1 Resist the temptation to demonstrate your individuality by bellowing down the phone, putting up pictures of lust objects or starting joke-telling sessions when your neighbours are having sensitive discussions with new clients.
fields.body:
1 Resist the temptation to demonstrate your individuality by bellowing down the phone, putting up pictures of lust objects or starting joke-telling sessions when your neighbours are having sensitive discussions with new clients.

2 Recognise the main issues and potential problems - technology, the physical layout and personality. Suggest you are all given voice mail facilities if you feel you are burdened by taking messages for other people. Understand that open-plan offices function well for people who need to be communicating with each other all the time - dealing rooms, for instance, where people are constantly getting information from colleagues. But they are bad for people who need to concentrate on writing law reports, for example, or adding up figures. Try to find a temporary location if you need to concentrate: borrow the boss's office, if you can.

3 Appreciate the burdensome associations that have built up around desks in offices. 'The desk is a symbol,' says Kathy Tilney of architect Tilney Shane. 'If you're not at your desk, it traditionally implies you are not working.' Do all you can to wean bosses and colleagues off this idea so that you can be judged by the results you produce rather than the hours you sit at your desk.

4 Feed your own spirit by putting up some mark of individuality by your desk. Even if you do not realise it, you can feel dehumanised and depressed by working in the open-plan equivalent of a monk's cell.

5 Communicate with other people. Open plan offices - an American phenomenon that was copied in the UK after the war - imply a flatter company structure where staff co-operate with each other rather than working in their own little units and keeping secrets.

6 Make use of the more comfortable furnishings that are appearing in many offices - the sofas, for instance. Most companies which provide them are poor at showing staff they should use them without feeling guilty. You can have better meetings on sofas or short breaks away from your screen - but most staff will avoid using them unless the bosses do so first.

webTitle: Must I miss out on pension bonus?

fields.headline: Must I miss out on pension bonus?
fields.trailText: Q: The trustees of my employer's final salary pension scheme decided in 1997 to change fund policy and start making contributions on bonus and extra shift payments as well as basic pay. But not all employees get bonuses or work shifts. Is it fair for the trustees to give a benefit to certain groups of employees in this way?
fields.body:
Q: The trustees of my employer's final salary pension scheme decided in 1997 to change fund policy and start making contributions on bonus and extra shift payments as well as basic pay. But not all employees get bonuses or work shifts. Is it fair for the trustees to give a benefit to certain groups of employees in this way?

Also, my employer is trying to include an improvement in the pension scheme as part of this year's pay deal. The fund is in surplus. It doesn't seem right that the surplus should be used to supplement a pay deal.

A: Your employer is almost undoubtedly entitled to do both of these things.

In the US there is a legal principle saying that the same benefits should be made available to all members - but there is no such principle in the UK.

If the company helps people who work longer hours, that is a rational, defensible position.

If, however, it discriminates against part-timers or on the basis of sex or race, there would be a case against it.

Secondly, it is probably in the interest of employees to get the employer to use the surplus in this way. If an employer does nothing with it, the money just sits there and is of no benefit to the pension scheme members.

 Legal advice this week from Hammond Suddards Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.
