webTitle: Resourceful? He certainly needs to be...

fields.headline: Resourceful? He certainly needs to be...
fields.standfirst:
Management: Simon Caulkin meets the new head of human resources at the BBC

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Urbane jazz plays gently in the background as you enter the office of the BBC's new director of human resources and legal affairs, Gareth Jones.
fields.body:
Urbane jazz plays gently in the background as you enter the office of the BBC's new director of human resources and legal affairs, Gareth Jones.

'You don't mind, do you? I can't work without music,' he says, launching into a disquisition on jazz and the 'buzz' of contributing to a recording by one of his heroes, the saxophonist Joe Henderson, during his time as human resources supremo at record and film company Polygram.

Other discursions follow - heavy sociology, political history, his years as an excited young lecturer at the then new University of East Anglia in Norwich in the 1970s. You wouldn't guess from his relaxed demeanour that Jones, now 39, has been in the thick of the most significant changes the Beeb has seen in years. Last week, to wide approval, director-general Greg Dyke announced sweeping reforms, aiming to cut out swathes of top-heavy management, re-create 'one BBC' and put programme creativity back on top.

However, as a sociologist and specialist in organisational behaviour, Jones will be aware of the signs his style broadcasts to an acutely political organisation. 'I feel completely awful for the people who will have to go,' he says. 'But we need to put creativity and innovation at the heart of everything we do - if we don't have that what are we here for?

'And by the way,' he adds, 'that also means an amount of failure. Within reason we need to encourage people to fail.'

Jones is not Dyke's man - he was headhunted by the BBC in November from Henley Management College, where he was BT professor of organisational development. But, hesitating over another 'very attractive' offer (from Virgin), he only agreed to move to Langham Place when he was sure that Dyke - 'one of the best chief executives I've ever met' - was joining too.

It is easy to see how Jones would complement his direct, hands-on boss. A rare combination of academic and businessman, he has made his name with sociologically-based work on culture and change. Nothing could be more important to today's BBC. In a 1996 article he wrote for Harvard Business Review , Jones described the BBC as a culture which like many others was fragmenting into uncollaborative individualism under the pressure of reforms which pushed efficiency and productivity rather than programme excellence. 'The BBC faces no alternative but to reinvent itself,' he concluded.

The beef of many BBC insiders is that the Birtist reforms created just the opposite of efficiency. Because no one was ever removed, just pushed sideways, the upper ranks of Langham Place were silted up with underemployed managers who could only justify their existence by reorganising (usually not to their advantage) the working lives of programme makers and journalists under them.

'It was impossible to fathom, let alone influence, the decision-making process,' sighs one ex-BBC journalist. Meanwhile, the deranged internal market meant it was easier and cheaper to buy a music CD for programme purposes than to borrow one from the BBC's own archive.

Dyke's description of the corporation as 'overmanaged and underled' has struck a chord with many BBC staffers. Yet for all the popularity of the cause, and the latent commitment of the staff to their uniquely prized and infuriating institution, Jones knows that reinventing the corporation will not be easy. The stakes are sky-high. As with the NHS, every taxpayer has a stake in the BBC and an opinion on how it should be run. Arguably, it is the UK's one true global brand. But at the same time, as a public-service broadcaster in a digital world, it is well into uncharted territory. 'We're living an experiment,' Jones says.

The BBC has followed a trajectory from monopoly to oligopoly to a market in which many people already have a choice of 200 channels. In this situation, he believes, a deep and informed debate is required to establish a new common purpose around which BBC staff can cohere. 'Exploring Britishness?' he suggests.

Jones knows the BBC is inherently resistant to change. 'It doesn't have shareholders or the City chasing it, so there's always a tendency for it to revert to its original shape - it's the most elastic organisation in the world. We are not going to have a "change programme", which would just generate passive resistance. But we do have to pull a cognitive switch which says that change is good - even if in a dynamic environment we'll never get it exactly right.'

What the BBC now needs, he believes, is a delicate shift towards a more sociable, supportive way of working, encouraging risk-taking and creativity while at the same time being committed to the collective purpose.

Only if people are convinced the BBC is the most attractive place to be in UK - even world - media will it be able to compete in the war for talent with the dot.coms and other new media start-ups which are playing havoc with the management ranks of established firms. 'This is a huge issue for us,' admits Jones. 'If we get less than the best for five years we're gone.'

This is one measure against which he - and the BBC - will judge success in the next few years. Another is staff morale. Third and most important will be the creativity applied not just to programming but to all the management decisions crowding in on the corporation as it pushes further into the online world. Whatever else, it will be the mother of all business school case studies.

webTitle: Buying a place in the Michelin league

fields.headline: Buying a place in the Michelin league
fields.standfirst: Mikkel Beck was a fan of the chef, so he invested in the restaurant
fields.trailText: A plug for Mikkel Beck's eaterie which recently made it to the Michelin guide. Come on he's the QPR striker. Who plays for Denmark...There you go, you do know.
fields.body:
Traditionally, the only contact footballers had with the catering trade was buying a pub the moment they stopped playing. Which, to be fair, was merely falling in line with expert opinion that it is always enriching during retirement to spend quality time on your favourite hobby.

So if you want evidence a be found on London's Old Brompton Road where property is now so expensive that a lock-up garage recently changed hands for £250,000. Here you will find Lundum's, a smart and airy Danish restaurant serving food of such insistent quality it recently came to the notice of the compilers of the Michelin guide, who included the place in their latest edition. Lundum's has a further distinction: it is part-owned by the former Middlesbrough striker Mikkel Beck.

"We opened about a year and a half ago," says Beck, who can be found in the restaurant most afternoons fuelling up after training with Queens Park Rangers, where he is currently on loan from Derby. "And already we are in the Michelin guide. We are very proud of that. It is the premier league of restaurants."

Following the lead of Victor Kiam, who bought the Remington company because he liked its razors so much, Beck invested in his venture because he liked the chef's food.

"I enjoy eating out, I've done it a lot, more or less once a day since I left Denmark seven years ago," he says. "But I always envied Italian players because wherever they play in the world there will be an Italian restaurant serving the food they are used to. For a Dane this is not so easy. I firmly believe that if you eat well you feel good about yourself and you play well. Then one day, when I was at Middlesbrough, I came down to London to see a friend who took me to this restaurant in the old Danish Club. Danish food: excellent. After the meal we got talking with the family who ran it and they asked if I'd be interested in opening a place with them, because they were only renting and they wanted somewhere of their own. And that is how it came about."

Does this suggest that the modern footballer, known to be loaded, can't even enjoy a meal without being bombarded by requests for financial backing?

"Not really," says Beck. "This was something out of the blue. But I am very patriotic and I was keen to help any Danish enterprise to get a foothold abroad."

Beck is coy about how much he put in, but his restaurant does not look like a cheap operation. Elegantly fitted out, in a prime location, on the lunchtime I visited it was full of the well-heeled enjoying an extensive menu of Danish fare. Which begs the question: what exactly constitutes Danish cuisine, beyond the bacon we have all seen Peter Schmeichel advertising on television?

"Fish," says Beck. "But not battered like the English way. You ruin your fish, don't you, with all that batter. At Middlesbrough we used to go to Whitby, where Dracula had his summer house, lovely place, to this restaurant known for serving the best fish and chips, very, very posh. But I never ate it. I had something against fish and chips. When we make fun of English food in Denmark we always laugh about fish and chips."

Fish maybe, but the co-owner himself always lunches on the same dish: an open sandwich of meatballs on rye bread with a cucumber and beetroot salad. It is, he says, the perfect fuel for the athlete, a tasty combination of protein, fibre and carbohydrate. Though it is not something he himself ever rustles up.

"I don't know how to cook," he says. "But I'm a very good judge. I tell them, cook something for me and I'll tell you whether you're any good or not. That's my role at the restaurant: I said from the beginning I cannot cook, I haven't got a clue about running the business, but what I can do is eat. I think I'm doing quite well there. Actually I feel uneasy in the kitchen, I know this is not my world."

Which is odd, as many have compared the way a kitchen operates to a football team: it is, after all, about working together for a common goal.

"Yeah, but I saw the programme on the telly about this guy Gordon Ramsay," says Beck of the former Rangers player turned celebrity chef. "I thought that was too much, the way he shouted. If you compare it to a football team, I suppose it's important to have a hierarchy. But I don't think you need to shout like he does. It's the same with some football managers, they think it's about shouting loudly. I don't believe in that. I don't think any human being can perform well in those conditions."

The Beck softly, softly approach seems to be working. The restaurant has certainly found favour among his fellow professionals.

"Bjarne Goldbaek and Allan Neilsen, the other Danish footballers in London, come here," he says. "And I brought the Derby team here after the last game of last season. It was against Chelsea so I brought everyone, the players, the staff. They loved it."

Even Jim Smith? He always strikes the seasoned observer as an inveterate pie-and-chips man, not a big fan of fancy foreign food.

"No, no. Jim loved it," Beck says, polishing off the last of his smorgasbord. "I think."

And the fact that soon after the visit he was farmed out on loan by Smith was entirely coincidental.

webTitle: Unable to see the individual for the whole

fields.headline: Unable to see the individual for the whole
fields.trailText: Two more people dead attending a football match, their names added to the grim toll associated with the sport and still we are no nearer arriving at a workable diagnosis of where the problem lies.
fields.body:
Two more people dead attending a football match, their names added to the grim toll associated with the sport and still we are no nearer arriving at a workable diagnosis of where the problem lies. Never mind what to do about it.

I participated in a Radio 5 Live phone-in this week after the deaths of the Leeds United fans in Istanbul and was struck by the range of opinions on the subject, most of them valid. For every caller who suggested that when innocent English fans go abroad they are routinely set upon by thugs there was another pointing out that, never mind the Rover group, hooliganism was this coun try's biggest export for 20 years. And when I said that in Barcelona last May, I was one of 60,000 over-excited English people and did not see a single incident of bad behaviour, a black Manchester United supporter rang in to say he had been so badly abused by a group of fellow fans at the game he feared for his life.

The thing is, we were both reporting what really happened and anyone who has followed their team abroad will know that the fans are a hugely disparate bunch. There are well-heeled jet-setters, sightseers and shoppers, sex tourists heading for the red light district and beer monsters venturing no further than the station bar. For every idiot shouting that the waiter doesn't speak English, there are a couple of hundred visitors consulting phrase books and enjoying the chance to experience a different culture.

We must not forget, particularly when England play, the other element: the bone-heads who think they are still empire-building, exploited by a handful of politically motivated trouble-stirrers. It is this crew whose presence and history make their fellow English travellers targets for every hoodlum in town.

And yet amid the usual recriminations that follow such disasters, one fact fails to be recognised: that trav elling fans reflect the full spectrum of our society.

No doubt at Euro 2000 English supporters will be regarded as a homogeneous unit and policed accordingly - as a riot about to happen. Virtual martial law is the only solution anyone has come up with to protect all parties when the English are in town. But it will mean that yet again the majority will be excluded from the carnival everyone else seems to enjoy at such tournaments.

Meanwhile, only the most blindly optimistic would dare propose that those two Leeds fans will be the last victims of blanket assumptions about who we are and why we are over there.

fields.headline: Lacey
fields.standfirst: Innocents abroad face time warp of violence
fields.trailText: The feelings of shock, horror and dismay which have followed the deaths of Kevin Speight and Christopher Loftus in Istanbul the night before Leeds met Galatasaray in the Uefa Cup are partly the result of the realisation that in spite of Heysel and Hillsborough, the Taylor report, the Premier League, all-seat stadiums and the football boom, so little in the wider world has really changed.
fields.body:
As always it is the innocent who die. This week a pub landlord and a fibre-optics engineer, with nothing in common apart from their devotion to Leeds United, were killed in Istanbul, apparently for no other reason than being caught in the wrong place at the wrong time.

The same was true 11 years ago when 95 Liverpool supporters who had made sure of a good view of an FA Cup semi-final from behind one of the goals at Hillsborough were crushed to death after police bungling allowed latecomers to press into a section of terracing at the Leppings Lane End which was already full.

Four years before that 39 mainly Italian spectators died at the Heysel stadium in Brussels before a European Cup final when Liverpool fans charged Juventus supporters and a retaining wall collapsed. At the time English football was still mourning the loss of 56 lives in the Bradford City fire.

From the late 60s until the late 80s English football experienced death on a regular basis. Rival fans stabbed one another as a matter of routine and those attempting to flee the trouble risked being killed by falling brickwork in decrepit stadiums.

This sort of thing belongs to the past, although as recently as March 1998 a Fulham supporter was knifed to death outside Gillingham's Priestfield stadium and several others were taken to hospital. Perhaps such isolated incidents are inevitable among crowds of any size but in the main English football has managed to distance itself from the sort of violence now more common in parts of continental Europe.

In fact the feelings of shock, horror and dismay which have followed the deaths of Kevin Speight and Christopher Loftus in Istanbul the night before Leeds met Galatasaray in the Uefa Cup are partly the result of the realisation that in spite of Heysel and Hillsborough, the Taylor report, the Premier League, all-seat stadiums and the football boom, so little in the wider world has really changed.

England can now claim to be the safest place in the world to watch a big football match. The stadiums are comfortable and, compared with the dark days, hooligan-free.

Spectators can take their seats shortly before kick-off with no hassle and, except in a couple of recent instances in the lower divisions where players have been attacked by pitch invaders, the crowds have justified the trust placed in them when perimeter fences were removed.

Yet when English supporters travel abroad they are apt to become caught up in a time warp which dictates the attitudes towards them not only of rival supporters but also the local police. Any trouble and the riot squads inevitably wade into the visiting fans, as they did during England's World Cup qualifier in Rome two seasons ago and, more recently, when Chelsea played a Champions League game in Marseille.

When Manchester United met Galatasaray in the Ali Sami Yen stadium in 1993 a small group of their followers were involved in some trouble at a hotel in Istanbul, whereupon the police rounded up innocent and guilty alike and held them incommunicado until the game was over.

To judge from the accounts of events in the Turkish capital on Wednesday night not a lot seems to have changed, except that this time the Constantinople constabulary have two murders to solve. On just how quickly they are able to bring the killers to justice may depend the whole future of playing European fixtures in Turkey.

Watching football in Istanbul can be an invigorating experience and the orchestrated passions of the Galatasaray supporters are worthy of the last night of the Proms. Yet these passions are forever walking a tightrope between fun and fatality.

Some English football supporters abroad are no angels, even apart from the psychopathic tendency who will doubtless attempt to establish links with fellow misfits from Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and elsewhere at this summer's European championship.

A group of foreigners getting loud in a bar is enough to attract the attention of the riot police and if some Leeds fans did abuse the Turks and their flag on Wednesday they displayed an abysmal ignorance of local sensitivities. On one England visit a few years ago a fan was locked up for ripping up a piece of Turkish currency in public.

The men who died, however, were not part of this even if a tabloid has described one of them, with vague and malicious innuendo, as "being on the fringe of a hard core of Leeds troublemakers, according to a police source". They were the victims of a group of Turks bent on attacking Leeds fans and if visiting supporters cannot be better protected then Uefa should place Turkey out of bounds until the country's security improves.

F or Leeds United, with four of their players facing charges arising from an assault on an Asian student outside a nightclub, these are delicate and disturbing times. At least their chairman Peter Ridsdale has managed to combine sympathy, common sense and diplomacy to a degree rare among his kind.

It is to be hoped that everybody involved in the second leg of this unhappy Uefa Cup semi-final shows similar qualities.

Some English football supporters abroad are no angels, even apart from the psychopathic tendency who will doubtless attempt to establish links with fellow misfits from Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and elsewhere at this summer's European championship. A group of foreigners getting loud in a bar is enough to attract the attention of the riot police and if some Leeds fans did abuse the Turks and their flag on Wednesday they displayed an abysmal ignorance of local sensitivities. On one England visit a few years ago a fan was locked up for ripping up a piece of Turkish currency in public. The men who died, however, were not part of this even if a tabloid has described one of them, with vague and malicious innuendo, as "being on the fringe of a hard core of Leeds troublemakers, according to a police source". They were the victims of a group of Turks bent on attacking Leeds fans and if visiting supporters cannot be better protected then Uefa should place Turkey out of bounds until the country's security improves. F or Leeds United, with four of their players facing charges arising from an assault on an Asian student outside a nightclub, these are delicate and disturbing times. At least their chairman Peter Ridsdale has managed to combine sympathy, common sense and diplomacy to a degree rare among his kind. It is to be hoped that everybody involved in the second leg of this unhappy Uefa Cup semi-final shows similar qualities.

fields.headline: White ' s week
fields.standfirst: Jim White explores the wider, weirder world of sport: The privilege of doing time with the best kids on the block
fields.trailText: Football is a liberating experience. If you've seen the Shawsank Redemption you'll love this article. If you haven't read it. And then watch the film (the storyline similarities small but poignant).
fields.body:
Ask any professional footballer if they were the best player on their block when they were a kid and they will invariably say no. There was this lad, they will say, who could do everything. He had more natural skill than they could ever learn, yet he didn't have the application or the mental discipline to exploit it. And when you ask what happened to this lad, the answer is always the same: he drifted away from the sport, got into bad company, ended up in prison.

Last Saturday morning, I found out what the professional players are on about: I played football against the inmates of Grendon high security prison near Oxford. It was an encounter in which appreciably more skill, cunning and footballing nous were on display than would be seen a few miles down the road at the Manor Ground later that afternoon when Oxford United played Bournemouth.

The invitation to participate came from Rob Clare, who runs the Kestrel theatre company, an organisation that conducts drama workshops in prisons. Perhaps to prove to the lags that there is more to a luvvie than merely pretending to be a tree, Clare had responded to a challenge to bring along a football side to play the inmates. In truth, my participation in a magnificent 3-3 draw was restricted to about 20 minutes of shadow chasing in which I touched the ball twice. And that was to take throw-ins. But I was around long enough to appreciate how much football can mean to people and what a liberating experience it can be.

Grendon is an experimental institution where long-termers are put through a regime of intense therapy in the hope it will help them move away from serial offending. There are some bad lads in there: lifers, disruptives, serious criminals. Which meant that there was a tangibly nervous edge to our preparations. As we made our way through body searches and security checks at the prison gates, seeing mobiles, chewing gum, even a stud key disappear into temporary custody, the nerves communicated themselves as bad jokes and over-elaborate banter. Don't overdo the warm-up, someone said, this isn't the sort of place you want to do a long stretch.

It was clear for most of us that the game represented not much more than an intriguing dinner party conversation topic. And, equally, it became clear immediately we met the opposition that for them it represented something else entirely. They had been waiting for weeks for this, longing for these 90 minutes in the open, 90 minutes of escape from drudging routine, 90 minutes competing on the same terms as representatives of the rest of society. Which was largely why they turned out to be about the cleanest team you could ever face.

True, the match was played on a field surrounded by 25ft-high razor wire, true there were warders standing sentry in wooden huts around its perimeter, true from the evidence of a 50-50 challenge that many of them appeared to be constructed not of bone and sinew but pre-stressed concrete. But there was no swearing, no abusing the referee and when bull-dozing through a tackle, just a polite inquiry of a winded, wheezing rival if he was all right.

For prisoners, football is too big a privilege to blow by behaving badly. A suspension for professionals merely means an opportunity to spend more time with their accounts. At Grendon, it means more time in the cell.

Their midfield general, a grizzled veteran of 47, but fitter than most 25-year-olds, told me football meant everything to him. "I live for it," he said. "We've talked about nothing else than you lot coming here all week. We're really grateful. You know, a game like this, it makes us feel normal."

Sadly, Clare's rag-bag assembly of students and has-beens were the first outsiders to play in Grendon for over a year. Usually, the inmates kick around among themselves, very occasionally they take on a side from the nearby open prison. According to Terry Goode, the prison's PE officer and a former player with Birmingham City, this is largely because, for security reasons, the latest they can kick-off is nine on a Saturday morning, a time when the rest of the world is locked in the self- inflicted prison of a hangover. But if anyone fancies a fixture against a team oozing skill and reckons they can rouse themselves in time, they should contact Goode at the prison. He would be extremely pleased to hear from you. He knows what a game of football can do.

Incidentally, as we left, it became clear that we all remained none the wiser about what specific crimes our opponents had committed. Somehow it would have offended etiquette to ask the bloke you were marking at a corner what exactly he was in for.

webTitle: Taming of the Shrews is a comedy of errors

fields.headline: Taming of the Shrews is a comedy of errors
fields.trailText: Kevin Ratcliffe, the Shrewsbury manager, talks about the threat of relegation and the undulating performances of his team.
fields.body:
The game at Darlington last Wednesday might serve as a sketch of how Shrewsbury's season has been going. They went 2-0 up against a team that had not lost at home all season, then conceded two goals in the last four minutes and were subjected to a pitch invasion by several hundred Darlington fans, some of whom reinforced their taunts with blows.

If you can keep your head while all around are losing theirs, you have some of the qualities needed to be a Third Division manager facing relegation to the Conference. Kevin Ratcliffe, the former Everton and Wales defender, has been here before - with Chester last season - and he is not panicking now that he finds himself back in the mire. "I don't feel there's going to be a problem," he said yesterday.

"He comes across as laid back but it's better to be that than put pressure on players," says Ross Davidson, one of the players assailed in the pitch invasion. "Everyone knows what the pressure is. We don't really need reminding."

Shrewsbury are not so much facing relegation as having their noses rubbed in it. They started the season poorly, threatened briefly to play up to their potential, lost key players to injury, sacked a manager and then embarked on their worst run of the season - a run that promises to carry them out of the league after 50 seasons of modest achievement.

They are one point off the bottom of the table. They have lost their past four home games. They have won only one of their past 18 games.

This is not a position Shrewsbury have been in too often. They spent the 80s, the decade that football forgot, in the old Second Division. In October 1983 they beat Leeds 5-1. The previous season they beat Chelsea 2-1 at Stamford Bridge after Steve Cross, the essence of a team that would run all day for £150 a week, sprinted the length of the field in injury-time to score the winner.

In 1989, finally, Chelsea and Shrewsbury got out of the Second Division, travelling in different directions.

The Shropshire club has made a series of misjudgments since, from the demolition of the old scoreboard for no apparent good reason to the expensive appointment of a chief executive whose achievements fell well short of his promises. But nothing has prepared them for this.

This is not a truly awful team, whatever the league table says. But they have proved all too susceptible to misfortunes of the Darlington kind, injuries requiring surgery and balls lobbed into the box.

"Mainly from set-pieces," Ratcliffe explained. "Performances have been good, the last two games especially, but we've conceded four goals all from set-pieces - if you can call the kick-off a set-piece."

Jake King, the manager they sacked in November, used to favour using three central defenders, a strategy rendered ineffectual by the reluctance of any of them to attack the high ball. Ratcliffe went one better, putting four central defenders across the back and then sticking another in midfield.

David Hughes, a 6ft 4in Wales Under-21 international who in these surroundings can look like Franz Beckenbauer, scored the opening goal at Darlington with a diving header. He owed the team that. He is a central defender who can pass the ball 40 yards with either foot but goes missing under crosses, the essence of a team that is supposedly too good to go down.

But now that Lee Steele, their best striker, and Austin Berkley, their most able midfielder, are back from injury, Shrewsbury have almost a full squad to chose from today at Barnet. They could do with another Steve Cross, of course, but the run-in does not look too formidable, confidence has not entirely disappeared and Ratcliffe, at least, will remain composed.

"I think we've got the character," he said. "We've just got to be mentally tough. And prepared."

webTitle: Newcastle stand to profit should Vialli's selection lack resolve

fields.headline: Newcastle stand to profit should Vialli's selection lack resolve
fields.trailText: David Lacey assesses the strengths of tomorrow's gladiators in football's equivalent of a Roman arena, Wembley.
fields.body:
The one misgiving about tomorrow's FA Cup semi-final between Chelsea and Newcastle United is that it would have made a better final than the actual final is likely to be. As it is, the match will not need much distinction to become an improvement on last Sunday's drab and scoreless affair between Aston Villa and Bolton Wanderers.

Villa, who won on penalties after Dean Holdsworth missed an open goal for Bolton late in extra-time, may prefer to meet Newcastle at Wembley on May 20 but to a certain extent they are at the mercy of Chelsea's priorities.

For Gianluca Vialli and his players the Champions League is the most important thing, closely followed by a place in the top three of the Premiership to ensure participation in next season's Champions League. Compared with those aims the FA Cup is just a pleasant curiosity.

For Newcastle, by contrast, winning the FA Cup would ensure not only a Uefa Cup place next season but confirm their resurgence after three years of drift and disillusionment. Kenny Dalglish and Ruud Gullit have led Newcastle to the last two finals, only for each occasion to magnify the shortcomings of both team and managers.

The recovery achieved by Bobby Robson has been well documented but remains remarkable. He took over a squad who had lost all confidence and were heading for relegation. Alan Shearer, at odds with Gullit, was going through the motions. Now, having taken Newcastle to a safe mid-table position in the league, Robson is on the threshold of leading them out for the last FA Cup final at Wembley before the stadium is knocked down. It is a win bonus few would begrudge him tomorrow.

Chelsea, though, will not be in the business of handing out prizes, however well deserved. On the evidence of their superb performance in beating Barcelona 3-1 in the Champions League quarter- finals, when they at last added English aggression to foreign technique, they should beat Newcastle as they have already done twice this season, but much depends on how their manager decides to play it.

Though Vialli is fully aware of the FA Cup's traditions, the return game against Barcelona will not be far from his mind when he selects tomorrow's side. The Chelsea manager has always tried to preserve his team's stamina by rotating players and it will not be surprising if Newcastle face a much-changed team.

Not that this will necessarily be good news for Robson. Gustavo Poyet did not appear against Barcelona and is capable of plotting Newcastle's downfall, and although Celestine Babayaro will be on international duty for Nigeria, Jon Harley has proved himself a match- winner from left-back.

Newcastle will trust in the ability of Shearer and Duncan Ferguson to disrupt Chelsea's central defenders, much as they did when Manchester United were roundly defeated 3-0 in February. On that day Jaap Stam was overrun by Shearer's tenacious strength and Ferguson's command of the air, not to mention his spectacular opening goal.

Much from Chelsea's point of view will depend on how well Marcel Desailly and Frank Leboeuf, suspended on Wednesday night, withstand a similar test, always assuming Vialli does not decide that the solidity of Emerson Thome is worth retaining. Chelsea will also be at pains to see that Newcastle's front pair do not receive regular service from Kevin Gallacher and Nolberto Solano.

Dennis Wise, the Chelsea captain, may be the biggest influence on a semi-final which promises much but may be the second on successive Sundays to be settled by penalties.

webTitle: Moves afoot to give Bosman the boot

fields.headline: Moves afoot to give Bosman the boot
fields.trailText: Leading figures from football and politics will meet in Lisbon next month with a view to altering the Bosman ruling.
fields.body:
Leading figures from football and politics will meet in Lisbon next month with a view to altering the Bosman ruling.

Fifa, the world governing body, and its European counterpart Uefa have been increasingly concerned by the adverse effects of the ruling, introduced in 1995. Wage demands have sent club costs spiralling and Fifa's president Sepp Blatter has indicated that he believes the trend can be reversed.

The meeting, including sports ministers and representatives of the European Union, will take place on May 10-11 but there will be no official representatives of player associations, who would be most affected by changes in the regulations.

There will also be discussions in Strasbourg and Brussels this month. "Obviously it is a legal matter because the law governing workers' rights is enshrined under EU law," said a Uefa spokeswoman, "and any change in that situation would need the agreement of all member countries."

Germany has a new law aimed at preventing its most violent hooligans travelling to this summer's European championship in the Netherlands and Belgium. Known troublemakers can now have their passports stamped to stop them leaving the country. About 2,700 German hooligans have been targeted and should any of them try to travel to the finals they will face criminal prosecution.

webTitle: Keegan boasts of strength in depth

fields.headline: Keegan boasts of strength in depth
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan's at it again. We're the best blah, blah, blah. But who knows maybe he's right and he will not have to eat his words in Euro 2000. By the way this time he says we've got strength in depth. Oh sorry, he's the England manager.
fields.body:
Few would claim that England will field the best XI of all the countries competing in Euro 2000, but Kevin Keegan believes that his squad's strength in depth can take them to glory.

The England coach will name his final 22-man squad on June 1 and, though he has said that 17 or 18 of those places are taken, he faces a difficult decision in choosing four or five from 15 remaining possibles.

If Robbie Fowler proves his fitness before the end of the season only three places may remain, with Andy Cole, Kevin Phillips, Jamie Redknapp, Darren Anderton, Steve McManaman, Paul Ince and Steven Gerrard still in the reckoning.

"What makes me believe that we can go out and beat them [Euro 2000 opponents] is looking at the players I will have to leave out. I don't think Germany at this moment in time have that strength in depth.

"We haven't got hundreds of them but we've got about 35 players who I can pick a squad of 22 from, which will be as good as anybody there and better than most teams. When I look at my squad and all the other squads - and I saw Italy play Spain last week - I can honestly say that nobody else has got that strength in depth.

"I feel it has turned our way, and whereas in the past Germany have had terrific sides and terrific players, they're now starting to go through a transitional stage.

"The secret for me is getting the right balance and blend. Truthfully, think that when we get together for three weeks, that's when the England side are at their best, when you build that club atmosphere that you cannot build in a couple of days for a friendly."

Speaking on TalkSport yesterday, Keegan gave a few insights into his thinking with less than two months remaining before he must make his choice. He emphasised the strong claims of Liverpool's Emile Heskey, who stood out on his international debut against Argentina in February, and Chelsea's veteran captain Dennis Wise.

He also hinted that two of England's brightest stars might find themselves in unfamiliar positions, with Sol Campbell seen as a potential solution to England's critical lack of left-sided players, and David Beck ham in line to move to a central midfield berth. "We've got to look at alternatives," he said. "David will eventually play central midfield as he gets more experienced. It will happen at Manchester United when they find someone who can play in that right-sided position. Sometimes, like the other night against Real Madrid, David can't get on the ball enough for his ability. That's why I look at him central."

Keegan also lent his weight to Uefa's attempts to restrict the number of foreign players at European clubs, though he believes it has come too late. "They're trying to close the stable door after the horse has bolted and I don't think it's ever going to happen. It's just the way that football has gone. It should have been done four or five years ago when it would have been easier."

webTitle: Harriers hunt for a League spot

fields.headline: Harriers hunt for a League spot
fields.trailText: A capacity crowd of 6,250 will cram into Kidderminster's Aggborough ground as the Harriers host second-placed Rushden and Diamonds in what could be a Conference clincher. Dominic Fifield talks to Jan Molby, the Harriers manager.
fields.body:
Neither team can win promotion to the Football League today, but the psychological war between the top two candidates will be won and lost this afternoon. A capacity crowd of 6,250 will cram into Kidderminster's Aggborough ground as the Harriers host second-placed Rushden and Diamonds in what could be a Conference clincher.

"There's no point trying to play this game down," says Jan Molby, the Kidderminster manager and former Liverpool midfielder. "It's possibly the biggest league game Kidderminster have ever played."

Worcestershire has never boasted its own league club, although it has come mighty close. The Harriers won the Conference in 1994, but the inadequate facilities at Aggborough barred them from promotion. Now the stadium is ready and, after two defeats in 23 Conference games, a win today would stretch their lead at the top to six points.

"People still talk about what happened six years ago," Molby says. "It bugs them and they think that if we do get promotion now it will be justice at last."

The Harriers' success this term has surprised even their manager. In a league that sports four full-time clubs, Molby's squad train twice a week. But they can call upon a wealth of experience - not least in Mike Marsh, Molby's former team-mate at Anfield who gave up full-time professionalism in 1997 after spells at Coventry, West Ham, Galatasaray and Southend.

"Mike's probably been the best player in the Conference since he joined us," says his manager. Should the Harriers take off, however, their star performer will stay grounded in non-League football courtesy of a hole in his left knee and a cashed insurance claim.

By contrast, Rushden, bankrolled by the Dr Martens footwear empire, are big spenders. Their Nene Park stadium puts many League grounds to shame, and their manager Brian Talbot demonstrated the club's ambitions with cheeky, if unsuccessful, deadline-day bids for three League strikers, including Darlington's Marco Gabbiadini.

Recently, however, the Diamonds have been less finely cut; a stuttering 1-1 draw against Nuneaton last Saturday compounded by a 2-0 reverse at home to Morecambe on Tuesday.

"We've simply got to go out and win," says Talbot. Should they fail, Rushden could become a spent force.

fields.headline: Fulham close in on Tigana
fields.standfirst: Owner Al Fayed takes Cantona's advice and offers Craven Cottage job to former Monaco manager
fields.trailText: Al Fayed is about to clinch the signature of France legend Jean Tigana as the new Fulham coach.
fields.body:
Fulham, desperate to become a major player in the Premiership, hope to announce the Frenchman Jean Tigana as their new manager in the next few days in a five-year deal worth up to £7.5m.

Negotiations are at an advanced stage and only a few details need to be ironed out before the former Monaco coach and France international agrees to take over at Craven Cottage. "We are still in discussions and hope to make an announcement next week," said the club's spokesman Max Clifford.

Tigana agreed on the timescale. "If anything's going to happen, it will be next week," he said. However, it is understood that if all goes well an announcement could be made this weekend.

If Tigana says yes, then he will only take over officially at the end of the season. Until then Karlheinz Riedle and Roy Evans will remain in temporary charge of team affairs with the club still in with a chance of making the First Division play-offs.

The Fulham owner Mohamed Al Fayed is prepared to agree to a package worth up to £7.5m, depending on team success, to tempt Tigana and his backroom staff to west London following the sacking of Paul Bracewell a week ago.

If he accepts the Fulham job Tigana will join Arsène Wenger of Arsenal and Liverpool's Gérard Houllier in this country as the third French manager in English football.

But despite his lack of experience of English football, his task at Craven Cottage will be made easier by the large transfer funds he will almost certainly be demanding as a condition of coming on board.

His name and reputation will also help to attract top-level players to Fulham, a task which will also be eased by the club's grand plans to turn Craven Cottage into a 30,000 all-seater stadium ready for the hoped-for elevation to the Premiership.

To many observers Al Fayed's choice of Tigana came as a surprise. He has never worked in English football, let alone the First Division. But it is understood that two factors swayed Al Fayed's decision. First, the Harrods owner is a big admirer of Wenger and sees Tigana in that mould.

Second, Al Fayed is a friend of Eric Cantona whom he met for lunch a couple of months ago. It is believed that at first Cantona was offered the Fulham job but was unable to accept. However, during the course of the conversation the Frenchman mentioned his compatriot Tigana in glowing terms.

Tigana was tipped as a possible coach for the France national side when Aimé Jacquet stood down in 1998, but Monaco refused to release him. He finally left Monaco in January last year to take up a coaching role at the French Football Association.

As a player Tigana was capped 52 times for France and was a member of their 1984 European Championship- winning side.

 Seven Premiership clubs, including Chelsea and Aston Villa, have applied to compete in next season's Intertoto Cup. West Ham, who reached this season's Uefa Cup via the Intertoto Cup, have applied again while Everton, Newcastle, Middlesbrough and Coventry also registered their interest before this week's Football Association deadline.

The highest placed English club who do not qualify for either the Champions League or Uefa Cup will go into the competition at the third-round stage in July.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: The lynx effect strikes again
fields.trailText: The is not for Da Ali G show fans, but if you like Paul Merton you'll love Martin Thorpe. Let your Saturday begin with a bang. (Oh, Ali G fans you might develop a taste after reading this).
fields.body:
 Bridgewater Town were in the middle of their half-time team talk during a recent Screwfix League game against Elmore when one of their substitutes, who had been warming up outside, burst into the dressing room with an unusual message: "There's a helicopter about to land on the pitch."

"We thought he was winding us up," said his manager Jon Bowering. "But then the pilot strode over and asked us what time we were kicking off."

Apparently the Royal Navy Sea Lynx had developed hydraulic problems and the crew, thinking the game had not begun, decided to drop in on the disbelieving crowd of 200.

"The pilot told me he had only one minute left to land and just had to do it," said the groundsman Winston Davey. Eventually the crew fixed the problem and after a quick cup of coffee with the players and a thank you they took off again.

That was little consolation for the crowd: the referee had abandoned the game when the helicopter landed because it was not known how long the repairs would take. And the groundsman wasn't happy either: "It left two big dents in my pitch."

 Talking about choppers, just imagine the TV commentary: "There's a helicopter on the pitch. They think it's all over. It is now." Well, that's what Merseyside police feared last Saturday when Watford police informed them that Sir Elton John planned to land his helicopter on the pitch before the Everton game. Then one of the northern officers remembered it was April Fool's Day.

 God moves in mysterious ways. "Chris, he's stupid. He's never serious. I invited him to the Fellowship where we speak about gospel and things, and instead of going there he went to buy pigs and goats. That was the excuse he gave me. And he named one of the pigs George" - Chelsea's George Weah on his strike partner Chris Sutton.

 Full marks to Evenwood Town's Steve Rutherford for commitment to the cause. The Northern League goalkeeper was sent off in last weekend's game against Ashington for protesting about a goal - the ninth in a 9-0 defeat.

 Lawrence Llewelyn Bowen may be an expert on Changing Rooms but he knows nothing about football. "I once spent ages in a bar talking to a chap I thought was Seal the singer," says the interior designer. "Later I found out it was someone called Ruud Gullit."

 When the defender Paul Jack became the 12th Airdrie player sent off this season in the recent match against Livingston, he was so angry as he left the pitch that he swung his boot at a waste-paper bin standing in the tunnel.

Unfortunately he missed. Livvy's groundsman Andy Forrest takes up the story: "I saw out of the corner of my eye that he was about to kick something and the next thing I knew I was in agony. "He said he didn't mean to kick me and apologised." A clear case of taking the man and not the bin.

 Two Grand National tips for Watford and Sheffield Wednesday: The Last Fling and Call it A Day.

 Life as a millionaire. The Chelsea programme questionnaire asked George Weah: "When was the last time you took public transport?" His reply: "Two weeks ago I took a taxi."

 The British Olympic Association is having its Games suits designed by David Beckham's tailor. Apparently it wanted something stylish but not too bright.

webTitle: Dalziel puts his faith in fresh Ayr

fields.headline: Dalziel puts his faith in fresh Ayr
fields.trailText: Ayr United are a whopping 16-1 to beat Rangers in the semi-final today. Ian Archer talks to their manager Gordon Dalziel. If all the FU punters went to the same bookie and had a flutter on them, then...what if they pull it off?
fields.body:
Ayr United took up residence in a respectable seaside hotel last night, as if to the manner born. "Same socks as last time, the same underpants. And I'll win the quiz night again, take a few bob off the players," said their manager Gordon Dalziel.

That mixture of superstition and hard-headedness will be carried to Hampden Park today for the Scottish Cup semi-final against Rangers, with a place in the final against Hibernian or Aberdeen - playing tomorrow - at stake.

Ayr's young, enthusiastic players are 16-1 to win, expected to be blown away without much fuss, but a few straws in the wind hint otherwise.

Dalziel, who at least has no injury or suspension worries for today, puts up a spirited case for the downtrodden. He is still young yet vastly experienced, the master of the one-liner and rarely without a smile.

A more than useful Rangers striker in a five-year spell at Ibrox, his main claim to fame is that he owns a Scottish League Cup medal as a member of the Raith Rovers side who beat Celtic in the 1994-95 season, still one of the greatest shocks in Scottish football.

"I remember that final because I was the one who was supposed to crack the jokes," he says. "But in the tunnel I couldn't get a word out and all the kids around me were laughing and not giving a damn. We'll need that attitude today.

"I know one thing: they will run further and sprint faster than they have ever done in their lives. You can get through these games on pure adrenalin rush. It is the biggest game the club has had for 27 years and the way they are treating it in the town you would think it was 127 years.

"At Hampden Park the whole thing will carry you through. Then you start thinking maybe we can score a flukey goal and they can miss a couple of sitters - and that's the game won. This is our cup final and we are there to try and win it."

It may sound as if Dalziel is doing little more than whistling in the wind but, the more you listen, the more tuneful it begins to sound.

fields.headline: Blow for Bould
fields.trailText: Steve Bould will miss the rest of Sunderland's season as he will undergo an operation on an injured toe next week.
fields.body:
Sunderland have suffered a new injury blow with the confirmation that their captain Steve Bould will miss the rest of the season.

The central defender made a substitute appearance two weeks ago against Everton after being out of action for two months with a hamstring injury and was expected to return to the starting line-up for today's home game against Wimbledon. But Sunderland's manager Peter Reid says the 37-year-old will have an operation on an injured toe early next week and will miss the rest of the campaign.

Reid lost Gavin McCann with damaged knee ligaments last month and last week Stefan Schwarz was also ruled out for the rest of the season after snapping an achilles tendon while playing for Sweden.

 Wimbledon's full-back Ben Thatcher has been charged by the FA for elbowing Sunderland's winger Nicky Summerbee when the teams met at Selhurst Park in January. It had already suspended Thatcher after the match officials failed to take any action.

 Hamilton Ricard is ready to turn down offers from Spain and Japan to sign a new deal at Middlesbrough. The 13-goal Colombian striker, aged 26, is a target for Yokohama and Malaga but yesterday he revealed that he plans contract talks with Boro's manager Bryan Robson in the summer.

And Boro's midfielder Paul Gascoigne has been back in hospital after complications with the arm he broke against Aston Villa. He was released yesterday but will not face Manchester United at the Riverside on Monday.

webTitle: Barton out to right a Wembley wrong

fields.headline: Barton out to right a Wembley wrong
fields.standfirst: Adopted Geordie aims for third time lucky
fields.trailText: Warren Barton talks to Roy Collins about a midget-reject turned the most expensive defender in the world. And Newcastle: the rise and fall of the FA Cup Final. It's the semi with Cosmo Chelsea tomorrow, but you know that already.
fields.body:
What, as the old riddle goes, is taken to Wembley on FA Cup final day every year and never used? The answer, of course, is the losers' ribbons. Though any embittered member of the Toon army who has been following the cup for only the past two seasons might suggest it is the boots of the Newcastle players.

Newcastle were so pitiful against Arsenal in 1998 and Manchester United last year that one might almost suspect the FA of choosing to stage the semi-finals at Wembley this time to increase the chances of the Magpies' removal now so that they cannot stink the old place out again next month.

Having experienced disaster at the place, Newcastle's players are now more interested in sampling the first of Kipling's twin imposters, as defined in If, though their defender Warren Barton believes the critics did not take full account of the quality of the opposition on either occasion.

"We tried our best but we played two teams at the peak of their form going for a double," says Barton, who did not come on as a substitute last year until Manchester United were 2-0 up and half-packed for the trip to Barcelona for the European Cup final four days later.

Barton's life has been shaped less by Kipling than by the dialogue more familiar to characters in a film by Mike Leigh. As such, the London-born defender understands that true disappointment is not losing at Wembley but having all realistic hope of ever playing there dashed as a teenager when a manager tells you: "Sorry, son, we're letting you go."

Barton heard those words from the then Leyton Orient manager Frank Clark and they were no less painful for the fact they were delivered because of the player's lack of inches rather than talent. Though, at 5ft 11in, Barton now stands only half an inch shorter than Mike Tyson, at the time he would have stood shoulder to shoulder with Barbara Windsor.

Many kids would have dumped their boots in the nearest skip and begun working on the chip on their shoulder. Instead, after a summer of brooding and self- examination, Barton decided to work on his game in the hope of keeping his promise to Clark that "one day I will prove you wrong".

He swallowed his pride and ambitions and signed for Dagenham. He now says: "That was probably the best thing that ever happened to me. When you walk into a dressing room with two builders, an electrician and a plumber, it makes you grow up a bit. If I had stayed at Orient, I might have never got a first-team game and rotted in the reserves. Instead, I was playing every week and maturing as a footballer."

Ian Wright and Stuart Pearce took similar routes from non-League to England stardom and until Pearce left Newcastle for West Ham last summer, he and Barton regularly gave their team-mates the you-boys-don't-know-you're-born routine.

Barton, 31, says: "Stuart and I used to reminisce about the old times and swap stories about skiving off work to play a game at Dulwich Hamlet. Those sort of experiences certainly make you appreciate what you've got now."

As his stature grew, in both senses of the word, Maidstone United paid £10,000 to take him from Leytonstone and Ilford. A year later, in 1990, Wimbledon restored the defender's professional dreams when they bought him for £300,000. Four years later, in a world that seemed to be turning into a dream, Kevin Keegan made him the most expensive defender in the world with a £4m cheque.

"I was proud of that title," he says, "and it helped take the pressure off when two days later the club paid £6m for Les Ferdinand." Barton, however, was about to get another lesson in life.

Although he was deemed an absolutely brilliant buy when Newcastle sailed 12 points clear at the top of the Premiership, as Manchester United started to reel them in the wise-after-the-event boys began asking what Keegan had been thinking of, paying so much for a former non-League full-back.

Whether or not the criticism got to Keegan, he did not give Barton a single start in the last 10 months of his managerial reign at St James' Park. For a man whose career has been forged from rejection, it was no hardship to sit it out and Barton was eventually restored to the team when Kenny Dalglish took over in January 1997.

Ruud Gullit, in that "I'm a genius who has to do something different" way, successfully switched him from right-back to left-back, though few players would have resisted the temptation to take a Bosman at the end of last year. "It would have been easy to leave," says Barton, "but this is a massive club and I wanted to stay to compete at the highest level."

These days, that means Europe and he has admitted to a tingle of envy watching tomorrow's semi-final opponents Chelsea take Barcelona apart in midweek. It brought back memories of a similar magical night at St James' in September 1997 when Newcastle beat Barcelona 3-2, although they still failed to qualify from their Champions League group.

As he plans for life after retirement, Barton has formed a travel company with a north-east businessman, Mark Gibbon. This is partly to offer a personal holiday service to professional people too busy to pop into their local Thomas Cook office and partly to facilitate exchange visits for players at his soccer schools on Tyneside and in the United States.

Barton, who already has a Uefa coaching badge, has been running the schools for three years and this summer he plans to coach in Washington DC, San Diego, Cincinnati, Montreal and Dallas. The kids, he says, appreciate being taught by someone who is still playing at the top level and whose career they can follow on cable television.

"They'll all be watching tomorrow," he says. "I've taken my losers' medals to show them the last two summers but you know Americans - they like winners. So I'll have to see what I can do."

If I had stayed at Orient, I might have never got a first-team game and rotted in the reserves. Instead, I was playing every week and maturing as a footballer." Ian Wright and Stuart Pearce took similar routes from non-League to England stardom and until Pearce left Newcastle for West Ham last summer, he and Barton regularly gave their team-mates the you-boys-don't-know-you're-born routine. Barton, 31, says: "Stuart and I used to reminisce about the old times and swap stories about skiving off work to play a game at Dulwich Hamlet. Those sort of experiences certainly make you appreciate what you've got now." As his stature grew, in both senses of the word, Maidstone United paid £10,000 to take him from Leytonstone and Ilford. A year later, in 1990, Wimbledon restored the defender's professional dreams when they bought him for £300,000. Four years later, in a world that seemed to be turning into a dream, Kevin Keegan made him the most expensive defender in the world with a £4m cheque. "I was proud of that title," he says, "and it helped take the pressure off when two days later the club paid £6m for Les Ferdinand." Barton, however, was about to get another lesson in life. Although he was deemed an absolutely brilliant buy when Newcastle sailed 12 points clear at the top of the Premiership, as Manchester United started to reel them in the wise-after-the-event boys began asking what Keegan had been thinking of, paying so much for a former non-League full-back. Whether or not the criticism got to Keegan, he did not give Barton a single start in the last 10 months of his managerial reign at St James' Park. For a man whose career has been forged from rejection, it was no hardship to sit it out and Barton was eventually restored to the team when Kenny Dalglish took over in January 1997. Ruud Gullit, in that "I'm a genius who has to do something different" way, successfully switched him from right-back to left-back, though few players would have resisted the temptation to take a Bosman at the end of last year. "It would have been easy to leave," says Barton, "but this is a massive club and I wanted to stay to compete at the highest level." These days, that means Europe and he has admitted to a tingle of envy watching tomorrow's semi-final opponents Chelsea take Barcelona apart in midweek. It brought back memories of a similar magical night at St James' in September 1997 when Newcastle beat Barcelona 3-2, although they still failed to qualify from their Champions League group. As he plans for life after retirement, Barton has formed a travel company with a north-east businessman, Mark Gibbon. This is partly to offer a personal holiday service to professional people too busy to pop into their local Thomas Cook office and partly to facilitate exchange visits for players at his soccer schools on Tyneside and in the United States. Barton, who already has a Uefa coaching badge, has been running the schools for three years and this summer he plans to coach in Washington DC, San Diego, Cincinnati, Montreal and Dallas. The kids, he says, appreciate being taught by someone who is still playing at the top level and whose career they can follow on cable television. "They'll all be watching tomorrow," he says. "I've taken my losers' medals to show them the last two summers but you know Americans - they like winners. So I'll have to see what I can do."

fields.headline: Travelogue
fields.trailText: Health check | Separate breaks | Double attraction
fields.body:
Health check
Got the travellers' cheques, the guide book and the sun hat. And, maybe, you pack something for a gippy tummy. But how many of us find out what health precautions we should take before we travel? The first UK NHS website, www.fitfortravel.scot.nhs.uk provides information on travel-related diseases and how to avoid them.

Separate breaks
Two-thirds of women taking a holiday last year gave getting away from their partners or family as the main reason. The survey of 15- to 65-year-olds across Britain by NOP for insurers Directline.com showed that, in the future, men and women may be holidaying separately - men in outer space and women under the ocean. More than half of those questioned in the south, would choose a health/spa retreat as their ideal break, while northerners prefer to go on a luxury cruise and Midlanders search for romance. Women lead the Internet - 53% would choose to book their holiday online, compared with 47% of men.

Double attraction
Attractions from all over the country are taking part in a two-for-one ticket promotion. In London, for example, two adults visiting the National Maritime Museum and the Royal Observatory at Greenwich could save up to £10.50. A 241 pack containing a passcard and 32 tokens costs £2.29 including p&p. Order from www.241.co.uk or send a cheque, payable to CPS, for £2.29 to CPS, PO Box 241, Melton Mowbray, LE14 4ZH.

Women only
Gran Canaria's leading gay resort, Vista Bonita, will be open just for women between May 22-29. Sensations for Women (020 89000809) has launched women-only weeks throughout Europe. Prices for Vista Bonita start from £299 per person and include return flights from Gatwick, transfers, seven nights' self-catering accommodation, an information pack and a welcome barbecue. Greece, the Caribbean and Australia are also featured.

Tall order
The Tall Ships will spend five days in Boston this year and then race to Amsterdam, their final port of call. Having left from Southampton and Genoa, they arrive in Boston on July 11 for a five-day festival including parades and fireworks. Details on www. travel-america.co.uk and 020-7978 7429.

A feminine gait
Women who like to walk and talk with women should try www.walkingwomen.com and 01926 313321 for details of walking holidays in the Lake District. There are three grades of walks with variations to cater for all levels of fitness. Prices range from three nights in a youth hostel at £105 to £535 for seven nights in a country house hotel.

fields.headline: Sintra of gravity
fields.standfirst: While the castles and quintas remain on high, the aristos who built them have long since fallen to earth.  John Cunningham gets a whiff of faded grandeur
fields.trailText: While the castles and quintas remain on high, the aristos who built them have long since fallen to earth. John Cunningham gets a whiff of faded grandeur.
fields.body:
Not the best introduction to Portugal, the underground carpark at Lisbon airport, but Hades turned into Kafka when the rep proffered three separate maps and diagrams for getting to the hotel on the Estoril coast. Nothing could be simpler, she insisted: just watch out for unmissable landmarks. These turned out to be cloned petrol stations and anonymous shopping centres. But at least they were visible, which is more than signs for Estoril were. Add the late afternoon rush hour: a labyrinth of flyovers, underpasses and junctions, idiosyncratic Portuguese driving, and the panic meter soon rises.

In a despairing moment, when it seemed easier to get to El Dorado than Estoril, the equally magic name of Sintra flashed by on an overhead gantry. It seemed better to head there instead, and come back to the Estoril coast, and the Tagus estuary leading up to Lisbon, later in the trip. The car agreed and drove itself as though summoned to a lost domain.

The Serra de Sintra (in which the small town of Sintra lies) is so unlike the surrounding countryside, it must have been formed by the gods taking a dollop out of a weird green planet and dumping it a few miles inland of the little right-angled corner formed by the Atlantic and Estoril coasts. This green lumpy goo settled, solidified and fissured to form verdant valleys, sprouted flora, extruded rocks and peaks. On top of these, conquerors, kings, aristos and eccentrics have glued all manner of architectural follies which, far from spoiling Sintra, enhance its natural drama.

Fanciful? Only a little. The Moors who occupied this part of the Iberian peninsula from the 8th to the 13th centuries felt Sintra was special. The shell of their crenellated fortress still hogs a hilltop overlooking the town. Portuguese royals built palaces here. Byron was bewitched, and referred to Sintra as a "glorious Eden" in Childe Harold's Pilgrimage.

It's a bit like, and no bigger than, a spa town in the Peak District, or a hill station in Darjeeling. It's healthy, steep, woody and walkable. There are perhaps too many shops selling souvenirs, not quite enough patisseries (to cater for the fabled Portuguese sweet tooth); there are comfortable hotels (from the old-fashioned Central to the newly-opened Lawrence, in a renovated historic building). But these are sideshows and looking at buildings, gardens and landscapes is what Sintra is all about.

Not a lot of distractions at night - except the soundtrack of tourist voices in the outdoor cafés, and keys being turned in big old locks by locals. So an early start next day is easy.

Right in the town square is the National Palace. Pevsner would be hard put to make sense of its style, but Disney would whoop with joy. The core dates from the 14th century; an earthquake in the 1750s meant substantial reconstruction, and the result is a joyful hodgepodge. Two white-walled Kentish oast houses turn out to be kitchens with mammoth chimneys.

Really, it's best not to get too fussed about dates, dynasties and decoration. A bracing zigzag walk up a hillside will, within an hour, take you to the shell of the Moorish castle; further along is the Pena Palace - a Hollywood creation conjured up in the 19th century.

The circuit through the Serra, on to the Cabo da Roca (a must see: it's Europe's most westerly point), back along the Estoril coast and the Tagus into Lisbon could be completed easily in half a day. But don't rush. In the car, heading towards the village of Colares, the road is drenched in every shade of green. Off it, indicated by the discreetest of signs, are the quintas : the country houses, some with land attached, some just bucolic retreats with formal gardens.

Unlike most stately houses in Britain, the quintas naturally dovetail into their rustic surroundings, rather than dominate them. Sadly, most aren't open to the public. A few owners do B&B and a small number are now hotels. During Sintra's summer music festival, some stage concerts.

There are two properties you can visit, however. The Quinta Regalia has a 19th-century house, a bit like a magnificent hunting lodge, but more interesting are its huge grounds. These are both stunning and spooky: an early owner was obsessed with the rituals of both Freemasons and the Knights Templar. There's a well with a staircase spiralling down to its depths. Its purpose was the initiation ceremony of some semi-secret order. Nuff said.

The gardens of Monserrate, another quinta further along the same road, are even more exotic. The English lawns are the least surprising feature. Re-fashioning the landscape was, for a posh 19th-century owner, the equivalent of today's DIY. Except that Sir Francis Cook, a London textile merchant, who built Monserrate (the house is OTT Moorish and currently being repaired) had 1,000 men to fulfil his arboreal fantasies.

This whiff of fading aristocracy is something you notice in the coastal towns as well. Estoril itself - a pleasant little resort, though its neighbour Cascais is livelier and jollier - is dominated by a grand casino.

Once this grand gambling parlour and the ranks of high-fenced villas, were favoured by the second-rank royals of Europe. If they're still around, they're keeping their heads down. Or maybe they're rentiers, living on reduced incomes in flats in Lisbon. It's only 30 minutes away on a dinky train that follows the banks of the Tagus into the capital.

As for the families who own historic quintas , maybe they disguise themselves as gardeners, tending the topiary work. Or maybe they tog up as butlers and waiters to serve foreign holiday-makers, or Portuguese wedding parties. Heritage weddings are big in these parts. The church in the picturesque village of Colares is regularly thronged with bridal processions.

"They come from Lisbon, from everywhere, to get married here," the owner of the bar said. And driving out of the village square on a Saturday afternoon, I got caught up in a motorcade of guests. Only the white pennants, fluttering from the aerials indicated this was no ordinary chaos, as they revved and hooted on their way, no doubt, to a reception at some stylish, hospitable quinta . The driving, by the way, was as carefree as on that motorway from Lisbon airport.

The practicals

John Cunningham was the guest of BA Holidays (0870 2424243). A two-night stay for two people at the four-star Via Gale in Estoril (car hire included) costs £405 per person from April 13 to 24; and £269 per person between April 25 and June 30.

Carnival Jamaica
Celebrate Carnival in Jamaica from April 23-30. Tropical Journeys (020-7849 4000) has special deals from £525 per person for seven nights at the three-star Fishermans Point, which includes return flights from Gatwick or Heathrow, transfers and accommodation.

Spring roll
Spring in Beijing. China Holidays (020-7287 6727) has six-day holidays for £499 including return British Airways flights from Heathrow with five nights' accommodation with breakfast at the four-star Grandview Garden Hotel.

Operatic Easter
A three-night Easter break in Paris with the best tickets for La Traviata through JMB Travel's Opera Holidays (01905 425628) costs £395pp. This includes three nights B&B at the three-star Hotel le Pavillon Bastille, opposite Opera Bastille, return Eurostar rail and opera matinée.

Mobile in France
Seven nights in a mobile home at Camping de la Baume near Frejus in the south of France costs £369 for two adults and up to three children and includes sea crossing. Details from Sunsites: 01606 787555.

Two for one
Two weeks for the price of one in Corfu. Stay in the Panayiota Apartments in Kerasla in May for two weeks at £352pp through Simply Ionian (020-8541 2277). The price includes flights, transfers and 14 nights' accommodation.

Red Sea romp
Nine nights all-inclusive at the Lagoona Hotel in Eilat cost from £1,005pp including return flights from Luton on April 18 and return transfers. Longwood Holidays (020- 8551 4494).

Holidays to Corsica during May and June cost £50 less per person with Corsican Places (01424 460046). One week in Les Terrasses des Oliviers on the Gulf of Valinco now costs £497pp with departures from Gatwick or Stanstead.

Jersey that fits
A week's self-catering in Jersey this month and next costs £99pp, including return sea crossing. Children under 11 go for £75 and under 2s go free. Jersey Travel Service (0870 8487001).

Bermuda cut
Book by April 14 and a seven-night holiday in Bermuda costs £995pp - a saving of £265. This includes return British Airways' flights from Gatwick and accommodation at the Southampton Princess. Premier Holidays (0870 7898923).

Lisbon getaway
Leave Heathrow on Good Friday (April 21) for three-nights' B&B at the four-star Hotel Sofitel in Lisbon for £360. Cresta Holidays (0870 1610900).
