fields.headline: Classic children's library: 4-7
fields.trailText: This is probably the most difficult age to choose for. There has been a huge boom in books for this age group; but sadly a very high proportion are not about reading but about learning to read, which is something entirely different
fields.body:
This is probably the most difficult age to choose for. There has been a huge boom in books for this age group; but sadly a very high proportion are not about reading but about learning to read, which is something entirely different.

As a parent it is hard not to be swept into the learning-to-read race, although it is worth reminding yourself that (unless your child has some undiagnosed condition) they will eventually learn to read, just as they once learned to walk, talk and use the potty; it is just that some do it quicker than others. But it does not matter if they do it at four, or do not start until seven: far better than worrying yourself and them about decoding the squiggles, you should provide them with books that give complete experiences, that take them on wild journeys of the imagination, that offer them visual stimulus, and that make them laugh and think about the world around them.

As soon as children do start reading, parents often think pictures are unnecessary. In fact they are crucial. Where would Roald Dahl's books be without the wacky line illustrations of Quentin Blake? And picture books that you enjoyed together when your child was a baby and toddler can get a new lease of life when she or he can read them for themselves: such books, loved and familiar, are more likely to enrich their life and help their reading than those written with that purpose in mind and with limited vocabularies to match.

Because of the wide range of reading ability, the ages suggested below are a guide only and make no distinction between being read to and reading for one's self alone.

4 upwards

I Hate School, by Jeanne Willis and Tony Ross (Anderson Press £5.99)

Honor Brown hates school, the worms the dinner ladies feed them, the smelly sand-pit, the killer sharks in the water tray. But what do you know? Come the end of year six, she is in tears at the thought of leaving. For all who are starting school this week, and for their parents who need a laugh.

Bunny Cakes by Rosemary Wells (Picture Corgi, £4.99)

It is impossible not to fall in love with Max the tearaway toddler rabbit who gives his rather bossy big sister Ruby a pretty hard time. Max causes mayhem in the kitchen when Ruby decides to make a cake for grandma's birthday, and gets to have his cake and eat it in the shape of red hot marshmallow squirters for his earthworm surprise cake. It is very simple, smart and sassy and the shopping lists get even the very young reading.

Owl Babies by Martin Waddell, illustrated by Patrick Benson (Walker, £4.99)

Dealing in a really imaginative way with the idea of separation from the mum you really love, this is a wonderful book that makes you feel cosy just to think about it. Benson's illustrations have a wonderful expressive quality.

A Squash and a Squeeze by Julia Donaldson, illustrated by Axel Scheffler (Mammoth, £4.99)

Endearingly dotty version of old English folk tale about a woman who thinks that her house is too small, and so it proves when the farmyard animals turn up. The text is simple and silly and the illustrations capture the sense of ordinary life gone mad.

The Big Big Sea by Martin Waddell , illustrated by Jennifer Eachus (Walker, £4.99)

One of those intensely magical books in which words and pictures come together to create a portrait of the world that is just a little bit different. It is a book about the importance of the very smallest things in life. A little picture book with a big wild heart.

My Uncle is a Hunkle Says Clarice by Lauren Child (Orchard, £10.99)

Lauren Child has burst exuberantly upon children's publishing with her funny daffy stories about Clarice Bean, a small girl who is eight going on eighty-eighty and who lives in a very modern household that is always in uproar. The latest has a ticklish title and is a ticklish book with Child's trademark hurdy gurdy mixture of drawings, photos and clever typography - the words for driving to the hospital very fast are very squiggly. Other delicious titles include Clarice Bean, That's Me and I Will Not Never Eat a Tomato.

The It-Doesn't Matter Suit by Sylvia Plath (Faber £3.99)

Only it matters a lot to Max, youngest of seven brothers residing in the town of Winkelburg, that he is the only member of his family that hasn't got a suit. But when a mysterious parcel arrives and it turns out to be a mustard yellow suit, Max is the last in line for a particularly special hand-me-down. Plath's book has a charming, dead-pan humour that is matched by Rotraut Susanne Berner's illustrations.

The Sea-Thing Child by Russell Hoban, illustrated by Patrick Benson (Walker, £10.99)

Russell Hoban's superb 30-year-old classic about the terrible power of nature seen through the sea and shoreline and the eyes of the sea-thing child as he grows in experience and confidence. Patrick Benson's paintings marvellously capture the immensity of the sea and sky.

Josie Smith in Summer by Magdalen Nabb (Collins, £3.99)

One in a jolly little series of nine books that tell of the adventures of the irrepressible Josie, her family and friends. These books are not stunningly well-written or even particularly perceptive, but their charm is in their depiction of everyday life, the perils and pleasures of friendship, the cares and concerns of Josie and her quirky view of adult behaviour. Child-sized in every way and all the better for it, these are books for readers going solo for the first time.

Rosie's Babies by Martin Waddell and Penny Dale (Walker, £4.50)

There are enchanting, highly detailed pastel pictures to accompany this story about four-year-old Rosie, trying to get her mum's attention while she puts the baby to bed. Rosie tells her own stories about her babies, bear and rabbit: how they make her cross, what she gives them to eat - apples, pears and grapes (but they do not like the pips). This is a great insight into the egocentric world of the small child and a gentle and sympathetic account of sibling rivalry.

The Cat in the Hat by Dr Seuss (Collins, £4.99)

We are in two minds about the world of Dr Seuss. We love the Cat in the Hat; we love it when The Cat in the Hat Comes Back, even naughtier than before. He is such a character - like the mad, bad, wild creature that lurks inside even the best behaved child - that you cannot help falling for him, even if the rhythm of the piece is irritatingly train-like. It is the other Dr Seuss titles that give us a problem. Is there a child in the world who really enjoys reading "I am Sam and Sam I am?" Sales suggest there are, but we bet it is parents anxious about their children reading, not children, who demand these titles.

Dogger by Shirley Hughes (Collins, £4.99)

A good story told with empathy for what it feels like to lose your favourite teddy - or, in this case, Dogger, a worn old dog that belongs to Dave. When Dave loses him at the school fete he only gets him back because of a generous gesture by his big sister, Bella.

The Mousehole Cat by Antonia Barber and Nicola Bayley (Walker, £4.99)

An utterly magical picture book with rich, vividly coloured illustrations, friezes and borders that complement Barber's simple, almost severe telling of the dramatic Cornish legend of Mowser the Cat and Tom, the old fisherman, who brave the fury of the Great Storm Cat to save their village from starving.

The Children of Lir by Shelia MacGill-Callahan (Ragged Bears, £9.99)

What are almost pre-Raphaelite pictures accompany this retelling of the legend of the children of the king of Ireland who are turned into swans by their wicked stepmother. Writing and visuals set each other off to create a rich story about the making and breaking of spells and the sorrow of exile. A book for sharing.

The Snowman by Raymond Briggs (Penguin, £9.99)

A classic story, told entirely without words, of the magical friendship between a boy and his frozen friend. Actually much improved by not having to listen to Walking On Air while watching the story unfold. If you like this, try The Bear - much the same except that the friend is furry.

Poems For the Very Young selected by Michael Rosen (Kingfisher, £6.99)

An excellent collection to suit all tastes. Worth it alone for Jack Prelutsky's Spaghetti! Spaghetti! - the kind of nourishing poetry that four-year-olds really understand.

Twinkle Twinkle Chocolate Bar compiled by John Foster (OUP, £7.99)

Some funny and some silly rhymes about swings and see-saws, cats and dogs, mums and dads, dragons and giants, and mudpie stew. Great fun.

The Owl and the Pussycat by Lewis Carroll and Edward Lear (OUP, £5.99)

Nonsense rhymes by two of the greatest exponents, beautifully illustrated with rich Victorian-style illustrations by Nicki Palin.

The Teddy Robber by Ian Beck (Corgi, £3.99)

Someone is stealing Teddies; Tom is determined to find out who, and is in for a giant surprise. This story is a mini-adventure for the very young with illustrations that play cleverly with size and perspective to give a sense of what it is like to be small in a big world.

Avocado Baby by John Burningham (Red Fox, £4.50)

This story tickles the sense of humour of the very young, and follows a weedy baby in a weedy family who beats the bullies when it starts on a diet of avocado pears.

Willy's Pictures by Anthony Browne (Walker, £10.99)

There is something completely clear-eyed and honest about the way Browne views the world of families and children. In the brilliant Zoo (Red Fox, £4.50), he charts a day out in which it is the humans who behave like the zoo's animals. This book is just as original, with Browne recreating some of the world's most famous paintings, adding to each his best-loved character, Willy the chimp. Magritte, Dali, Rousseau and Edward Hopper all get the monkey treatment; the results are funny and disturbing at the same time.

The Tale of Peter Rabbit by Beatrix Potter (Puffin, £4.99)

Large-format version of the classic tale about the disobedient little rabbit in Mr McGregor's garden who almost ends up as stew.

Reckless Ruby by Hiawyn Oram (Carnival, £4.99)

Ruby's parents think she is so precious that they want to wrap her in cotton wool. Ruby has other ideas, and decides that only by being reckless can she avoid this terrible fate. Crucial reading for little girls who do not want to grow up to marry princes.

Winnie the Witch by Korky Paul and Valerie Thomas (OUP, £3.99)

A Children's Book Award winner that full of visual jokes and amusing detail. Winnie the Witch decides that having a black cat when you live in an all-black house is very confusing.

Not Now, Bernard by David McKee (Red Fox, £3.99)

One of those books that stays in the mind. Bernard would like a little attention from his parents, but they are so busy they do not even notice that he has been eaten and replaced by a monster. McKee's sly pictures are so delicious you want to gobble them up. A stark reminder that there is no such thing as quality time.

Princess Smartypants by Babette Cole (Puffin, £4.99)

This princess enjoys being a Ms, but all the princes want her to be their Mrs. A feminist fairytale with a difference, full of good humour. If you enjoy this, try Cole's gender-bending variation on the Cinderella story, Prince Cinders.

Mrs Wobble the Waitress by Allan Alberg (Puffin, £3.99)

One in a series of user-friendly and funny stories that help children learn to read without patronising either them or their parents. Our favourites are Mr Biff the Boxer, Mr Tick the Teacher, and Mrs Jolly's Joke Shop, from which most children learn their first knock knock joke.

Something Else by Kathryn Cave and Chris Riddell. (Puffin, £4.99)

Elsie tries and fails to be like everyone else, then something completely different turns up and wants to be friends. A gentle, eloquently told story about the meaning of tolerance.

Winnie the Pooh by AA Milne (World International, £4.95)

Your children may well have been introduced to Pooh, Christopher Robin and the "100 aker wood" long before reaching four, but now is the time to start reading them the full version with colour illustrations by EH Shepard. Just don't try to imitate Alan Bennett when you do.

5 upwards

The Magic Finger by Roald Dahl (Puffin, £3.99)

The little girl in this fantasy has a unique gift. When someone makes her angry she simply points her finger and - zap! - an instant punishment is visited on the offender. When her teacher calls her "a stupid little girl" because she misspells cat, she points her finger and her teacher sprouts whiskers. Quite right! A small child used to being coerced will warm to the summary justice meted out in this tale. A little book with a great big message about the enormity of small children's feelings.

The Jolly Postman or Other People's Letters by Janet and Allan Ahlberg (Puffin, £11.99)

Children are intrigued by this highly original book containing witty cards in envelopes for the Jolly Postman to deliver to fairytale characters. Hours and hours of fun.

6 upward

The Dinosaur's Packed Lunch by Jacqueline Wilson (Corgi, £3.50)

A great story about a little girl who is looked after by her dad, and has the day from hell on a school visit to the dinosaur museum. Things look up when she turns into a dinosaur, although being scaly-skinned brings its own problems. A perceptive story from an author likely to figure large in your child's reading over the years.

Advanced readers could also try Cliffhanger (£3.99), a good read about Tim, a boy who is hopeless at sport and, to his horror, is sent away on an adventure holiday.

A brilliant, simple idea - and talk about value for money! A series of well-known tales retold by some of the best writers around; each is just fantastic and at £1 very affordable. The Enormous Crocodile by Roald Dahl (Puffin, £5.99)

A golloping, gulping, grumptious story from the master storyteller, concerning a horrid, greedy, brutish crocodile who has secret plans and clever tricks to fill up his tummy with a yummy child. Will make them scream with laughter.

The Adventures of Mr Toad by Kenneth Grahame, abridged and illustrated by Inga Moore (Walker £14.99)

An introduction to the riotous adventures of the wayward toad. Full colour illustrations.

7 upward

The Enchanted Horse by Magdalen Nabb (Collins, £3.50)

Irina is a sad and lonely child; the wooden horse she sees in a junk shop is sad and lonely too, and needs a home. Nabb's book is a superb internalised dialogue, a modern fairytale in which the horse comes alive and liberates Irina from the burden of her sadness. Seven upward. In a different vein, Nabb has written a very enjoyable series of stories about a funny, feisty little girl called Josie Smith (Collins, £3.99). Heart-warming without being twee. Six upward.

The Hundred-Mile-An-Hour Dog by Jeremy Strong (Puffin, £3.99)

A Children's Book Award winner that tells about Streaker, a rocket on four legs with a woof attached. Children giggle uncontrollably at the humour, and it will raise a smile in mums and dads as well. Seven upward. Strong is prolific, although the quality of his work is variable, and confident seven-year-old readers will love Lightening Lucy (Puffin, £3.99) about a little girl who can fly, a sort of miniature Wonderwoman.

Snow White and the Seven Aliens by Laurence Anholt (Orchard, £3.99)

A seriously silly retelling of the story in which Snow White is a wannabe pop star who has to defeat the mean queen, who was once the lead singer with The Wonderful Witched Witches. Parents may sigh, but children find it hilarious. Great pictures.

The Worst Witch by Jill Murphy (Puffin, £3.99)

This is the place where for most little girls real reading begins. Few can resist Mildred Hubble, the little witch at Miss Cackle's academy who is always crashing her broomstick and getting her spells wrong. Much copied but not bettered. There are three more.

First in a witty series about class three, who get a bit of a shock when their new teacher does not enter by the door but flies in through the window. But then, Mr Majeika is a wizard, albeit one for whom things are always going wrong. Not much sub-text, but real page turners and plenty of other tales the series to satisfy ravenous readers.

When Bill Simpson wakes up one Monday morning he finds he is a girl, and his mum packs him off to school in a frilly pink frock. So begins one of the worst days of his life. A gender-bending fable that is a great feminist romp for the over-sevens.
fields.bodyText: This is probably the most difficult age to choose for. There has been a huge boom in books for this age group; but sadly a very high proportion are not about reading but about learning to read, which is something entirely different. As a parent it is hard not to be swept into the learning-to-read race, although it is worth reminding yourself that (unless your child has some undiagnosed condition) they will eventually learn to read, just as they once learned to walk, talk and use the potty; it is just that some do it quicker than others. But it does not matter if they do it at four, or do not start until seven: far better than worrying yourself and them about decoding the squiggles, you should provide them with books that give complete experiences, that take them on wild journeys of the imagination, that offer them visual stimulus, and that make them laugh and think about the world around them. And picture books that you enjoyed together when your child was a baby and toddler can get a new lease of life when she or he can read them for themselves: such books, loved and familiar, are more likely to enrich their life and help their reading than those written with that purpose in mind and with limited vocabularies to match. fields.headline: Sixty seconds in archaeology
fields.standfirst: Rob Masefield, an archaeologist with RPS Consultants, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: Rob Masefield, an archaeologist with RPS Consultants, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.body:
You'd think that most of the interesting pieces of our heritage would have been found by now, but there's still a huge amount being uncovered every week - much of it prehistoric. I'm one of four archaeologists working for environmental consultancy RPS and most of our work comes from construction companies. They will usually be looking to build on a new site, and bring us in to satisfy the local authority that they're not about to destroy any important remains beneath the project.

Our first task is to examine the local council's monuments record to establish whether anything important has been found in the vicinity. Often we'll get some aerial photographs taken - you can make out the shape of a former dwelling where the crop's growth is stunted by what's beneath. Our other option - short of digging a hole - is a geo-physical survey which will show unequivocally that there is something there. Then comes what for me is the most interesting bit - the actual digging. On most sites we dig a 2% sample of the area to confirm our findings. This generally starts with a JCB digger removing the topsoil and then one of us getting in the hole and using hand-held tools. We are very careful as we go down - even when using mechanical tools. Invariably it's a slow and deliberate process.

We present the findings to the local authority who will decide what action, if any, the developer should take. The law is very clear on what is expected if something important is found and the authority can demand that it be excavated. If that's the case we'll take the bad news back to our employer and explain how it will affect the project. Although you'd think that the company finding an important site would be the one to excavate it, this isn't so. Most large digs go out to tender and the company showing the greatest expertise and best price will win. If we are to manage it, I put together a team of diggers - many of whom will be post-graduates looking to get established. Each stage of the excavation is meticulously recorded with photos, co-ordinates and the finds themselves. In some cases the whole area has to be dug by hand. All our findings are logged with the local authority's monuments archive, the same one we consulted at the beginning of the process.

Although a lot of the work is about writing reports, about half my work is spent on sites overseeing digs. When you stand on site next to the Thames in east London and a tool-making factory dating from 5000BC is unearthed before your eyes, it's exhilarating.

webTitle: Propping up the student bar could help you find a good job

fields.headline: Propping up the student bar could help you find a good job
fields.standfirst: Even working as a bouncer can be useful in your future career
fields.trailText: Even working as a bouncer can be useful in your future career
fields.body:
Don't be ashamed of the hours you've spent in the student bar. Given the right spin at interview, your appetite for socialising at university can come in very handy at the next stage of your career. Even final year students can find themselves with a couple of spare hours and there's worth to be found in most part-time jobs, however unlikely that might seem at the time.

Jackie Parr, an events organiser from Plymouth, loved attending union activities during her time at Reading University. It was only when she thought that she could do things better that she approached the union with ideas about setting up alternative entertainment.

"I once organised a 70s disco complete with glitter ball and Abba lookalike competition - now I organise events for local leisure centres such as swimming galas and children's parties," she says.

"All the job advertisements for events organisation asked for experience and although mine was specialised, it was still relevant enough for it to matter," she says.

Working on an IT helpdesk might sound less fun but according to Igho Wekpe, who does evening shifts at the London College of Printing, helping stressed students battle with deadlines and improve their computer knowledge displays his "communication skills". He reckons that the tenacity and patience involved working on a helpdesk will show a future employer that he has an ability to "interact with people" - an elusive quality that many employers are looking for. "You can tailor the work to make yourself appear dynamic and special," says Igho, who is currently studying at LCP for a BSc in information studies.

Working during study is a fact of life for most cash-strapped students and there is no reason why this work cannot be related to your future career aspirations - it just requires a little imagination. Even something as mundane as administration can be useful. When a couple of staff fell ill at Central St Martins College of Art, Anna Gilmore - who was studying fashion and design at the time - volunteered to oversee the handing out of grant cheques.

"When I first started looking for work as a fashion buyer I had no experience and I was forever needing to prove my reliability. When I told interviewers I was once responsible for handling sums of money that meant life or death to hundreds of students they began to take me a bit more seriously," she says.

"I knew that if I managed to get someone's cheque in the wrong hands or lose it I would be in trouble. They paid me only £15 for the whole morning, but I was able to talk about it in my first interview which was far more valuable," Anna says.

According to the National Union of Students, working at college can be a useful addition to the graduate's CV, providing it has not affected their studies or interfered with their deadlines. The NUS is more enthusiastic about students working outside term time.

"If you can type, you can always work in the holidays and temp which will help to hone your office skills," says a spokesperson. However, the NUS is more sniffy about working in pubs and shops which, it reckons, will be of "very little use" to graduates taking their first career steps.

But David Hands of the Federation of Small Businesses disagrees: "Working in a shop can be quite valuable for anyone who wants to learn about dealing with the public. Businesses don't just think about profits," he says.

According to the FSB, businesses are always keen to employ staff who are customer care aware and it reckons that working in the service industry at any level will improve this aptitude. "Even in these hi-tech times, employees appreciate candidates who can work with a broad range of customers," says David.

This was certainly the case for Jason Moreland, a graduate of Durham University. At first, Jason was wary of starting work as a bouncer at an "unfriendly" local club to supplement his finances, but eventually he realised the full benefits of the job.

"Customers could be rude, sometimes even insulting... it was not what I was used to," he says. But when Jason began work in an insurance claims call centre, he discovered that working in the deep end of the service sector had given him, "a lot of confidence in dealing with stressed and annoyed customers".

The NUS says that about 40% of students work part-time during term-time at college and the union grudgingly admits that the majority work in shops and pubs. It claims that service-related jobs will be "unlikely" to "tie up with a graduate's future career". But hundreds of students like Moreland can testify to the contrary.

A few hours of your spare time each week can easily be exploited to gain cash and experience, and this need not infringe upon your study time. Even a vague knowledge of menial shop, bar or club work will be a selling point to potential employers who will value your initiative and resourcefulness.

Five top tips

1. Don't dismiss unpaid work but don't let yourself be exploited.

2. Look for opportunities in local papers. Not everything interesting makes it to a college noticeboard.

3. Always make sure that a written reference will be provided, possibly even stating your benevolence.

4. Try and make sure that the work doesn't interfere with your studies - even if you do see a viable career move in it. Remember, you could always change your mind.

5. Try and make friends with whoever you meet at your work. You never know when you might need them again.

webTitle: How to do something completely different

fields.headline: How to do something completely different
fields.standfirst: The wrong job is no joke
fields.trailText: The wrong job is no joke
fields.body:
When Cindy Jefferies resigned from her job as a trainee solicitor, just three months before her final exams, her parents thought she'd gone bonkers.

"Not about the resignation particularly," says Cindy, "but the fact that I was going to work in a bar instead. It just seemed incomprehensible to them. But the fact was, I'd never wanted to be a solicitor - I'd just fallen into it after university by taking work as a legal temp."

Taking a decision to change career can be extremely difficult, but Cindy has never regretted it. "I was unhappy in the legal world," she admits, "and one night when I was moaning to a friend, she said 'Since when did you want to be a solicitor anyway? You always wanted to run a bar.'

"It was like a complete bolt from the blue - I'd got so caught up in exams and moving up the career ladder that I'd forgotten all about my real dreams and ambitions."

"It's very common for people in their 20s to feel they are in the wrong job," says Professor Ben Fletcher, dean of the Business School at Hertfordshire University.

"Many people are unsure about what they want to do when they leave college and so take the first job that comes along which sounds vaguely interesting and has a decent salary. Years later, they find themselves stuck in a career that doesn't suit them, trapped by their position and income."

It can seem a huge risk to give up a secure job for an uncertain future - but employers are becoming increasingly flexible about previous experience and are happy to take on people from unrelated fields.

"Any good employer looks for two main factors in a prospective employee - suitability and eligibility," says chartered corporate psychologist Ben Williams. "Eligibility in terms of past experience and relevant qualifications, suitability in relation to their character, personality and whether they have the right sort of interpersonal skills for the job.

"Although the ideal is to have a combination of both, it's perfectly possible to land a job with only suitability - which many employers now see as more important than relevant qualifications."

Lack of experience was a big cause of anxiety for Justin Lovett who, after three years in banking, decided that he had to get out.

"I had huge debts after university and the salaries offered by banking seemed huge," he says. "For the first year it was great - the novelty of having money and going out and about in London was a total change from student life.

"But gradually I realised that the job itself was dull and frustrating - and the thought of still being in the same field in 10 years time made me feel really depressed."

In one way, Justin was fortunate in that he knew what he wanted to do. "I've always been fascinated by new technology and I wanted to work for an internet company. I took a night school course in the computer language HTML and spent hours at home on my computer learning and researching about the web.

"I used up loads of my holiday allowance going for interviews, but finally landed a job in the production department of a website design company. It was a lot less money - most of the people I worked with thought I was mad - but after six months I got promoted and instead of dreading going to work, now I positively look forward to it."

Both Justin and Cindy had to deal with negative reactions from friends and family when they decided to shift careers - and this is often one of the main reasons why people can remain in the wrong job.

"Everyone is constrained, to some degree, by their personal history and situation," says Professor Fletcher. "People may worry that their family will be disappointed in them, or they compare their career success to other people and feel they don't measure up.

"Others feel that changing careers may be seen as sign of weakness or lack of commitment. The only way to overcome these feelings is to focus on what is the right thing for you - regardless of what others will say or think."

Cindy Jefferies agrees. "I had a couple of really bad arguments with my Dad, who couldn't believe what I'd done. There were moments in the first few months, when I'd been on my feet for five hours a night and took home £150 a week, that I did worry if it was all going to work out.

"But now, two years on, that I'm running my own wine bar he's really proud - he can see how much happier I am."

French philosopher Bertrand Russell summed it up when he said: "Success is getting what you want, happiness is wanting what you get."

If you don't remember anything else, remember this...

Work isn't just about doing something you're good at, it's also about doing something that makes you happy. Take control - go on a course, write 'on spec' letters, focus on what you really want - and don't let anyone put you off.

fields.headline: Tip of the week
fields.standfirst: Yield to temp-tation
fields.trailText: Yield to temp-tation
fields.body: Deciding what to do with your life after graduation can be frightening. But it needn't be. Today's economy provides the opportunity for almost everyone to try before they buy - buy into a career, that is, says author and temping advocate Carol Feltman. "You will learn how to interview. If you do it often enough, you'll become comfortable with the process, figure out what works for you, and more importantly what doesn't. You will earn while you learn and you will quickly find those tasks and career fields that you are neither interested in nor suited for," she says. "And if you mess up, you can move on to something else without a dismal record following you."

webTitle: Moving on up: An ABC guide to following performance curves

fields.headline: Moving on up: An ABC guide to following performance curves
fields.trailText: Pacing yourself can be the key to success in a new position
fields.body:
A. Going up

Performance in a job is of a curvaceous nature, best represented by an S. Until you get used to your new surroundings, employers don't expect too much of you - although that period can be as short as a few hours. Then you're expected to improve. Rapidly. Pace yourself: the more steeply you ascend, the sooner you reach the top, often exhausted. Once there, you've no option other than levelling out or descending.

B. Level ground

Where performance is judged solely on the rate of climb, failure often follows. Constant improvement cannot be sustained. Interludes when experience is capitalised on allow energy to be channelled into consolidation. Every individual needs occasional respite from challenge: feeling relaxed, you can begin to enjoy what you do. Every employer needs people who have reached level ground. They provide continuity, stability and a backbone of knowledge. Companies staffed entirely by a workforce clinging to the precipitous slopes of steep learning and performance curves invite disaster.

C. Bounce forward

The knowledge that you're on top of your job should not leave you feeling vulnerable or stuck in a rut, but in merciless environments plateauing out after excelling can be the cue for being managed out. Keep a look-out for the most effective springing off point to the next opportunity. Choose one that values and rewards experience.

webTitle: Help: I don't want to be a snitch!I

fields.headline: Help: I don't want to be a snitch!I
fields.trailText: Being asked to judge the performance of your peers can be a daunting experience but, says Irene Krechowiecka, the experience can lead to increased trust and dissemination of good practice
fields.body:
I have to carry out performance audits on colleagues and am unhappy about being put in that position. It feels like being asked to tell tales on those I work with.

Penny S, lecturer, Liverpool

You've got it wrong. This is a worthwhile exercise in building trust and sharing good practice, particularly if you all agree what you'll say and how you'll phrase it beforehand. That sort of mutual help and understanding can lead to some serious workplace bonding, which you need if your management is intent on raising levels of scrutiny, anxiety and paperwork. Peer review is only threatening and divisive where you let it be.

Managers who have time to devise and implement such schemes are usually so removed from workday realities they wouldn't be able to distinguish a good performance from a bad one - which is why they need you to do it for them. Because they don't know what's going on they'll be unaware that the tyrannised talk to each other and even on occasion co-operate to subvert some of their dafter edicts.

The simplest, least stressful solution is to go through the motions. Show how seriously you are taking it by insisting on dropping other work to give this task the time it deserves, then assess as you would like to be assessed. Identify and exclude anyone with a prefect mentality from your co-op. Consider abusing power to settle old scores with them.

Your other option is to tell management to do it themselves. But who would you rather have appraising you, them or us?

 Email Irene Krechowiecka with your comments and questions

webTitle: Make the most of life as an expat and you could hit the Biggs time

fields.headline: Make the most of life as an expat and you could hit the Biggs time
fields.standfirst: Working abroad can give a sense of freedom
fields.trailText: Working abroad can give a sense of freedom
fields.body:
Like many graduates, Nicola King wasn't sure what kind of career she wanted when she finished university. She knew she wanted to travel. With her degree in modern languages and a PGCE, teaching English as a foreign language (TEFL) seemed the obvious answer. She signed up with a language school and was thrilled when they offered her a placement in Leipzig in Germany teaching business English.

However, just a few weeks into her new job, things started to go wrong. "The teaching itself was fine but the atmosphere at the school was so insular," Nicola explained. "Most of the staff were English speaking and they'd been there a long time. They all socialised together after work, some of them were living together and some of them were even having affairs.

"But it was an incongruous group of people and because they spent so much time together they'd run out of things to talk about. There was a lot of gossiping and bitching and I never really felt like I fitted in. I was miserable a lot of the time."

Nicola's experience highlights some of the problems you can face when joining an expat community. Taking a job abroad may be exciting but it can also be daunting and joining a ready-made group of people from your own culture is a reassuring safety net. However, there's no guarantee that you'll get on with your new colleagues any more than if you were working at home. But, whereas you can escape from dodgy colleagues on home turf, in an expat environment, you're stuck with them.

Most of the problems of expat communities stem from unrealistic expectations, says Siobhan Hamilton-Phillips, senior consultant with Career Psychology in London. "People who go and work abroad are usually looking for a bit of excitement," she says.

"They expect to be stretched and having to adapt to a new environment is all part of the challenge. But if your expectations are too high, the reality can be a let-down and a lot of people end up gossiping and bitching because they're disappointed. There's also a sense of freedom when you're abroad that makes people try and get away with bad behaviour that they wouldn't try at home."

If you find yourself the subject of expat bitching, confront it, says Siobhan. "Unravel the rumours and find out who it's coming from. Put things straight and tell them in a pleasant and mature manner that you don't like what's been said and you don't expect it to happen again. That usually does the trick."

For those about to set off for jobs in more exotic climes, she recommends you throw yourself into life in the new country so you don't depend too much on your workmates. "Learn as much about the local culture as you can before you go and make a commitment to learn the language," she says. "If you had a particular hobby at home, make an effort to keep it up when you're abroad.

"Be inquisitive, track down clubs and societies where you'll meet other people with the same interests. If you're not going to take part, what are you there for?"

Engineer Richard Marron has spent the six years since completing his masters degree working abroad in the oil and gas industries. He's worked in Oman, Brunei and the USA and is currently posted in Italy. "I've always worked in expat communities and I find it useful to be able to speak to people who can tell me the dos and don'ts of the country when I arrive," he says.

"I know there can be bitchiness in these kinds of situations but it tends to be more among people who bring their families with them. Perhaps it's because the families often live together in a compound and they spend too much time together. But I'm a single man, so it's much easier for me to draw back and do my own thing if things get intense."

Like Siobhan, Richard stresses the importance of embracing the experience of living in a foreign culture. "I think it's great to be paid to visit interesting parts of the world but in my experience, the people who don't succeed are those who just do it for the money and don't try to enjoy themselves," he says. "It's important to get out and meet local people as well as your colleagues from home.

"But I would advise people not to go with too many pre-conceived ideas. You can't prepare totally for something you've never done before, so be flexible and adapt to the customs of the country you're visiting and you'll have a good time."

Nicola's story has a positive ending. She stuck out her placement in Germany but was determined to learn from the experience. Her next posting was also in Germany but this time to Cologne.

"I had a better time there because I made more of an effort," she says. "I found lodgings with a local family and most of the time I socialised with Germans. It was still difficult at times, though.

"But working abroad is about learning about different people and cultures," she concludes. "If you don't make an effort to get involved, you're just being British abroad and there's no point."

Put things straight and tell them in a pleasant and mature manner that you don't like what's been said and you don't expect it to happen again. That usually does the trick." For those about to set off for jobs in more exotic climes, she recommends you throw yourself into life in the new country so you don't depend too much on your workmates. "Learn as much about the local culture as you can before you go and make a commitment to learn the language," she says. "If you had a particular hobby at home, make an effort to keep it up when you're abroad. "Be inquisitive, track down clubs and societies where you'll meet other people with the same interests. If you're not going to take part, what are you there for?" Engineer Richard Marron has spent the six years since completing his masters degree working abroad in the oil and gas industries. He's worked in Oman, Brunei and the USA and is currently posted in Italy. "I've always worked in expat communities and I find it useful to be able to speak to people who can tell me the dos and don'ts of the country when I arrive," he says. "I know there can be bitchiness in these kinds of situations but it tends to be more among people who bring their families with them. Perhaps it's because the families often live together in a compound and they spend too much time together. But I'm a single man, so it's much easier for me to draw back and do my own thing if things get intense." Like Siobhan, Richard stresses the importance of embracing the experience of living in a foreign culture. "I think it's great to be paid to visit interesting parts of the world but in my experience, the people who don't succeed are those who just do it for the money and don't try to enjoy themselves," he says. "It's important to get out and meet local people as well as your colleagues from home. "But I would advise people not to go with too many pre-conceived ideas. You can't prepare totally for something you've never done before, so be flexible and adapt to the customs of the country you're visiting and you'll have a good time." Nicola's story has a positive ending. She stuck out her placement in Germany but was determined to learn from the experience. Her next posting was also in Germany but this time to Cologne. "I had a better time there because I made more of an effort," she says. "I found lodgings with a local family and most of the time I socialised with Germans. It was still difficult at times, though. "But working abroad is about learning about different people and cultures," she concludes. "If you don't make an effort to get involved, you're just being British abroad and there's no point."  Career Psychology, tel: 0207-976-1010.

fields.headline: Top rung/Bottom rung
fields.trailText: Two employees from either end of the career ladder share their experiences of working at London Electricity
fields.body:
John Davies
Aged 51
Customer service manager London Electricity

John Davies trained as an accountant with the Central Electricity Generating Board but by the early 80s had moved into customer services with the South West Electricity Board.

He became its customer affairs manager and later customer services manager, continuing with that title when it combined with London Electricity last October.

London Electricity is French-owned and is a gas and electricity supplier throughout Britain with a £2bn turnover last year. It also owns a power station.

Power pack: John is responsible for 1,000 staff who are based at two centres: Doxford near Sunderland and Sowton near Exeter. They serve 3m electricity and 50,000 gas customers - looking after bills, meter readings, new customers, payments problems and special needs customers.

The buzz? He enjoys seeing his staff fulfil their potential with 70% of his time devoted to staff matters. "We look to employ the best people and to give them the best training. From that we will get highly satisfied customers."

Must-have qualities: "Within our side of the business, you need common sense, to be caring and want to help customers and to show teamwork with colleagues."

Sapna Nijhawan
Aged 25
Retail strategy executive London Electricity

Sapna Nijhawan graduated with a business degree (Nottingham Trent) in 1997 and, after a year temping and travelling abroad, applied to major company graduate schemes. "I was looking for one offering comprehensive experience and variety," she says.

Sapna joined London Electricity as one of four commercial graduates recruited in 1998. Other LE streams have their own graduate recruitment -but all graduates are trained over an 18-month to two-year period.

To date: Sapna has four placements during her training. So far she has worked in change management, marketing and customer operations. She is currently in retail strategy.

Training and progress: "All graduates have an induction programme, then every two months we attend one to two-day courses on such subjects as negotiation and presentation skills. There are also 'buddying' and mentoring schemes and appraisals, setting individual targets, are fixed with each placement."

Next move: "I would like to stay on the commercial side of the business."

Tip to graduates: "Learn to take the inevitable knock-backs you get when applying."

 For more details visit the website www.london-electricity.co.uk

Finish your message with :-D and you're laughing while :-> means you're being sarcastic. Type in :-X to sign off with a kiss or >:-> to suggest mischievous intents. We'll leave the meaning of ~*#@ to your imagination.
fields.body:
Mixed messages: Time to introduce some character to your office emails. Orange's free magazine for users provides a handy guide to email sign-offs. Finish your message with :-D and you're laughing while :-> means you're being sarcastic. Type in :-X to sign off with a kiss or >:-> to suggest mischievous intents. We'll leave the meaning of ~*#@ to your imagination.

Dream on: Winning the lottery and retiring to a life of luxury may not be all it's cracked up to be. That's the verdict of researcher and author Joanne Ciulla. "Work structures our time and imposes a rhythm on our lives. It gets us organised into various kinds of communities and social groups. And perhaps most importantly, work tells us what to do every day."

Too plane: If you're going on a business trip soon, you might want to toss something else in with the clothes, laptop and papers -like some food. Nutritionist Joanne Lichten, author of a forthcoming book on healthy on-the-road eating, suggests "quick-cooking oatmeal, nonfat milk powder, a box of raisins, dried fruit and granola-typebars". Mmm!

£25,000 up for grabs: Kickstart your career by winning a share of a £25,000 investment fund. The organisers of this year's Bodyform Career Awards are keen to hear from anyone seeking finance, whether for training, a piece of equipment or help in starting a new business. For more info send an SAE to Bodyform Careers Awards, PO Box 12, Nottingham NG7 2GB.

Hack attack: Choose your profession carefully. Journalists are among the least-trusted members of society, below sales people and only a notch above politicians. That's the conclusion of a survey of MBA graduates from the Open University Business School. Family and friends come top of the trust scale. Between the lepers and the loved ones are doctors, teachers and the police.

Time out: Smokers spend an average of 36 minutes a day outside the workplace to indulge their habits, says an American study. In Michigan, for example, they average three trips outside each day and spend a total of 138,059,844 hours a year smoking claims research company EPIC/MRA.

fields.headline: Kids stuff
fields.trailText: Gail Dickman, financial controller for Nickelodeon UK and Paramount Comedy Channel
fields.body:
Name: Gail Dickman.

Status: Financial controller for Nickelodeon UK and Paramount Comedy Channel.

Past: Business graduate from Curtin University in Western Australia. Worked in Perth as an accountant before moving to UK. Temped at BSkyB and through contacts landed job as management accountant at Nickelodeon. Became financial controller last year.

Present: "I supervise the whole finance department, putting together a monthly report for shareholders and heads of department within the company."

Future: "I'd like to broaden my accounting experience in the media industry because it's growing and so diverse."

Strengths: "I'm always willing to learn new things and prepared to work hard or work late to meet the next challenge - whatever it takes really."

Weaknesses: "Sometimes I lack confidence in my own ability and need to adopt a more 'can do' attitude."

Wisdom: "The harder you work, the more people will be prepared to take risks to find out what you want in a career."

References: www.nickelodeon.co.uk

webTitle: Do your homework and show your best side

fields.headline: Do your homework and show your best side
fields.standfirst: In an age of dressing-down Fridays, how you present yourself - clothes, appearance, speech, manner and body language - is still important when meeting prospective employers. Eileen Sheridan spells out the do's and don'ts
fields.trailText: In an age of dressing-down Fridays, how you present yourself - clothes, appearance, speech, manner and body language - is still important when meeting prospective employers. Eileen Sheridan spells out the do's and don'ts
fields.body:
You've got the qualifications, you've got the CV and now you've got what you wanted - an interview. And that's where the real test starts. No matter how good you look on paper, it is you in person that will ultimately be judged by the employer and there is no hiding place from that.

Job interviews are now the stuff of urban myth, there are apocrypha in plenty which are best ignored - job interviews can be tough enough without silly stories unsettling you. The worst things that can happen are the trick question or the unexpected test, but even these can be anticipated to some degree, say employment specialists. Wendy Seal, from Securicor Recruitment Services, advises that even killer questions are designed to determine your suitability for the job. If you know what a prospective employer is looking for before you go into an interview you should be able to tailor your answers accordingly.

Research is always the key to an interview which will not leave you looking silly, even if only in your own eyes. If you find out as much as is humanly possible about the company, the job and, even more importantly, the company's clients, your foundations are sound and it will be easier to deal with whatever comes along. And you have paid them the compliment of being deeply interested in them which is always a winner.

Sources for company information are even easier to access now that any organisation worth working for has a website. However, the website will only tell you what the company wants you to know. It is also worth looking in the Companies' House Register which is policed by the Department of Trade and Industry and gives information on limited companies, including their latest reports. The register should be on microfiche at any decent sized library. General business and trade directories will also provide information and you must make sure you read any literature which has been sent along with your application form. If the job you are applying for has a professional body, get in touch and ask for any information they can supply about employment in their field, and let your interviewer know you have done this.

The other part of being prepared is, in a sense, to research yourself - because that is what the interviewer will be doing with you. "Work out from what you know about the job what are the key selling points about yourself that you want to get across," says Catherine Gilbert of recruitment agency Drake Beam Marin (DBM). "And be prepared to back up those points. For instance, if you say you are very creative, be prepared to give examples of where you have used that creativity."

Professor Gavin Kennedy, of Heriot Watt Business School, says it is good to have a strategy to sell your strong points. So, job hunters should write down a "benefit" next to each part of their CV before attending the interview and plan to talk about how that is relevant to the job. As well as being prepared, you need to be positive about the company or organisation, and about yourself, although not insanely so. A favourite question is: "Have you any weaknesses?" John Waddingham, author of The Job's Yours, advises interviewees to say that they have no weaknesses which would affect their performance in the job that is on offer. Saying you have none is arrogance.

Another area which can be a minefield if you are moving from one job to another is your reason for leaving your present post. You might be tempted to tell the truth - the job's a nightmare, your boss a tyrant, your pay is lousy. Even criticism of your present job gives you a chance to be positive. A bit of spin can change the nightmare job into one which does not offer enough of a challenge, a tyrannical boss can be transformed into a lack of opportunity to progress and if you are looking for more money, you're ambitious and you value what you will bring to the company.

Professor Kennedy says interviewees must bring the positive spin to every part of their history, even a period of unemployment. "Focus on what you learned or gained from that period, even if it was not the happiest time," he says. "Interviewers will appreciate honesty. I think it is fair to say that things were not going well - as long as you can show that something positive came out of it."

There is clearly a danger in overselling yourself, but don't undersell yourself either. "Always go into the interview ready to get to the next stage of the process," advises DBM's Catherine Gilbert. "You must focus on getting your selling points across. Don't undersell yourself because you think it might not be the job for you. Give it your best shot. You can always turn down an offer."

These are the personality and skills part of the interview, but your stunning character will count for nothing if you fail to observe the basics. First impressions count. (Be punctual, be pristine and be polite.) John Waddingham warns interviewees to look keen even in the waiting room - the receptionist and other staff may be watching to judge your attitude and report back to the employer.

In this era of greater informality, dress has become a variable. Catherine Gilbert advises dressing appropriately, although bear in mind it is traditional to dress up somewhat for an interview. "While you wouldn't probably turn up in a suit for businesses known for casual dress, such as advertising, graphics or public relations, you would still dress smart casual - the sort of thing you would wear on behalf of the company," she advises. "And if you are being introduced by a recruiter, ask them what you think is appropriate."

And you have your body language to consider. John Waddingham points out that poor body language creates an immediate barrier and cites sitting with your arms folded which can be interpreted as saying that you are in charge or that you are hiding something. He advises the nervous against retreating into their private space, but warns against anything which might look like an invasion of your interviewer's space, such as leaning too far forward across the desk or standing too closely. But lean forward slightly to show interest in what the interviewer is saying. Avoid unnecessary gestures and don't let your gaze wander. If your gaze is wandering, your mind is probably wandering too and this is a situation where you should pay 100% attention.
And last impressions count as well. Don't forget those final moments when you will be asked if you have any questions. Be prepared for this, keep a little back, otherwise you are in danger of spoiling what might have been a good interview with a last lack-lustre "Oh, I can't think of anything." This is where you can show you can think on your feet and pick up some of the points made by the interviewer, explains Professor Kennedy. "It's also good to ask about the timing of promotion and training opportunities and show that you expect the company to play its part," he says. In other words: remember that the company is going to get something out of this as well - they are going to get you!

 The Job's Yours! by John Waddingham, Elliott Right Way Books, £3.99.

fields.headline: Elian case lifts anti-Castro lobby
fields.standfirst:
Fight for Cuban boy reminds Miami's exiles of past struggles

More about the Elian Gonzalez case
Campaign to keep Elian in US
Let Elian go home
fields.trailText: On Thursday night, there were loud cheers as the leader of the anti-Castro Democracy Movement, Ramon Saul Sanchez, urged supporters to crowd the access roads to Miami airport and drive slowly yesterday to protest at the US government's plans to reunite Elian with his father.
fields.body:
There is a ramshackle quality to the protest camp encircling Elian Gonzalez's temporary Miami home. Most of the posters denouncing Bill Clinton and Fidel Castro in equal measure have been scrawled in felt-tip and tentative English.

There are just about enough Cuban flags and Stars and Stripes to go around the two score demonstrators who constitute the protest's day shift, but the sound system is fit to rouse only the smallest rabble, consisting of a handheld tape machine connected to a cheap megaphone, blaring out tinny renditions of old patriotic songs.

As viewed from this dusty corner of Miami's Little Havana, the great Cuban-US lobby does not look like the political juggernaut it once was. The formerly mighty Cuban American National Foundation, known locally as just "The Foundation", cannot deploy its battalions at the anti-Castro front the way it used to before 1997, when its founder, Jorge Mas Canosa, passed away.

A plethora of small competing groups have grown up around the foundation, drawing on the same political nutrients - the wealth produced by the phenomenally successful Cuban-American community in Florida. They have produced their own pamphlets, posters and T-shirts, which can be seen - like a directory of Cuban ethnic politics - on the suntanned torsos of the diehard Elian protesters.

The quasi-religious fervour generated by the tale of the little boy cast adrift on waves between Miami and Communist Cuba has generated a fresh burst of energy and determination in the exile community, giving it a sense of purpose which had begun to seep away after Mr Mas Canosa's death and the ageing of his contemporaries.

On Thursday night, there were loud cheers as the leader of the anti-Castro Democracy Movement, Ramon Saul Sanchez, urged supporters to crowd the access roads to Miami airport and drive slowly yesterday to protest at the US government's plans to reunite Elian with his father.

"The campaign of civil disobedience begins," said Mr Sanchez, standing atop a trash can. "When they don't leave you an option, you must choose to stand up upon your dignity or live like a slave, humiliated and on your knees for the rest of your life."

Juan Torres Mena, a 66-year-old veteran of the ill-fated Bay of Pigs invasion, says he has not felt so full of life for years. Standing at the police barricade beside a poster arguing that "Freedom supersedes fatherhood", he is wearing a baseball hat inscribed Brigada de Asalto 2506, the unit he was in when a band of poorly trained Cuban exiles tried to recapture their homeland from Fidel Castro's forces in 1961, only to find themselves abandoned by their supposed US backers. Mr Torres was captured and spent 22 months as a prisoner of war.

"Now it's all happening again," he said. "The United States is betraying us over Elian, the same way it betrayed us at the Bay of Pigs."

The anti-Castro forces, he might have added, look just as ragtag as they did 39 years ago. Turnout at demonstrations has been patchy and the flow of US public opinion about Elian has turned against them. A clear majority of Americans now think that Elian should be returned to his father, even if that means a return to Cuba.

As a measure of their weakness, the Cuban exile lobby in Washington has been unable to push a bill giving Elian permanent US residence, first drafted in December, on to the congressional agenda.

"That would never have happened when Jorge Mas Canosa was alive. He never fell on his face like that," said Philip Peters, a Cuba analyst at the Lexington Institute.

Beyond Elian, in the broader struggle against Havana, the exile hardliners have been losing ground dramatically. Last month, when a bill to allow for food and humanitarian exports to Cuba - knocking holes in the 40-year-old embargo - came before the senate foreign affairs committee, the chairman, the famously conservative Republican Jesse Helms, waved it through.

Last year, he had blocked a similar measure. But this year, there was little he could do to fend off the pressure from US farmers and businessmen, straining to have their share of the Cuban market.

With its diminished clout, the foundation and its lobby, the Free Cuba Political Action Committee, have tried to spend their money wisely, targeting funds at a small number of influential politicians on both sides of the fence.

In the current election campaign, 55% of its money spent on congressional campaigns has gone to Democrats such as Patrick Kennedy, who co-sponsored a bill in the House of Representatives to grant Elian permanent residency.

Mr Kennedy, Senator Ted Kennedy's son, has broken with the Clinton administration and his father, calling for Elian's fate to be decided in the courts, rather than by an immigration service ruling.

"Those elements are particularly necessary because of the fact there is no freedom of speech in Cuba, and therefore, we still do not know what Elian's father truly wants in this matter," Mr Kennedy said.

It is likely that the foundation's time-tested fundraising and organisational abilities were also a factor in Vice-President Al Gore's decision to split from his boss and oppose Elian's repatriation.

"He knows those people are needed to bring in the votes. They carry a disproportionate amount of weight," said Peter Eisner, a political analyst at the Centre for Public Integrity.

But most observers in Miami believe the vice-president may have made a crucial misjudgment, grounded in the old conventional wisdom about the foundation's muscle, rather than the more subtle and multihued Cuban-American scene today.

David Rieff, the author of The Exile: Cuba in the Heart of Miami, argues that "the arrival of Elian Gonzalez breathed new life into the traditional ways of doing exile politics in south Florida".

fields.bodyText: There is a ramshackle quality to the protest camp encircling Elian Gonzalez's temporary Miami home. Most of the posters denouncing Bill Clinton and Fidel Castro in equal measure have been scrawled in felt-tip and tentative English. There are just about enough Cuban flags and Stars and Stripes to go around the two score demonstrators who constitute the protest's day shift, but the sound system is fit to rouse only the smallest rabble, consisting of a handheld tape machine connected to a cheap megaphone, blaring out tinny renditions of old patriotic songs. As viewed from this dusty corner of Miami's Little Havana, the great Cuban-US lobby does not look like the political juggernaut it once was. The formerly mighty Cuban American National Foundation, known locally as just "The Foundation", cannot deploy its battalions at the anti-Castro front the way it used to before 1997, when its founder, Jorge Mas Canosa, passed away. A plethora of small competing groups have grown up around the foundation, drawing on the same political nutrients - the wealth produced by the phenomenally successful Cuban-American community in Florida. They have produced their own pamphlets, posters and T-shirts, which can be seen - like a directory of Cuban ethnic politics - on the suntanned torsos of the diehard Elian protesters. On Thursday night, there were loud cheers as the leader of the anti-Castro Democracy Movement, Ramon Saul Sanchez, urged supporters to crowd the access roads to Miami airport and drive slowly yesterday to protest at the US government's plans to reunite Elian with his father. "The campaign of civil disobedience begins," said Mr Sanchez, standing atop a trash can. "When they don't leave you an option, you must choose to stand up upon your dignity or live like a slave, humiliated and on your knees for the rest of your life." Standing at the police barricade beside a poster arguing that "Freedom supersedes fatherhood", he is wearing a baseball hat inscribed Brigada de Asalto 2506, the unit he was in when a band of poorly trained Cuban exiles tried to recapture their homeland from Fidel Castro's forces in 1961, only to find themselves abandoned by their supposed US backers. "The United States is betraying us over Elian, the same way it betrayed us at the Bay of Pigs." The anti-Castro forces, he might have added, look just as ragtag as they did 39 years ago. webTitle: Romeo, the spanner and Tybalt's nipple

fields.headline: Romeo, the spanner and Tybalt's nipple
fields.trailText: The narrator set the scene: "And now to the feast of Capulet/ Where Romeo is doomed to meet Juliet,/ And in a scene of timeless romance/ He tries to get into Juliet's pants."
fields.body:
The narrator set the scene:
"And now to the feast of Capulet
Where Romeo is doomed to meet Juliet,
And in a scene of timeless romance
He tries to get into Juliet's pants."

Romeo was played by an American man. Juliet was played by an American man. She sat on the branch of a beech tree grimly clutching a window box. It was, quite possibly, meant to be the balcony scene. His gangly legs, swathed in tights, were very nearly knock-kneed. His wig might well have been trimmed with shears. He was the spitting image of Emo Phillips, that now nearly forgotten proto-alternative comic. She, too, looked like Emo Phillips, but with a skirt, all of which did nothing for me.

"Call me butt love," said this American Romeo to Juliet on her makeshift balcony. She raised a sarcastic eyebrow higher and higher until he corrected his mistake. "Call me but love and I'll be new baptised."

The thing, ultimately, with Shakespeare, is that you have to stay true to the verse. Otherwise you wind up calling yourself butt love. "What I was taught," said Peter Hall during The Genius of Shakespeare, "was that Shakespeare wrote in lines, not words, that the iambic pentameter, which is like the system under a piece of jazz, has a strong rhythm and needs marking as a line, and that great Shakespeare playing is, as we would say now, exactly like great jazz playing: you keep the beat, you understand the beat, you preserve the line, but it's how you nearly break the line which enables you to express the emotion." The great British actors - Gielgud, Richardson, Edith Evans, Arthur Mullard etc - all knew this, if not instinctively, then rather because their acting culture was imbued with the jazz-like sensitivity to verse mastery.

Good points, lessons learned over a career of directing our greatest playwright in the best theatres in the land. But lessons that have been cast aside by the Reduced Shakespeare Company. "What's in a name anyway?" Juliet told Romeo from her branch. "That which we call a nose would still smell."

The company's specially commissioned TV production of Romeo and Juliet in the Woods would not suit purists. When Tybalt and Romeo fought, for instance, they proved their masculinity by means of table football. Next, Tybalt smacked Romeo around a bit with giant boxing gloves. Romeo retorted by twisting one of Tybalt's nipples with a huge spanner, which must have smarted. Tybalt picked up his pencil sharpener, a model so big that it fitted over Romeo's sword arm. He then twisted and twisted and twisted. Again, that probably hurt a great deal. When Tybalt was dispatched, we cut to a stuffed hare. He, or perhaps she, was the moral conscience of this scene, and looked as upset as only a stuffed hare can.

Here's something distressing that the famous Shakespearean, Professor Harold Bloom, told me only the other day. I don't think he'll mind me quoting him in full. "Recently, Shakespeare went into a pub. He walked up to the bar and asked for a drink. 'Oi! I've told you before,' said the publican, 'you're Bard!'" It comes to something, doesn't it, when our greatest playwright is refused admission to some seedy boozer? It shows, quite clearly to my mind, that we need a full evening of Shakespeare programming on telly to restore him to his cultural pre-eminence.

And so it was. Last night on BBC Knowledge was A Night in With Shakespeare. There was an interesting documentary about the 20-year restoration and reconstruction of the Globe theatre in Southwark, a programme about an experiment to persuade people in inner-city Birmingham to rehearse and perform Shakespeare's work, a Trevor Nunn-directed production of Macbeth starring Ian McKellen and Judi Dench, and more. In addition, there was allied information on www.bbc.co.uk/knowledge/arts/shakespeare, with the full panoply of audio clips, quick time videos and nice graphics. It is great to see the BBC doing this kind of stuff. Particularly great that it does so on a digital channel that hardly anybody has access to. Especially so when you see that at the same time on BBC2 there was two hours of golf from Augusta, a documentary about the Grand National and Gardeners' World. Marvellous stuff.

In The Genius of Shakespeare, there was one particularly lovely moment. Vanessa Redgrave recalled that she used to listen to old 78s of her father, Michael, and Dame Edith Evans playing Orlando and Rosalind in As You Like It. That was how she learned to speak Shakespearean lines properly. We cut to a 1940 production. Redgrave's Orlando had turned up late for his tryst and Evans's Rosalind told him off. "Break a promise in love!" said Evans's Rosalind in unison with Vanessa's Rosalind from a 1968 production, then Vanessa carried on the speech wonderfully, having learned her lesson well.

webTitle: Britain's biggest movie tipped for Bafta failure

fields.headline: Britain's biggest movie tipped for Bafta failure
fields.standfirst: Your guide to the front-runners and full coverage of the Bafta awards at www.filmunlimited.co.uk
fields.trailText: Its thirtysomething first-time director has been feted worldwide, and last month it became the most successful British film ever made, but if Barry Norman is to be believed, it will not win a Bafta tomorrow night.
fields.body:
Its thirtysomething first-time director has been feted worldwide, and last month it became the most successful British film ever made, but if Barry Norman is to be believed, it will not win a Bafta tomorrow night.

No, not the Oscar-winning Sam Mendes and his American Beauty, but East Is East, a small-budget comedy about an Anglo-Asian family who run a Salford fish and chip shop, which with little or no media fanfare became the surprise hit of last year, taking £10.3m at the box office.

Although the film has seven Bafta nominations, including best director for Damien O'Donnell and best screenplay for Ayub Khan Din, few critics are betting on it taking any of the top awards.

That East Is East has become the highest grossing fully British funded film ever should in itself make it worthy of a Bafta, its producer Leslee Udwin said.

"It is all very well giving Baftas to big American films, but we should be standing up for films that were actually made here with British money. All along, the film was written off as a small or Asian film when it was neither and every time it has confounded people. Barry Norman's predictions, I notice, have us winning nothing. Very few others are tipping us, but we may surprise everybody."

It is one of the Baftas' perennial problems. Whether they should grandstand truly British films as the French do with their Césars, or simply be a low-rent version of the Oscars, held a few weeks after the main event, where big Hollywood winners get a chance to take a second bow.

British writers, actors, directors and costume and set designers again dominate this year, but almost all were working on American or US-funded films. The other major exception is Mike Leigh's Gilbert and Sullivan costume drama, Topsy-Turvy.

Tim Angel, the director of the Baftas - which have this year been renamed the Orange British Academy Film Awards - said that narrow nationalism has never been their way.

"You can't be jingoistic about this because so much of the talent these days on big Hollywood films is British, never mind the writers, actors and directors. There are no frontiers in the film business any more. It would also damage the credibility of the Baftas if we were seen to favour purely British films like the French do with their Césars," he said. "You can't deny the money is American in a lot of films nominated this year, but the talent is British."

Barry Norman described East Is East as a "smashing" movie. "I wouldn't be surprised if it sneaked best newcomer for Ayub Khan Din, but you are on terribly dangerous ground if you allow nationality to be the arbiter," he added. "Money makes all the difference, and that is an area where British films suffer."

The Baftas' major problem was their timing, he said. "So often they are just trotting along placidly in the wake of the Oscars. It would be more fun it they were before them."

With 14 nominations, there is an air of inevitability about American Beauty. But Mendes may face stiffer opposition at home than he did in Hollywood. The Baftas often depart from the script.

Last year The Truman Show - ignored at the Oscars - won best film.

Neil Jordan has 10 nominations for The End Of The Affair and Anthony Minghella's underrated The Talented Mr Ripley may also emerge from the pack. Barry Norman is tipping Topsy-Turvy for best British film while the smart money is on Russell Crowe (The Insider) and Jim Broadbent (Topsy-Turvy) for best actor.

And the candidates for main awards are...

Best film

American Beauty, East is East, The End of the Affair, The Sixth Sense, The Talented Mr Ripley

Best director

All About My Mother (Pedro Almodovar), American Beauty (Sam Mendes), The End of the Affair (Neil Jordan), The Sixth Sense (M Night Shyamalan), The Talented Mr Ripley (Anthony Minghella)

Best British film

East is East, Notting Hill, Onegin, Ratcatcher, Topsy-Turvy, Wonderland

Best actress

Linda Bassett (East is East), Annette Bening (American Beauty), Julianne Moore (The End of the Affair), Emily Watson (Angela's Ashes)

Best actor

Jim Broadbent (Topsy-Turvy), Russell Crowe (The Insider), Ralph Fiennes (The End of the Affair), Om Puri (East is East), Kevin Spacey (American Beauty)

Best supporting actress

Thora Birch (American Beauty), Cate Blanchett (The Talented Mr Ripley), Cameron Diaz (Being John Malkovitch), Maggie Smith (Tea With Mussolini), Mena Suvari (American Beauty)

Best supporting actor

Wes Bentley (American Beauty), Michael Caine (Cider House Rules), Rhys Ifans (Notting Hill), Jude Law (The Talented Mr Ripley), Timothy Spall (Topsy-Turvy)

Carl Foreman Award for most promising newcomer in British film

Justin Kerrigan, Ayub Khan Din (East is East), Kirk Jones (Waking Ned), Lynne Ramsay (Ratcatcher)
