fields.headline: Brave new words
fields.standfirst: Alexander Hemon arrived in Chicago, a refugee from Sarajevo, speaking only tourist English. Now, a master of the language, he's being hailed as the 'new Nabokov'. How did he do it, asks Julian Borger
fields.trailText: Alexander Hemon arrived in Chicago, a refugee from Sarajevo, speaking only tourist English. Now, a master of the language, he's being hailed as the 'new Nabokov'. How did he do it, asks Julian Borger
fields.body:
At the University of Sarajevo, Aleksandar Hemon had an English professor who introduced him to the great works of world literature. And, as time went by, the aspiring young writer would present his own efforts to the great man, who, in turn, was only too happy to nurture his favourite student. Professor Nikola Koljevic taught Hemon just about everything he knew about the world of letters, but his most important lesson - and the most devastating - came later.

When the killing started in the former Yugoslavia, the erudite and admired professor took up the banner of the most bloodthirsty killers.

Koljevic, a Shakespeare specialist, became Radovan Karadzic's smooth-tongued deputy in the Serb Democratic Party and helped run the ethnic-cleansing machine in Bosnia. He spent the war laughing off reports of massacres, smiling as he denied the existence of death camps. And, in a twist Shakespeare himself would have appreciated, Koljevic the man of letters masterminded the bombing of Sarajevo's revered library.

Meanwhile, the student - who had become a refugee in Chicago - looked on in dismay as his former mentor mutated on television into an absurd, chauvinist caricature. Hemon's mother was a Bosnian Serb, but, like her, he had never felt any strong affiliation with the new Serb nationalism. When pressed, he identified himself as Ukrainian - a reference to his father's roots, and exotic enough to be neutral at a time when ethnicity was taking on lethal significance.

"I tried to detect the moment when he [Koljevic] crossed the line," Hemon said. "When did it happen? What were the signs? Should I have known? I re-read things he liked, to see how they were in retrospect. Because I thought if you liked literature and you could quote Shakespeare, you're a good person. At least you couldn't possibly be bad. I learnt that was not true." Thus endeth Koljevic's last lesson. After the war was over, the ex-academic sank deeper into a stupor of alcohol and denial, muttering about the past slights he imagined at the hands of his former academic colleagues, who were by then either dead, emotionally shattered or in exile.

Then, one winter's day in January 1997, the great Koljevic shot himself in the head. In fact, he shot himself twice in the head - a feat that led many to wonder about the official verdict of suicide. But, either way, his days as a Shakespearean authority were over.

Thousands of miles away, his favourite student spent the early years of the war in the utmost misery. Hemon was cut off from his family and friends who were still trapped in Bosnia as the blood began to flow. He had been betrayed by his literary mentor, and by everything he thought literature represented. He was an immigrant with no money, doing odd-jobs in a strange country where he spoke only a tourist phrase-book version of the language.

Fast-forward eight years to present-day O'Hare Airport, Chicago. The big, burly 35-year-old with close-cropped brown hair waiting for my plane to arrive is tipped to be the "new Nabokov" - an outsider who has come to English as a second language and shown us how it should be written. Awards are beginning to fall on him like the first snow in a long winter. His stories have been published in the New Yorker and the latest prestigious collection of Best American Short Stories. This week, his first book will be published in Britain. It is a novella and a collection of stories entitled The Question Of Bruno, and it is generating near-messianic excitement in the publishing world, which fought over the rights in the highest-grossing auction for a literary work last year - £154,000.

The book is a satirical, often surreal, meander through a family's half-remembered, half-imagined history, from the Soviet Gulag to Yugoslavia's woeful past to the life of an exile in millennial Chicago. It is cut up into a series of episodes as different from each other as they are from the rest of current English fiction. Yet, by the end, the book feels like a single work. The stories are connected by common themes - the displacement and mixed allegiances of the outsider - as well as characters and places that seep from one tale to the next, like the irrepressible Hemon dynasty itself. It is semi-autobiographical, in that many of the details are authentic, but they have been rearranged in the interests of literature rather than of history - "a consequence of irresponsible imagination and shameless speculation," as Hemon describes it in one of his stories.

Thus, the doomed Archduke Franz Ferdinand - as he is driven through the streets of Sarajevo on his way to being shot by the assassin Gavrilo Princip - can catch the eye of a smiling accordionist in the crowd who turns out to be Hemon's great-grandfather. The great-grandfather, the accordion and Princip himself all make guest appearances in other stories, as if they were all members and props in Hemon's touring troupe.

The early reactions to The Question Of Bruno have verged on the religious, particularly from Hemon's fellow writers. The remarks of US-based Irish writer Colum McCann typify the general tone. "Anarchic, yet beautifully controlled," he said. "In fact it is difficult to find the proper words with which to praise this book - it creates a sort of awed silence around itself."

Hype and hyperbole are the flesh and blood of publishing, but Picador has indeed stuck its neck out on Hemon's future, putting down an extraordinary amount of cash for a debut volume. And Hemon is drawing praise from people whose whole lives have revolved around the crafting of the English language. So the real question here is: How? Most native-born writers hear English from their days in the womb and spend their lives crafting clauses, polishing paragraphs. Yet they can only dream of the sort of acclaim now piled on Hemon.

Vladimir Nabokov, one of Hemon's literary heroes, had an easy transition by comparison. He grew up in Russia, but in a trilingual household speaking English and French as well as Russian. Nabokov read Browning and Keats as a child, and studied at Cambridge long before he arrived in the US as a refugee. Hemon's deep, nonchalant Balkan accent is still audible. It rumbles along in its shoulder-shrugging way as he chats about his new life in Chicago. He speaks the language with relish and a sense of appreciation, the same way he writes. However, he points out that his transformation from a struggling Bosnian writer to a successful English author was not some effortless, overnight miracle. First, he had to overcome the illusion, commonplace among refugees, that the war would somehow turn out to be a mere misunderstanding and that he would soon be on a flight home.

Hemon had found himself in the US almost by accident, having been on a government goodwill tour for aspiring foreign writers when the fighting erupted. He had been due to fly home on May 1, 1992, the first day of Sarajevo's four-year siege. He sat dumbfounded in front of CNN on a friend's television set. The next few weeks were a blur of tormented transatlantic calls from public pay phones to his family living in Sarajevo. "I walked around with a pocket full of coins," he said. "The summer of '92 was the worst. People didn't know what to do - how to hide from the snipers. I had no idea what I should do. My father said, 'Stay away.' Then my mother would say something like, 'Oh, the shooting is less than it was yesterday.'" Hemon took his father's advice and stayed in the US, while his parents found their own way out. (They left for Canada in 1993, having slipped out of Sarajevo for Serb-controlled Banja Luka at the beginning of the city's siege.) Their escape lifted some of the personal urgency from Hemon's situation, but it did not diminish the soul-destroying impact of one atrocity after another in a multicultural republic where people used to get along. The nadir of his exile came with the discovery of the horrific Serb prison camps at Omarska and Trnopolje, where Bosnian Muslims were starved, tortured and executed.

"I was devastated by the camps," Hemon said. "I walked around thinking I should get some help. I was even thinking about going to a psychiatrist, but what are they going to say - 'Think positive'? But it should upset you. If it doesn't, then there's something wrong with you." Instead of seeing a shrink, Hemon performed a sort of amputation on himself, severing his ties with the Bosnian language and with his past as a writer. He simply stopped trying to record his thoughts in his mother tongue, notifying his putative employer, Dani magazine in Sarajevo - a feisty, independent journal that documented the war - that he would not be writing any further columns on the grounds that he had nothing relevant to say.

My Bosnian was pre-war Bosnian." From that moment on, Hemon vowed, he would write exclusively in a language with which he had hitherto had only a colloquial acquaintance. It was a rash act, but Senad Pecanin, Dani's editor and an old Sarajevo friend, was not altogether surprised. "It was a typical thing for Sasha to do. He is a fanatic. The chronically unworldly Hemon started keeping a diary written in his tourist's English, and set about expanding his literary vocabulary in the most direct way he could think of - by following in Nabokov's footsteps. Hemon soon ventured far beyond Lolita, becoming possessed by what he calls the "library demons". "I read everything all the time," he said, all the while obsessively hoarding his stock of words. He transcribed them on to hundreds of index cards, and if he could not immediately remember a word he had already looked up, he would punish himself with the laborious process of leafing through the weighty dictionary once more. The hoard became a "mental warehouse" of industrial proportions, jammed with a bookish vocabulary that went far beyond the requirements of his employment - which, at that time, consisted of going door to door raising funds for Greenpeace. He would drop words such as "thwart" and "hirsute" into his casual banter, and then wonder why his would-be contributors looked at him as if he were a salesman from Mars. He learnt his next lesson: "Every word has its context. You have to learn the context." Memorising an entire language by rote was an arduous and often dispiriting process, and for a long while, Hemon found himself in the tongue-tied limbo of the hapless exile. Eventually, however, Hemon's obsessive dictionary-diving and stockpiling of index cards began to bring results in the deep linguistic recesses of his mind. I remembered things that happened in Sarajevo as if they happened in English." Hemon had given himself five years to write a publishable story in English, and he ended up achieving his goal in three. In 1995, he wrote an unusual contemplation about espionage, called The Sorge Spy Ring. It contained two narratives in one: on the top of the page was a part-autobiographical account of his own childhood suspicions that his father was a Soviet agent (fictionalised by a dénouement in which the poor man is actually carted off to jail). Below, in the form of a series of historical footnotes, is the true story of Richard Sorge, a German diplomat in Japan who passed on Nazi secrets to Moscow, only to have his warnings of imminent invasion disregarded by Stalin.

Together, the halves constitute a meditation on mixed and complex allegiances - a recurring motif in Hemon's work and life: as a Ukrainian-Serb hybrid in Bosnia when ethnic tensions were at their height eight years ago, and more recently as an immigrant trying to fit in while retaining a distinct identity. "What attracted me was the multiple identity of Sorge," Hemon says. "The idea of 'legend' - a spy's story of his imaginary life. My previous life was my 'legend'. I could say anything about my life, and no one would know it wasn't true. I didn't do it, because I was worried I would get out of control."

The piece had rough edges, but in Gibbons' eyes it stood out as fresh and innovative. "I liked him very much and I was also interested in his way of working," Gibbons said. "We liked the same writers, such as Bruno Schulz and Danilo Kis. Both are outside the mainstream, and both are writers who wrote not in a straight-ahead way but who tried to capture the unrealistic nature of life.

"Sasha also used these modes outside realism - footnotes, mindgames, telescoping of time - devices that are an attempt to get a hold of a complex and absurd reality . . . I wish there were more American-born writers who would venture out of the realistic box. We seem to need infusions of Sashas." Gibbons also saw Hemon's natural advantage. By coming to the language from outside, he was all the more respectful of its quirks and its peculiar noises, like someone using a car for the first time. "He's had a great ear for the way language is used, and he is very, very gifted," said Gibbons. "It gives him a place to stand which English speakers don't have. Most writers are somewhat lazy and don't listen to what they write. He has a way of hearing English one word at a time."

The remark chimed with something that Hemon said once over the phone. The way he put it was, "In English, I have the linguistic sensibility of a child, and the mind of an adult." Hemon did not expect to be greeted like Nabokov's second coming, and has no aspirations to leave his Edgewater home in the Chicago suburbs, nor give up his weekend football games with Uptown United - a bunch of fellow immigrants from around the globe, who knock the ball about, yelling in mutually unintelligible versions of English.

But get him on the subject of the current state of English-language fiction and he sounds as arrogant and dismissive as any London literary lord. He does not mean to, and occasionally apologises for giving that impression, but he insists he is simply being straightforward.

However, when he did learn to comprehend English, he found very little to excite him in contemporary writing. When he first hungrily picked up some modern US short stories, he found himself throwing the book across the room. "There was such carelessness about language," he explained. "It was sloppy. And there was that unfortunate tendency towards Hemingway-style minimalism. You remove all the adjectives. I don't believe in that. I believe in Nabokov's way. You pile them up until the object is formed completely."

By now, Hemon was sitting at his favourite local Italian joint and audibly warming to the theme. His second beef was that he initially found very little US or British writing that is about anything. If I'm a good writer, it's because I'm a good reader. I was reading and there was nothing there," he says. "I don't expect them to write about war, but it was so unambitious, as if it was their hobby, as if they didn't need to write stories. I felt I needed to write stories and I couldn't."

Now he can, and has, and is, for the time being, happy with what he's produced. "I wrote this book the way I wanted it," he said at one point during an afternoon-long conversation in Chicago. Hemon believes he is a better writer now in English than he ever was in Bosnian, because of what he has experienced in between: the destruction of his country and life in exile. He checked himself, and pointed out that his problems as a refugee had never been comparable to those who endured Sarajevo's bloody siege, in which 10,000 are thought to have been killed. He is, after all, happily married to an American writer and journalist, and "comfortable" with his mixed identity. "One thing I don't want to do," he declares with a sudden surge of feeling, "is to claim I am the voice of Bosnian suffering."

Yet everything Hemon writes is unmistakably flavoured by Bosnia in all its modern ages - from the assassination of Archduke Ferdinand through the long years of Tito's rule to a golden period of a few brief years between the extinction of communism and the explosion of rabid nationalism, when Sarajevo flowered as an exciting and magnetic cultural centre. The number of Hemon's contemporaries to have settled around the world as successful writers, artists and film-makers is phenomenal. To be creative as a generation, Hemon argued, "you have to have a sense that the old order is not valid any more. I had a sense that the previous generations used it up, used their chance up."

During his spell as cultural editor on Dani, he refused to allow anyone older than 27 to write for the magazine, despite the pleas of his friend and editor, Senad Pecanin. For Pecanin, too, those years - the late 80s, 1990 and 1991 - were a golden era. "Sasha belongs to a good generation of poets, film-makers, and writers right before the war," he said. "At the time, we couldn't imagine a war. Who could attack us, we thought. How stupid."

Many of those who spent much of 1991 partying are still astonished at their own disregard for the menace looming over Bosnia. Hemon explains it this way: "There is a psychological mechanism in human beings which doesn't allow them to imagine their own demise. But the imagination of evil people exceeds the imagination of good people."

The sense of history lurking beneath the present is a key element of the central European experience. It is this history that has condemned the Hemon family to be perpetual outsiders since they arrived in Bosnia from Ukraine. For Sasha, in his story Exchange Of Pleasant Words, the family's rootlessness weighs like a punishment for some past transgression: "Perhaps this is the punishment: we have to live these half-lives of people who cannot forget what they used to be and who are afraid of being addressed in a foreign language, no longer able to utter anything truly meaningful."

It is, Hemon argues, immigrants and outsiders, with their blurred affiliations, who are positioned to write the best prose, because they are one step removed from both a society's language and its everyday reality. It is something he did not fully appreciate when he was Professor Koljevic's favourite student. But Koljevic, while helping to turn a million Bosnians into refugees, also gave Hemon a unique outsider's perspective, and taught him that history counts.

"Before, I didn't see any difference between history and fiction. It was a typical nihilist point of view," he said. "What I later realised was that history came and bumped me on the head, but I should have paid attention all along."

To be creative as a generation, Hemon argued, "you have to have a sense that the old order is not valid any more. I had a sense that the previous generations used it up, used their chance up." During his spell as cultural editor on Dani, he refused to allow anyone older than 27 to write for the magazine, despite the pleas of his friend and editor, Senad Pecanin. For Pecanin, too, those years - the late 80s, 1990 and 1991 - were a golden era. "Sasha belongs to a good generation of poets, film-makers, and writers right before the war," he said. "At the time, we couldn't imagine a war. Who could attack us, we thought. How stupid." Many of those who spent much of 1991 partying are still astonished at their own disregard for the menace looming over Bosnia. Hemon explains it this way: "There is a psychological mechanism in human beings which doesn't allow them to imagine their own demise. But the imagination of evil people exceeds the imagination of good people." The sense of history lurking beneath the present is a key element of the central European experience. It is this history that has condemned the Hemon family to be perpetual outsiders since they arrived in Bosnia from Ukraine. For Sasha, in his story Exchange Of Pleasant Words, the family's rootlessness weighs like a punishment for some past transgression: "Perhaps this is the punishment: we have to live these half-lives of people who cannot forget what they used to be and who are afraid of being addressed in a foreign language, no longer able to utter anything truly meaningful." It is, Hemon argues, immigrants and outsiders, with their blurred affiliations, who are positioned to write the best prose, because they are one step removed from both a society's language and its everyday reality. It is something he did not fully appreciate when he was Professor Koljevic's favourite student. But Koljevic, while helping to turn a million Bosnians into refugees, also gave Hemon a unique outsider's perspective, and taught him that history counts. "Before, I didn't see any difference between history and fiction. It was a typical nihilist point of view," he said. "What I later realised was that history came and bumped me on the head, but I should have paid attention all along."  The Question Of Bruno, by Aleksandar Hemon, is published by Picador on April 21 at £12.99. To order a copy at the special price of £9.99, plus 99p UK p&p, freephone CultureShop on 0800 3166102, or send a cheque to CultureShop, 250 Western Avenue, London W3 6EE. Hemon will be in conversation with Guardian columnist Gary Younge at Waterstone's, 203 Piccadilly, London WC1 at 7pm on April 19; 020-7851 2400 for details.

webTitle: Last chapter for a Scottish bookselling institution

fields.headline: Last chapter for a Scottish bookselling institution
fields.standfirst:
Burns's imprimatur not enough to fend off hi-tech competition
Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: It may have been a favoured haunt of Robert Burns, but even the praise of Scotland's national bard has not been enough to save the world's oldest bookseller from the competitive ravages of multi-national superstores and internet booksellers.
fields.body:
It may have been a favoured haunt of Robert Burns, but even the praise of Scotland's national bard has not been enough to save the world's oldest bookseller from the competitive ravages of multi-national superstores and internet booksellers.

Within a whisker of its 250th anniversary, John Smith & Son will permanently close the doors on its two bookstores in Glasgow.

The decision to shut up shop and restrict itself to the academic niche market represented by its campus outlets has been greeted with dismay in the book world.

"It is a travesty, something that will pain the heart of every bookseller in Britain," said Martin Grindley, president of the Booksellers' Association. "It is becoming impossible for the independent retailer to compete in cities against the big boys, and against their bland McDonald's-isation of bookselling," he added.

Willie Anderson, the store's managing director and only the eighth person to take that title since John Smith & Son began trading in 1751, described it as the most painful decision he has ever made.

But, although British book-buying is on the increase, the shop can no longer compete against the Borders and Waterstone's chains or the increasing pressure of online shopping.

"The big stores have deep pockets and they receive favourable deals from publishers, but you can also buy books from supermarkets, garden centres, the internet. There may be a future for independents in small towns, but in the cities we have lost the battle," said Mr Anderson.

With the end of John Smith & Son's trading dies a unique piece of literary history. Burns was a customer and after a visit in 1788 he wrote to John Smith in praise of the store. "You seem a very decent sort of folk, you Glasgow booksellers. But eh! They're sair birkies in Edinburgh," wrote Burns.

John Buchan is reputed to have written part of one of his lesser novels in the company's St Vincent Street store, and the best of modern Scottish authors have regularly shopped or read there.

Since it was founded in 1751 by the youngest son of the laird of Craigend to sell books - with the accompaniment of a little snuff and coffee - to Glasgow's tobacco lords, John Smith & Son has become the world's longest continuously trading bookseller. The Cambridge University Press is older, but it has changed hands and closed down on occasion.

Yet longevity was not enough to save it. With the collapse of the net book agreement in 1996, booksellers were free to sell at any price they wished. Although this led to cheap popular books in supermarkets and via the internet, independent stores could not discount so heavily.

As independents like John Smith & Son go to the wall, insiders warn that prices will rise and choice diminish. But Philip Downer, managing director of Borders, dismisses this suggestion.

"Our stores offer an enormous range and good value and they will continue to do so," he said.

Yet even in the remotest corners of Britain, booksellers feel a degree of trepidation at John Smith & Son's closure. In Ullapool, in what she describes as "the wee-est bookshop in the world", Jean Urquhart says the internet and the chains are affecting business.

"After the internet, the next big fear is that bookshops simply become a row of computers where people go in to download their books and print them off," she said. "But these things can't offer the personal choice a place like this can. I think that's what will save us in the end."

fields.headline: Respite
fields.trailText:
Rain in the beech trees at 4 a.m.:

I ran away from your voice to
sit in an upright chair...
fields.body:
Rain in the beech trees at 4 a.m.:
I ran away from your voice to
sit in an upright chair. Useless
in your despair, I had no
strength to scoop you
out of your long story,
let alone think of rescue.

Somewhere, the elfin child
of your tinted sepia photo
was still bravely smiling,
with a nail of ice in his heart.
And how can we be reconciled
to that, or hope to unfreeze
what has been so long frozen?

Then you struggled, on sticks,
to my side. You kissed my fingers,
and face, begging me back into bed,
calling me good and kind.
And generous words of love
flowed on all night long, as if
they healed your flashing mind.
fields.bodyText: Rain in the beech trees at 4 a.m.: I ran away from your voice to sit in an upright chair. Useless in your despair, I had no strength to scoop you out of your long story, let alone think of rescue. Somewhere, the elfin child of your tinted sepia photo was still bravely smiling, with a nail of ice in his heart. And how can we be reconciled to that, or hope to unfreeze what has been so long frozen? Then you struggled, on sticks, to my side. You kissed my fingers, and face, begging me back into bed, calling me good and kind. And generous words of love flowed on all night long, as if they healed your flashing mind.

fields.headline: The impersonation of Emily
fields.standfirst: Emily Dickinson. But something wasn't quite right. And so began a labyrinthine investigation of secretive deals and mysterious middlemen. Could the poem really be a forgery - the work of a double murderer?
fields.trailText: Part two of Simon Worrall's investigation into Mark Hofmann
fields.body:
Lombardo could have kept quiet about what he had found out: by proving the poem was a forgery, he would be proving that his finest hour had been his greatest blunder. But, instead, he became even more determined to find out the truth. His doubts about the poem reached critical mass when he tracked down one of the key books about the Hofmann case, Victims, by Richard Turley. In an appendix to the book was a list. "I read how investigators had found a piece of paper in Hofmann's cell," recalls Lombardo. "On one side, he listed all the Mormon documents he had forged. On the other, he listed the literary and historical figures." Emily Dickinson was the sixth name on the list. "It was the first really dark moment in all of this," Lombardo recalls. "It entered my mind that, if this really was a forgery, I did not think I could be part of this town any more. I would not be able to face people knowing that I had caused all this."

But this was no time for self-pity. If he was to convince Sotheby's that the poem was a forgery - and thereby ensure that the library's $21,000 be refunded - he would have to have a watertight case. Again, he turned to Franklin, who had first examined the poem from one perspective - for evidence that it was genuine. Now, at Lombardo's request, he began to study it for flaws. "I kept looking and looking for something that would show a forger's hand," he says. "And I finally came up with a few anomalies." One detail Franklin focused on was the capital "E" in "Everyone". Forgers often give themselves away by lifting the pen or pencil as they laboriously try to copy a sample of handwriting: and Franklin felt that it showed signs of hesitation. "It has an awkwardness that is not typical of her," he explained. "But who is to say that Emily couldn't have burped at that moment?"

By now, Lombardo and Franklin were conferring almost daily and, gradually, these two very different men - an anti-establishment liberal from Amherst and a patrician academic from Yale - were becoming firm friends. Franklin offered to call Sotheby's. As the director of the Beinecke, he is an important Sotheby's customer. "I called David Redden, a man I have known for years," Franklin said. "What I was trying to press him on was the provenance - whether the Gallery of History had consigned this document to Sotheby's."

Redden, a member of Sotheby's board of directors and worldwide head of books, manuscripts and collectables, insisted that the poem had not come from the Gallery of History. Franklin was not convinced. If everything Lombardo had been told was true, then the manuscript had, in less than three years, gone from an estate in California to the Gallery of History, to a collector in the Midwest, to a dealer there who had died, and then to Sotheby's. "Things just don't move that fast in the book trade," says Franklin.

The next day, Lombardo called Marsha Malinowski again, to say that, given the suspicions surrounding the poem, Sotheby's now had a responsibility to prove its authenticity. There was, she replied, "absolutely no question" of the poem's authenticity. She insisted that several experts had studied the poem, among them, one of the world's leading experts on forgery: Kenneth Rendell, the man who exposed the fake Hitler Diaries, and who had also been the key specialist witness at Hofmann's trial. Selby Kiffer confirmed that 10 to 15 manuscript experts had seen the poem, adding that a woman named Jennifer Larson had been consulted about two questionable documents in the previous, May 1997 auction, but that she had not raised any concerns about the Dickinson manuscript.

Larson is a respected rare books dealer and former chairperson of the Ethics Committee of the Antiquarian Booksellers' Association of America. Since the mid-80s, she has also been on a personal crusade, cataloguing Hofmann's non-Mormon forgeries in an attempt to prevent them from contaminating the trade she loves. She had indeed been asked by Sotheby's about two other possible Hofmann forgeries, but not about the Dickinson poem. If she had been, she would have faxed them the documentation she now forwarded to Lombardo. One was an illustration from a book by Todd Axelrod, owner of the Gallery of History, showing an "unknown" Dickinson poem, which Lombardo could see was the poem he had bought from Sotheby's. Another was a copy of a letter Hofmann had written to his lawyer from jail in October 1986. In it, he stated, "The E Dickinson item referred to is a forgery."

The final piece of the puzzle fell into place when Lombardo reached a man called Shannon Flynn at a gun-shop in Salt Lake City. Flynn had negotiated many of Hofmann's business deals, and acted as his courier. He is also a crack marksman and firearms expert. When Hofmann was arrested, the police found a cache of weapons at Flynn's apartment but, after 12 hours of questioning, he was cleared of all suspicion, and has since co-operated fully with police. He confirmed to Lombardo that, in 1985, on Hofmann's behalf, he had flown to Las Vegas with an Emily Dickinson poem that he had sold to Axelrod.

Lombardo notified Sotheby's that in 48 hours he would be issuing a press release stating that the poem was a forgery, and that he would like the auction house's assurance in writing that the Jones Library would receive a full refund. Sotheby's immediately complied. "There was no apology. No embarrassment," recalls Lombardo. "As if this was just a little blip in its daily business. Just routine."

It was a telling perception. Sotheby's and the other auction houses are allowed to operate under terms tolerated in no other branch of commercial life. The small print in their catalogues does include a guarantee of authenticity (albeit one limited to only five years ), but if anything proves to be "wrong", they can say, as they routinely do, that they are merely the agents for the sale and, therefore, not directly responsible. The onus is on you, the purchaser, to satisfy yourself that the article you buy is genuine. Caveat emptor.

Although Sotheby's refunded the Jones Library's money, many questions remained. I knew, from Flynn, that the poem had come from Hofmann and been sold to Axelrod. I knew from Brent Ashworth that Axelrod had displayed it in his gallery. And I knew from Ralph Franklin that, in 1994, two-and-a-half years before it turned up at Sotheby's, Axelrod's archivist had contacted him to have it authenticated. But I did not know the crucial, middle part of the story: how the poem had got from the Gallery of History in Las Vegas to Sotheby's in Manhattan. And I never thought I would. But then occurred an event of such improbable coincidence that if I had seen it in a movie, I wouldn't have believed it.

I had flown to Las Vegas to find out what I could about the Gallery of History. By chance, Flynn was going to be there at the same time, so we arranged to meet. A round-faced leprechaun of a man, he cracked jokes and called me buckaroo. I liked him immediately. At the same time, I felt a tinge of nervousness. "Any guns back there, Shannon?" I asked, pointing at the jumble of boxes in the back of his van, as we stopped at a traffic light on our way to find Axelrod. Flynn pulled a blue case from under the seat and opened it. Inside was a 9mm Glock and a clip of bullets. "An armed society is a polite society," he said, with a grin, ramming the clip home.

In the basement of the two-storey, concrete building in which the Gallery of History was housed was a restaurant with poker machines set into the bar top. Upstairs, I was approached by a salesman with grey skin and a toupée. Did they have any autographs of famous poets? I enquired. Tennyson? Whitman? Perhaps an Emily Dickinson?

The salesman went to consult the inventory. While he was gone, Axelrod walked out of an office at the back of the showroom. He was even bigger than his photos suggested: big, like a Sumo wrestler. A cinnamon-coloured poodle trotted at his heels. Moments later, two men walked into the showroom carrying a white, oblong package. One was a courier. The other, I guessed, was a driver.

"I have the Sotheby's package," I heard the courier say. Pretending I needed a smoke, I hurried downstairs to the front door. A few minutes later, the two men followed.

"I couldn't help hearing the word Sotheby's," I asked one of them nonchalantly. "Anything exciting?"

"Oh, just a few documents," the courier said. "A Daniel Boone and some other stuff."

Sotheby's, I knew, had withdrawn another Hofmann forgery, a Boone autograph, from the sale prior to the one at which the Dickinson poem was auctioned. Was that what was in the box?

"What's the name of your company?" I asked. "I often need a good art shipper."

The courier pulled back his jacket front to reveal the logo on his shirt. It was a Brooklyn company. I asked for the telephone number. He held up the top of the invoice.

"Was that 9770 or 9970?" I queried.

The courier let the invoice fall open. The driver scowled, and tried to cover it with his hand. Then the two men left the building, crossed the parking lot and climbed into a silver-coloured stretch limo. Three items from the top of the invoice, I had seen the words "Emily Dickinson poem".

Back in the showroom, I thought for a moment Axelrod would throw me out. When I told him that Flynn was outside, he swelled up like an angry bull-frog.

When I returned the next day, he was more composed, and he was not alone. On a sofa sat his wife, Pamela; on her left was Axelrod's legal counsel, and next to me sat a PR consultant in cowboy boots. Axelrod countered almost all of my questions with amnesia. He could not recall what Flynn had told him about the poem's provenance. He could not recall whether the poem had been printed in his book. He could not recall whether it had been displayed in his store during the 80s. He was also careful to maintain a firewall between himself and any direct responsibility for the poem. It was always "Tammy" or "our archivist" who gave opinions or wrote reports. When I asked to speak to Tammy , Axelrod told me that she was, unfortunately, no longer with the company. What happened?

"She is dead," said Axelrod. He paused, looked at his wife, then continued uncertainly. "She . . . ugh . . . she left our organisation. To join a hotel. And then I believe she fell down in the bathtub."

"In the bathroom," Pamela Axelrod corrected, staring into her lap. "It was very sad."

Axelrod did not want to share with me the contents of the Dickinson "narrative" - a short history of a document that the Gallery of History would have provided for Sotheby's. He used the same excuse that Gareth Williams had used to Lombardo six months earlier: that the computers were down.

He did answer my most important question, however. How had the Dickinson poem got from the Gallery of History in Las Vegas to Sotheby's in Manhattan? It had, indeed, been consigned by a dead man, and he was the fifth corpse to have floated to the surface of this fetid pond. This dead man was real. His name was James E Halden, and he was a multi-millionaire from Glenbrook, Nevada. His wife, Ethelmae Stuart, is a jelly and jam heiress. With 49% of the shares, Halden was also the largest investor in the Gallery of History Inc. After his death in 1995, the trust established to administer his estate, the Ethelmae Stuart-James E Halden Trust, sensing that the wind had gone out of Axelrod's sails, decided to bail out of the company. As part of the liquidation of their investment, the trust received from Axelrod more than $2 million-worth of historical documents.

I had always wondered why Sotheby's would take any risk at all for a 25% commission on a risible $21,000 (the sale price of the Dickinson manuscript), but on a consignment worth $2 million, the commission would be $500,000. The rare books and manuscripts department is the poor cousin within the Sotheby's family - the big money is in fine art and jewellery - and is under tremendous pressure to perform. And complete inventories are particularly sought-after because they involve less work and expense to sell than individual documents.

Significantly, the catalogues for the May and June 1997 auctions made no mention of the trust. They dropped names such as the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Ryerson Library at the Art Institute of Chicago, and the Estate of William Randolph Hearst. "The way the deal evolved," Axelrod explained, "was that copies of the documents we had given to our client [the Stuart-Halden trust] were forwarded to Sotheby's. Sotheby's carried out an analysis of their estimated value. The client was then furnished with their estimates, and we negotiated our transaction."

When it was time to close the deal in October 1996, Justin Caldwell (yet another Sotheby's vice-president in the rare books and manuscripts department) flew to Las Vegas to inspect and take possession of the consignment. Axelrod provided Caldwell with an office at the Gallery of History, where he checked each document against an inventory approved by his department. Axelrod could not recall the exact number of documents in the consignment - he estimated it at between 500 and 600 - but he did recall, with considerable pique, how suspiciously the Sotheby's representative had treated him.

Sotheby's claim to be the unwitting victim of Hofmann's crime. In a three-page statement that Kiffer faxed me in February 1998, he said that he had taken Ashworth and Larson's warnings seriously and had subsequently read up on Hofmann in two books. What Kiffer discovered in these books, for apparently the first time, was "Hofmann's incredible and continuing deceptiveness". His account of the authentication of the Dickinson poem is that it was studied closely at Sotheby's exhibition by several prominent Dickinson scholars, and that none of them questioned its authenticity. Kiffer does not name these "scholars", but as Ralph Franklin is the only person Sotheby's mentioned to Lombardo, we can assume Kiffer means, among others, him.

Franklin did travel down to New York to look at the poem four days before the auction. And while he was studying it, a Sotheby's employee engaged him in conversation. "It was mostly small-talk," recalls Franklin, "but I suppose that they could have interpreted from that conversation that I thought the poem was genuine."

Kiffer's statement lists four "inconsistencies in the handwriting and dating of the poem" that Franklin is supposed to have detected. As a result of these inconsistencies, Kiffer implies, Sotheby's declared the poem a forgery. He asserts that Brent Ashworth had not told him that this poem was a forgery nor that it had been offered to him by Hofmann. He concludes: "Perhaps Ashworth intended to warn me; but, to my mind, this was simply an interesting but tangential anecdote from someone who had many dealings with Hofmann."

The question remains: why did Sotheby's proceed with the sale? The answer to that lies in the escalating competition between auction houses, both real and virtual, for the burgeoning market in collectables, today worth an estimated $30 billion annually. America, awash in money from the longest bull-run in history, has gone auction mad. Where there was once a handful of auction houses, there are now dozens. The biggest growth is on the internet. With the success of eBay, America's first and biggest on-line auction house, there has been a proliferation of virtual sale-rooms. Sotheby's has teamed up with Amazon.com to hold online auctions. In all, there are 150,000 online auction sites where, for as little as $1, punters can bid on anything from original artwork to a baseball signed by Babe Ruth.

The sky-rocketing prices of collectables in general have driven up the price of historical documents and autographs. "A George Washington letter that used to sell for $500 can now fetch $500,000," says Charles Sachs, owner of The Scriptorium, a well-established dealer in Beverly Hills, California. "What has happened is that people have drifted in from the art world, where they were used to paying that kind of money." Billy Crystal is a collector, so is Barbra Streisand. "Hollywood people have started to buy extensively for gifts," says Sachs. "Lincoln letters for their lawyers, Freud for their psychiatrists."

And with the demand for manuscripts have come the forgeries. "I probably came across one forgery per week," recalls Roy Davids, the head of the Books and Manuscript Department at Sotheby's, in London, from 1970-1994. "But we had very few things returned. In fact, I can remember only one case: a letter by the painter, Raphael. It's one's first duty: to make sure that something is right. And when I was at Sotheby's, it was a fairly rare occurrence that forgeries went undetected. My impression is that the system is not as water-tight as it used to be."

"Forgery is rife at the moment," says Ian Sayer, a leading British collector of second world war memorabilia, "particularly in the sports and celebrity area. And the internet has only made the situation worse. I estimate that 60-70% of the stuff being traded on the internet is forged. It's becoming a plague."

In parallel, as prices sky-rocket, buyers are becoming increasingly less concerned with whether something is genuine. "There is an incredible desire on the part of people to believe that something they have purchased is real," says Jennifer Larson. Hofmann knew this. His forgeries told the stories that people wanted to hear. "It mattered to us so much that we had found a new poem", recalls Susan Juhasz, a Dickinson scholar from Colorado who contributed money to buy the poem. "It was very heady. Very exciting."

Lombardo makes no bones about how deeply Sotheby's sale of a forgery by a convicted double-murderer has affected him. At first, when the story of his sleuthing became known in Amherst, he was treated as a hero - a small New England community had shown Madison Avenue that they were no hicks. Within a year, disillusioned by his experiences with Sotheby's, he had given up his job.

As for Mark Hofmann - little remains of the plump, rosy-cheeked bookseller who was once a Mormon missionary. He is lean and mean, his right arm atrophied as a result of a suicide attempt, his skin blotched and scarred from the bomb blast. His wife divorced him some years ago. Hofmann writes the chess pages for the prison newspaper. He has an IQ of 138, and is a member of Mensa. His only visitor is his ageing mother. He will almost certainly die in jail. His forgeries continue to plague the historical documents trade. Jennifer Larson estimates that there are 50-100 literary forgeries currently on the market, including writings by Mark Twain, Jack London, John Quincy Adams and George Washington.

In a letter he wrote to Lombardo from jail, Hofmann gives an account of the genesis of the poem. "I picked Dickinson because her autograph material is among the most valuable of American poets. And it was a challenge. My critique of Dickinson's poems is that a few of them are great, some are good, but many are inferior (some so much so I think she would have considered them drafts). My attempt was nowhere near her best, but is, I think, better than some. . . Just before composing the poem I attempted to read enough of her material until I felt in touch with her muse. I may have made three or four working drafts. The only thing I remember about the composition is whether I should use the words 'summer's grass' or 'winter's sun'. I thought the words 'Aunt Emily' added a touch of veracity." Hofmann had thought that when he was exposed as a forger in 1985, it became common knowledge that the poem was a forgery.

When I called Axelrod to confirm that he still had the poem, he was by turns vague, and aggressive. "I don't know if it was returned," he said. When I told him that I had seen it delivered from Sotheby's with my own eyes, he said: "Well, I guess it's in our bogus files. When we find forgeries, we don't just throw them in the garbage."
