Again, he turned to Franklin, who had first examined the poem from one perspective - for evidence that it was genuine. Now, at Lombardo's request, he began to study it for flaws. "I kept looking and looking for something that would show a forger's hand," he says. "And I finally came up with a few anomalies." One detail Franklin focused on was the capital "E" in "Everyone". Forgers often give themselves away by lifting the pen or pencil as they laboriously try to copy a sample of handwriting: and Franklin felt that it showed signs of hesitation. "It has an awkwardness that is not typical of her," he explained. "But who is to say that Emily couldn't have burped at that moment?" By now, Lombardo and Franklin were conferring almost daily and, gradually, these two very different men - an anti-establishment liberal from Amherst and a patrician academic from Yale - were becoming firm friends. Franklin offered to call Sotheby's. As the director of the Beinecke, he is an important Sotheby's customer. "I called David Redden, a man I have known for years," Franklin said. "What I was trying to press him on was the provenance - whether the Gallery of History had consigned this document to Sotheby's." Redden, a member of Sotheby's board of directors and worldwide head of books, manuscripts and collectables, insisted that the poem had not come from the Gallery of History. Franklin was not convinced. If everything Lombardo had been told was true, then the manuscript had, in less than three years, gone from an estate in California to the Gallery of History, to a collector in the Midwest, to a dealer there who had died, and then to Sotheby's. "Things just don't move that fast in the book trade," says Franklin. The next day, Lombardo called Marsha Malinowski again, to say that, given the suspicions surrounding the poem, Sotheby's now had a responsibility to prove its authenticity. There was, she replied, "absolutely no question" of the poem's authenticity. She insisted that several experts had studied the poem, among them, one of the world's leading experts on forgery: Kenneth Rendell, the man who exposed the fake Hitler Diaries, and who had also been the key specialist witness at Hofmann's trial. Selby Kiffer confirmed that 10 to 15 manuscript experts had seen the poem, adding that a woman named Jennifer Larson had been consulted about two questionable documents in the previous, May 1997 auction, but that she had not raised any concerns about the Dickinson manuscript. Larson is a respected rare books dealer and former chairperson of the Ethics Committee of the Antiquarian Booksellers' Association of America. Since the mid-80s, she has also been on a personal crusade, cataloguing Hofmann's non-Mormon forgeries in an attempt to prevent them from contaminating the trade she loves. She had indeed been asked by Sotheby's about two other possible Hofmann forgeries, but not about the Dickinson poem. If she had been, she would have faxed them the documentation she now forwarded to Lombardo. One was an illustration from a book by Todd Axelrod, owner of the Gallery of History, showing an "unknown" Dickinson poem, which Lombardo could see was the poem he had bought from Sotheby's. Another was a copy of a letter Hofmann had written to his lawyer from jail in October 1986. In it, he stated, "The E Dickinson item referred to is a forgery." The final piece of the puzzle fell into place when Lombardo reached a man called Shannon Flynn at a gun-shop in Salt Lake City. Flynn had negotiated many of Hofmann's business deals, and acted as his courier. He is also a crack marksman and firearms expert. When Hofmann was arrested, the police found a cache of weapons at Flynn's apartment but, after 12 hours of questioning, he was cleared of all suspicion, and has since co-operated fully with police. He confirmed to Lombardo that, in 1985, on Hofmann's behalf, he had flown to Las Vegas with an Emily Dickinson poem that he had sold to Axelrod. Lombardo notified Sotheby's that in 48 hours he would be issuing a press release stating that the poem was a forgery, and that he would like the auction house's assurance in writing that the Jones Library would receive a full refund. Sotheby's immediately complied. "There was no apology. No embarrassment," recalls Lombardo. "As if this was just a little blip in its daily business. Just routine." It was a telling perception. Sotheby's and the other auction houses are allowed to operate under terms tolerated in no other branch of commercial life. The small print in their catalogues does include a guarantee of authenticity (albeit one limited to only five years ), but if anything proves to be "wrong", they can say, as they routinely do, that they are merely the agents for the sale and, therefore, not directly responsible. The onus is on you, the purchaser, to satisfy yourself that the article you buy is genuine. Caveat emptor. Although Sotheby's refunded the Jones Library's money, many questions remained. I knew, from Flynn, that the poem had come from Hofmann and been sold to Axelrod. I knew from Brent Ashworth that Axelrod had displayed it in his gallery. And I knew from Ralph Franklin that, in 1994, two-and-a-half years before it turned up at Sotheby's, Axelrod's archivist had contacted him to have it authenticated. But I did not know the crucial, middle part of the story: how the poem had got from the Gallery of History in Las Vegas to Sotheby's in Manhattan. And I never thought I would. But then occurred an event of such improbable coincidence that if I had seen it in a movie, I wouldn't have believed it. I had flown to Las Vegas to find out what I could about the Gallery of History. By chance, Flynn was going to be there at the same time, so we arranged to meet. A round-faced leprechaun of a man, he cracked jokes and called me buckaroo. I liked him immediately. At the same time, I felt a tinge of nervousness. "Any guns back there, Shannon?" I asked, pointing at the jumble of boxes in the back of his van, as we stopped at a traffic light on our way to find Axelrod. Flynn pulled a blue case from under the seat and opened it. Inside was a 9mm Glock and a clip of bullets. "An armed society is a polite society," he said, with a grin, ramming the clip home. In the basement of the two-storey, concrete building in which the Gallery of History was housed was a restaurant with poker machines set into the bar top. Upstairs, I was approached by a salesman with grey skin and a toupée. Did they have any autographs of famous poets? I enquired. Tennyson? Whitman? Perhaps an Emily Dickinson? The salesman went to consult the inventory. While he was gone, Axelrod walked out of an office at the back of the showroom. He was even bigger than his photos suggested: big, like a Sumo wrestler. A cinnamon-coloured poodle trotted at his heels. Moments later, two men walked into the showroom carrying a white, oblong package. One was a courier. The other, I guessed, was a driver. "I have the Sotheby's package," I heard the courier say. Pretending I needed a smoke, I hurried downstairs to the front door. A few minutes later, the two men followed. "I couldn't help hearing the word Sotheby's," I asked one of them nonchalantly. "Anything exciting?" "Oh, just a few documents," the courier said. "A Daniel Boone and some other stuff." Sotheby's, I knew, had withdrawn another Hofmann forgery, a Boone autograph, from the sale prior to the one at which the Dickinson poem was auctioned. Was that what was in the box? "What's the name of your company?" I asked. "I often need a good art shipper." The courier pulled back his jacket front to reveal the logo on his shirt. It was a Brooklyn company. I asked for the telephone number. He held up the top of the invoice. "Was that 9770 or 9970?" I queried. The courier let the invoice fall open. The driver scowled, and tried to cover it with his hand. Then the two men left the building, crossed the parking lot and climbed into a silver-coloured stretch limo. Three items from the top of the invoice, I had seen the words "Emily Dickinson poem". Back in the showroom, I thought for a moment Axelrod would throw me out. When I told him that Flynn was outside, he swelled up like an angry bull-frog. When I returned the next day, he was more composed, and he was not alone. On a sofa sat his wife, Pamela; on her left was Axelrod's legal counsel, and next to me sat a PR consultant in cowboy boots. Axelrod countered almost all of my questions with amnesia. He could not recall what Flynn had told him about the poem's provenance. He could not recall whether the poem had been printed in his book. He could not recall whether it had been displayed in his store during the 80s. He was also careful to maintain a firewall between himself and any direct responsibility for the poem. It was always "Tammy" or "our archivist" who gave opinions or wrote reports. When I asked to speak to Tammy , Axelrod told me that she was, unfortunately, no longer with the company. What happened? "She is dead," said Axelrod. He paused, looked at his wife, then continued uncertainly. "She . . . ugh . . . she left our organisation. To join a hotel. And then I believe she fell down in the bathtub." "In the bathroom," Pamela Axelrod corrected, staring into her lap. "It was very sad." Axelrod did not want to share with me the contents of the Dickinson "narrative" - a short history of a document that the Gallery of History would have provided for Sotheby's. He used the same excuse that Gareth Williams had used to Lombardo six months earlier: that the computers were down. He did answer my most important question, however. How had the Dickinson poem got from the Gallery of History in Las Vegas to Sotheby's in Manhattan? It had, indeed, been consigned by a dead man, and he was the fifth corpse to have floated to the surface of this fetid pond. This dead man was real. His name was James E Halden, and he was a multi-millionaire from Glenbrook, Nevada. His wife, Ethelmae Stuart, is a jelly and jam heiress. With 49% of the shares, Halden was also the largest investor in the Gallery of History Inc. After his death in 1995, the trust established to administer his estate, the Ethelmae Stuart-James E Halden Trust, sensing that the wind had gone out of Axelrod's sails, decided to bail out of the company. As part of the liquidation of their investment, the trust received from Axelrod more than $2 million-worth of historical documents. I had always wondered why Sotheby's would take any risk at all for a 25% commission on a risible $21,000 (the sale price of the Dickinson manuscript), but on a consignment worth $2 million, the commission would be $500,000. The rare books and manuscripts department is the poor cousin within the Sotheby's family - the big money is in fine art and jewellery - and is under tremendous pressure to perform. And complete inventories are particularly sought-after because they involve less work and expense to sell than individual documents. Significantly, the catalogues for the May and June 1997 auctions made no mention of the trust. They dropped names such as the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Ryerson Library at the Art Institute of Chicago, and the Estate of William Randolph Hearst. "The way the deal evolved," Axelrod explained, "was that copies of the documents we had given to our client [the Stuart-Halden trust] were forwarded to Sotheby's. Sotheby's carried out an analysis of their estimated value. The client was then furnished with their estimates, and we negotiated our transaction." When it was time to close the deal in October 1996, Justin Caldwell (yet another Sotheby's vice-president in the rare books and manuscripts department) flew to Las Vegas to inspect and take possession of the consignment. Axelrod provided Caldwell with an office at the Gallery of History, where he checked each document against an inventory approved by his department. Axelrod could not recall the exact number of documents in the consignment - he estimated it at between 500 and 600 - but he did recall, with considerable pique, how suspiciously the Sotheby's representative had treated him. Sotheby's claim to be the unwitting victim of Hofmann's crime. In a three-page statement that Kiffer faxed me in February 1998, he said that he had taken Ashworth and Larson's warnings seriously and had subsequently read up on Hofmann in two books. What Kiffer discovered in these books, for apparently the first time, was "Hofmann's incredible and continuing deceptiveness". His account of the authentication of the Dickinson poem is that it was studied closely at Sotheby's exhibition by several prominent Dickinson scholars, and that none of them questioned its authenticity. Kiffer does not name these "scholars", but as Ralph Franklin is the only person Sotheby's mentioned to Lombardo, we can assume Kiffer means, among others, him. Franklin did travel down to New York to look at the poem four days before the auction. And while he was studying it, a Sotheby's employee engaged him in conversation. "It was mostly small-talk," recalls Franklin, "but I suppose that they could have interpreted from that conversation that I thought the poem was genuine." Kiffer's statement lists four "inconsistencies in the handwriting and dating of the poem" that Franklin is supposed to have detected. As a result of these inconsistencies, Kiffer implies, Sotheby's declared the poem a forgery. He asserts that Brent Ashworth had not told him that this poem was a forgery nor that it had been offered to him by Hofmann. He concludes: "Perhaps Ashworth intended to warn me; but, to my mind, this was simply an interesting but tangential anecdote from someone who had many dealings with Hofmann." The question remains: why did Sotheby's proceed with the sale? The answer to that lies in the escalating competition between auction houses, both real and virtual, for the burgeoning market in collectables, today worth an estimated $30 billion annually. America, awash in money from the longest bull-run in history, has gone auction mad. Where there was once a handful of auction houses, there are now dozens. The biggest growth is on the internet. With the success of eBay, America's first and biggest on-line auction house, there has been a proliferation of virtual sale-rooms. Sotheby's has teamed up with Amazon.com to hold online auctions. In all, there are 150,000 online auction sites where, for as little as $1, punters can bid on anything from original artwork to a baseball signed by Babe Ruth. The sky-rocketing prices of collectables in general have driven up the price of historical documents and autographs. "A George Washington letter that used to sell for $500 can now fetch $500,000," says Charles Sachs, owner of The Scriptorium, a well-established dealer in Beverly Hills, California. "What has happened is that people have drifted in from the art world, where they were used to paying that kind of money." Billy Crystal is a collector, so is Barbra Streisand. "Hollywood people have started to buy extensively for gifts," says Sachs. "Lincoln letters for their lawyers, Freud for their psychiatrists." And with the demand for manuscripts have come the forgeries. "I probably came across one forgery per week," recalls Roy Davids, the head of the Books and Manuscript Department at Sotheby's, in London, from 1970-1994. "But we had very few things returned. In fact, I can remember only one case: a letter by the painter, Raphael. It's one's first duty: to make sure that something is right. And when I was at Sotheby's, it was a fairly rare occurrence that forgeries went undetected. My impression is that the system is not as water-tight as it used to be." "Forgery is rife at the moment," says Ian Sayer, a leading British collector of second world war memorabilia, "particularly in the sports and celebrity area. And the internet has only made the situation worse. I estimate that 60-70% of the stuff being traded on the internet is forged. It's becoming a plague." In parallel, as prices sky-rocket, buyers are becoming increasingly less concerned with whether something is genuine. "There is an incredible desire on the part of people to believe that something they have purchased is real," says Jennifer Larson. Hofmann knew this. His forgeries told the stories that people wanted to hear. "It mattered to us so much that we had found a new poem", recalls Susan Juhasz, a Dickinson scholar from Colorado who contributed money to buy the poem. "It was very heady. Very exciting." Lombardo makes no bones about how deeply Sotheby's sale of a forgery by a convicted double-murderer has affected him. At first, when the story of his sleuthing became known in Amherst, he was treated as a hero - a small New England community had shown Madison Avenue that they were no hicks. Within a year, disillusioned by his experiences with Sotheby's, he had given up his job. As for Mark Hofmann - little remains of the plump, rosy-cheeked bookseller who was once a Mormon missionary. He is lean and mean, his right arm atrophied as a result of a suicide attempt, his skin blotched and scarred from the bomb blast. His wife divorced him some years ago. Hofmann writes the chess pages for the prison newspaper. He has an IQ of 138, and is a member of Mensa. His only visitor is his ageing mother. He will almost certainly die in jail. His forgeries continue to plague the historical documents trade. Jennifer Larson estimates that there are 50-100 literary forgeries currently on the market, including writings by Mark Twain, Jack London, John Quincy Adams and George Washington. In a letter he wrote to Lombardo from jail, Hofmann gives an account of the genesis of the poem. "I picked Dickinson because her autograph material is among the most valuable of American poets. And it was a challenge. My critique of Dickinson's poems is that a few of them are great, some are good, but many are inferior (some so much so I think she would have considered them drafts). My attempt was nowhere near her best, but is, I think, better than some. . . Just before composing the poem I attempted to read enough of her material until I felt in touch with her muse. I may have made three or four working drafts. The only thing I remember about the composition is whether I should use the words 'summer's grass' or 'winter's sun'. I thought the words 'Aunt Emily' added a touch of veracity." Hofmann had thought that when he was exposed as a forger in 1985, it became common knowledge that the poem was a forgery. When I called Axelrod to confirm that he still had the poem, he was by turns vague, and aggressive. "I don't know if it was returned," he said. When I told him that I had seen it delivered from Sotheby's with my own eyes, he said: "Well, I guess it's in our bogus files. When we find forgeries, we don't just throw them in the garbage." © Simon Worrall, 2000

fields.headline: The impersonation of Emily
fields.standfirst: It was a thrilling find: an unknown poem in her own hand by one of AMerica's greatest poets, Emily Dickinson. But something wasn't quite right. And so began a labyrinthine investigation of secretive deals and mysterious middlemen. Could the poem really be a forgery - the work of a double murderer?
fields.trailText: It was a thrilling find: an unknown poem in her own hand by one of AMerica's greatest poets, Emily Dickinson. But something wasn't quite right. And so began a labyrinthine investigation of secretive deals and mysterious middlemen. Could the poem really be a forgery - the work of a double murderer?
fields.body:
Prisons are forlorn places at the best of times. But the Utah state correctional facility is a particularly bleak and lonely place. Situated on a drab, windswept plain 20 miles south of Salt Lake City, in the shadow of the Oqhirra Mountains, its squat, 50s concrete buildings look like something from the Gulag. "That's the maximum-security wing," said Shannon Flynn, pointing at a low, grey building below us. "Hofmann was in there at the beginning. But he's in minimum-security now." We had driven across the desert from Las Vegas. In the distance, the setting sun was turning the mountains a bruised, purple-blue. "He told me once that he ranks pretty high on the prison hierarchy," Flynn continued. "Evidently, rapists and child molesters are on the very bottom of the list. But murder rates high."

The man he was describing is no ordinary murderer. Poetry and literature were the accomplices in his crimes; parchment and ink the tools of his trade. His name is Mark Hofmann and, until he was incarcerated, he was America's greatest literary forger: a man who combined obsessive historical research, extraordinary craftsmanship and an unerring instinct for what his customers wanted. Two years ago, one of those forgeries, a masterfully-executed poem by the much-loved American poet Emily Dickinson, who died in 1886, turned up at Sotheby's, New York, where it was sold for $21,000 to the Jones Library, in Dickinson's home town, Amherst, Massachusetts.

"I thought: this is just extraordinary," says Daniel Lombardo, the former curator of special collections at the Jones Library, recalling the moment when he first saw the poem in Sotheby's catalogue for its June 1997 auction of fine books and manuscripts. "A complete poem, not a fragment of a poem. In my recollection, it had been decades since a poem came up this way."

In fact, it was the first new poem by Dickinson to be discovered since 1955, when Thomas H Johnson published his three-volume variorum edition, fixing the Dickinson canon at 1,775 poems. It was like finding a new sonnet by Shakespeare, or a drawing by Turner. It was a sensation. From Puritan New England, Dickinson reaches across the years - a feminist icon who sang from her soul in a jazzy, idiosyncratic voice that chimes with contemporary tastes. In the opinion of the celebrated critic Harold Bloom, she is, with Walt Whitman, America's greatest poet.

The poem was written in pencil, on a piece of blue-lined paper, measuring 8in by 5in and was signed "Emily". On the top left corner was an embossed insignia, and, in red ink, at the top right corner of a blank page attached to the poem, someone had also written the words "Aunt Emily" in an unidentified hand. It read:

That God cannot

be understood

Everyone agrees

We do not know

His motives nor

Comprehend his

Deeds -

Then why should I

Seek solace in

What I cannot

Know?

Better to play

In winter's sun

Than to fear the

Snow

For the people of Amherst, acquiring the poem was a coup. Not only is Emily Dickinson this small university town's most famous daughter, she is, as the Wordsworths are to Grasmere, a minor industry. Cafes offer tins of gingerbread baked to her original recipe. Scholars fill the town's B&Bs. Each year, thousands of Dickinson fans from as far away as Japan and Chile make the pilgrimage to the ivy-covered house on Main Street where this famously reclusive poet lived.

As part of his preparations for an exhibition on the poem's history, Lombardo called Marsha Malinowski, an expert in the department of books and manuscripts in New York, one of the two Sotheby's employees who had handled the sale. The trade in historical documents and manuscripts is as secretive as a Masonic order. Many collectors - such as Bill Gates, who set a world record two years ago when he paid $35 million for a Leonardo da Vinci notebook - are extremely wealthy, and do not wish their identities, or their collecting interests, to be known. "Dealers are not forthcoming about provenance, and the auction houses also don't want to disclose their sources," says Jennifer Larson, an expert on Hofmann's forgeries. "It's like a private club."

Lombardo knew this as well as anyone, but he hoped that, as the poem had been bought by a public institution, Malinowski might be willing to disclose something of the poem's history. He was particularly curious about who had signed the words "Aunt Emily". It was the sort of telling, human detail that can breathe the spark of life into faded parchment. Malinowski said that she would be happy to ask the consignor for permission to waive Sotheby's standard confidentiality agreement and reveal his or her identity. But, a week later, she called back to say that the consignor of the poem had unfortunately not agreed. All she could say was that the poem had come from a collector, who had bought it from a dealer in the Midwest. Who had died.

A few days later, Lombardo received a phone call from a man named Brent Ashworth, in Provo, Utah. Ashworth is an attorney, businessman and prominent member of Mormon society. He has also been a lifelong collector of historical documents, and is a passionate fan of Emily Dickinson. What he had to say sent a shiver down Lombardo's spine. In the early 80s, said Ashworth, a historical documents dealer named Mark Hofmann had offered to sell him an unpublished Dickinson manuscript for $10,000.

"I usually went up [to Hofmann's house] on Wednesdays, on the way to the law-firm that does our stock transactions," recalls Ashworth. "He usually had a little valise or a folder he pulled things out of . . . something juicy he wanted to offer me. And one of those days he pulled out this Emily Dickinson." Ashworth believed that this was the same poem that Lombardo had just bought in Manhattan.

Mark Hofmann was born in Salt Lake City in 1951, the son of a devout Mormon family. As a child, he was bookish, introspective, overweight. His parents hoped that their son would devote his life to God. And, for a time, it seemed as though he would. Hofmann did a stint abroad as a missionary (in Leicester). He sang in the Tabernacle choir. But, unbeknown to his parents and the Mormon community, Hofmann had already begun to live a double life. Since the age of 14, he had been forging, and selling, rare Mormon coins. On his return from England, he enrolled at university in Salt Lake City to study biology and zoology. His mother's anguish over his father's polygamy had aready caused him to question the Mormon faith. Instead of a world view based on the Gospels, Hofmann adopted a grim, nihilistic brand of Darwinism. His favourite TV programmes were nature documentaries showing predatory animals stalking and killing their prey. A semester short of graduation, he dropped out of university to become a rare books dealer. And a full-time forger.

Forging coins had taught him two lessons: that things have no intrinsic value, and that people will believe what they want to believe. The Church of the Latter Day Saints was the perfect victim. Since its beginnings, in 1863, it has been a religion in search of authentication. The hundreds of thousands of dollars-worth of documents that Hofmann sold to the church were faith-promoting documents of the highest order. They included the earliest known Mormon artefact - a letter from the mother of the church's founder, Joseph Smith - and the last: a letter written by Smith from jail just before he was murdered.

Hofmann's real intention, however, was to destroy the faith he despised. Like a virus planted in a computer, he began to feed the Church of Latter Day Saints with documents that called into question some of the fundamental tenets of the faith. His most famous forgery came to be known as The White Salamander Letter. In it, Hofmann portrayed the Mormon church's prophet, Joseph Smith, as a money-grubbing gold prospector who dabbled in black magic. Instead of angelic inspiration, he invented a diabolic, talking lizard. The Mormon Church bought the document for $250,000, and locked it away so that no one would see it.

By then, Hofmann had begun to produce a string of brilliantly-executed literary forgeries. They were nearly always of American icons, charismatic historical figures, who touched a deep chord in the national consciousness, such as Nathan Hale, the young patriot executed by the British in the War of Independence, Abraham Lincoln, Mark Twain, Daniel Boone. Hofmann's favourite stratagem was to exploit lacunae in the historical record, creating a document that was known to have existed but had disappeared.

Hofmann was a brilliant forger, and a brilliant dissembler. He was a happily married family man who spent hundreds of thousands of dollars assembling one of his country's finest collections of rare children's books as a patrimony for his own four children. He was charming, personable and knowledgeable; ruthless, cynical and amoral.

Hofmann's weakness was, ironically, his passion for (genuine) antiquarian books. The more money he made on forgeries, the more he blew on precious books: $6,300 for a first edition of The Lord Of The Rings, $1,500 for a first edition of The Tailor Of Gloucester signed by Beatrix Potter. Meanwhile he was travelling America, living high on the hog.

By October 1985, he was more than a million dollars in debt. To keep his creditors at bay, he began to resort to ever more machiavellian ruses. He offered investors in Salt Lake City part-ownership of documents he was planning to forge, then pocketed the money. And when a Salt Lake City businessman named Steve Christensen grew suspicious of a series of Mormon documents he was about to buy, Hofmann, the forger, mutated into Hofmann, the psychopath.

Christensen was found whimpering like a child in the corridor outside his office in downtown Salt Lake City. The pipe-bomb Hofmann had left for him in a brown-paper bag was as meticulously constructed as his forgeries. Around a length of galvanised pipe, Hofmann had packed hundreds of 1in steel masonry nails that were meant not just to kill but to mutilate. One of them went straight through Christensen's eye and into his brain. He died.

Later that day, another bomb shook the Mormon capital. It was meant for a man called Gary Sheets. Sheets had no connection to the historical documents world, but he was involved with Christensen in a failing savings-and-loans scheme that had left several Utahans bankrupt. The bomb was Hofmann's most elaborate and diabolical ruse so far: a decoy intended to make the police think that the two murders were revenge killings by disgruntled investors. But instead of killing Sheets, the bomb killed his wife.

A few hours later, a third bomb exploded in the back of Hofmann's sports car, which was parked not far from the Mormon Tabernacle. Hofmann was found bleeding on the sidewalk. There was gaping hole in one knee and a gash in his head. Scattered about the street were shreds of both forged and genuine historical documents. Among them was a piece of Egyptian papyrus. In 1986, Hofmann was jailed for life for the two murders.

Salt Lake City police believe that the third bomb was meant for Brent Ashworth. From 1981 to 1985, Ashworth had bought nearly $500,000-worth of documents from Hofmann and traded a further $300,000-worth of his own collection of genuine documents for forgeries. "As I've been burned by a forger," he told me, "I feel like: if the auction houses themselves don't stand up against these forgers, then the field itself is not going to be worth two cents to us collectors that invest a lot of time and money." When he saw the Dickinson poem in the Sotheby's June 1997 catalogue, Ashworth called Selby Kiffer, the other Sotheby's executive who had handled the sale and a man with whom Ashworth had had extensive dealings as a collector. "One of the things I told him [Kiffer] was that I realise that there's no tests for pencil . . . but this thing Hofmann showed me . . . it's a fake," recalls Ashworth. "That's what I told him."

Kiffer's nickname at Sotheby's is Special Agent Kiffer, because he has always been so zealous in reporting stolen books to the FBI, but he did not appear particularly interested in Ashworth's story. "He said that doesn't mean that it was necessarily a fake," says Ashworth. Kiffer also insisted that he'd had the poem checked out. When Ashworth asked by whom, Kiffer mentioned a Yale University professor, Ralph Franklin.

Ironically, Ashworth's information had only further convinced Daniel Lombardo that the Dickinson manuscript was "right". Surely, he reasoned, if Ashworth had told Kiffer about the possible Hofmann connection, Sotheby's must have redoubled its efforts to authenticate the poem. But he had to be sure. So he contacted Franklin, the director of Yale's prestigious Beinecke Library and the world's leading expert on Dickinson's "fascicles" -the improvised books she made by copying her poems on to folded pieces of paper and binding them together.

Using a linen-tester - a small, pocket magnifying glass used by textile merchants to evaluate cloth - Franklin studied the poem seraph by seraph. He measured the paper. He studied the boss-mark. Everything looked right. Dickinson had, for instance, used the kind of paper on which the poem was written - Congress paper, which was manufactured in Boston - only twice in her life. One of those times was 1871, the year the poem had supposedly been composed. The size of the paper was exactly right. Even the folds in the paper conformed to the way Dickinson had folded her poems before placing them in an envelope. But what convinced Franklin more than anything else was the handwriting - Dickinson's handwriting was an organic, living thing that changed radically in the course of her lifetime. In 1871, her handwriting was, literally, coming apart. "Eventually, she would print nearly every letter," explained Franklin as we sat in his office at the Beinecke Library. "At this point, Dickinson's ligatures of vowels and following consonants are fracturing. Things like '-an' or '-em' or '-en'. And what you have here are both versions. You have the word 'cannot' with '-an' linked. And you have 'cannot' with the '-an' open." His speech quickened. "Look at this final 'd'!" he said, pointing to the word "comprehend". "There's a flip at the top of it. She does not make these neatly the same every time. It might lie down a little more, or be more erect. But it's just like her. That's Dickinson's 'd'!"

The biographical evidence was also compelling. In the early 1870s, Dickinson was in her 40s and, though her most prolific period was over, she was still writing about four poems a month. Some of these were just such playful pieces of impromptu verse as this one. "The fact that the poem was ascribed to 'Aunt Emily'," explains Lombardo, "suggested that it had been written for a child - most likely for Ned Dickinson, the poet's nephew, who lived next door to her. In 1871, he would have been 10." Since 1864, Dickinson had also begun to use pencil more often. "Ralph and I both agreed that, if this was a forgery, it would be mind-boggling," recalls Lombardo.

But Hofmann was no ordinary forger. She also posed her own questions. Was the poem unpublished? To whom might it have been sent? Franklin confirmed that it was unpublished, and suggested that it could have been sent to Dickinson's nephew, Ned. In the course of one of their conversations, Kahrs also asked Franklin if the Gallery of History could use his name when they offered the manuscript for sale. Franklin, who never does authentications, rejected the request out of hand.

The real-estate business went sour on him, but by the early 80s he made himself a multi-millionaire trading in securities in New York. He then moved to Las Vegas and began to turn his longtime passion for collecting historical documents into a business empire.

Collecting historical documents used to be the hobby of a few dedicated individuals. There were a few high-profile collectors, such as Malcolm Forbes and Armand Hammer, who steadily amassed collections worth hundreds of millions of dollars. But, generally, it was a low-key, economically insignificant business. But with the spiralling market for collectables of all kinds, the trade in rare manuscripts and autographs has gone through the roof, and is today worth an estimated $100 million per year. "What price can you put on history?" Forbes once quipped.

By the mid-80s, Axelrod had assembled one of the US's largest private collections of historical documents and autographs: 100,000 items preserved, as he liked to boast, to "Library of Congress standards". They wanted to see their money hanging on the wall. So, out of historic documents, Axelrod fashioned sexy "works of art". Each autograph was lavishly framed with an elegant portrait of the historic figure encased in the frame, and a grandiose plaque underneath. fields.bodyText: Prisons are forlorn places at the best of times. But the Utah state correctional facility is a particularly bleak and lonely place. Situated on a drab, windswept plain 20 miles south of Salt Lake City, in the shadow of the Oqhirra Mountains, its squat, 50s concrete buildings look like something from the Gulag. "That's the maximum-security wing," said Shannon Flynn, pointing at a low, grey building below us. "Hofmann was in there at the beginning. But he's in minimum-security now." We had driven across the desert from Las Vegas. In the distance, the setting sun was turning the mountains a bruised, purple-blue. "He told me once that he ranks pretty high on the prison hierarchy," Flynn continued. "Evidently, rapists and child molesters are on the very bottom of the list. But murder rates high." The man he was describing is no ordinary murderer. Poetry and literature were the accomplices in his crimes; parchment and ink the tools of his trade. His name is Mark Hofmann and, until he was incarcerated, he was America's greatest literary forger: a man who combined obsessive historical research, extraordinary craftsmanship and an unerring instinct for what his customers wanted. Two years ago, one of those forgeries, a masterfully-executed poem by the much-loved American poet Emily Dickinson, who died in 1886, turned up at Sotheby's, New York, where it was sold for $21,000 to the Jones Library, in Dickinson's home town, Amherst, Massachusetts. "I thought: this is just extraordinary," says Daniel Lombardo, the former curator of special collections at the Jones Library, recalling the moment when he first saw the poem in Sotheby's catalogue for its June 1997 auction of fine books and manuscripts. "A complete poem, not a fragment of a poem. In my recollection, it had been decades since a poem came up this way." In fact, it was the first new poem by Dickinson to be discovered since 1955, when Thomas H Johnson published his three-volume variorum edition, fixing the Dickinson canon at 1,775 poems. It was like finding a new sonnet by Shakespeare, or a drawing by Turner. It was a sensation. From Puritan New England, Dickinson reaches across the years - a feminist icon who sang from her soul in a jazzy, idiosyncratic voice that chimes with contemporary tastes. In the opinion of the celebrated critic Harold Bloom, she is, with Walt Whitman, America's greatest poet. The poem was written in pencil, on a piece of blue-lined paper, measuring 8in by 5in and was signed "Emily". On the top left corner was an embossed insignia, and, in red ink, at the top right corner of a blank page attached to the poem, someone had also written the words "Aunt Emily" in an unidentified hand. It read: That God cannot be understood Everyone agrees We do not know His motives nor Comprehend his Deeds - Then why should I Seek solace in What I cannot Know? Better to play In winter's sun Than to fear the Snow For the people of Amherst, acquiring the poem was a coup. Not only is Emily Dickinson this small university town's most famous daughter, she is, as the Wordsworths are to Grasmere, a minor industry. Cafes offer tins of gingerbread baked to her original recipe. Scholars fill the town's B&Bs. Each year, thousands of Dickinson fans from as far away as Japan and Chile make the pilgrimage to the ivy-covered house on Main Street where this famously reclusive poet lived. As part of his preparations for an exhibition on the poem's history, Lombardo called Marsha Malinowski, an expert in the department of books and manuscripts in New York, one of the two Sotheby's employees who had handled the sale. The trade in historical documents and manuscripts is as secretive as a Masonic order. Many collectors - such as Bill Gates, who set a world record two years ago when he paid $35 million for a Leonardo da Vinci notebook - are extremely wealthy, and do not wish their identities, or their collecting interests, to be known. "Dealers are not forthcoming about provenance, and the auction houses also don't want to disclose their sources," says Jennifer Larson, an expert on Hofmann's forgeries. "It's like a private club." Lombardo knew this as well as anyone, but he hoped that, as the poem had been bought by a public institution, Malinowski might be willing to disclose something of the poem's history. He was particularly curious about who had signed the words "Aunt Emily". It was the sort of telling, human detail that can breathe the spark of life into faded parchment. Malinowski said that she would be happy to ask the consignor for permission to waive Sotheby's standard confidentiality agreement and reveal his or her identity. But, a week later, she called back to say that the consignor of the poem had unfortunately not agreed. All she could say was that the poem had come from a collector, who had bought it from a dealer in the Midwest. Who had died. A few days later, Lombardo received a phone call from a man named Brent Ashworth, in Provo, Utah. Ashworth is an attorney, businessman and prominent member of Mormon society. He has also been a lifelong collector of historical documents, and is a passionate fan of Emily Dickinson. What he had to say sent a shiver down Lombardo's spine. In the early 80s, said Ashworth, a historical documents dealer named Mark Hofmann had offered to sell him an unpublished Dickinson manuscript for $10,000. "I usually went up [to Hofmann's house] on Wednesdays, on the way to the law-firm that does our stock transactions," recalls Ashworth. "He usually had a little valise or a folder he pulled things out of . . . something juicy he wanted to offer me. And one of those days he pulled out this Emily Dickinson." Ashworth believed that this was the same poem that Lombardo had just bought in Manhattan. Mark Hofmann was born in Salt Lake City in 1951, the son of a devout Mormon family. As a child, he was bookish, introspective, overweight. His parents hoped that their son would devote his life to God. And, for a time, it seemed as though he would. Hofmann did a stint abroad as a missionary (in Leicester). He sang in the Tabernacle choir. But, unbeknown to his parents and the Mormon community, Hofmann had already begun to live a double life. Since the age of 14, he had been forging, and selling, rare Mormon coins. On his return from England, he enrolled at university in Salt Lake City to study biology and zoology. His mother's anguish over his father's polygamy had aready caused him to question the Mormon faith. Instead of a world view based on the Gospels, Hofmann adopted a grim, nihilistic brand of Darwinism. His favourite TV programmes were nature documentaries showing predatory animals stalking and killing their prey. A semester short of graduation, he dropped out of university to become a rare books dealer. And a full-time forger. Forging coins had taught him two lessons: that things have no intrinsic value, and that people will believe what they want to believe. The Church of the Latter Day Saints was the perfect victim. Since its beginnings, in 1863, it has been a religion in search of authentication. The hundreds of thousands of dollars-worth of documents that Hofmann sold to the church were faith-promoting documents of the highest order. They included the earliest known Mormon artefact - a letter from the mother of the church's founder, Joseph Smith - and the last: a letter written by Smith from jail just before he was murdered. Hofmann's real intention, however, was to destroy the faith he despised. Like a virus planted in a computer, he began to feed the Church of Latter Day Saints with documents that called into question some of the fundamental tenets of the faith. They were nearly always of American icons, charismatic historical figures, who touched a deep chord in the national consciousness, such as Nathan Hale, the young patriot executed by the British in the War of Independence, Abraham Lincoln, Mark Twain, Daniel Boone. Hofmann's favourite stratagem was to exploit lacunae in the historical record, creating a document that was known to have existed but had disappeared. Hofmann was a brilliant forger, and a brilliant dissembler. He was a happily married family man who spent hundreds of thousands of dollars assembling one of his country's finest collections of rare children's books as a patrimony for his own four children. He was charming, personable and knowledgeable; ruthless, cynical and amoral. Hofmann's weakness was, ironically, his passion for (genuine) antiquarian books. Meanwhile he was travelling America, living high on the hog. By October 1985, he was more than a million dollars in debt. He offered investors in Salt Lake City part-ownership of documents he was planning to forge, then pocketed the money. Christensen was found whimpering like a child in the corridor outside his office in downtown Salt Lake City. The pipe-bomb Hofmann had left for him in a brown-paper bag was as meticulously constructed as his forgeries. Around a length of galvanised pipe, Hofmann had packed hundreds of 1in steel masonry nails that were meant not just to kill but to mutilate. One of them went straight through Christensen's eye and into his brain. He died. Later that day, another bomb shook the Mormon capital. It was meant for a man called Gary Sheets. Sheets had no connection to the historical documents world, but he was involved with Christensen in a failing savings-and-loans scheme that had left several Utahans bankrupt. The bomb was Hofmann's most elaborate and diabolical ruse so far: a decoy intended to make the police think that the two murders were revenge killings by disgruntled investors. But instead of killing Sheets, the bomb killed his wife. A few hours later, a third bomb exploded in the back of Hofmann's sports car, which was parked not far from the Mormon Tabernacle. Hofmann was found bleeding on the sidewalk. There was gaping hole in one knee and a gash in his head. Scattered about the street were shreds of both forged and genuine historical documents. Among them was a piece of Egyptian papyrus. In 1986, Hofmann was jailed for life for the two murders. Salt Lake City police believe that the third bomb was meant for Brent Ashworth. From 1981 to 1985, Ashworth had bought nearly $500,000-worth of documents from Hofmann and traded a further $300,000-worth of his own collection of genuine documents for forgeries. "As I've been burned by a forger," he told me, "I feel like: if the auction houses themselves don't stand up against these forgers, then the field itself is not going to be worth two cents to us collectors that invest a lot of time and money." Kiffer's nickname at Sotheby's is Special Agent Kiffer, because he has always been so zealous in reporting stolen books to the FBI, but he did not appear particularly interested in Ashworth's story. "He said that doesn't mean that it was necessarily a fake," says Ashworth. Kiffer also insisted that he'd had the poem checked out. When Ashworth asked by whom, Kiffer mentioned a Yale University professor, Ralph Franklin. Ironically, Ashworth's information had only further convinced Daniel Lombardo that the Dickinson manuscript was "right". fields.headline: Hardback fiction
fields.trailText: According to our sources, Mother's Day accounts for a healthy boost in the sales of Kate Atkinson, Joanna Trollope, Helen Fielding and Catherine Cookson...
fields.body:
According to our sources, Mother's Day accounts for a healthy boost in the sales of Kate Atkinson, Joanna Trollope, Helen Fielding and Catherine Cookson. It's a nice thought, but since when did giving your mum a book entitled Emotionally Weird, or a tale of a Silk Cut-puffing, Chardonnay-swilling singleton become an acceptable alternative to a bunch of daffs and half a pound of Black Magic? Strange times, indeed.

Meanwhile, a five-year break seems to have whetted the reading public's appetite for Kazuo Ishiguro, whose London-Shanghai detective story enters the charts at number 1 only days after publication. In any case, this popularity might filter through to the massing ranks of prize judges struggling under the weight of novels to read - although, given the current emphasis on marketability, one might equally expect John Grisham or Jeffrey Archer to turn up on the Booker Prize shortlist.

fields.headline: Onward and Upward
fields.standfirst: John Cunningham ascends beyond Shangri-La to meet the enduring author who created a surreal fictional world with Isherwood
fields.trailText: John Cunningham ascends beyond Shangri-La to meet the enduring author who created a surreal fictional world with Isherwood
fields.body:
Past houses called Bali Hai, Belmore and Shangri-La lies Edward Upward's home. You expect a sign saying Mortmere, breaking the line of happy havens by alluding to its owner's shocking short stories, which he suppressed for decades. But there's just a number. Everything on the Isle of Wight is miniaturised to suit the old and the very old. Upward, 96 and still writing, has become part of the process: dwarfed in a big winged armchair, in his bit of offshore Britain where his family has its roots.

Edward Upward is a bit of an oddity: a Repton and Cambridge chum of Isherwood, and co-creator with him of the surreal, salacious world of Mortmere. Isherwood always stressed how working with Upward developed the element of fantasy in his own fiction.

Then there's Upward's 30 years as a public school teacher - during which time he had an extra-mural career as a Marxist activist. And his break with the Communist party of Great Britain in 1948 because, he felt, it was diluting its ideals. There's also a self-imposed literary silence of almost 20 years, mainly for political reasons. When he started writing again in 1961, the surreal, nightmare style which had won acclaim was replaced by a spare, bare prose which baffled some critics.

Odd, too, are the vicissitudes of Upward's reputation. Journey to the Border, his first novel, came from the Hogarth Press in 1938. "The madness in it appealed to Virginia [Woolf]," he says. Subsequently he was taken up, then dropped, by Heinemann and Penguin. Finally, he was rediscovered in the 90s by a small press, Enitharmon.

Through all this, the drive to write survived. Without any apology, many characters in his new short story collection are old active lefties. The title story, The Coming Day, is about Cedric, who absconds from a residential home and crosses the familiar Upward divide from reality to fantasy. His picaresque journey takes him to such places as an abattoir hung with human corpses; a football riot; and a private school run by a paedophile, all of which episodes elicit didactic reflections.

Cedric is a retired, widowed teacher. The one solace in his wanderings is the young woman he meets who happens to be a gerontophile. Upward shows that the saving grace of sex extends even to wrinklies. There's a gay gerontophile in another story, though the poor chap gets kicked out of bed by the greyhead he attempts to snuggle up to.

But don't look for any autobiographical links in any of this fictional sex. When bawdy Auden and his mates went to a gay brothel in Berlin before the last war, the happily heterosexual Upward remained outside. Even now, the long-married but widowed author is shy about any personal revelation. He admits only that, even at his age, "life without female company would be unbearable".

It would be unbearable without politics, too. His characters still carry their beliefs in their rucksacks, for Upward remains an unswerving Marxist. This gives them a shining, simple view of the mess we've made of the world. At the same time, certainly in the later collections of stories, it doesn't make them naive or crankish: they are presented as interesting, experienced old folk.

From his straight-jacket prose, you might imagine that Upward is a humourless ideologue. In fact, he's quite the opposite. In conversation he's jolly, even japish: it's easy to picture him chuckling with Isherwood over Mortmere and its cast of snobby grotesques.

Long ago he destroyed the manuscripts of almost all the 20s fantasies. However, Isherwood's pieces - none of which had seen the light of day - and a very few by Upward (including The Railway Accident, acclaimed, but long out of print) were published by Enitharmon as The Mortmere Stories in 1994.

Even 70 years after they were conceived, they can shock. Isherwood has a gothick tale about an aristocratic hunchback with an appetite for faeces. Upward's railway tale about sabotage on the line, with soldiers among the gory dead, was even more horrific in its uncut version. One scene described the rape by three choristers of a fellow schoolboy.

"I could easily have gone on writing as I had in the unexpurgated Railway Accident. I would have sold hundreds of thousands." But he consciously chose to cut off a vein, comic and Kafkaesque, that was uniquely his. Was it wise for a writer to change track so abruptly? You must remember the period, says Upward. With the atrocity of war, "I felt it was anti-human, really. That spurt of soldier's blood coming out of the carriage windows; the whole thing was treated as a joke. I felt it was unethical. After the extermination camps, I sometimes wondered if anyone could ever write anything again of an imaginative kind."

During his apparent silence (when he worked at Alleyn's School, Dulwich), he continued trying to write, but connecting the prose with the ideology came hard. There was consolation in his lonely stance. He recalls that Isherwood said "your trouble is not due to weakness; it's due to strength".

So it was. Luminaries including Frank Kermode and Spender have championed his recent work; he's sold his lifelong diaries to the British Library, but retains the use of them. Plenty to mine there: not new themes, but endless variations on old ones. That, after all, is what we most value Upward for.

You expect a sign saying Mortmere, breaking the line of happy havens by alluding to its owner's shocking short stories, which he suppressed for decades. But there's just a number. Everything on the Isle of Wight is miniaturised to suit the old and the very old. And his break with the Communist party of Great Britain in 1948 because, he felt, it was diluting its ideals. There's also a self-imposed literary silence of almost 20 years, mainly for political reasons. webTitle: Tired of London? There's always Birmingham...

fields.headline: Tired of London? There's always Birmingham...
fields.trailText: Launching in the midlands, plus some vigorous hybrids and some business solutions
fields.body:
 To the packed Fiddle & Bone pub in Birmingham for the launch of two first novels, by Jackie Gay and Michael Richardson, both of whom are published by the city's newly established Tindal Street Press.

Guests from London might have been surprised to see Jonathan Coe in attendance, but in fact, Birmingham is his home town. "I'm a veteran of literary launch parties," he remarked, "and this was the best I've been to in years. The London publishing scene is becoming so tired and predictable and afraid to take risks, whereas in Birmingham there seems to be this incredible buzz and confidence." We won't expect to see Coe nibbling on an anchovy and sipping a glass of fizz at the Groucho Club in the near future, then.

 News of two forthcoming books reaches us from the vibrant world of cut-throat publishing deals. Knowing a dead cert when they see one, HarperCollins have snapped up Amanda Foreman's new book, an account of the British men and women who fought in the American Civil War. Foreman's editor, Mike Fishwick, describes it as "Stalingrad crossed with Gone With the Wind", which, as an example of the hyped strapline, is only pipped to the post this week by "Loaded meets Le Carré", used to alert us to a book about the Moscow underworld.

Meanwhile, fans of Amis fils et père will be interested to hear that Elizabeth Jane Howard, one-time Mrs Kingsley, is to publish her autobiography. Given that Howard makes more than a fleeting appearance in her former husband's soon-to-be published letters, and that her stepson Martin's memoir, Experience, is also due out in a month or so's time, this could be a great opportunity for a bit of score-settling.

 And another in our occasional series of odd little books (last: the so-called Leaf-Girt Vagina). Fictions of Business thuds onto the mat, with its enticing subtitle "Insights on Management from Great Literature". Immerse yourself in Joseph Conrad's Typhoon to understand office politics and how to manage stress, Shaw's Major Barbara to settle into corporate life, and - best of all - The Canterbury Tales to get to the bottom of the self-made man. Coming next: how Jane Austen can help you surf the Internet, with an audiobook read by Colin Firth.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: A uniquely beguiling take on the abandoned husband story plus By the Shore, Wedding by the Sea and Going Loco
fields.body:
Tomcat In Love
Tim O'Brien
Flamingo, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Abandoned and vengeful husbands are a staple of fiction but Prof Thomas "Tomcat" Chippering is uniquely beguiling. As he tells it, childhood sweetheart Lorna Sue has left him for a Tampa tycoon. "Why me?" he asks. "By any estimate I am a man of some majesty, tall and eye-catching, no paunch, no deficits worth the spill of ink." Naturally, there is another side to this story which the pompous, verbose and self-deluding prof cannot see. Insanity, love and linguistic trickery take us into Nabokov territory and O'Brien pays dutiful homage, but Tomcat has an etymology all his own and comedy is seasoned with anguish.

Wedding By The Sea
Abdelkader Benali
Phoenix, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Lamarat is young man with a mission, and that mission is to drag his uncle, Mosa, out of the local brothel in time for his wedding - "with any luck at all this will clear up a lot of things," writes the Moroccan author, Benali. Lamarat hires Bucket of Bolts Chalid and his beaten-up taxi and as they dodge potholes and screech around hairpin bends on the way to town, so the story of Lamarat and his family is steered between low comedy and fairy-tale, while everything becomes as clear as the mud in the village pond. Benali does Moroccan magic realism with great gusto.

By The Shore
Galaxy Craze
Vintage, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

May, like all girls on the edge of puberty, feels things with a stomach-wrenching agony and a heightened sense of reality. She has plenty of growing-up to do and a quirky, alienated take on the adult world, as experienced in the seaside guesthouse run by her mum, Lucy, a London hippie in exile. Craze explores May's bitter-sweet adolescent impressions with style and a sure sense of a 12-year-old's priorities. Her problems include her difficult relationship with her father, and her anxiety when a handsome writer seems to be claiming her mother's affections. This is an intimate portrayal of a little girl's world view, simply and delicately written.

Going Loco
Lynne Truss
Review, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

If books with Dayglo covers bring you out in an irritable rash then you will probably skip over Truss's latest. Despite the usual ingredients of hysterical women, nice flats and unhappy relationships, Going Loco is an exquisite farce. Belinda's book about literary doppelgängers is not going well: the mess in her house screams reproach while Neville, the circus rat, is using her guts as a performance space. The only things right in her life are her geneticist husband Stefan and her cleaning lady, until reality starts to imitate literature. Truss piles on the silliness, and no one is quite who they seem in this ridiculous but highly readable entertainment.

fields.headline: Small press corner
fields.trailText: A blood and guts account of the role of women in the Jacobite uprising
fields.body:
Damn' Rebel Bitches: The Women of the '45
Maggie Craig
Mainstream Publishing, £9.99
Buy it at BOL

Our understanding of female participation in the Jacobite Rebellion of 1745 has been so concentrated on one woman that the working title of this book was Not Flora MacDonald. Not that Craig wishes to run Bonnie Prince Charlie's saviour down; but her aim is to bring to life the legions of women who fought against the British - not on the battlefield, but mobilising support, raising money and creating as much havoc as possible, despite the condemnation of the Hanoverian press. Craig is a highly enthusiastic and, on occasion, racy writer, and this blood and guts account is as entertaining as it is informative. A great corrective to shortbread tins and Mel Gibson's painted face.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: Michael Brunson has lost his rhythm and left out the gossip
fields.body:
A Ringside Seat
Michael Brunson
Hodder Headline, £8.99, 120mn
Buy it at BOL

What we want now from the man who has been beamed into our living rooms for 30 years, straining to keep neutral in the Westminster bearpit, is bias and bile. Who were the real charlatans? Who tried to bribe or bully you? Who shafted whom?

If only. About the only decent tale concerns the Blairs, whom Brunson filmed at home during the Labour leadership campaign following John Smith's death. Fine, said the Blairs, but keep our kids out of it. Unfortunately Cherie got a bit carried away and babbled about how much she relished the chance of living at No 10.

Hubbie, visibly distraught at her previousness, struck a deal: if Brunson cut Cherie's gaffe out of the film, he could shoot a few feet of young Euan practising the piano. Brunson's voice, so reassuring on News at Ten, soon starts to sound bland when it is stretched beyond bulletin length.Those short spurts on the telly ruin the rhythm necessary for longer speech.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: John Aubrey's stories of the rich and famous in the 17th century and Peter Hall's of the mediacracy of the 70s
fields.body:
Brief Lives
John Aubrey
Penguin Classics, £8.99
Buy it at BOL

Aubrey thought himself a failure, skittering about 17th century England, making little notes on the famous - knew 'em all, or at least, as with Shakespeare, knew somebody who had known 'em - as guest in old homes and sipper in new coffee houses. In truth, he was a gossip of genius. He set all he heard and saw down, with a sharp melancholy which later passed from social reporting - for he was born in the afterglow of Gloriana's reign and wrote during the Restoration; by then, his own estate had been quite ruined, confirming his belief that, in the long view, glory is fleeting and even tombs are consumed by time. Super edition.

Peter Hall's Diaries
edited by John Goodwin
Oberon, £15.99
Buy it at BOL

Hall knew everybody, too, or rather the entire mediacracy of the 70s, when the National Theatre was solidifying from acting company to concreted South Bank institution. Skip the life, as Hall's personal entries are trite in language and meanly low in self-knowledge. But there is a wise sadness to the stage anecdotes: Albert Finney as Hamlet addressing his ghostly father onstage at the very moment of the clock his real, adored dad died; Ralph Richardson, cast as an aged servant, muttering a running commentary on his last scene in Chekhov's Cherry Orchard: "Now I come through the door in my slippers. Good Lord, they've all gone. Then I die..."

fields.headline: Shades of blue
fields.standfirst: Catherine Bennett  on doom and doilies in two very different Tory novels
fields.trailText: Catherine Bennett on doom and doilies in two very different Tory novels
fields.body:
The Clematis Tree
Ann Widdecombe
Weidenfeld, £9.99, 288pp
Buy it at BOL

Chasing Men
Edwina Currie
Little, Brown, £14.99, 372pp
Buy it at BOL

Ann Widdecombe received an odd compliment recently. It came from her young master William Hague. "If we could get the commonsense revolution to stand up and walk around," he said, "it would look like Ann Widdecombe." Although this is probably one of the nicest things anyone has ever said to Widdecombe, and doubtless well meant - Hague's idea of a love token, remember, is a £-shaped charm - it could not be further from the truth. There is nothing common about this devout virgin, and, as most of her interviews confirm, not all that much that is sensible. Only last week she expressed a wish for a sort of "social revolution" which would resurrect the nuclear family and reverse the "liberalisation of the 70s".

Outside media interviews, which she gives promiscuously, the shadow home secretary has few opportunities to harangue degenerates on their moral decline, which appears to be one reason she embarked on a novel. The point of The Clematis Tree is to hold a debate about euthanasia (and, by extension, a debate about another of her interests, abortion) in which Widdecombe's orthodox Catholic view - that all life is sacred - is the one that naturally prevails. It can only be inadvertent, then, that human life as portrayed in The Clematis Tree is so extraordinarily grim as to be barely worth living.

She opens with a birthday party at which little victims play. "In the distance a low rumble foretold a storm." Within minutes, four-year-old Jeremy has been mown down by a speeding car, crippled and massively brain-damaged. Thereafter, events are narrated by Jeremy's father, Mark, a man who has no faith and is rapidly cooling towards his bad-tempered wife Claire.

Claire does have faith, but this does not make her appreciably nicer or happier. Nor does the existence of their sweet healthy child, Pippa, a loving extended family and Claire's rich father (who ensures that Jeremy has everything he needs and that Widdecombe never has to write about the practical anxieties that, for most people, are inextricably mixed up with the threat of acute disability). In this novel, money is only bothersome in its excess.

Jeremy falls ill and nearly dies, after which Mark decides the marriage is over and goes on holiday alone. In Portugal he encounters perfect faith in the shape of a comely young widow, Mrs Smith, and her two children, one of whom has a facial birthmark so ghastly that her playmates cry out at the sight. It is sexy Smith's job to give the hapless Mark some hope, by delivering the parable of the clematis tree. She had a sumac tree in her garden; after it died, she trained a vigorous clematis around the branches. "You see, Jeremy is like the tree: passive but giving beauty, and the clematis is all that love which embraces him and grows stronger and more beautiful."

Perhaps the strangest thing about Widdecombe land is how little such glimpses of religious enlightenment are allowed to ease the endless torment of being on this earth. Sure enough, when a still discontented Mark returns home, he discovers, among a variety of temptations and disappointments, that his wife, the pious Claire, is a compulsive shopper who has in the past hit her defenceless son. Before long, there is a tell-tale "rumble of thunder... Mark, remembering the storm on the day of the accident, could not repress a feeling of its being a bad omen, a herald of doom..."

This time the forces of doom threaten Mark's daughter and her little classmates with a horrible coach crash. Pippa survives, although not before Widdecombe has had her sport describing the mix-up of bereaved and non-bereaved parents in the same school hall.

There is something horribly compelling about Widdecombe's casual cruelty towards her cast. What will she think of next? A sudden heart attack? An agonising deathbed scene? A fatal accident? Yes, yes, and yes! Even her happy ending - a new life - is blighted, the child being unwanted by one parent. To find wilful authorial cruelty on this scale, you have to go back to Hardy's Jude the Obscure and "Done because we are too menny".

In many ways Hardy's Wessex is a jollier place than Widdecombe's suburban Surrey, a region she has emptied not merely of sexual pleasure, but more strikingly of the filial and familial contentment she advertises in her politics. It is beyond Widdecombe's skill to animate her argument on the sanctity of life, but the many episodes of marital claustrophobia are written with enough energy and inventiveness to leave quite a different moral: that family life is a painful mess better viewed from the sidelines - perhaps as a spinster, like Aunt Isobel, "a sharp-witted, worldly-wise woman who knew those around her better than they knew themselves". Useful to know that, next time Aunt Ann gets started on family values.

If it was ever useful to know anything about the former MP Edwina Currie, it was a long time ago, on a different political planet. Which means that the only reason to read her fifth and latest offering, Chasing Men, is to find out if she can still do to the written word what she did to the egg industry. She can. Chasing Men has chapter headings like "Sod the Curtains" and characters who say things like "I do like country house hotels, don't you? With a pool for preference." It is the story of an Ugly Duckling - plump, newly divorced, provincial Hetty Clarkson - who moves to the capital, sheds her fat and becomes a media Swan who has money, parties and men in cravats falling at her feet.

If Chasing Men can be said to have anything as ambitious as a subject, it is weight. Hetty, perhaps through long practice at the village fetes of her married years, possesses a rare ability: to guess the weight of complete strangers. In a supermarket she spots an attractive item: "This man was impossibly handsome, with a shock of tousled golden hair, blue-eyed. Over six foot. Probably around 13 and a half stone." On the staircase outside her flat she finds a suicidal fat girl. "She loomed over Hetty; she must be five feet 10 and over 15 stone." As for Hetty, she is a size 14 going on 16, until she loses weight and discovers that 20lbs is the difference between sex with a banana and sex with Norman, a man so perfect "she could detect not an ounce of spare fat on him".

In the strange parallel universe inhabited by Currie, where Jaffa Cakes, Drambuie and Ritz crackers are singled out for product placement and biscuits are still proudly served on doilies, the name Norman has no less erotic a cadence than Nabokov's Lolita. "Norman", Hetty whispers "Norman..." And when Hetty whispers, Currie makes everything from the trees to the "mousse dispenser" in her bathroom talk back. "Don't be dazzled" says a champagne glass. "Face the outside world with confidence" says a wardrobe. Alas, the only inanimate object for which one actually feels some sympathy remains mute, "bruised and blackened, under the bed". In a final gimmick, Currie asks readers to email a Hetty Clarkson website with suggestions for what her heroine should do next. Well, I can think of one thing: give that banana a decent burial.
