It came from her young master William Hague. "If we could get the commonsense revolution to stand up and walk around," he said, "it would look like Ann Widdecombe." Although this is probably one of the nicest things anyone has ever said to Widdecombe, and doubtless well meant - Hague's idea of a love token, remember, is a £-shaped charm - it could not be further from the truth. There is nothing common about this devout virgin, and, as most of her interviews confirm, not all that much that is sensible. Only last week she expressed a wish for a sort of "social revolution" which would resurrect the nuclear family and reverse the "liberalisation of the 70s". Outside media interviews, which she gives promiscuously, the shadow home secretary has few opportunities to harangue degenerates on their moral decline, which appears to be one reason she embarked on a novel. The point of The Clematis Tree is to hold a debate about euthanasia (and, by extension, a debate about another of her interests, abortion) in which Widdecombe's orthodox Catholic view - that all life is sacred - is the one that naturally prevails. It can only be inadvertent, then, that human life as portrayed in The Clematis Tree is so extraordinarily grim as to be barely worth living. She opens with a birthday party at which little victims play. "In the distance a low rumble foretold a storm." Within minutes, four-year-old Jeremy has been mown down by a speeding car, crippled and massively brain-damaged. Thereafter, events are narrated by Jeremy's father, Mark, a man who has no faith and is rapidly cooling towards his bad-tempered wife Claire. Claire does have faith, but this does not make her appreciably nicer or happier. Nor does the existence of their sweet healthy child, Pippa, a loving extended family and Claire's rich father (who ensures that Jeremy has everything he needs and that Widdecombe never has to write about the practical anxieties that, for most people, are inextricably mixed up with the threat of acute disability). In this novel, money is only bothersome in its excess. Jeremy falls ill and nearly dies, after which Mark decides the marriage is over and goes on holiday alone. In Portugal he encounters perfect faith in the shape of a comely young widow, Mrs Smith, and her two children, one of whom has a facial birthmark so ghastly that her playmates cry out at the sight. It is sexy Smith's job to give the hapless Mark some hope, by delivering the parable of the clematis tree. She had a sumac tree in her garden; after it died, she trained a vigorous clematis around the branches. "You see, Jeremy is like the tree: passive but giving beauty, and the clematis is all that love which embraces him and grows stronger and more beautiful." Perhaps the strangest thing about Widdecombe land is how little such glimpses of religious enlightenment are allowed to ease the endless torment of being on this earth. Sure enough, when a still discontented Mark returns home, he discovers, among a variety of temptations and disappointments, that his wife, the pious Claire, is a compulsive shopper who has in the past hit her defenceless son. Before long, there is a tell-tale "rumble of thunder... Mark, remembering the storm on the day of the accident, could not repress a feeling of its being a bad omen, a herald of doom..." This time the forces of doom threaten Mark's daughter and her little classmates with a horrible coach crash. Pippa survives, although not before Widdecombe has had her sport describing the mix-up of bereaved and non-bereaved parents in the same school hall. There is something horribly compelling about Widdecombe's casual cruelty towards her cast. What will she think of next? A sudden heart attack? An agonising deathbed scene? A fatal accident? Yes, yes, and yes! Even her happy ending - a new life - is blighted, the child being unwanted by one parent. To find wilful authorial cruelty on this scale, you have to go back to Hardy's Jude the Obscure and "Done because we are too menny". In many ways Hardy's Wessex is a jollier place than Widdecombe's suburban Surrey, a region she has emptied not merely of sexual pleasure, but more strikingly of the filial and familial contentment she advertises in her politics. It is beyond Widdecombe's skill to animate her argument on the sanctity of life, but the many episodes of marital claustrophobia are written with enough energy and inventiveness to leave quite a different moral: that family life is a painful mess better viewed from the sidelines - perhaps as a spinster, like Aunt Isobel, "a sharp-witted, worldly-wise woman who knew those around her better than they knew themselves". Useful to know that, next time Aunt Ann gets started on family values. If it was ever useful to know anything about the former MP Edwina Currie, it was a long time ago, on a different political planet. Which means that the only reason to read her fifth and latest offering, Chasing Men, is to find out if she can still do to the written word what she did to the egg industry. She can. Chasing Men has chapter headings like "Sod the Curtains" and characters who say things like "I do like country house hotels, don't you? With a pool for preference." It is the story of an Ugly Duckling - plump, newly divorced, provincial Hetty Clarkson - who moves to the capital, sheds her fat and becomes a media Swan who has money, parties and men in cravats falling at her feet. If Chasing Men can be said to have anything as ambitious as a subject, it is weight. Hetty, perhaps through long practice at the village fetes of her married years, possesses a rare ability: to guess the weight of complete strangers. In a supermarket she spots an attractive item: "This man was impossibly handsome, with a shock of tousled golden hair, blue-eyed. Over six foot. Probably around 13 and a half stone." On the staircase outside her flat she finds a suicidal fat girl. "She loomed over Hetty; she must be five feet 10 and over 15 stone." As for Hetty, she is a size 14 going on 16, until she loses weight and discovers that 20lbs is the difference between sex with a banana and sex with Norman, a man so perfect "she could detect not an ounce of spare fat on him". In the strange parallel universe inhabited by Currie, where Jaffa Cakes, Drambuie and Ritz crackers are singled out for product placement and biscuits are still proudly served on doilies, the name Norman has no less erotic a cadence than Nabokov's Lolita. "Norman", Hetty whispers "Norman..." And when Hetty whispers, Currie makes everything from the trees to the "mousse dispenser" in her bathroom talk back. "Don't be dazzled" says a champagne glass. "Face the outside world with confidence" says a wardrobe. Alas, the only inanimate object for which one actually feels some sympathy remains mute, "bruised and blackened, under the bed". In a final gimmick, Currie asks readers to email a Hetty Clarkson website with suggestions for what her heroine should do next. Well, I can think of one thing: give that banana a decent burial.

fields.headline: The heart's blood
fields.standfirst: Alex Clark  is bewitched by Julie Myerson's grisly Victorian tale, Laura Blundy
fields.trailText: Alex Clark is bewitched by Julie Myerson's grisly Victorian tale, Laura Blundy
fields.body:
Laura Blundy
Julie Myerson
Fourth Estate, £15.99, 263pp
Buy it at BOL

This is a novel steeped in blood and all the bodily detritus that goes with it. As it opens, Laura Blundy stoves her husband's head in with an ornament she has always hated and the crutch she has used since her leg was amputated, and listens curiously as nonsense words spew out of his mouth "all cock-a-snip". Soon, "a bloody black hole" takes the place of his mouth, and he falls silent. As Laura attempts to finish him off, hearing "the bone that held his nose in place crunch like sugar", a ham skids - "pinkly glossy in the half-light" - across the pantry floor.

In another writer, this determination to document the physical reality of the world might tip over into gratuitous phrase-making. One can imagine someone straining for the right words to describe, say, a poker skewering a brain; here we are simply alerted to a "definite juicy crunch, like going into raw potato. Another sigh, a rushy liquid sound."

Throughout Laura Blundy, Myerson takes apart our notions of Victorian melodrama and mawkishness. Her heroine has lived the perfect Dickensian life: thrown out onto the street after a "mischievous will", raped in the back of a cab by a fine gentleman and landed with a baby at 15, familiar with foundling hospital, workhouse and prison alike. Yet Laura, and those around her, are also immediately recognisable.

Myerson refuses to lard her dialogue with cod-Victoriana ("I can't save you from your frigging mother", Laura remonstrates with her future husband), or to allow the staples of a reconstructed London - the grimy river, families sleeping five to a room, cabs whose iron wheels crush a woman's bones like eggshells - to obscure the urgency and intimacy of her story.

That story is told with an exceptionally subtle understanding of the macabre and the desperate. Laura is a woman to whom shocking incidents have occurred with nightmarish frequency, her destitution leading her into an underworld where death meshes with the everyday business of living.

The most vividly recreated of these acts of brutality becomes the pivot of the novel when, mown down by a cab, she is taken to hospital and has her leg sawn off at the knee. The surgeon who operates on her, beguiled by her mixture of stoicism and frantic neediness, caresses her hip as he shows off his handiwork to onlookers and keeps her quiet with tots of brandy. Later he marries her, and begins the wretched process of trying to convert her into his ladylike consort. Later still, she murders him, cuts his body into small pieces and tries to burn his head over a makeshift fire.

If Laura has power, it lies in her ability to simultaneously attract and repel men. In turn, she herself both needs and despises them. One of the grisliest scenes in the book - pokers and bonfires notwithstanding - comes as she gives her new husband an account of her rape. She, for once, is attempting to put aside the manipulation and hard-as-nails banter that characterise her dealings with men; he finds the story the most immense turn-on and promptly re-enacts the assault.

No wonder, then, that she turns to Billy, 15 years her junior but already locked into poverty-stricken marriage and fatherhood, when her husband's body lies oozing blood in their richly decorated, eerily silent house. Billy and Laura's relationship, reprised in flashbacks that alternate with an almost comic description of their body-disposal ordeal, is brilliantly realised as a tense see-saw between passion and terror, the promise of love eclipsed by the far more probable doom-laden outcome. But the most convincing portrait in the novel is of Laura alone, struggling to subdue and contain her desires as life metes out punishment after punishment. "I have lost all manner of things," she remarks as she grieves over her lost leg. "A person can only take so much loss."

One of the things Laura has lost is her baby, and with that her sense of her life as one with the potential for happiness or stability. Veering between almost infantile dependency and hard-hearted recklessness, she is heart-breakingly unpredictable and savagely out of control. This is not a predicament that is confined to a particular period or situation, and Myerson makes the extremity of her circumstances almost irrelevant to the empathy we feel for her.

It is likely that this will be one of the strangest, most compelling novels this year. It's not for the squeamish; but if you'd like to see a writer really trying to do something different, then take your courage in your hands.

fields.headline: The List
fields.trailText: The cosmological constant comes back into fashion, plus Defending the Cavewoman and Deep Time
fields.body:
God's Equation: Einstein, Relativity and the Expanding Universe
Amir Aczel
Piatkus, £16.99
Buy it at BOL

Picture Einstein beavering away at the culmination of his theory of general relativity: his gravitational field equation. Oops. It doesn't seem to work, unless you cheat slightly by bunging in a seemingly arbitrary number. Oh, what the hell, give it an impressive-sounding name: call it the "cosmological constant".

That's what Einstein did, and years later it was known as his "greatest blunder", disaverred by its creator later in life. Fast-forward to 1998, and a bunch of astronomers are aghast to discover that the universe will expand for ever until suffering "heat death". There's no explanation for that, unless you resurrect the derided old cosmological constant. So was Einstein right after all? This latest book from the industrious Aczel (the author most recently of the excellent Probability 1, which proves mathematically the existence of aliens) is another professional piece of pop-science storytelling, though the maths is pitched at rather a crunchy level. But then, only God really understands it.

Defending the Cavewoman
Harold Klawans
Norton, £15.95
Buy it at BOL

The look-at-me title conceals a pleasantly thoughtful collection of Oliver Sacks-style case studies in evolutionary neurology. We meet a conductor who has lost the power of speech but can still work with his left arm; a man who cannot read but manages to teach himself Hebrew; and, in the title chapter, a near-feral six-year-old girl who's never learned to talk but acquires language in a new therapeutic environment. Klawans defends the cavewoman because, as it turns out, the females of the species more or less invented language while the men were out playing with their flint-tipped spears.

Deep Time: Cladistics, the Revolution in Evolution
Henry Gee
Fourth Estate, £20
Buy it at BOL

Cladistics (from the Greek for "offshoot", by the way) is a method of looking at fossil records that refuses to tell nice and easy teleological stories. Fish grew legs so they could flop out onto the land and then it was smoothly onwards and upwards to the glorious ascent of homo sapiens, right? Wrong. As a science, cladistics insists that we can know much less than we think we can. There's no way of determining, for example, whether a particular fossil is a direct ancestor of ours, and the only reliable way of classifying species is on the basis of measurable similarities.

Truth is, this is hardly such fresh and "revolutionary" news as this book is pretending, unless you are Charles Darwin awakening from cryogenic suspension. Stephen Jay Gould has been saying much the same things for several books now, and Gee does quietly admit in his introduction that no professional paleontologist has seriously held the views against which he is arguing for some 30 years. But some pop-evolution books still peddle the old triumphal, linear stories, and this readable and generous account of theoretical humility is a welcome antidote.

fields.headline: Big in first novels
fields.trailText: Something between a poem and a short story, plus Sunset Over Chocolate Mountains, The Danish Girl and Lost
fields.body:
Kate Jennings is a poet and short story writer; not surprising then that Snake (Fourth Estate, £10) should fall somewhere between these two forms. A string of what are essentially prose poems draw the reader into intoxicating confinement with two Australian newlyweds, Rex and Irene, just after the second world war.

While he farms his 800 acres, she has babies and spends her time gardening obsessively, nurturing a perfect Eden out of a less than ideal existence. Jennings conveys both the vast landscape of New South Wales and a sense of excruciating suffocation that threatens to drive the family apart. The snakes of the title occasionally weave through the text with understated symbolism, subtle emblems of the brooding sexual frustration that ripples beneath Jennings's spare prose.

Theobold Moon, unlikely hero of Susan Elderkin's richly imaginative Sunset Over Chocolate Mountains (Fourth Estate, £9.99), never goes anywhere without his snake-bite kit. At 34 and 22 stone, he has recently relocated from England to Arizona. He, too, is determined to make the desert bloom, but steps tentatively through his thirsty garden with a constant ear out for the "buzz of a rattler".

Both mother and father to four-year-old Josephine, Theobold is the quintessential candyman, feeding his daughter ice-cream concoctions and fantastical tales about the universe. But when Josephine finds some gold strappy sandals, and tries them on, Theobold's anger tells her more about her mother than all his fantastical tales. A strange and compelling blend of early Kingsolver and Bruno Schulz, this novel contains as many stinging surprises as the desert in which it is set.

A pair of strappy sandals are also at the centre of David Ebershoff's The Danish Girl (Weidenfeld, £12.99). In this extraordinary fictional exploration of a true story - that of the first documented transformational surgery in the 1930s - Einar puts the shoes on at his wife's request, and precipitates a crisis that transforms their lives for ever.

Einar and Greta are painters, and the incident is innocent enough - she needs a pair of female legs for an unfinished painting - but Einar discovers that he quite likes dressing up in women's clothes. He and the accepting Greta name his alter ego Lili and are thrilled when their circle is fooled into believing her to be Einar's cousin. But soon Lili starts to take on a life of her own and Einar becomes unable to dictate her arrivals and departures.

Einar never considers himself homosexual: Greta is his perfect woman, but Lili wants to be loved by a man, as a woman. Eventually, Lili's presence threatens to destroy her host, who must choose once and for all to disappear. Ebershoff shows, with poise and sensitivity, that sexuality is no respecter of gender or physical body.

Lucy Wadham's Lost (Faber, £9.99) is also loosely based on a true story. Here, on an unnamed Mediterranean island dominated by a Mafioso bad guy, a seven-year-old boy is abducted; the kidnap gives the local police chief his chance to see his opponent finally behind bars.

Sadly this is not the riveting thriller of the publisher's blurb; Wadham has crammed the narrative with a slew of walk-on characters who do their best to distract us from from a slender and predictable plot. The action sinks beneath the weight of peripheral information, even if the sporadically muscular prose does its best to engage us. Wadham needs to decide whether she wants to write a mournful literary novel or a hard-boiled thriller - at the moment, she is writing neither.

fields.headline: The law that doesn't suit
fields.standfirst: David Leigh  is horrified by David Hooper's libel lore in Reputations Under Fire
fields.trailText: David Leigh is horrified by David Hooper's libel lore in Reputations Under Fire
fields.body:
Reputations Under Fire
David Hooper, Little, Brown, £25, 523pp
Buy it at BOL

English libel litigation is a scandalous theatre. The courtroom scene is crowded like a Hogarth cartoon with senile judges, fraudulent plaintiffs, rascally defendants and lawyers whose financial rapacity makes those killer sharks from Jaws movies seem like vegetarians.

This bad law is protean in the way it constantly changes shape, allowing yet more pointless novelty actions to be launched. In the very month this book comes out, the high court has seen opposing TV and print journalists trying to sue each other to pieces and the Hitler-friendly writer David Irving managing to advertise his views for weeks on end by suing in person a Jewish academic who criticised his revisionist approach to the Holocaust. The spirit of free speech must weep, confronted with the mess we have made of libel law in this country.

Although he is himself a fairly posh libel solicitor by trade, David Hooper is a congenial soul who enjoys these encounters in a cynical sort of way. One of his explanatory footnotes, referring to work done "pro bono", reads in its entirety: "An unusual instance: lawyers acting for nothing."

Hooper very nearly came a bad libel cropper himself in this compendium of famous recent actions. He devotes a whole chapter to what he calls "The Destruction of Jonathan Aitken". But the chapter as published today is utterly different from the one Hooper originally drafted. He at first wrote a tear-stained apologia for the fallen Tory cabinet minister, explaining at some length how most of the charges made against him were false - a "vendetta" got up by the makers of the "tawdry" World in Action film and the politically vindictive liberals of the Guardian newspaper.

I had made the World in Action film that led to much of the trouble, and eventually prevailed on Hooper to show me his original chapter in the interests of accuracy. "Where on earth did you get all this tosh from?" I asked. Hooper replied sheepishly that it had all been supplied by Aitken himself. The old perjurer had slipped Hooper a manuscript - the basis of his own memoirs, also out this month - in which he paid back his journalistic enemies with a full measure of spite.

It is to Hooper's credit that once he saw there had been an attempt to make a fool of him, he rewrote the Aitken chapter extensively (although a close reader will still detect a somewhat strangulated and equivocal tone to it). I was half sorry he'd done so: to judge by some of the more hair-raising recent libel tales in Reputations Under Fire, I might have done better to have sat back, let the book come out and sued the publishers into the ground. That would at the very least have generated what members of the police call a "garage action" - a nice little libel suit leading to damages that pay for a house extension.

And I wouldn't have had to prove that I'd suffered any loss or actual damage at all, or even had to show that any of it was lies: I could have relaxed in the knowledge that everything in the book would be presumed false under the law, and the burden of proof be on the publishers. A garage? Excuse me: I could probably have won a Porsche or two as well.

Hooper's Aitken lapse seems to have been an isolated one. fields.bodyText: Reputations Under Fire David Hooper, Little, Brown, £25, 523pp Buy it at BOL English libel litigation is a scandalous theatre. The courtroom scene is crowded like a Hogarth cartoon with senile judges, fraudulent plaintiffs, rascally defendants and lawyers whose financial rapacity makes those killer sharks from Jaws movies seem like vegetarians. This bad law is protean in the way it constantly changes shape, allowing yet more pointless novelty actions to be launched. In the very month this book comes out, the high court has seen opposing TV and print journalists trying to sue each other to pieces and the Hitler-friendly writer David Irving managing to advertise his views for weeks on end by suing in person a Jewish academic who criticised his revisionist approach to the Holocaust. Although he is himself a fairly posh libel solicitor by trade, David Hooper is a congenial soul who enjoys these encounters in a cynical sort of way. One of his explanatory footnotes, referring to work done "pro bono", reads in its entirety: "An unusual instance: lawyers acting for nothing." Hooper very nearly came a bad libel cropper himself in this compendium of famous recent actions. He devotes a whole chapter to what he calls "The Destruction of Jonathan Aitken". But the chapter as published today is utterly different from the one Hooper originally drafted. He at first wrote a tear-stained apologia for the fallen Tory cabinet minister, explaining at some length how most of the charges made against him were false - a "vendetta" got up by the makers of the "tawdry" World in Action film and the politically vindictive liberals of the Guardian newspaper. I had made the World in Action film that led to much of the trouble, and eventually prevailed on Hooper to show me his original chapter in the interests of accuracy. "Where on earth did you get all this tosh from?" I asked. Hooper replied sheepishly that it had all been supplied by Aitken himself. The old perjurer had slipped Hooper a manuscript - the basis of his own memoirs, also out this month - in which he paid back his journalistic enemies with a full measure of spite. It is to Hooper's credit that once he saw there had been an attempt to make a fool of him, he rewrote the Aitken chapter extensively (although a close reader will still detect a somewhat strangulated and equivocal tone to it). That would at the very least have generated what members of the police call a "garage action" - a nice little libel suit leading to damages that pay for a house extension. And I wouldn't have had to prove that I'd suffered any loss or actual damage at all, or even had to show that any of it was lies: I could have relaxed in the knowledge that everything in the book would be presumed false under the law, and the burden of proof be on the publishers. fields.headline: Beautiful but damned
fields.standfirst: 75 years after The Great Gatsby,  Jason Cowley  remembers F. Scott Fitzgerald's doomed youth
fields.trailText: 75 years after The Great Gatsby, Jason Cowley remembers F. Scott Fitzgerald's doomed youth
fields.body:
Hemingway Vs. Fitzgerald: The Rise and Fall of a Literary Friendship
Scott Donaldson
John Murray, £25, 352pp
Buy it at BOL

Trimalchio: An Early Version of The Great Gatsby
edited by James LW West Cambridge University Press, £30, 192pp
Buy it at BOL

F. Scott Fitzgerald author page
Hemingway author page

No one has written more elegiacally about America than F. Scott Fitzgerald. As a young man, when the writing life stretched before him like an ocean of discovery and he was experiencing the first flush of early success, Fitzgerald remained oppressed by feelings of inauthenticity. He felt powerfully that something important was missing from his life, and spoke repeatedly of the "hauntedness" of The Great Gatsby.

It is not difficult to understand what he meant: a sense of lost time and the irretrievability of the past gave much of his work - indeed, his life - an ineradicable undertone of mourning. "All the stories that came into my head had a touch of disaster in them," he reflected in the autobiographical essay "Early Success", written in 1937 when he had already entered the long twilight of his short career.

More than a decade earlier, high on the thin air of his own celebrity after the triumphant publication of his debut, This Side of Paradise, Fitzgerald was travelling along Broadway in an open-top car. It was a warm, still night, and he was in a heightened state of drunken exhilaration. The future seemed infinitely inviting. Then, bafflingly, he began to cry - because "life would never be so sweet again".

This story, found in Andre Le Vot's superb F. Scott Fitzgerald (Penguin, 1984), is archetypal Fitzgerald behaviour, at once poignant and self-savouringly sentimental. A similar sense of fragility was present in the distinctive moments of his best work - in Gatsby's doomed quest to recapture the past, in Dick Diver's retreat from the world in Tender is the Night, in the failed romance of the story "Winter Dreams". Fitzgerald, like his revered Keats, was a compulsive nostalgic, locating happiness in the search for sensation rather than in its realisation; in the dream of desire, not in its fulfilment.

Paradise was published when Fitzgerald was 24, amiably recasting the wasted promise of his Princeton years as a frivolous romance elevated by flights of transcendence. Within five years came the slight The Beautiful and the Damned, about the excesses of the idle rich he'd met there; and then, improbably, in 1925, The Great Gatsby, perhaps the most perfect short novel in the English language. It is on this - along with Tender is the Night, the unfinished The Last Tycoon and some of the more accomplished stories - that his reputation rests.

From there, it seemed Fitzgerald had nowhere else to go. Once past 30, his descent into alcoholism was swift. His subsequent struggles make for a familiar story; indeed, an overfamiliar one. Scott Donaldson, who has been writing about Fitzgerald and Hemingway for more than 40 years, diligently chronicles this narrative of decline all over again: the intense, difficult relationship Fitzgerald had with his unstable wife, Zelda; the ambivalent self-positioning; the aimless wandering in Europe; the last wretched years as a hack writer in Hollywood before his fatal heart attack in 1940.

In one sense, Fitzgerald willed himself into decline. His father was a failed businessman from Maryland, and as a child Scott was encouraged to nurture a wistful romanticism about the American South, with its faded elegance, genteel old families and confederate honour. He nurtured, too, a cult of doomed youth, whereby to be young and beautiful (and certainly rich) was to be most fully alive, and to be old was nothing.

As Hemingway once told him: "You put so much damned value on youth it seemed to me that you confused growing up with growing old." Above all, the young Fitzgerald nurtured the idea of falling in love - preferably painfully, which he did soon enough when, before leaving for Princeton, he met a girl called Ginerva King, who would become the model for all those rich, lovely, careless women in his stories and novels.

Yet out of this essentially jejune adolescent sensibility Fitzgerald constructed a poetics of romantic despair, the expression of what it means to seek individual fulfilment in a time of nihilism. He conveyed, as the critic HL Mencken put it, something of the "inexplicable tragedy of being alive".

You won't find Mencken's remark in Hemingway Vs. Fitzgerald. In fact, you will find very little of interest at all if you have read any previous Fitzgerald biographies. Like Jeffrey Meyers, another American much drawn to Fitzgerald and Hemingway, Donaldson operates as a kind of high-class literary gossip, scattering speculations about penis size and chatter about money like cheap confetti. He seems unwilling or unable to separate the life from the work, so that every fictional event finds its locus in actuality.

Like Meyers, he also writes with grim mechanical efficiency. Practical criticism and close reading are kept to a perfunctory minimum, and language is hurried into cliché - Hemingway, we are told, "cuts a romantic figure", critics "sing his praises" and, worst of all, his son is "built like a brick shithouse".

The best feature of the book is Donaldson's engagement with American literary celebrity. He understands how the great writer's life is a monument of striving, paranoia and anguished rivalry; how competition between writers can be endless. Both Fitzgerald and Hemingway urgently craved early success, as if, like someone with a congenital heart condition, they knew that time was short. Both produced their best work before they were 30.

At first, they were extremely supportive of each other - Fitzgerald in particular, recommending his younger friend to his editor, Maxwell Perkins at Scribner's, and offering valuable critiques of what became The Sun Also Rises (1926). Slowly, their friendship was corrupted by competition. Fitzgerald knew that Hemingway was the more innovative writer; that his anti-style, stripped of all excessive ornamentation, was something new in American letters (although the hard journalistic prose of Stephen Crane was a precursor). But above all, Fitzgerald envied Hemingway's vigorous worldliness, his swagger and adventurism.

As Fitzgerald sickened, becoming less productive and more detached from reality as he entered his 30s, so Hemingway flourished, even as his own fiction became formulaic and tired. And as he flourished, he came to loathe his former mentor. In private he referred to Fitzgerald as "poor old Scott", mocking his clumsy drinking and reliance on Zelda. After Fitzgerald's death, he wrote: "What a lovely writer he was within his ignorance and lack of education, and his adoration of the rich. He should have been a spaniel."

What is unpleasant about this remark - apart from its obvious viciousness - is the way Hemingway seizes on the widespread idea that Fitzgerald was no more than a literary barbarian, an uneducated fool who by a fluke wrote a great novel. Edmund Wilson, an old friend from Princeton, was fond of saying that "F. Scott Fitzgerald mispronounces more words than any educated person [I] know". (Privately, the same Wilson, having re-read Gatsby, could also write enviously of how "much better Fitzgerald's prose and dramatic sense were than mine".)

The real hero of Donaldson's study, though, is neither of the rivalrous writers, but Maxwell Perkins, who never ceased encouraging and believing in Fitzgerald, especially during the nine unhappy years he took to complete Tender. A selection of the correspondence between them is published as an appendix to Trimalchio, an early version of Gatsby submitted to Scribner's during the summer of 1924. It reminds us how important Perkins was in smoothing it into the form we know today, encouraging Fitzgerald to rework several chapters and even questioning the position of certain commas.

Fitzgerald, who died aged 44, never matched the achievements of his early precocity. His last years, spent stumbling around Hollywood, were particularly wretched. His only consolation was the memory of his talent: he had always known he was good. "I feel I have an enormous power in me now," he told Perkins while revising Gatsby. We still feel that power today, 75 years after the first publication of a novel that is the verbal equivalent of perfect pitch.

fields.headline: Fool for love
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 32 3/4
fields.trailText: The secret diary of a provincial man: Adrian Mole, aged 32 3/4
fields.body:
Tuesday, March 28, 2000

It's Pamela! Pamela! Pamela! I keep whispering her name to myself. However, I don't whisper her surname - Pigg - though I remain optimistic that she will eventually seize the day and change her name by deed poll.

But oh, those sublime three syllables: Pam-e-la. It's Abba's music! It's a mountain stream. It's Leicester Town Hall gardens with the cherry blossom out. It's Edward Heath's laugh. It's a refrigerated Crunchie bar.

But Pigg. Pigg is brutish and short. It's slurry. It's the Queen Mother's teeth. It's that local authority prickly stuff that thrives next to inner ring roads. It's the predictable twist at the end of a Jeffrey Archer story. It's Ann Widdecombe's fringe.

Wednesday, March 29

Am I in love? I rang Nigel at work, and he faxed me a questionnaire. Some of the questions were relevant, some were not. He told me that if I answer yes to any four, then I am definitely in love. He had scribbled on the bottom that the questionnaire was obviously prepared for gay men, but it probably works for straights, too.

a) Do you think about him constantly?

b) Have you had your chest hair waxed?

c) Do you ring him more than four times a day?

d) Have you stopped going to saunas?

e) Are you afraid to have your hair cut in case he doesn't like it?

f) Are you writing overwrought poetry about nature?

I sat at the kitchen table with a cup of Kenco and a ballpoint, and quickly found out that I am in love with Pamela Pigg. I rang her at the housing office to tell her so (my fifth call of the day), but the senior housing officer, Terry Nutting, told me that he had given Pamela "compassionate leave" to have her hair done.

Nutting thinks he is such a wit. He'll be laughing on the other side of his beardy face when Pamela leaves to become my wife. According to Pammy, Nutting is an incompetent idler who sits all day in his office answering the personal adds in Private Eye.

She said, in that sweet voice of hers (like a zephyr blowing across a linnet's egg), "Terry Nutting wouldn't recognise a homeless person if he fell over one in a shop doorway."

Friday, March 31

Pamela's new hairstyle is growing on me. Not, of course, literally growing on me. What I mean is that I can now glance in her direction for seconds at a time without flinching. I still think it was a mistake to go quite so short: her head is a rather peculiar shape, and her scalp is criss-crossed with scars and the evidence of childhood accidents.

Saturday, April, 1 - April Fool's Day

At 11.30am, my sister Rosie rang to say that there was a letter at their house addressed to me from Greg Dyke, head bloke at the BBC, to say that he had read the Restless Tadpole, my epic poem, and wanted Andrew Davies to adapt it for BBC2. When I asked her to fax me the letter, she laughed her horrible laugh and put the phone down.

Sunday, April 2

So, I have reached the age of 33 - the same age as Jesus was when he was killed. Glenn gave me a card which said on the front in gothic print "Happy Birthday Single Father". There was a picture of a man with a moustache standing on a hump-backed bridge and staring down into a river - as though he was thinking about throwing himself in. Perhaps to escape his responsibilities. William had made a card at nursery school out of egg shells, lentils and crushed cornflakes. I thanked him but privately thought it was disgusting, especially when half the world is starving.

fields.headline: Secrets and spies
fields.standfirst: Mark Hollingsworth  on Stephen Dorril's revealing history of MI6
fields.trailText: Mark Hollingsworth on Stephen Dorril's revealing history of MI6
fields.body:
MI6: Fifty Years of Special Operations
Stephen Dorril
Fourth Estate, £25, 907pp
Buy it at BOL

At the heart of this exceptionally well researched book is the notion that MI6 has operated as the covert interventionist instrument of British foreign policy. In forensic detail Stephen Dorril shows how, since 1945, our secret service has engaged in what he politely calls "disruptive actions": attempted assassinations (Egypt, Libya), coup d'états (Albania, Iran, Oman), forging Swiss bank account documents (East Germany) and psychological warfare (planting of false information, secret funding of propaganda and smearing opponents).

Many MI6 officers believed in the 50s and 60s that they were the true arbiters of the national interest. As former deputy chief George Young stated: "It is the spy who has been called upon to remedy the situation created by deficiencies of ministers, diplomats, generals and priests." So, for the past 50 years, argues Dorril, MI6 has operated as a state within a state, influencing and manipulating foreign policy to suit its jaundiced view of the world.

Like most western leaders, MI6 believed that nationalism in the Middle East and Africa would inevitably lead to communism. That baseless but popular preconception, alongside a desire to protect US/UK oil interests, coloured their operations, and Dorril catalogues just how far the service was prepared to go to ensure that a government was to its liking. A recurring theme is MI6's dependence on the CIA, whose financial fire-power often gave it the edge, notably in funding European anti-communist networks and technical intelligence-gathering.

But their joint covert actions were not always successful. The 1949 attempt to overthrow the communist regime in Albania ended in abject failure. "It is a gruesome story," wrote defence specialist John Keegan, "made all the more so by the perception, apparently denied to the masterminds of subversion, that the Albanian communists were far more adept at deciding the future of their country than a bunch of romantic meddlers with a public-school education and a free supply of plastic explosives."

A more effective operation was the MI6-controlled coup in Iran, which removed the popular and moderate prime minister, Mohammed Mossadeq, despised by the British because he nationalised the Iranian oil industry. MI6 and the CIA armed, funded and directed the conspirators, and Mossadeq was ousted in 1953.

A crucial component of what MI6 calls "special political action" is the use of psychological warfare. According to Dorril, MI6 planted false stories, secretly subsidised news agencies and radio stations, manipulated opinion polls and smeared opponents by leaking forged documents. Known as "black propaganda", this was a combination of covert news management and sinister dirty tricks.

What emerges from Dorril's exhaustive research is that MI6 has been a law unto itself. A group of senior operatives were obsessed with Britain's decline as a world power, and would resort to any illegal operation to reverse it; they appeared to think foreign policy should be founded on the maxim "God is an Englishman" (as stated by ex-operative Julian Amery). Former MI6 controllers admit that the period 1948-1958 was a horrific dark age, but they claim that the service was cleaned up by Harold Macmillan and has been under ministerial control ever since. Any controversial "black arts" operation needs full Foreign Office sanction. Is this credible?

Dorril provides evidence to the contrary. He cites MI6's involve ment in the 1970 coup in Oman and, to a lesser extent, in Yemen, and relates how, in 1965, MI6 conspired with the CIA to "liquidate" Indonesia's president Sukarno. Margaret Thatcher showed no reluctance in sharing the burden of policing the world; Dorril claims that, in 1980, Thatcher "authorised MI6 to undertake 'disruptive actions' " during the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan.

More recently, former MI6 officer Richard Tomlinson described how, in 1992, he saw an internal document that described a plan to assassinate President Milosevic. Three years later, according to former MI5 officer David Shayler, MI6 plotted to murder Colonel Gaddafi by funding and running Libyan agents who opposed the regime. As more evidence emerges to support Shayler's allegation, it appears that MI6 has not quite relinquished its self-appointed role as an international enforcer of British foreign policy.

If it is to be effective in its new role - investigating the proliferation of nuclear and chemical weapons, tracking drug smugglers and countering money-laundering - MI6 will need to lift the veil of secrecy behind which it has hidden for too long. The lesson of this book is that, unless there is more transparency and accountability, a revival of unofficial bomb-and-blast foreign policy cannot be ruled out.

Dorril, co-author of books on the Profumo scandal and MI5's plot against Harold Wilson, has read an enormous amount. He has interviewed some former MI6 officers who have not spoken before; however, the book relies largely on published sources and there are some gaps. For example, there is not enough on MI6's organisation, its internal structure and how special operations were authorised.

It also suffers from inadequate editing, and Dorril has a tendency to bombard the reader with a bewildering array of facts and names. Given its ambitious scope, though, this is a remarkable achievement and an encyclopedic post-war history which any student of the secret world should read.

fields.bodyText: MI6: Fifty Years of Special Operations Stephen Dorril Fourth Estate, £25, 907pp Buy it at BOL At the heart of this exceptionally well researched book is the notion that MI6 has operated as the covert interventionist instrument of British foreign policy. In forensic detail Stephen Dorril shows how, since 1945, our secret service has engaged in what he politely calls "disruptive actions": attempted assassinations (Egypt, Libya), coup d'états (Albania, Iran, Oman), forging Swiss bank account documents (East Germany) and psychological warfare (planting of false information, secret funding of propaganda and smearing opponents). Many MI6 officers believed in the 50s and 60s that they were the true arbiters of the national interest. As former deputy chief George Young stated: "It is the spy who has been called upon to remedy the situation created by deficiencies of ministers, diplomats, generals and priests." So, for the past 50 years, argues Dorril, MI6 has operated as a state within a state, influencing and manipulating foreign policy to suit its jaundiced view of the world. Like most western leaders, MI6 believed that nationalism in the Middle East and Africa would inevitably lead to communism. That baseless but popular preconception, alongside a desire to protect US/UK oil interests, coloured their operations, and Dorril catalogues just how far the service was prepared to go to ensure that a government was to its liking. A recurring theme is MI6's dependence on the CIA, whose financial fire-power often gave it the edge, notably in funding European anti-communist networks and technical intelligence-gathering. But their joint covert actions were not always successful. The 1949 attempt to overthrow the communist regime in Albania ended in abject failure. "It is a gruesome story," wrote defence specialist John Keegan, "made all the more so by the perception, apparently denied to the masterminds of subversion, that the Albanian communists were far more adept at deciding the future of their country than a bunch of romantic meddlers with a public-school education and a free supply of plastic explosives." A more effective operation was the MI6-controlled coup in Iran, which removed the popular and moderate prime minister, Mohammed Mossadeq, despised by the British because he nationalised the Iranian oil industry. MI6 and the CIA armed, funded and directed the conspirators, and Mossadeq was ousted in 1953. A crucial component of what MI6 calls "special political action" is the use of psychological warfare. According to Dorril, MI6 planted false stories, secretly subsidised news agencies and radio stations, manipulated opinion polls and smeared opponents by leaking forged documents. Known as "black propaganda", this was a combination of covert news management and sinister dirty tricks. What emerges from Dorril's exhaustive research is that MI6 has been a law unto itself. A group of senior operatives were obsessed with Britain's decline as a world power, and would resort to any illegal operation to reverse it; they appeared to think foreign policy should be founded on the maxim "God is an Englishman" (as stated by ex-operative Julian Amery). Former MI6 controllers admit that the period 1948-1958 was a horrific dark age, but they claim that the service was cleaned up by Harold Macmillan and has been under ministerial control ever since. Any controversial "black arts" operation needs full Foreign Office sanction. Is this credible? Dorril provides evidence to the contrary. He cites MI6's involve ment in the 1970 coup in Oman and, to a lesser extent, in Yemen, and relates how, in 1965, MI6 conspired with the CIA to "liquidate" Indonesia's president Sukarno. Margaret Thatcher showed no reluctance in sharing the burden of policing the world; Dorril claims that, in 1980, Thatcher "authorised MI6 to undertake 'disruptive actions' " during the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan. If it is to be effective in its new role - investigating the proliferation of nuclear and chemical weapons, tracking drug smugglers and countering money-laundering - MI6 will need to lift the veil of secrecy behind which it has hidden for too long. The lesson of this book is that, unless there is more transparency and accountability, a revival of unofficial bomb-and-blast foreign policy cannot be ruled out. webTitle: Sinn Fein chief likely to testify

fields.headline: Sinn Fein chief likely to testify
fields.standfirst: The Bloody Sunday inquiry: special report
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein was yesterday inching closer to confirming that Martin McGuinness would appear after all at the Saville inquiry, in which he has been accused of firing the shot that sparked the army shootings of Bloody Sunday in 1972. Mitchel McLaughlin, the Sinn Fein chairman, who also comes from Londonderry, said yesterday Mr McGuinness had yet to be invited to give evidence before the inquiry. "It would seem to me inconceivable that he would refuse to go," he added
fields.body:
Sinn Fein was yesterday inching closer to confirming that Martin McGuinness would appear after all at the Saville inquiry, in which he has been accused of firing the shot that sparked the army shootings of Bloody Sunday in 1972. Mitchel McLaughlin, the Sinn Fein chairman, who also comes from Londonderry, said yesterday Mr McGuinness had yet to be invited to give evidence before the inquiry. "It would seem to me inconceivable that he would refuse to go," he added

Mr McLaughlin dismissed claims of Mr McGuinness's involvement, made in army documents, as a dirty trick of the military establishment. He said it had already destroyed evidence which might have aided Lord Saville of Newdigate's inquiry.

Mr McGuinness, Sinn Fein's chief negotiator, was last week playing for time before deciding whether to give evidence. He has refused several requests to offer a statement, and said he was waiting to see if the Saville inquiry was a genuine attempt to get at the truth before deciding.

Mr McGuinness was yesterday preparing for this weekend's Sinn Fein annual conference in Dublin. He delivers a key address tomorrow, the eve of the second anniversary of the Good Friday agreement.

Christopher Clarke QC, counsel to the inquiry, in the most sensational moments of his opening statement so far, said on Thursday an IRA informer, codenamed Infliction, had said in April 1984 that Mr McGuinness had admitted to him firing a single shot from a Thompson submachine gun which precipated Bloody Sunday. The allegation was subsequently contained in a classified message which was conveyed to the RUC, Northern Ireland Office and British embassy in Dublin.

It came with the rider that there was no verification of Infliction's claim. But it did suggest Mr McGuinness was a high ranking figure in the Provisional IRA at the time, and was involved in terrorist incidents soon after Bloody Sunday.

Mr Clarke said it was vital for Mr McGuinness to clarify his role. He pointed out that witnesses to the inquiry enjoyed immunity from prosecution.

Paratroopers shot dead 13 unarmed Catholics on an illegal rally in Londonderry on January 30 1972. Another man, who was wounded, died five months later.

Families of those who died were stunned by Mr Clarke's revelation of the Infliction document. They pointed out no one had ever alleged Mr McGuinness was involved in events before the deaths, despite there being several books and documentaries on Bloody Sunday.

They believe the move was a ploy to ensure Mr McGuinness, placed in an embarrassing situation after long campaigning for an inquiry, agreed to give evidence. Although jailed twice in the Irish republic for IRA membership, he has never faced questioning on oath about his role in the republican movement.

But Mr McGuinness gave hints of his past during his tenure as minister of education in the Stormont executive. He said last week: "I have never hidden my past from anyone."

fields.headline: Mugabe warns 'Boers' to leave
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: President Robert Mugabe yesterday said that those whites who do not agree with the new constitutional reform permitting the seizure and redistribution of their farmland without compensation should leave Zimbabwe.
fields.body:
President Robert Mugabe yesterday said that those whites who do not agree with the new constitutional reform permitting the seizure and redistribution of their farmland without compensation should leave Zimbabwe.

Addressing an election rally in the north-east of the country, Mr Mugabe also let loose at an array of other opponents. He warned opposition politicians against "starting a fire" that will consume them and declared that Zimbabweans will "rise up and repel" Britain if it interferes in the land issue.

Mr Mugabe, who discarded his usual western suit in favour of an olive-green safari outfit with overtones of combat fatigues, offered his backing to the invasion of nearly 1,000 white farms by poor blacks and veterans of the independence war. He warned whites against resisting the land seizures.

"Have we now come to the position where they [whites] are determined to fight against Mugabe and his government? he asked. "If that is the case, I will declare the fight to be on and we will win it."

"We appeal for the farmers to be reasonable... Let there be no clashes between them and the war veterans," he said. "There have been some cases of violence, but many of these have been due to resistance by the farmers."

The Commercial Farmers Union (CFU), which represents most of the country's 4,500 white farmers, said land on a total of 926 farms has been seized and at least 50 farmers assaulted. Two men arrested by police for beating one farmer so severely that he was taken to hospital were released yesterday and returned to reoccupy their victim's land.

Zimbabwe's president denied there is an anti-white policy, but several times he de scribed his country's white citizens as "Boers" and accused white farmers of bankrolling an increasingly popular new opposition movement.

The opposition has dismissed the occupations and constitutional amendment as a ploy by Mr Mugabe to whip up support ahead of parliamentary elections, scheduled for next month. The ruling Zanu-PF party faces the biggest opposition challenge of its 20 years in power amid a crumbling economy, soaring inflation and fuel shortages.

The CFU said yesterday it was still deciding its response to the constitutional reform, but that seizing farms without compensation will "render land worthless".

However, the leader of the country's war veterans association, which is spearheading the land seizures, said that they will continue despite parliament's vote to pave the way for the government to legally take over land redistribution.

"We are staying there. We are prepared to fight on," said Chenjerai Hunzvi. "We have to protect our gains. We are in the second phase of liberation. This is why there is this war."

The US said it has with drawn about $1m aid for land reform because Mr Mugabe has failed to stop the farm invasions.

"That programme has broken down in recent weeks as war veterans and their supporters illegally occupied hundreds of commercial farms in clear violation of Zimbabwean law," said the state department spokesman, James Rubin. "Zimbabwe's future and reputation are threatened by this display of political intolerance." The US called for "rational, sustainable and equitable land reform in Zimbabwe.".

The new constitutional amendment requires that, as the former colonial power, Britain compensate whites who lose their farms. A statement from the British high commission in Harare yesterday rejected the demand. "One sovereign and independent state cannot use its constitution to impose conditions on another," it said.

The Foreign Office said Britain has agreed to accept a Zimbabwean delegation to discuss the issue. The Department for International Development said the UK has spent £44m on resettlement projects since Zimbabwe's indepen dence in 1980. But as a result of the land invasions, a further £5m earmarked for resettlement is being diverted to other projects.

The violence on the farms continued yesterday with at least one other white couple assaulted. And one of the leaders of the war veterans association, Agrippa Gava, warned that reporters will also become targets if they visit the occupied farms. "If you go to these places, you will die," he said.

fields.headline: Australian coup for Milosevic
fields.standfirst: Anger in US as Canberra falls out of line by telling new ambassador to present himself to Yugoslav leaderKosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Australia has broken ranks with the west by sending a new ambassador to Yugoslavia and instructing him to hand his credentials to the head of state - President Slobodan Milosevic, who is charged with war crimes.
fields.byline: Christopher Zinn  in Sydney and  Owen Bowcott
fields.body:
Australia has broken ranks with the west by sending a new ambassador to Yugoslavia and instructing him to hand his credentials to the head of state - President Slobodan Milosevic, who is charged with war crimes.

Charles Stewart, Canberra's new man, arrived in Belgrade on Tuesday. He replaces the outgoing ambassador, Chris Lamb, who left on February 15. A time and date for formal presentation of Mr Stewart's credentials is to be discussed with the Yugoslavian foreign ministry, a spokesman for the embassy said.

Canberra's decision has provoked anger in western capitals, where a policy of sanctions and diplomatic isolation are viewed as crucial in the attempt to make Serbia a pariah state and hasten the downfall of the Milosevic regime.

Madeleine Albright, the US secretary of state, is understood to have phoned Canberra to urge the administration to drop the idea.

The Foreign Office in London was reluctant to voice any concerns. A spokesman said: "Australian diplomatic representation is a matter for them. We are aware of it. It is not causing us any worry."

The only UN embargo in force against what remains of Yugoslavia - made up of Serbia and Montenegro - is a ban on arms sales. An EU ban on commercial flights was suspended in February; EU sanctions against oil sales and financial investments go on.

There is speculation in the Yugoslav capital that the improvement in relations with Canberra has its origins in missions that visited Belgrade to seek the release of three Australian workers from the aid organisation Care, who were arrested at the beginning of the Kosovo conflict and jailed on espionage charges.

Long meetings were held between leading figures in Australia's large Serbian expatriate community, government representatives and officials from Care, to win the men's release. Malcolm Fraser, a former Australian prime minister who is chairman of Care Australia, went to Belgrade several times to meet Mr Milosevic to lobby for the men's release; they were freed late last year.

Defending its present move, Canberra's department of foreign affairs and trade said the ambassador was needed to serve the large number of Australian citizens and dual nationals living in and visiting Yugoslavia; it did not signify support for the regime.

Mr Fraser insisted that no deal had been struck to secure the aid workers' surprise release: "There were no bar gains." Asked about other nations' refusal to renew diplomatic relations with Belgrade, he replied: "I could think of nothing worse for Australia than to be bound by European Union or Nato policy. We're an independent country, we need to make our own decisions."

EU and Nato states have so far avoided creating the spectacle of a western ambassador paying homage to Mr Milosevic, fearing it would boost his credibility. Mr Stewart's presentation of his credentials to the president is bound to be on Yugoslav TV and the press.

Other governments have avoided this by not rotating ambassadors or by bringing in a lower level of representative.

The US has no diplomatic post in Belgrade; the British, French and Germans have so-called interest sections hosted by other countries and confined to cultural, consular and commercial activities.

Italy is very keen to have a full ambassador to handle the substantial issues between Belgrade and Rome. It wants a deal where a new ambassador does not have to present him or herself to Mr Milosevic.

Under the Vienna convention, a new ambassador is only an ambassador-designate until his "letter of credence" is accepted by the head of state. So Mr Stewart will be Australia's new ambassador only when Mr Milosevic accepts him.

fields.headline: Farming today
fields.standfirst:
More than 100 years since Zimbabwe was seized, white landowners face a bit of stick

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: It's often said and seldom with a sense of proportion: the boot is on the other foot; the pendulum has swung too far; the oppressed have become the oppressors.
fields.body:
It's often said and seldom with a sense of proportion: the boot is on the other foot; the pendulum has swung too far; the oppressed have become the oppressors.

Finally, over 100 years since Zimbabwe was seized, some white landowners are getting some stick. Mugabe, his corrupt and vicious regime floundering, is trying to use racism to deflect attention - hardly a new trick - and is struggling because his opposition is not falling for it. Most Zimbabweans know that he is not interested in equitable redistribution of land because he's had two decades to do it and has shown no interest so far.

There is much wrong with his rule and great opposition to it but, the way the story is told, one could be forgiven for thinking that opponents of the regime are solely concerned about the confiscation of white-owned farms; realising, I suppose, that people of empire-building stock know how a farm should be run, while black people are best at holding wooden things and singing mournfully at dusk.

As with all colonial stories, there is a revisionist version in which nothing existed before the coming of the settler: there were no Palestinians in Palestine; the Irish lived in burrows; and Africa wasn't there at all. Before the British and the Dutch came, there was just sea. Then all the uptight people in Holland, the ones who didn't have the relaxed attitudes one associates with that waterlogged land of dope-smoking cyclists, sailed southward and ploughed up the sea to reclaim rocks and build a continent. Then some rather debonair, buccaneering British joined them, and suddenly all was cultivation and infrastructure. There was some racial insensitivity to the locals but that's been resolved and we should all stop carping about it now.

It might be my imagination, but it appears that Zimbabwe's white landowners, being of British and Irish ancestry, get a much better press than do Afrikaners. Those sandy-faced Boers, with faces out of rural scenes by obscure Flemish painters, never sat well with British liberals. But the white elite of Zimbabwe, 0.6% of the population owning 70% of the land, seem to be a jolly good bunch: nice foreheads, English names, English accents even. Hardly fair to associate them with the country's history of racial oppression; some of them have only been there since the 60s, after all. They might just as easily have gone to Australia, to where some of them are now indeed headed. As with every territorial dispute, people will ask how far back in history I want to go. Well, living memory would be a start. When I read that someone bought his land in 1964, I'm inclined to suggest that he should've found out whether it was the vendor's to sell. Receipt of stolen property is not a defence. In fact, I believe it's an offence.

I am perhaps guilty of depicting this as a black-versus-white issue, in the way that large sections of the press are doing. But it so happens that white Africans have, for a very long time, done very well at the expense of black Africans. The black poor would have been no better off under black overlords, it is true. But there was no possibility of that because racial subjugation was enforced by law. It is only fair to acknowledge the role played by progressive white people in opposing that injustice, but the way the story is told by wealthy whites in southern Africa, none of them were ever in favour of it. Everyone is pleased with the new South Africa; Mandela should have thought of it years ago, but perhaps he was away somewhere.

The reason why the transition in South Africa is so popular in the northern hemisphere is that it was fostered by business, once it became clear that apartheid had ceased to be of assistance and was becoming counter-productive. And, since it was agreed that nothing was going to be seized from anyone, life for the capitalist was to carry on much the same.

I don't want to see white farmers beaten or killed in Zimbabwe, and I know some of them have been decent to their workers. But should we not remember who it was who broke the land and tilled the soil? Yes, the landowners were prepared to roll up their sleeves come harvest time and get out in the fields and do a lot of pointing, but did their hands ever bleed? You might say that the same argument applies to car firms in Britain, that Ford and BMW don't "make" anything, but rather profit from the labour of others, and I would agree with you.

It is this word "seize" that fogs the issue. By the way, the founding of the NHS involved the seizure of private assets, or so said its critics. We might not like the people who are occupying farms in Zimbabwe. The regime's opponents are rightly appalled that they are Mugabe's stooges. So isn't the point that it's not the seizure itself that's questionable, but the people doing it?

They might just as easily have gone to Australia, to where some of them are now indeed headed. As with every territorial dispute, people will ask how far back in history I want to go. Well, living memory would be a start. When I read that someone bought his land in 1964, I'm inclined to suggest that he should've found out whether it was the vendor's to sell. Receipt of stolen property is not a defence. In fact, I believe it's an offence. I am perhaps guilty of depicting this as a black-versus-white issue, in the way that large sections of the press are doing. But it so happens that white Africans have, for a very long time, done very well at the expense of black Africans. The black poor would have been no better off under black overlords, it is true. But there was no possibility of that because racial subjugation was enforced by law. It is only fair to acknowledge the role played by progressive white people in opposing that injustice, but the way the story is told by wealthy whites in southern Africa, none of them were ever in favour of it. Everyone is pleased with the new South Africa; Mandela should have thought of it years ago, but perhaps he was away somewhere. The reason why the transition in South Africa is so popular in the northern hemisphere is that it was fostered by business, once it became clear that apartheid had ceased to be of assistance and was becoming counter-productive. And, since it was agreed that nothing was going to be seized from anyone, life for the capitalist was to carry on much the same. I don't want to see white farmers beaten or killed in Zimbabwe, and I know some of them have been decent to their workers. But should we not remember who it was who broke the land and tilled the soil? Yes, the landowners were prepared to roll up their sleeves come harvest time and get out in the fields and do a lot of pointing, but did their hands ever bleed? You might say that the same argument applies to car firms in Britain, that Ford and BMW don't "make" anything, but rather profit from the labour of others, and I would agree with you. It is this word "seize" that fogs the issue. By the way, the founding of the NHS involved the seizure of private assets, or so said its critics. We might not like the people who are occupying farms in Zimbabwe. The regime's opponents are rightly appalled that they are Mugabe's stooges. So isn't the point that it's not the seizure itself that's questionable, but the people doing it?

webTitle: Bank ignores protests and shuts branches

fields.headline: Bank ignores protests and shuts branches
fields.standfirst:
As villages say farewell to local staff Barclays claims the closures were essential to avoid 'ending up in a grave like Rover'

Special report on Barclays' rural closures at www.newsunlimited.co.uk/country
fields.trailText: Barclays shut the doors of 171 of its rural branches for the last time last night despite furious condemnation of the move from customers, church leaders and politicans.
fields.body:
Barclays shut the doors of 171 of its rural branches for the last time last night despite furious condemnation of the move from customers, church leaders and politicans.

The bank, which claims in its TV adverts to be the big bank for the big world, was unrepentant about the unpopular move, insisting it was essential for its long term survival.

It also stood firm against demands that figures confirming the size of potential bonus payouts to top directors should be made public.

Some calculations would allow Matt Barrett, the chief executive, to receive as much as £30m.

In an attempt to quell the critcism, the bank insisted that despite the closures it still had the second largest branch network of all its rivals and that an agreement with the Post Office would give the 3% of its 13m customers affected an alternative way to conduct their banking.

John Varley, chief executive of the bank's retail financial services operation, insisted the closures were essential to stop the bank ending up "in a grave like Rover or NatWest".

He said: "This industry is going through a seismic change. When industry goes through changes you've got to be at the front and that's something that can be uncomfortable."

As Barclays pressed ahead with the closures, which will leave 63 towns and villages without a bank at all, Nationwide Building Society said it would install cash machines in up to 70 of the areas where Barclays was shutting and would not charge customers for using them.

And, in an attempt to tackle the issues faced by people in rural areas, government advisers are to press ministers to adopt a new charter for the countryside under which people would be guaranteed a minimum number of services, such as public transport, shops, post offices and affordable housing.

The government's own countryside agency will shortly present its far-reaching plan as a saviour for more remote communities.

With more sevices, such as magistrates courts, facing closure, its chairman, Ewen Cameron, yesterday accused Whitehall of ignoring many problems in the countryside.

"They are putting the expenses on to the people rather than shouldering the expense themselves," he said. "There's a lack of thinking of what life is like in the countryside."

The charter plan, which is likely to form a key part of a rural white paper later this year, would mean the agency, backed by the government, setting basic standards for services in rural areas.

With the countryside now a big election issue, as more people leave cities for the shires, the agency will portray a bleak picture of life in some rural areas in a survey later this month.

The Barclays closures were said to have prompted hundreds of protesters to have laid a wreath on the door of the branch at Belford in Northumberland and prompted condemnations from senior church figures.

Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, also joined the chorus of dissent.

He said: "This is going down like a lead balloon in many parts of the country, particularly when people see the juxtaposition of this alongside the rather megalomaniac scale of salary increases which have been awarded to top executives."

But the bank insisted that mass protests outside the doomed branches had failed to materialise.

"There have been no protests or sit ins. Many customers have been bringing in chocolates or champagne for staff.

"After all the negative focus, that is an amazing and reassuring gesture," a spokesman said.

The closures are part of a plan by Barclays to cut costs and axe 6,000 jobs.

While the bank is one of many to be closing branches, it has incurred more criticism than most because some of the branches are the last ones left on the high street.

Lloyds TSB, which has the largest branch network, rejected suggestions last night that it had a policy to ensure it was never the last one left, saying it was the sole survivor in 125 towns or villages.

webTitle: Valley in revolt as big bank forgets its small customers

fields.headline: Valley in revolt as big bank forgets its small customers
fields.standfirst: Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: In the same week that the Welsh actor Sir Anthony Hopkins began extolling the virtues of Barclays' bigness in a TV advertising campaign, Mairwen Cook received a letter from the bank informing her that her branch in the Ogmore valley was to close.
fields.body:
In the same week that the Welsh actor Sir Anthony Hopkins began extolling the virtues of Barclays' bigness in a TV advertising campaign, Mairwen Cook received a letter from the bank informing her that her branch in the Ogmore valley was to close.

Shock at the announcement turned to anger on reading the suggestion that she might like to try using the bank's Treorchy branch six miles away in the neighbouring Rhondda valley.

To head office it may look like six miles on the map. But the bank that likes to think big had failed to spot the Bwlch, one of the biggest peaks in this part of south Wales and a large obstacle to the elderly and those without a car.

"The Treorchy road has been closed by rockfalls in the past. Only this week it was covered in snow", Mrs Cook, a community councillor, said yesterday.

"If you haven't got a car you have either got to get yourself hiking boots and sandwiches or you face an 80 mile round trip on three buses. It takes three to four hours provided you can get good connections."

In Ogmore Vale, the largest of the valley's communities, the way in which the closure was handled has begun to cost Barclays in lost custom and public image at a time when it is spending millions on the Hopkins advert.

Like other former mining communities, it has seen a steady erosion of its commercial centre since the closure of the last pit, Wyndham Western, in 1984.

It does, however, enjoy the luxury of a second bank. Barclays customers are transferring their business there in droves.

The tiny HSBC branch, across the street from its rival, used to open three mornings a week but is now running a pilot six-hour, Monday to Friday service as a result of new business that has come its way.

A bank spokesman said the branch had picked up 45 business accounts and 300 personal accounts since the Barclays closure was announced.

Malcolm Baker, 63, who has used the Barclays branch for more than 10 years, said people in Ogmore Vale were disgusted at the closure.

"I would like to see the people of the valleys transfer their accounts to another bank," he said.

Mrs Cook, 71, believed that transferring accounts to a rival, as she had, was the only way the valley community could show its contempt for Barclays.

"That advert is about being a big bank but it is made up of an awful lot of little people. They have looked at a map and seen places but they haven't looked at the faces. I don't think they looked at their staff either. It is the staff who have had to face the anger and frustration."

Despite her criticism of the multi-million pound advertising campaign she reserved her anger for the message, not the messenger, Sir Anthony.

"I wouldn't have thought he would have known about the closures," Mrs Cook said. "We're not holding it against him."

webTitle: 'So this isn't to do with giving yourself a bonus?'

fields.headline: 'So this isn't to do with giving yourself a bonus?'
fields.trailText: Edited highlights of an interview on yesterday's Today programme between John Humphrys and John Varley, director of retail banking at Barclays.
fields.body:
Below are edited highlights of an interview on yesterday's Today programme between John Humphrys and John Varley, director of retail banking at Barclays.

John Humphrys: It is an extraordinary way to run a bank, isn't it, Mr Varley? You close all these branches and then you award yourself potentially massive, massive amounts of money.

John Varley: Well, I think there is a profound change in the way customers are banking in the United Kingdom.

JH: So that isn't anything to do with you awarding yourself lots of money, is it?

JV: Well, I'm here to talk about branch closures.

JH: Oh, you're not here to talk about the whole picture?

JV: I'm here to talk about branch closures. I'm also happy to talk about the importance of organisations such as Barclays being profitable.

JH: In order for you to get massive, massive bonuses. Is that not a factor in this?

JV: It isn't a factor in this. Profits are good because profits enable successful industries to invest, invest on behalf of customers, to offer their people good employment prospects. The profits of Barclays are owned by pension funds for the most part, representing pensioners all round the United Kingdom. So, if Barclays is successful, that's good for all its stakeholders.

JH: It's especially good for you, though, isn't it? You personally would pick up £15m if all goes well.

JV: Well, that's an assertion, an allegation you're making which I deny.

JH: When people come into this programme, they normally answer the questions that are relevant and this is a relevant question because you are closing these branches to be more profitable. And most people would say a perfectly acceptable reason, but one thing you will do with the money you save on this is pay yourselves very large amounts, including the man who runs the bank potentially £40m, and yourself £15m.

JV: I reject those numbers.

JH: What are the accurate numbers?

JV: And I reject that assertion. We're closing these branches because we need to redirect resource into upgrading other branches, integrating better telephone banking and online banking, into cash machines.

JH: But a lot of the money is going to go in very large bonuses and share options to people like yourself who run the bank. People say fine, if you run a good business, you're entitled to be properly remunerated, but £40m for the man who runs the bank? £15m for yourself? And if those aren't the right figures, tell me what are the right figures and I'll change them.

JV: Provided there are common interests between Barclays shareholders and the management of Barclays then it is good that the management of Barclays should be incentivised.

JH: Forty million quid?

JV: If we're operating, as we are, in an intensely competitive industry, then it is right that when Barclays seeks a new chief executive that it should go to one of the best managers in the world and Matt Barrett is one of those.

JH: £40m worth of management?

JV: I haven't accepted those numbers... We have to compete for the best intellectual capital in the world... We are seeking to create choice.
