fields.headline: Someone has blundered
fields.standfirst: How could such stars contrive this fiasco?Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: In Liphook and Gamlingay, Todmorden and Polperro, Moreton-in-Marsh and Kippax, Barclays Bank shut its doors for the last time yesterday. One hundred and seventy-one communities have been, as they see it, abandoned. Closures on this scale were always certain targets for outrage. But what has made it far worse is that, just as these doors were closing, reports began to appear of whacking great bonuses due to be paid in the highest reaches of Barclays Bank.
fields.body:
In Liphook and Gamlingay, Todmorden and Polperro, Moreton-in-Marsh and Kippax, Barclays Bank shut its doors for the last time yesterday. One hundred and seventy-one communities have been, as they see it, abandoned. Shops and small businesses will have nowhere to stow their takings. People who do not run cars will have long and tedious journeys by public transport to use a service which used to be round the corner. There is outrage across rural Britain. An archbishop and a bishop, even, have joined in the condemnations.

Closures on this scale were always certain targets for outrage. But what has made it far worse is that, just as these doors were closing, reports began to appear of whacking great bonuses due to be paid in the highest reaches of Barclays Bank. The chief executive, Matthew Barrett (annual salary a modest £850,000), is in line for a juicy £30m or more. His director of retail banking, John Varley, is thought likely to be taking delivery of £15m. (He says that is wrong, but coyly refuses to disclose a more accurate figure.) The chairman, Sir Peter Middleton, will not be going hungry either.

A valid case can be made for some of this. The bank needs to be profitable, since otherwise, in a competitive world, it will not survive. Because of what Mr Varley calls a "seismic" change in banking habits, branches like Liphook and Gamlingay are no longer used as they were: the resources released by closing them can be used to fund growing sectors both in conventional banking and the new electronic variety. What is more, Barclays are only doing what most of their rivals have done already rather more sneekily, closing branches piecemeal without local bishops noticing. Yet the way the programme has been handled might almost have been devised to make it look indefensible. The stars of the Barclays hierarchy, Mr Varley suggested yesterday, need to be paid these whacking great sums because if they are not they might take their talents elsewhere to the detriment of Barclays' customers. Given the bad luck or bad management which has recently seen the loss of two chief executives, that calculation may seem understandable. If they are really worth all this money, however, it is hard to see why such a sensitive exercise as the closure programme has been handled with such clumping incompetence.

The news of the intended bonus and share option hikes was always bound to break about now, in the run-up to the annual general meeting. And Mr Varley should surely have gone into yesterday's breakfast time interview better prepared than he was to deal with a famous rottweiler like John Humphrys. Did he really think he could get away, when the issue of fat cats payments was raised, with saying he was there to discuss the entirely separate question of closures? These were not the first such miscalculations. Only a few weeks ago, Barclays somehow contrived to make themselves look like public enemy number one on the issue of bank "disloyalty" payments, even though they were no more culpable than some of their rivals.

There is no bringing back the branches now lost to Liphook and Gamlingay, Todmorden and Polperro. But there is a chance for the bank's annual general meeting to ask some ferocious questions about this blundering conduct of events, and to question whether the mighty rewards due to be paid to the hierarchy are justified and defensible. Mr Barrett and colleagues ought to come in for some further examinations at least as rough as the one to which Mr Varley was deservedly treated yesterday morning.

fields.headline: Five blueprints for defunct dome
fields.standfirst: The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: Only one of the five bidders to take over the Millennium Dome when it closes in December would keep most of its much-criticised contents.
fields.body:
Only one of the five bidders to take over the Millennium Dome when it closes in December would keep most of its much-criticised contents.

Details of the multi-million pound schemes proposed for the Greenwich site by the rival consortiums yesterday showed that only Greenwich Media World was likely to keep most of the 14 zones, and it would turn the central arena into a concert hall capable of staging large pop concerts.

Nomura, the Japanese bank behind the £100m Dome Europe theme and shopping park proposal, said it would incorporate only the "best aspects" of the present set-up, but it was vague on which zones it would keep, if any. By giving visitors a taste of "the best of European culture, entertainment and innovations" in several new pavilions in the tent - and giving the public a chance to buy what they had seen over the internet - Nomura hoped to attract half as many people again as the dome has managed.

Another consortium, backed by Sky Sports, wants to turn the dome into a giant sports theme park, including a football hall of fame. It plans to keep the present timekeepers area of the play zone and to extend its games area, and to retain the shell of the body zone but to transform it into a "sporting health zone".

Most of the blueprints are business oriented, with vast multi-storey office and hotel developments to rival Canary Wharf on the opposite bank of the Thames.

The plans went on display in London yesterday, with the public being asked for their views.

The shortlist will be shortened to two or three next month, and a final decision on the winning team is expected by July.

The most unusual bid is from Legacy plc, whose chief executive, Robert Bourne, wants to use the dome as a giant incubator for a "community of new businesses dedicated to developing knowledge-based skills". He hopes the new firms setting up home in the tent would act as a catalyst for other companies to embrace the new technologies.

Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, the dome's chief executive, last month hinted that the dome might stay open for another year, but the millennium commission dismissed such speculation as "fanciful".

Lord Falconer, the minister for the dome, said: "We have five very impressive consortiums and I am delighted by the response from the private sector. The dome is now a national asset and a landmark recognised around the world.

"Through this competition we will clearly secure a sustainable alternative use for the dome so that it continues for many years to come."

Bidders with grand designs for inside job

Meridian City

The most far-reaching and expensive scheme - costing £1bn - it is also the most commercial, with plans for a complex of high-rise hotel and office blocks and a conference centre. Its property developer backers claim they would create 25,000 jobs.

Greenwich Media World

Like Meridian City, this is another bid from hard-headed property developers. Sir Robert McAlpine and the Tussaud's Group plan to create a business district around the tube station, a Sports City theme park nearby and a new theatre capable of staging pop concerts in the central arena of the dome.

Dome Europe

The most modest proposal. The dome turns into a European theme and shopping park, with the best of each country represented in various national pavilions. It also plans to turn the 15 acres around the dome into an adventure playground and interactive garden.

Legacy Plc

Entrepreneur Robert Bourne wants to spend £130m transforming the dome into a "community of new businesses" which would be a beacon to the world. His bid is chaired by Sir Christopher Benson, a former chairman of the London Docklands Development Corporation and the man who drove forward the Canary Wharf expansion in Docklands.

Sports Dome

BSkyB wants to turn the dome into "the world's greatest sports experience", featuring 50 sports, a 10,000-seater sports theatre and a football hall of champions.
fields.bodyText: Only one of the five bidders to take over the Millennium Dome when it closes in December would keep most of its much-criticised contents. Details of the multi-million pound schemes proposed for the Greenwich site by the rival consortiums yesterday showed that only Greenwich Media World was likely to keep most of the 14 zones, and it would turn the central arena into a concert hall capable of staging large pop concerts. Nomura, the Japanese bank behind the £100m Dome Europe theme and shopping park proposal, said it would incorporate only the "best aspects" of the present set-up, but it was vague on which zones it would keep, if any. By giving visitors a taste of "the best of European culture, entertainment and innovations" in several new pavilions in the tent - and giving the public a chance to buy what they had seen over the internet - Nomura hoped to attract half as many people again as the dome has managed. Another consortium, backed by Sky Sports, wants to turn the dome into a giant sports theme park, including a football hall of fame. It plans to keep the present timekeepers area of the play zone and to extend its games area, and to retain the shell of the body zone but to transform it into a "sporting health zone". Most of the blueprints are business oriented, with vast multi-storey office and hotel developments to rival Canary Wharf on the opposite bank of the Thames. The plans went on display in London yesterday, with the public being asked for their views. The shortlist will be shortened to two or three next month, and a final decision on the winning team is expected by July. The most unusual bid is from Legacy plc, whose chief executive, Robert Bourne, wants to use the dome as a giant incubator for a "community of new businesses dedicated to developing knowledge-based skills". He hopes the new firms setting up home in the tent would act as a catalyst for other companies to embrace the new technologies. Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, the dome's chief executive, last month hinted that the dome might stay open for another year, but the millennium commission dismissed such speculation as "fanciful". Lord Falconer, the minister for the dome, said: "We have five very impressive consortiums and I am delighted by the response from the private sector. The dome is now a national asset and a landmark recognised around the world. "Through this competition we will clearly secure a sustainable alternative use for the dome so that it continues for many years to come." Bidders with grand designs for inside job Meridian City The most far-reaching and expensive scheme - costing £1bn - it is also the most commercial, with plans for a complex of high-rise hotel and office blocks and a conference centre. Its property developer backers claim they would create 25,000 jobs. Greenwich Media World Like Meridian City, this is another bid from hard-headed property developers. Sir Robert McAlpine and the Tussaud's Group plan to create a business district around the tube station, a Sports City theme park nearby and a new theatre capable of staging pop concerts in the central arena of the dome. Dome Europe The most modest proposal. The dome turns into a European theme and shopping park, with the best of each country represented in various national pavilions. It also plans to turn the 15 acres around the dome into an adventure playground and interactive garden. Legacy Plc Entrepreneur Robert Bourne wants to spend £130m transforming the dome into a "community of new businesses" which would be a beacon to the world. His bid is chaired by Sir Christopher Benson, a former chairman of the London Docklands Development Corporation and the man who drove forward the Canary Wharf expansion in Docklands. Sports Dome BSkyB wants to turn the dome into "the world's greatest sports experience", featuring 50 sports, a 10,000-seater sports theatre and a football hall of champions.

webTitle: Cigarette firms face $300bn damages after verdict

fields.headline: Cigarette firms face $300bn damages after verdict
fields.standfirst: Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: A jury in Miami last night set the stage for a potentially crippling blow to the US tobacco industry by awarding a total of $12.7m in compensatory damages to three sick smokers in a landmark case.
fields.body:
A jury in Miami last night set the stage for a potentially crippling blow to the US tobacco industry by awarding a total of $12.7m in compensatory damages to three sick smokers in a landmark case.

The wider significance of the Florida verdict is that it paves the way for punitive damages to be also imposed in the three smokers' class action. Punitive damages could total as much as $300bn for the illnesses of all of Florida's estimated half million sick smokers. A liability of this size would do vast damage to the tobacco industry and could set a crippling new benchmark in other US states in the long-running legal war between health groups and big tobacco interests.

The Miami case has become the key flashpoint in the struggle between plaintiffs and the tobacco companies following the US Congress's failure last year to agree to a multi-billion settlement between the federal government, the states and the industry.

In their verdict, the jury ordered the tobacco industry to pay two of the plaintiff smokers $6.9m. A third smoker was awarded $5.8m but that award was frozen under the state's four year statute of limitations. Judge Robert Kaye said he would decide later how to handle that award.

"I'm smiling, I'm smiling, I'm smiling," plaintiff Frank Amodeo said after the verdict, even though the jury blocked his award.

Yesterday's verdict, in the class action suit that has been before the Florida courts for more than a year, concerned only the companies' liability for compensatory damages, which are meant to compensate victims for their medical expenses, pain and suffering.

However, once a jury decides that compensatory damages are warranted, it can also consider ordering punitive damages, which, as their name implies, are meant to punish. The tobacco industry has said that it fears the punitive-damage phase could bring a potentially ruinous $300bn verdict.

The implications of yesterday's decision extend far beyond the individual circumstances of the three Florida smokers, important though those are. By opening the way to the imposition of punitive damages in tobacco health cases, the verdict puts all the public health and compensation issues back on the table across the US, and makes big tobacco into an election year issue.

The Republican presidential candidate George W Bush is heavily funded by tobacco interests and is pledged to introduce widespread "tort reform" - a euphemism for passing new laws to protect Mr Bush's big business backers from the financial effects of class actions on issues such as smoking and firearms.

Judge Kaye told the jurors that he would call them back to court later this month to start the punitive-damage phase. Martin Feldman, an analyst who follows tobacco stocks for Salomon Smith Barney, said that given Friday's verdict, it appears "the jury is going to go in there with some tough attitudes about tobacco" during the punitive-damage phase.

RJ Reynolds Tobacco, the maker of Camel and Winston cigarettes, said in a statement that it would appeal against the award. "The errors committed by the trial judge during this trial are too numerous to mention, but all of them will be raised during our appeal," the company said.

The case against the tobacco companies was brought by three long-term smokers: Mary Farnan, 44, a nurse from Inglis who began smoking at the age of 11; Angie Della Vecchia, a housewife from New Port Richey, who died in 1999 at the age of 53, and who also began smoking as a child; and Mr Amodeo, a 60-year-old clockmaker from Orlando, who began at 14.

The industry argued that Mr Amodeo's cancer was caused by exposure to wood dust at his job and argued that the women suffered from a form of lung cancer not attributed to smoking. But the jury gave the three smokers close to the amounts they asked for. Ms Farnan got $2.85m and the estate of Mrs Della Vecchia was awarded $4.023m.

The same jury, which began hearing the case 18 months ago, ruled last July that five cigarette companies and two industry groups conspired to produce a dangerous, addictive product that causes 29 illnesses, including cancer and heart disease.

webTitle: School run causes third of traffic

fields.headline: School run causes third of traffic
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The early morning "school run" is responsible for almost a third of polluting traffic on the roads, the government warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The early morning "school run" is responsible for almost a third of polluting traffic on the roads, the government warned yesterday.

The education secretary, David Blunkett, said his department was looking at the problem and wanted targets to increase the levels of walking, cycling and bus use.

He called for an end to "the vicious cycle in which unsafe roads lead parents to prefer driving their children to school", saying 24,000 people were now estimated to die prematurely each year because of air pollution.

Education has a critical role to play in ensuring that young people learned to protect and respect the world in which they were growing up, Mr Blunkett told a conference in London organised by the Labour Environment Campaign. "This can do more than anything to move us away from the image of environmental protection as a fringe, liberal issue to being a core concern across society," he said. "To this end, citizenship will be a new national curriculum subject from September 2002."

The need to develop industries which could deliver sustainable ecological benefits and strong employment growth could not be ignored.

webTitle: Cigarette firms face $300bn damages after trial

fields.headline: Cigarette firms face $300bn damages after trial
fields.trailText: A jury in Miami last night set the stage for a potentially crippling blow to the tobacco industry by awarding a total of $12.7 million in compensatory damages to three sick mothers in a landmark case.   The verdict paves the way for punitive damages in a class action which could total as much as $300 billion for the illnesses of all Florida's sick smokers.
fields.body:
A jury in Miami last night set the stage for a potentially crippling blow to the tobacco industry by awarding a total of $12.7 million in compensatory damages to three sick mothers in a landmark case. The verdict paves the way for punitive damages in a class action which could total as much as $300 billion for the illnesses of all Florida's sick smokers.

In yesterday's verdict , two smokers were awarded $6.9 million and a third a record $5.8 million in compensatory damages. Judge Robert Kaye , who presided over the trial, told the jurors at Miami-Dade County Court that they must return to consider whether punitive damages should be awarded, but did not set a date. However he said it could be several weeks before they return to begin the final phase of the trial.

The Miami case is the first smokers' class-action to come to trial. The compensatory issue has been overshadowed by industry fears of a ruinous dlrs 300 billion award in the next phase seeking punitive damages for an estimated 500,000 sick Florida smokers. But under state law, a punitive verdict cannot put a company out of business.

Cigarette makers hoped to be spared some liability by asking the jury to decide based on brands smoked rather than industry behavior, but that strategy failed as the panel ruled against all companies and industry support groups. Several tobacco-growing states have rushed to protect the industry from any crippling punitive award by set ting a cap of dlrs 25 million to dlrs 100 million on the amount a company has to post as bond to pursue an appeal.

Jurors heard the life stories and microscopic details of cancer in Inglis, Florida nurse Mary Farnanaged 44; Orlando clock maker Frank Amodeo, aged 60; and New Port Richey housewife Angie Della Vecchia, who died three weeks after the initial verdict last year at 53. Both women started smoking at 11. Della Vecchia smoked for 40 years and Farnan for 29. Amodeo started smoking at 14 and kept it up for 34 years. The jury awarded Farnan $ 2.85 million and the estate of Della Vecchia $ 4.023 million. The jury also awarded $5.831 million to Amodeo, but ruled the statute of limitations had expired on his claim. Smokers' attorney Stanley Rosenblatt argued all three became addicted in the 1950s long before they became aware of the health dangers of smoking even though the industry was discovering links to disease and addiction at the same time.

The industry disputed smoking as a cause of their cancers, fought the smokers' addiction claims and said they should not be rewarded for continuing to smoke years after health dangers became widely known.

The defendants are Philip Morris Inc., R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co., Brown and Williamson, Lorillard Tobacco Co., Liggett Group Inc. and the industry's Council for Tobacco Research and Tobacco Institute.Although the jury is likely to to award punitive damages, the situation has become murkier with the Florida legislature inserting itself into the trial process. Politial leaders in Florida are considering four or five proposals to mitigate any threats to the money that Florida expects to receive from the tobacco industry's $246bn settlement with the states in 1998. Florida's share is $13bn and it has already received $2bn. Shares in Philip Morris closed unchanged on the news.

"I'm smiling, I'm smiling, I'm smiling," plaintiff Frank Amodeo said after the verdict, even though the jury blocked him from immediately collecting his award, because a four year statute of limitations has expired on his claim. "Everyone should be happy with what happened," said fellow plaintiff Mary Farnan, who was awarded dlrs 2.85 million. The estate of Angie Della Vecchia was awarded dlrs 4.023 million. The three smokers had asked for dlrs 13.2 million in compensatory damages: a total of dlrs 4.2 million in medical costs and other past and future expenses and up to dlrs 3 million each for pain and suffering.

The judge still did not immediately determine how much each defendant must pay. The jury, which deliberated for more than two days, heard the life stories and microscopic details of cancer in the three plaintiffs. Farnan is a 44-year-old nurse from Inglis, Amodeo is a 60-year-old clockmaker from Orlando, and Della Vecchia, a housewife from New Port Richey, died last year at 53, three weeks after the initial verdict. Both women started smoking at 11. Della Vecchia smoked for 40 years and Farnan for 29.

Amodeo started smoking at 14 and kept it up for 34 years. The same jury, which began hearing the case 18 months ago, ruled last July that the industry fraudulently conspired to produce a dangerous, addictive product that caused 29 illnesses, including cancer and heart disease. Around the country, juries have awarded damages to individual smokers only six times. Three verdicts were overturned, two are on appeal, and one was returned last month with a then-record dlrs 1.72 million compensatory award to a single smoker.

webTitle: Livingstone's anti-hunt bill bites the dust

fields.headline: Livingstone's anti-hunt bill bites the dust
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone's bill to outlaw fox hunting collapsed in the Commons yesterday, despite winning the surprise support of Frank Dobson who briefly put aside his differences with his rival in the London mayor election.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone's bill to outlaw fox hunting collapsed in the Commons yesterday, despite winning the surprise support of Frank Dobson who briefly put aside his differences with his rival in the London mayor election.

The bill now has virtually no chance of being revived after Mr Livingstone failed to muster enough Labour MPs to take the measure to its next parliamentary stage.

MPs, who voted overwhelmingly to ban fox hunting in 1997, will have to wait at least another year before they have the chance to vote on the issue again.

Ministers are expected to introduce a special "multi-choice" bill - with options ranging from an outright ban to leaving the law unchanged - in the Queen's speech in the autumn or after the next general election.

The hopes of anti-hunt campaigners were briefly raised yesterday when a Labour MP killed off a separate Tory private member's bill, clearing the way for a lengthy debate on Mr Livingstone's bill. Andrew Dismore used the rare parliamentary procedure of calling for the Commons to sit in private - knocking out the Tory bill when fewer than 40 MPs voted.

A few hours later, however, Mr Livingstone's bill fell apart when fewer than 100 MPs voted to allow the measure to proceed to its next stage.

The Tories claimed that the move by Mr Dismore was a ham-fisted attempt by the Labour whips to kill off both the Tory bill and Mr Livingstone's bill. Mr Livingstone's supporters initially supported this theory because they claimed he had no idea about Mr Dismore's vote.

Labour sources said they were delighted with events yesterday. They said that opening a lengthy debate had allowed the "real" opponents of hunting, such as the Labour backbencher Michael Foster, to "share the limelight" with Mr Livingstone. The bill's failure also means that Mr Livingstone will be denied further coverage on fox hunting which is helpful for his mayor campaign.

The Countryside Alliance dismissed Mr Livingstone's "anti-hunting posturing" as an attempt to publicise his London mayor campaign.

Sam Butler, its campaign for hunting chairman, called for attention to be focused on the government inquiry on hunting which is due to report next month.

webTitle: I've heard the voice of reason, and it's fruity

fields.headline: I've heard the voice of reason, and it's fruity
fields.trailText: 'Aim at excellence, and at nothing else. There's no word about the size of the audience in that brief. If it gets a low audience figure, I shall not be surprised. So the programme is protected to that extent."
fields.body:
'Aim at excellence, and at nothing else. There's no word about the size of the audience in that brief. If it gets a low audience figure, I shall not be surprised. So the programme is protected to that extent."

It seems a lifetime ago that any Radio 4 controller could write like this, and it is - 1970. Try it today and you might as well invite the press along to individually skewer you. Reading Tony Whitby's 1970 manifesto in the Radio Times on the launch of the current affairs series Analysis shows how much the broadcasting world has changed. Listening to the programme itself (which celebrates its 30th birthday next week) reminds us how little the series has.

Last week's programme asked whether obituaries for God and religion are not premature, given the growth of fundamentalism around the world. By its very subject matter, Analysis announces its difference. While so much current affairs either elaborates the news or further tabloidises it, Analysis's agenda and style veer towards that of the senior common room.

Sometimes its insistence on ploughing its own furrow can seem perverse. Last month, for instance, it asked whether the NHS has (good) enough information about treatment to be effective. Coming so soon after the lack of beds scandal, this was not the NHS's most pressing issue, and yet Frances Cairncross's interesting report threw up scores of pertinent questions enabling one to refigure the current crisis. Last week's elegant essay, too, challenged traditional divisions, arguing that the idea of science and religion as mutually exclusive is old-fashioned, with physics increasingly moving closer to metaphysics.

Now that Channel 4 has abandoned the cerebral, it is hard to think of another place in British broadcasting where you could hear a commentary as uncompromising and ornately high-brow as presenter Felipe Fernandez-Armesto's, or as fruity a voice.

Lecturer Hugh Chignell, who has studied the Analysis archive held at Bournemouth University, has argued that Analysis was always targeted at a "listening elite" whose original presenters - like its current ones - assumed that the audience was familiar with the English literary canon and history (an audacious presumption today). This was a Radio 4 programme trying to sound like a Radio 3 one, holding out against TV's populism (the "dumbing-down" accusation of that time).

Analysis still builds its argument by synthesis rather than through the knockabout polarisation of most current affairs, and resolutely resists the addition of "actuality" or human interest. Though I've got reservations about its demanding, dated style (each programme entitles me, I feel, to several ERs and a Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?), its continuing existence and unfashionable commitment to ideas need celebrating.

Women Behind Bars (Radio 4) demonstrates a more contemporary way of doing current issues. Edi Stark, producer-presenter of last year's major series on Scottish male lifers, now examines women prisoners. For this bleakly powerful new three-parter, she gained unprecedented access to Scotland's only women's jail, demonised in the media for its number of suicides.

Here are tearfully desperate, drug-dependent women, for whom photos of their children is their only thread of hope. The chief inspector of prisons said most of them should not be there, and the jail offers its own catch-22. It has a (safe) suicide block, but none of the women who want to end it will admit to feeling suicidal or they'll be sent there - and then won't be able to commit suicide.

Finally, in Peter Tinniswood's fabulously black monologue about an aged removal man The Packer (Radio 4), Michael Williams was glorious. Pompous-camp, music-hall hilarious, he sounded as though he had thought it all up himself - rare in the reading-heavy world of radio acting.

This was a Radio 4 programme trying to sound like a Radio 3 one, holding out against TV's populism (the "dumbing-down" accusation of that time). Analysis still builds its argument by synthesis rather than through the knockabout polarisation of most current affairs, and resolutely resists the addition of "actuality" or human interest. The chief inspector of prisons said most of them should not be there, and the jail offers its own catch-22. Pompous-camp, music-hall hilarious, he sounded as though he had thought it all up himself - rare in the reading-heavy world of radio acting.

fields.headline: Crusading inertia
fields.standfirst: Julie Burchill will soon be available to give more practical and personal advice as an online agony aunt. Post your problems at www.newsunlimited.co.uk/burchill
fields.trailText: Julie Burchill: Mediation is the opposite of justice, not its beautiful assistant. It is the lubricant of tyrants, helping them slip out of all sorts of corners
fields.body:
I'm always getting post that asks me to do weird things; things that would be so odd and out of character for me to do that, even though the sender invariably claims to be completely clued-up about me and my work, I can't help but think that they've got me mixed up with some stonking old party girl such as Tara Palmer-Tomkinson or Melanie Phillips.

Getting asked to write for the Erotic Review was a good one. Have I or have I not repeated at least a dozen times in as many months that erotica is to porn what a crocheted cover is to a toilet roll: deeply naff and beloved only of a) self-pleasuring women who wish they liked real sex a whole lot more; and b) haggard seat-sniffing men who wish they could do it a whole lot more. I love the way erotica thinks it's better than porn - in much the same way as "travellers" think they're better than tourists, but end up twice as loathed by the locals for being so presumptuous and tight - yet is as completely made up of clichés as the bored housewife, randy plumber and saucy schoolgirl of more honest smut. That is: ankles, buttocks, spanking, wisps of hair falling from a chignon, Victorian maids, the curtains blowing in the wind. (Sounds like an informal Wednesday night dinner party round my house, actually.)

Invitations to join a gym! Give a "Masterclass" to a top advertising agency! (For no money. As if!) To take a course and become a successful writer! (Very funny.) Last week, I was asked to be on the radio show In The Psychiatrist's Chair, in the footsteps of all my heroes - those modest, mega-talented, gentle giants, Steven Berkoff, Stephen Fry, Ken Russell and Barbara Cartland - even though my whole raison d' être in recent years has been to expose how the cult of psychiatry in general has brought us nothing but trouble, and how moaning micro-celebrities in particular should just SHUT UP and GET ON WITH IT. It does make you wonder what solar system these people have been in for the past 20 years.

Best of all, however, was an offer this week from a TV production company developing "an exciting new series for Channel 4 about reconciliation through mediation. The purpose behind the series is to show how disagreements can be amicably resolved without loss of face and to the benefit of both parties involved in the debate. Mediation is pragmatic, it does not apportion blame, no sides are taken; mediators call this the win/win approach, because it is relatively quick and inexpensive, particularly compared to a court case, and circumvents the frustration and anger that long-running disputes can cause. As a way of illustrating the power of mediation, we are seeking the help of celebrities who are themselves involved in a long-running dispute, but are now interested in reconciliation. Each programme will focus on one dispute between two famous people. Both parties will talk about the dispute from their point of view (sic), they will then come together with a mediator to reconcile their differences, or at least reach a mutually agreeable truce."

Of course, the point is that both In The Psychiatrist's Chair and this new one are exactly the sort of thing I delight in listening to/watching with my boyfriend, and shrieking, "Ohmigod! How can people bear to do that to themselves in public!" It is a rule of thumb that the radio and TV programmes we most adore are those that we would run a mile not to be on, while we'd consider it a real feather in our cap to appear on those that bore us to tears. I, for one, won't be appearing in the Channel 4 series, because I believe in what Tennessee Williams said: "Things are only ever black and white. The only people who think things are shades of grey are people who've had some of the black rub off on their souls."

If this sort of sloppy thinking had been about 50 years ago, we wouldn't have had the Nuremberg Trials but the Nuremberg Mediations, and the Jews would have been encouraged to admit to their part in annoying Hitler. In short, I believe that mediation, like mercy, is the opposite of justice, not its beautiful assistant, as it is now being painted. Time and time again, mediation and reconciliation has been used as the lubricant of tyrants, helping them to slip out of all sorts of sticky corners.

The first known mediation, don't forget, was the Judgment of Solomon, which mooted that a baby be cut in half to keep two women - both claiming to be its mother - happy! It was only when the true mother backed down that Solomon handed the baby over to her, but in real life I'm afraid this rarely happens. In real life, it's the good guy who loses out from this sort of carry-on. In Chile and Argentina, the mothers of the Disappeared still wear black, because mediation and reconciliation have let the people who dropped trades unionists from helicopters and tortured three-year-old children in front of their parents get off scot free. Surely only the dimmest IRA groupie (hi, Tone!) hasn't cottoned on yet that the big-time M&R that was the Good Friday Agreement was nothing more than a way for those brave butchers of Omagh to keep all their weapons while getting their goons out of jail. The Third Way is just a kid-gloved approach to letting business demoralise and exploit labour.

I'll never forget, also, the seminar organised by liberal Jews and Christians in an effort to reconcile with Muslims, which broke up early when the Muslims began to scream at the Jews and Christians about being blasphemers. Meanwhile, fathers are now routinely allowed to pay supervised visits to children whom they have raped, and I've lost count of the number of women killed in the process of being "reconciled" with their violent partners. A few years ago, an Asian woman was actually killed in the very police station where she had fled for protection - when her husband came after her, the police put them in their "domestic reconciliation unit" to talk it over. Ten minutes later, she was dead.

M&R represents all that is worst about the crusading inertia that so plagues us, the blundering zeal that has all but ruined the quality of everyday life here, in everything from rail privatisation to automated inquiries. In the realms of both the political and the personal, M&R is nothing more than yet another excuse for the nasty to walk all over the nice - even if they do coo, "I hear what you're saying, I know where you're coming from", as they do it.

webTitle: Gypsies feel the lash of everyone's hatred

fields.headline: Gypsies feel the lash of everyone's hatred
fields.standfirst:
Racist attacks and discrimination increase across Europe

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The plight of Europe's Gypsies has worsened dramatically in recent years, with increases in racially motivated attacks against them, and rising levels of unemployment, evictions, and even exclusions from their home towns, according to a major new report.
fields.body:
The plight of Europe's Gypsies has worsened dramatically in recent years, with increases in racially motivated attacks against them, and rising levels of unemployment, evictions, and even exclusions from their home towns, according to a major new report.

The study, by the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), also says that, in spite of greater awareness of Gypsy, or Roma, issues, the number of Roma representatives in national parliaments has dropped.

Prepared by Max van der Stoel, the OSCE's high commissioner on national minorities, the report came out yesterday on the eve of Roma day, which marks the anniversary of the first international Roma congress in 1971, when Gypsies managed to succeeded in putting their problems on the international agenda.

The report deals mainly with the countries of central Europe with high Gypsy populations: the Czech Republic, Hungary, Romania and Slovakia, but it also highlights problems in Italy, France, and other western European countries.

It looks at some appalling racial attacks, including a skinhead raid last June on a Gypsy camp near Naples. The camp was burned down, apparently in a revenge attack, after a Gypsy car-driver had seriously injured two girls riding on a motorscooter.

In Bulgaria, 14 Gypsies died between 1992 and 1998 while being held in police custody or as a result of police shootings. Many more have been beaten by police, but there have been few attempts by the authorities to investigate.

The worst violence has occurred in Kosovo in recent months where tens of thousands of Gypsies have been forced to flee their homes and take refuge in camps guarded by international troops.

The collapse of communism across the region and the fall in living standards led to widespread joblessness, with Gypsies often the first to be fired.

Drops in income forced some Gypsies to sell their homes. Others were evicted from state-owned flats when they were privatised and their former owners took them over. Private landlords often refused to let to Gypsies.

In some places they were even expelled from municipalities. In 1997 Gypsy families were banned from settling in, or even entering, two villages in eastern Slovakia, Nagov and Rokytovce, capping what one mayor called a campiagn "to get rid of local Romanies".

In 1998 the mayor of Evosmos in Greece ordered the eviction of 3,500 Gypsies from an area that had been their home for 30 years.

The report highlights one encouraging development - a housing project in Kremnica in Slovakia for Gypsies and non-Gypsies. Jobless people participated in the building of homes under the leadership of the town's non-Gypsy mayor.

Education is the trickiest area, because of constant arguments over when segregated schooling is justifiable. In the main, the use of "special schools" has been aimed at excluding Gypsies from mainstream education, but the report mentions one school in Pecs in Hungary run by Gypsies, and aimed at developing a Gypsy intelligentsia.

The report condemns involuntary segregation but says that European governments should consider supporting pre-school programmes for Gypsy infants and "booster" programmes for Gypsies in ordinary schools.

Gypsy parents repeatedly said that they wanted better access to school for their children and blamed poor attendance not on "Roma values", but on children's experience of racism when they did go to school, the report says.

Mr van der Stoel recommends several measures, from better training for the police in Gypsy issues, including the recruitment of Gypsies into the police, to laws providing for higher sentences for crimes motivated by racism.

webTitle: Europe's nomads... but not by choice

fields.headline: Europe's nomads... but not by choice
fields.standfirst:
Refugees in Britain: special report
European Roma rights centre
Roma News
fields.trailText: Why do Gypsies migrate, and how serious a problem do they present to the European Union? A collection of academic studies, to be published shortly in the Cambridge Review of International Affairs, throws doubt on many preconceptions about the so-called "exodus" of Gypsies - a term which they all reject.
fields.body:
Why do Gypsies migrate, and how serious a problem do they present to the European Union? A collection of academic studies, to be published shortly in the Cambridge Review of International Affairs, throws doubt on many preconceptions about the so-called "exodus" of Gypsies - a term which they all reject.

In the first place, the image of Gypsies as a nomadic people is very out of date. "Modern stereotypes still characterise Gypsies as a wandering people, even though settled Gypsies are in the majority," writes Sir Angus Fraser, the foremost British authority and author of The Gypsies. Their migrations since the second world war have involved greater numbers than ever before, but have been largely provoked by wars and racial attacks.

"On the whole, the extraordinary feature of Romani migration is that so many Roma are prepared to take the risks of migrating despite their lack of nomadic traditions," writes Yaron Matras, a lecturer in linguistics at Manchester University. "Only a very few Roma, if any, are genuinely nomadic in the sense that they lack any permanent dwelling."

Dr Matras also points out that Gypsy migration is "never a migration of individuals, but of nuclear families, where a decision in favour of taking the risks of migration is adopted, a collective attitude of non-confidence is involved". And it is the families that make Gypsy movements uniquely visible.

Many of the studies show how Gypsies in eastern Europe felt compelled to migrate, not because of a nomadic instinct, but as a result of persecution and extreme hardship, exacerbated by wars. The break-up of Yugoslavia produced intolerable conditions for Gypsies, above all for the 150,000 in Kosovo.

Before and during the Kosovo conflict these Gypsies fled wherever they could. But after the war, while 600,000 other refugees went home, there was no return for the Roma, who were blamed by either side while being shunned abroad.

But even without wars, most Gypsies in eastern Europe already felt alienated by what Mr Matras calls their "non-confidence and non-identification" with their countries. This attitude is very different from the feelings of Gypsies in western Europe. Mr Matras points out that there has been no noteworthy migration among the large numbers of Gypsies in Spain and Greece, even though they are free to seek jobs in richer countries within the EU, because they feel a sense of general stability and historical attachment to their countries.

The lack of confidence among eastern European Gypsies became more extreme with the creation of new nation states, particularly the Czech Republic. Meanwhile, their persecution has increased and many have tried to emigrate. Canada eventually accepted most Czech Gypsy immigrants as refugees, but most European countries, including Britain, have remained hostile.

How can an enlarged EU accommodate the large Gypsy populations in the Czech Republic and elsewhere without compromising its principles? The most pessimistic view is put forward by Mark and Matthew Braham, researchers in Switzerland, who write that "the Roma are perhaps the most singularly disliked ethnic group in the world".

They argue that EU enlargement will provide, perhaps for the first time, an "opportunity for the transformation of Roma societies from sub-marginality and exclusion to inclusion and integration within the wider European context". But they suggest that Gypsy resistance to economic and social trends will make integration impossible.

"The Roma too are a part of the problem through the persistence of a cultural style that, as an 'attractor' for victimisation, is as much a source of their marginalisation as is the majority prejudice against them."

But other scholars claim this kind of generalisation does not allow for the diversity and adaptability of the Gypsies. Martin Kovats of Birmingham University calls the Brahams' analysis "an implausibly static concept of Roma culture". He says: "The circumstances of Roma people are fundamentally determined by conditions within their own home countries and societies."

He says more research is needed, but there are still very few Gypsy academics - as the editors admit, this collection "despite all our efforts, stayed largely non-Roma dominated". Yet only the Gypsies can fully explain their people's attitudes and relationships with the rest of Europe.

 Romani East-West Migrations: Strangers in Anybody's Land is published in the Spring-Summer 2000 Issue of Cambridge Review of International Affairs, 32 Trumpington Street, Cambridge CB2 1QY.

fields.headline: The wolf at football's door
fields.trailText: Your reports of the tragic killings in Istanbul (Murder hunt as match goes on, April 7) are unusual in their fairness, compared to the bulk of English and Turkish newspapers. Reading their coverage, one is presented with a disturbing mirror image of racism, as each nation attempts to blame the other and present only one side of the story.
fields.body:
Your reports of the tragic killings in Istanbul (Murder hunt as match goes on, April 7) are unusual in their fairness, compared to the bulk of English and Turkish newspapers. Reading their coverage, one is presented with a disturbing mirror image of racism, as each nation attempts to blame the other and present only one side of the story.

In common with English teams, football in Turkey is the target for extreme nationalist and fascist groups. Many photos have featured "fans" making the Grey Wolf hand gesture associated with the fascists (the equivalent of a Nazi salute). Many have commented on the failure of the police to protect English fans. This is no surprise as most Turkish police are connected with the extreme nationalist MHP party or other right-wing/religious parties.

It is ironic that the same newspapers which criticise the behaviour of the Turkish police are also the first to reject the rights of those asylum seekers trying to escape the repression they face in Turkey. Moreover, the UK continues to sell arms to the Turkish armed forces, which, alongside the police, continue to persecute Kurds, socialists and human rights campaigners without a word of protest from the "ethical" foreign office. We believe the best response for all football fans is to campaign against racism and fascism's attempts to infiltrate the game in Turkey or England. By this means we can ensure the failure of attempts by the media to foster racism and division between English fans and those from Turkey.
Deniz Kartal
Turkish Education Group

 As a Leeds United fan I have often believed that the football authorities and people in charge of running the game have taken for granted the loyalty and passion people feel both for the game and their clubs. The decision not to allow Leeds United to respect the death of two of their supporters, or even acknowledge the family's grief, by not allowing a postponement to their European cam paign, is unconscionable. I hope when counting the profits from the next financial year, the football authorities will spare more than a second's thought to the small fiscal difference improvements on the poor organisation of events would have made to the needless injury and suffering caused to innocent people.
Eddie Rivlin
London
e.rivlin@huxley.co.uk

 Shocked and horrified as one is to learn of the untimely and violent deaths of two Leeds supporters, in what appears to be violent and racist attacks, one hopes that Peter Ridsdale, the Leeds chairman, shows as much compassion and understanding to anyone charged with any offence. He must recall that "someone is innocent until proven guilty", or doesn't that count now? Does he wish that he had made a stand against brutality and mob violence?
Mary Sanderson
Wakefield
maryelizsand@hotmail.com
fields.bodyText: Your reports of the tragic killings in Istanbul (Murder hunt as match goes on, April 7) are unusual in their fairness, compared to the bulk of English and Turkish newspapers. Reading their coverage, one is presented with a disturbing mirror image of racism, as each nation attempts to blame the other and present only one side of the story. In common with English teams, football in Turkey is the target for extreme nationalist and fascist groups. Many photos have featured "fans" making the Grey Wolf hand gesture associated with the fascists (the equivalent of a Nazi salute). Many have commented on the failure of the police to protect English fans. This is no surprise as most Turkish police are connected with the extreme nationalist MHP party or other right-wing/religious parties. It is ironic that the same newspapers which criticise the behaviour of the Turkish police are also the first to reject the rights of those asylum seekers trying to escape the repression they face in Turkey. Moreover, the UK continues to sell arms to the Turkish armed forces, which, alongside the police, continue to persecute Kurds, socialists and human rights campaigners without a word of protest from the "ethical" foreign office. We believe the best response for all football fans is to campaign against racism and fascism's attempts to infiltrate the game in Turkey or England. By this means we can ensure the failure of attempts by the media to foster racism and division between English fans and those from Turkey. Deniz Kartal Turkish Education Group  As a Leeds United fan I have often believed that the football authorities and people in charge of running the game have taken for granted the loyalty and passion people feel both for the game and their clubs. The decision not to allow Leeds United to respect the death of two of their supporters, or even acknowledge the family's grief, by not allowing a postponement to their European cam paign, is unconscionable. I hope when counting the profits from the next financial year, the football authorities will spare more than a second's thought to the small fiscal difference improvements on the poor organisation of events would have made to the needless injury and suffering caused to innocent people. Eddie Rivlin London e.rivlin@huxley.co.uk  Shocked and horrified as one is to learn of the untimely and violent deaths of two Leeds supporters, in what appears to be violent and racist attacks, one hopes that Peter Ridsdale, the Leeds chairman, shows as much compassion and understanding to anyone charged with any offence. He must recall that "someone is innocent until proven guilty", or doesn't that count now? Does he wish that he had made a stand against brutality and mob violence? Mary Sanderson Wakefield maryelizsand@hotmail.com

fields.headline: Ode to Martha Lane Fox
fields.trailText: Such a sense at the end of this wet and windy week that spring is here, summer is just round the corner, and things are getting better every day. My magnolia is in full bloom, Winifred Robinson has reappeared on the Today programme, and now a plump parcel arrives bringing Wisden. I turn as ever to its beautifully crafted obituaries.
fields.body:
Such a sense at the end of this wet and windy week that spring is here, summer is just round the corner, and things are getting better every day. My magnolia is in full bloom, Winifred Robinson has reappeared on the Today programme, and now a plump parcel arrives bringing Wisden. I turn as ever to its beautifully crafted obituaries.

Thus: "Worthington, Primrose, who died on January 23, 1999, aged 93, was the last surviving grandchild of WG Grace. She remembered sitting on his knee and tying ribbons in his beard." It has been a melancholy year for the deaths of great cricketers. The West Indians Malcolm Marshall, Conrad Hunte and Sylvester Clarke; our own Godfrey Evans and Cyril Washbrook; and the lesser known but wonderfully talented New Zealand left-hander, Martin Donnelly, whom I once saw playing an innings at Scarborough of no more than 30 or so which nonetheless touched perfection. But as always there is special poignancy in some of the minor figures.

Leonard Arthur Butterfield played in just one test for New Zealand, failing to take a wicket and being lbw to Bill O'Reilly for nought in both innings: "this left him on a list of 10 players (beginning with GF Grace and ending, at present, with Gavin Hamilton) to be out for a pair in their only test." He was later chief stipendiary steward for the New Zealand Trotting Conference. Professor John Joseph Maria Figueroa, Wisden records, "was one of the most arresting and improbable figures in the cricket press box. With his long white beard, he looked like a child's conception of God" . Even the late EW Swanton wasn't quite in that class.

Though mildly sneered at by Wisden, those of us who are certain that this is still the 20th century and the second millennium have a powerful new adherent: the BBC. Tony Blair, a reporter told us the other day, has created more peers than any other PM this century. Since he's the only PM of what is wrongly taken to be the 21st century, that statement must have applied to the 20th. Welcome aboard, BBC. As for the latest list of appointments of peers though it was right to roll the Tory advantage back, they still look too much like the work of a rigger. Rigger Blair is how I increasingly think of him. Having tried and failed to rig the outcome of elections in Wales and London, he now hopes to rig a "reformed" House of Lords in which he will rarely be beaten; and even when beaten, can denounce the event as undemocratic because the Lords, as he has rigged it, will have no proper mandate. There's a shop round the corner from me called a poodle parlour. If present trends continue there will soon be one round the corner from Downing Street too.

Three hundred and nineteen complaints (all of which failed) were lodged against the ad for the internet bookshop Bolcom which shows a couple, naked and intertwined, reading books. I never got round to lodging what would have been the 320th complaint - but on very different grounds from the others. My objection is this. You can see the name of the book he is reading: the cover plainly says "Football"; but you can't see the cover of hers. This is blatant discrimination. Indeed, after prolonged study of the ad in question - purely, you understand, in the hope of resolving this point - I have come to the sad conclusion that he is not really reading at all: merely holding the book in front of him and pretending to read while thinking of other things, bimetallism, for instance, or the state of the zinc industry. How wrong to parade such an example on hoardings where young readers are likely to see it.

And now for my weekly dose of John Betjeman, featuring this time part of a poem discovered last Saturday morning which he presciently wrote well ahead of recent events.

Martha Lane Fox, Martha Lane Fox, so sweet, so discreet, in your e-cotton socks. How we cherished your cool and approved your aplomb! How disarming, how charming, your Last Minute.com!

But Martha Lane Fox, Martha Lane Fox, so varnished and tarnished by stock market shocks. Once your shares were quite massively-over subscribed. Now no one is buying, not even if bribed.

Martha Lane Fox, Martha Lane Fox, as sprightly as Spring and as fragrant as phlox: Whatever becomes of your internet stocks, Whatever your fate in the school of hard knocks, We hope you will never be shunned like the pox. (We trust that this view is not heterodox).

Martha Lane Fox, Martha Lane Fox, let nobody say you are now on the rocks. Fling off your foes with the strength of an ox; Spring back to life like a jack-in-the-box; Open the throttle, away with the chocks: Soar back to success for us, Martha Lane Fox.

A poet laureate writes: I think you should warn any reader who has persisted thus far that this work may well be a forgery.

Nightingales, the Daily Telegraph warns us, no longer occur over much of Britain. But that was always the case. The nightingale, a Victorian reference book assures us, is unseen in Wales, Scotland or Ireland and does not visit Cornwall or even West Devon, nor does it cross the Trent. This last information seems unnervingly precise. Are we to suppose that a nightingale spotting the Trent instantly heads off for somewhere more salubrious? West Bridgeford, yes; Nottingham proper, no? A famous popular song - which I will not quote verbatim for reasons explained last week, but merely paraphrase - asserts that a bird of the luscinia class gave throatsome utterance in a London square which share it name, though not its pronunciation, with a celebrated US university. The lyricist (Eric Maschwitz) knew his ornithology. Had he alleged that a nightingale sang in, say, the City Square, Leeds, or Forster Square, Bradford, nobody would have believed him and his song would by now be forgotten.

webTitle: More burble, less squeak on good-listening menu

fields.headline: More burble, less squeak on good-listening menu
fields.trailText: Why the wealthy love London | Caught in a jam
fields.body:
Sara Cox took over the Radio 1 breakfast show this week, and every bus shelter in the land seems to have a life-sized poster of her saluting, with the legend: "Going To Bed Early For Britain", ironically implying that she was making a huge personal sacrifice to perform a vital public service.

Which she does, I suppose. I listened to her show a few times this week - it was good to hear the glottal stop back on national radio, as in "he were in t' basement" - and she does it very well. What she does is burble. She rabbits on about a concert, or someone she's met (of the Sun's show biz correspondent, " 'E seems ter think 'e's the celebrity," an illusion shared by many hacks), or what was on TV the other night. It's amiable, affable, background noise. Lying listening in my bath, I felt like a chap in a wine bar waiting for someone, while eavesdropping the next table which is full of young women straight from the office. Usually there's one who's sharper and wittier than the rest, and she does most of the talking.

It's perfectly pleasant, in-one-ear-and-out-the-other stuff, a million miles from the elaborate, structured creativity of a Kenny Everett. I think we should have more burbling in this country. Life gets more hectic and demanding, and there are times when we need pointless blather. It's like a sensory deprivation tank, designed to strip away our stresses and tension. Other people use mobile phones for the same purpose: the endless, "so I'm like, and he goes..." is actually rather therapeutic.

 Ms Cox comes from Bolton, where you used to be able to find plenty of UCPs, a chain cafe whose acronym stood for United Cattle Products. They sold to generations of cheerful eaters the parts of the cow which polite cows don't talk about. My old Manchester colleague John Hudson tells me of once going into a UCP in Preston, smartly dressed for an interview. "'Steak and cowheel,' I said to the waitress.

"'Do you know what it's like luv?' she asked me." (This reminds me of asking for an andouillette, a chitterling sausage, in Paris. "Yuh know what is een eet?" asked the astonished waiter.)

 On Tuesday I was one of the judges in the Citizenship Foundation youth parliament awards, sponsored by Motorola. The four finalist schools were all very good, and the winner - to be announced in a day or so - outstanding. My only niggling anxiety was, do we really want our young people to replicate parliament and parliamentary procedure? The demented confrontational style, the knock-down argu ments, and the obsession with point-scoring make my job as a sketch writer much easier. I cannot imagine having to sketch, say, the European parliament or the US senate. But as a means of getting people to consider all sides of a matter, to assimilate difficult and complicated arguments and facts, it seems fairly hopeless. Still, I got to sit next to the other Theresa May, the one who isn't a porn star. (I mentioned sitting next to the nude soubrette on a train a fortnight ago). I tried keying Theresa's name into an internet search engine, but instead of saucy pictures, I only got some stuff about Conservative education policy.

 All the comment on the decision by the French "Marianne" model Laetitia Casta to live in London, which she might or might not do - she's turned very coy on the subject - has concentrated on comparing the cost of living in the two cities, while the French complain that British property prices are ridiculously high, that the tube doesn't work, and the NHS is woefully inadequate.

All of which is true, but it does miss the point. Since Mlle Casta is very highly paid, she can afford the property, can take taxis everywhere, and would no doubt have private health insurance. This is the real legacy of Margaret Thatcher: she created a land in which the rich pay less and less tax, while the poor are obliged to use the increasingly underfunded public services. Of course wealthy people love living in London: to them it's a wonderful place with everything their hearts could desire available for purchase. Pity about everyone else.

 The other day I was stuck in a traffic jam about half a mile long. It was mid-morning, an unusual time for heavy traffic near us, so I wasn't surprised that it was caused by a car which had parked on double yellow lines just at a traffic light. The effect was to close down one of the two lanes, halving the speed of the flow. There's a dry cleaner round there, so no doubt the driver had popped in, then found he or she had lost their ticket, so it took 20 minutes to find the garments.

Naturally the car had its hazard flashers on, since drivers who do this kind of thing seem to think that this makes their car dematerialise. The result was that hundreds of people were delayed by up to 10 minutes each, to save some idiot the few moments it would have taken him to find a proper parking space.

This kind of thing goes on everywhere. Why don't councils take up my simple idea of mobile traffic wardens on motorbikes? They would spot the jams, race ahead of the traffic and have the offending cars ticketed (I suggest fines of £100, rising on a sliding scale) while the owner emerges from Snappy Snaps or the 8 Til Late Mini-Mart, protesting, "But I was only there for a minute!" The benefits would be enormous, and a year's fines in most council areas would fund a whole set of playing fields for this poor, spindly, pigeon-chested generation of schoolchildren.

 I'm delighted to see that the Ann Summers chain of sex shops has taken over the outlets belonging to the failed Knickerbox chain. I hope very much that the deal includes the boutiques at big railway stations. Chaps going home late after staying too long in the pub with their mates can attempt to placate the wife with a sex toy, marching past the queue, boldly waving a vibrator as they shout briskly, "d'you mind, I have a train to catch". Instead of a copy of Popular Caravanning, they'll get on the train with an Ann Summers box marked: "with realistic motorised suction action", or else "French maid outfit, XL". And they say commuters are boring.

fields.headline: Taxing issue of the euro
fields.trailText: I agree with Hugo Young (Comment, April 6) that the constraints of both Labour and the Tories have blinded them to joining the euro. Both parties, however, operate under another set of constraints which have conspired to bring the pound to its present destructive level.
fields.body:
I agree with Hugo Young (Comment, April 6) that the constraints of both Labour and the Tories have blinded them to joining the euro. Both parties, however, operate under another set of constraints which have conspired to bring the pound to its present destructive level.

An unwritten consensus on underfunding the NHS and essential infrastructure investment has contorted our crucial economic and trading relationship with euroland. When preaching the merits of a third way to France and Germany, Tony Blair makes much of the UK's lower add-on social costs. That differential, however, has been partly won by allowing NHS patients to die or suffer unnecessarily. The bipartisan short-termism in infrastructure has left the UK lagging behind on road and rail capacity, rail safety, school buildings, water and sewage.

This sacrifice of fiscal tools to dampen economic demand has forced Bank governor, Eddie George, into the "one club" interest rate trap, forcing up the pound.

The two main parties should call a truce on tax cutting. A depoliticised approach would help politicians of all parties to get Blair and Hague off the tax hook. Were the UK to embark upon a health and infrastructure spending programme, with appropriate tax levels, Eddie George could discard the "one club" straitjacket. Lower interest rates would reduce artificial upward pressure on the pound and the process of convergence would become easier.
Ken Daly
Pro Euro Conservative party

 It is instructive to watch Hugo Young twisting economic facts to support his obsession that Britain is doomed unless we join the euro.

Britain's long-term interest rates are lower than Germany's for the first time in 40 years, reflecting greater market confidence in Britain's monetary policy. The weakness of the euro against the pound is partly because of capital flooding out of the eurozone into Britain.

Many commentators, including the European Central Bank's chief economist, Otmar Issing, are concerned about the viability of Emu. Britain is better off than the continent, so long as we dodge the Emu bullet and do not shackle ourselves to uncompetitive economies with bankrupt pension systems.
Dominic Cummings
Business for Sterling

 Hugo Young demonstrates how much democracy has been undermined. Britain should join the euro because the people decide to, not because it's good for businesses and the free market.
Karl Osborne
London
karl.osborne@inra.co.uk

fields.headline: It's still the beautiful game
fields.standfirst: Even after this week's tragedy, it was right for the match to go on
fields.trailText: Mark Lawson, a Leeds fan among other things, on why it was right for the Galatasaray-Leeds quarter-final to go ahead...
fields.body:
During the recent relentless success of Manchester United, my only consolation, as for many supporters of other teams, was the growing certainty that the Lancashire club had done some kind of pact with the devil. A suppurating portrait would eventually be found in the attic of Sir Alex Ferguson's mansion or Brooklyn Beckham's daddy would one week trot on to the pitch revealing not a new haircut but sulphur smoking from his sponsored boots.

Regrettably, this season the theory has had to be revised. The club which has increasingly seemed to have done some terrible deal with destiny is another - my own, Leeds United. Having survived a plane crash which almost wiped out the team on the way back from a London match, Leeds began this year to play attractive, attacking football. At Christmas, they were top of the Premiership.

By March, they had four members of the first team squad awaiting trial on charges relating to an alleged racist assault outside a nightclub. Now (in an incident unrelated to the first except in the sense of continuing a run of bad luck and publicity), they have two fans dead after a pre-match encounter in Istanbul. The football team you support isn't (or shouldn't be) a matter of choice - it follows from where you grew up - and the allegiance should remain almost unbreakable; but Leeds is currently an uncomfortable club to support. There are possible outcomes to the forthcoming trial and the investigation into the Turkish deaths which might make it unbearable.

It is not to detract from the tragedy of the families involved to suggest that the tabloid press's presumption of sanctity about the men is usually unwise on the first day of a murder investigation. But - as we wait for those results - a phrase much used on Thursday and Friday's radio phone-ins seems to me to be where the cross should go in this moral spot the ball. Objecting to the decision by the game's ruling bodies that the match should go ahead, Leeds fans complained that this sent the message that "football is more important than life".

This heartfelt objection misses several points. There was a strong practical reason for the game to proceed. Whether or not football hooliganism was connected with the Istanbul deaths, it would soon get through to psychopathic soccer fans around the world that a reliable way of allowing your side a bye to the next round was knifing a few of the rival fans to death the night before. (Although widely presented as mindless violence, a significant proportion of football hooliganism has been an attempt to force the abandonment of matches.)

But, apart from this, the view that the tie should have been moved or removed is illogical. Football is a leisure industry with occasionally lethal consequences. In this, it resembles aviation. Within minutes of the mass murder over Lockerbie, the same airline was flying holiday-makers to the Caribbean. No one objected that vacations were more important than life. At least two Premiership matches this season have started late because of fatal motorway pile-ups. In a strict factual sense those passengers died for football, but it was accepted that the match should proceed, though delayed to allow the safe transport of other fans. A distinction has to be drawn - morally and practically - between incidents which happen at matches (Heysel, Hillsborough) and terrible deaths external to them.

And the brutal truth is that football is more important than those lives. In the list of recent Leeds misfortunes, I omitted the fact that they have lost their last four matches and seem likely to end the season as briefly beautiful losers. The media consensus on Thursday was that football no longer mattered after the Istanbul killings. It's what people say after football tragedies. But is it true? Can I really be the only Leeds fan who felt disappointed that they lost on Thursday night and began to calculate the results in the return leg which might yet see them to the final. Even after blood is spilled, it's in the blood.

It's because the result always matters that working people pay large sums of money to follow their club to a mid-week fixture in distant Turkey. It's because the result always matters that young men are paid huge sums of money which they spend in nightclubs and elsewhere and become a magnet for attention, with all that may bring.

As with recent publicity over the home lives of footballers, the events involving Leeds United this season show a collision between the new image of football - the "beautiful game", family orientated, attractive, even cerebral - and the potential ugliness underneath.

What's especially upsetting is that, while many unpleasant men with unprintable views have run football clubs in the past, the current Leeds set-up has in chairman Peter Ridsdale and manager David O'Leary prize examples of the sensitive, enlightened, media-friendly, hooligan- hostile new football establishment. Kept awake in Istanbul by shock and duties with the bereaved, they will also have had sleepless moments this week and earlier this year that the thug culture which has blighted football in the past still remains.

But, despite all this, I want Leeds to beat Aston Villa tomorrow - and Manchester United to lose catastrophically to Middlesbrough on Monday - and this I suppose is the problem from which all football's other problems follow. The match does always matter.

fields.headline: Underside
fields.trailText: At the sign of the white vulture, the Barclays public relations deathwish continues. The rap sheet to date: closure of 172 branches; charges for non-customers who have the temerity to use its cash machines; a hugely expensive television advertising campaign extolling its own virtues; and a massively lucrative bonus plan for its directors, including new chief executive Matthew Barrett
fields.body:
At the sign of the white vulture, the Barclays public relations deathwish continues. The rap sheet to date: closure of 172 branches; charges for non-customers who have the temerity to use its cash machines; a hugely expensive television advertising campaign extolling its own virtues; and a massively lucrative bonus plan for its directors, including new chief executive Matthew Barrett. Now the countryman's friend is splashing out more money on sponsoring a seminar. Topic? The need to tackle financial exclusion, the very problem it has just exacerbated nationwide. Martin Mosley, the bank's director of consumer and community [sic] affairs, is speaking at the event, which is being staged by the New Policy Institute think-tank. Should you wish to grill Mr Mosley about the valuable contribution his bank is making to life in scores of soon to be bankless towns and villages, head down to the New Connaught Rooms, Holborn, London, on Wednesday.

 A reminder that our super-socko competition is alive and kicking for anyone who wishes to join the pantheon of winners, of which there are two to date. The rules are: you nominate a product/company/entity every word of whose title is inaccurate/misleading/a lie - e.g. "National Health Service". To spice things up, and make our competitions more, er, competitive - thus avoiding an Office of Fair Trading investigation - a parallel prize-giving is on offer. The rules are: you nominate a product or service that - being too convenient, useful and customer friendly - has, naturally, been or is being withdrawn. Examples: eurocheques, the West London Air Terminal, British Visitors' Passports, open-platform buses...

 On the subject of transport, Abbey National has just lashed out £1.44bn on Porterbrook, the rolling stock leasing company formerly owned by Stagecoach, the bus operator. A deal, one would think, to put a smile on the face of Abbey's wholesale markets supremo Gareth Jones. In his spare time, we understand, Mr Jones follows the craft of his illustrious namesake John Luther, alias Casey, tooting the whistle and generally reliving the great age of the train. Don't expect Porterbrook back on the market any time soon, but keep an eye open for changes to the fleet - observation platforms, cow-catchers, Pullman cars...

 Stagecoach itself, meanwhile, is bringing home its forgotten army of north-country bus drivers who have been keeping the company's southern operations ticking over during the winter months. In Cheltenham, Catford, Lewes and Eastbourne, Lakeland accents have rung out from behind the wheel, but the northerners - who have been billeted in hotels with weekend trips home on Branson bullet trains - are now needed back at base as the tourist season kicks into gear. The busmen's holiday is over - for now. Here's hoping Stagecoach has trained some southern recruits over the winter;.

 No such gentle leave taking at Charles de Gaulle airport in Paris, where Air France pilots came close to mutiny this week over plans to make them - horreur! - speak English. The airline's anglophone policy collapsed on Thursday after just 10 days, with the French government weighing in on the side of the mother tongue, declaring, according to Reuters, that "it will continue to promote multilingualism in flight communications". That ought to do wonders for air safety. The shock waves from CDG's brief flirtation with the hated tongue of perfidious Albion and the despised Americains reached - where else? - Quebec, where minister Louis Beaudoin excoriated the intolerable threat of fewer aeroplane accidents: "If France lays down its arms, imagine what will happen elsewhere." Cheer up, matey - you've still got the "e" on Concorde.

 To end where we began, blockbuster writer Arthur Hailey anticipated Barclays' problems 25 years ago in a novel called The Moneychangers, set in a large midwestern American bank. After an executive decision to shrug off its minimal social responsibilities and concentrate instead on making even larger profits - sound familiar? - the bank is besieged by protesters. An emergency board meeting is called at which the fictional public relations chief lashes the directors, telling them that had he decided to blow the whole year's PR budget on one thing to make the bank look bad, "I couldn't have done a better job than you guys have managed unaided". Sort of rings a faint bell, doesn't it?
