fields.headline: Nuclear street cred
fields.trailText: You hardly needed to scour the pavements around Aldermaston to find material for your article on the Atomic Weapons Establishment (Nuclear papers found on street, April 5). I do not know precisely which documents you have seen, but none of the issues raised are new and most of the information is already in the public domain.
fields.body:
You hardly needed to scour the pavements around Aldermaston to find material for your article on the Atomic Weapons Establishment (Nuclear papers found on street, April 5). I do not know precisely which documents you have seen, but none of the issues raised are new and most of the information is already in the public domain. Safety-related incidents are extensively published on the AWE website and options to amalgamate Aldermaston and Burghfield (and these as yet only options) have been made public before.

You have also drawn the wrong conclusions from what you have read. There is, in fact, no new nuclear weapon system under development at AWE although, as we announced in the Strategic Defence Review in 1998, AWE maintains a capability to produce a successor to Tri dent should this be required by the government. That decision point is still some way off.

There is nothing new about secondments of Atomic Weapons Establishment staff to US nuclear laboratories. There are no secondments with the French, although there are discussions from time to time between British and French nuclear scientists.

It is also wide of the mark to suggest that BNFL, or indeed any of the other AWE parent companies, would pay for weapon development. Finance for the weapon programme remains the responsibility of the MOD. The suggestion that BNFL won the contract to operate AWE by offering a secret promise to develop such a weapon system is frankly nonsense.
Baroness Symons
Minister of state for defence procurement

fields.headline: Face the music
fields.trailText: If the intemperate head of Classic FM, Roger Lewis, seriously thinks the Classical Brit Awards will perform any useful evangelising role in its popularising of the already popular, this music critic issues a challenge to him. Give me an hour a week on your radio station and I'll show you what popularising classical music should be all about.
fields.body:
If the intemperate head of Classic FM, Roger Lewis, seriously thinks the Classical Brit Awards will perform any useful evangelising role in its popularising of the already popular (Classical in a modern style, Friday Review, April 7), this music critic - not, I hope, grey-faced, and notoriously rarely grey-suited, but simply and enduringly passionate about music - issues a challenge to him. Give me an hour a week on your radio station - no rules about what can or can't be played - and I'll show you what popularising classical music should be all about.
Stephen Pettitt
London
editor@theartspages.com

 It seems the government has capitulated to customs and excise's insistence that our national museums and galleries should levy a minimum entrance fee of £1 if they are to be allowed to recover VAT (Report, April 4). Thus, even though free admission is New Labour policy, customs has had the final say. Who actually runs the country?
Sir Hugh Leggatt
Vevey, Switzerland

 Barclays shuts more than a hundred rural branches with consequent job losses (Letters, April 7) - and where is the Countryside Alliance?
Ian Williams
Lichfield
ian.williams@bigfoot.com

 Mention of Puccini's turan. etc (Letters, April 6 and 7) recalled the case, in the 50s, of a Boston printer who provided a local choral society with a batch of programmes for their forthcoming performance of a worked called Massachusetts in B Minor.
Robin Dow
Sheffield

 Why don't the Russians call in the Changing Rooms team to update the Mir space station (Mission to stop Mir sinking to earth, April 5).
Roy Payne
King's Lynn, Norfolk

fields.headline: Offshore net
fields.trailText: The £250,000 penalty imposed on the Demon internet service provider (Cyberspace faces up to its Demon, April 1) has already had effect: a gay current affairs website has shut because of the possibility of trouble. But there is an answer.
fields.body:
The £250,000 penalty imposed on the Demon internet service provider (Cyberspace faces up to its Demon, April 1) has already had effect: a gay current affairs website has shut because of the possibility of trouble. But there is an answer. Our charity website was closed by the service provider earlier this year because, among reports of what we consider to be false convictions of women presumed to have murdered infants, there was a "guest item" the Police Federation considered libellous. Now the www.portia.org.uk site has reopened as www.portia.org (based in the US) but containing the same material.
Ken Norman
Portia Campaign
kenportia@beeb.net

fields.headline: It's a cracker
fields.trailText: Simon Hoggart's Diary item about cream-cracker sandwiches (Saturday Review, April 1) brought on a wave of nostalgia.
fields.body:
Simon Hoggart's Diary item about cream-cracker sandwiches (Saturday Review, April 1) brought on a wave of nostalgia. During the late 1940s and early 1950s in Sheffield my mum used to make us a teatime treat - her cost-effective version of a vanilla slice - cream crackers sandwiched together with thick, cold custard all coated with glace icing. We also loved cream crackers spread with golden syrup. These I still love, but now I succumb to notions of healthy eating and substitute honey for treacle.
Margaret Day
Wetherby, W Yorks

fields.headline: Wittering on
fields.trailText: Mike O'Brien MP writes: I was amused to be called a "neo-fascist" and a "wittering bully" by Hugo Young for my somewhat prosaic reference to the "democratic deficit" in Britain, that "democracy must mean something" and that politicians are elected to govern in the public interest (Poodles or politicians? April 4).
fields.body:
Mike O'Brien MP writes: I was amused to be called a "neo-fascist" and a "wittering bully" by Hugo Young for my somewhat prosaic reference to the "democratic deficit" in Britain, that "democracy must mean something" and that politicians are elected to govern in the public interest (Poodles or politicians? April 4).

What was over the top was to say that if Labour MPs do not vote against their government they are "crawlers for office whose reforming faculties have been lobotomised". Only if they do as Hugo tells them will they be regarded as "serious politicians prepared to acknowledge that ministers have for the last year been acting in bad faith." Now, that's bullying. Several colleagues have commented that if they ever had any doubts, the article resolved them to vote with the government.
Mike O'Brien MP
Under secretary, Home Office

fields.headline: Waste not, want not
fields.trailText: Wouldn't the answer to the amount of food thrown away by supermarkets (Scandal of the food Britain throws away, April 4) be to produce less in the first place? As it is, all the shops are vying with each other's superfluity, while 24-hour shopping means the shelves have to be continually full.
fields.body:
Wouldn't the answer to the amount of food thrown away by supermarkets (Scandal of the food Britain throws away, April 4) be to produce less in the first place? As it is, all the shops are vying with each other's superfluity, while 24-hour shopping means the shelves have to be continually full.

It wouldn't hurt if food items actually did sell out before their expiry date; nor if customers were disappointed at not finding their favourite brand and actually had to buy a substitute or do without.
A Neuhaus
Harlow, Essex

 It is true that charitable food donations perpetuate poverty. None the less, any recommendation to discontinue them is bad advice.

First, such a "strategy" makes pawns of the poorest and hungriest people. They must starve in the name of a theory of social change.

Second, it will not work. Governments have shown themselves willing to tolerate mass levels of poverty for long periods. The homeless and the hungry do not vote.

The solution is an expanded, efficient and well-supported scheme for the collection and redistribution of "waste" food; plus a reorientation of government priorities, to make the elimination of poverty the number one goal.
JT Winkler
Food & Health Research
wink@talk21.com

 If soup kitchens can use surplus food to make nutritious soup, then surely the government, in partnership with food stores and international charities, could set up processing plants to convert this surplus into dried soup powder, for storage and distribution to starving peoples?
Margaret Ogden
London
Mjogdenx21@cs.com

fields.headline: Targeting Mr Prodi
fields.standfirst: The Euro-plot that may not have beenThe European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: There can be no denying that the European Commission has plenty on its plate at present. Yet despite their daunting workload, the college of unelected commissioners, chaired by the unelected Romano Prodi, spent much of the week tackling a more pressing issue. Is there a secret plot to depose Mr Prodi?
fields.body:
There can be no denying that the European Commission has plenty on its plate at present. There is the ambitious, some might say Napoleonic enlargement process; there is the requirement of the recent Lisbon "dot.com summit" that all EU citizens be electronically linked to each other at all times via the internet; there is the continuing, vexed dispute about whose cows - French or British - are the maddest; and then there is the intergovernmental conference. This atrocity, if Eurosceptics are to be believed, will finally confirm the utter destruction of Britain's sovereign independence, when it concludes under French auspices in December with the soon-to-be-notorious Treaty of Nice.

Despite this daunting workload, the college of unelected commissioners, chaired by the unelected Romano Prodi, spent much of the week tackling a more pressing issue. Is there a secret plot to depose Mr Prodi? For once, it was the German, not the scrupulously impartial British press, which started it. Leading Euro-club members Neil Kinnock and Chris Patten were, it was claimed, planning "regicide". Even as denials flowed hot and furious, suspicion switched to Paris. fields.headline: Riding for a fall
fields.standfirst: An ominous prelude to today's great race
fields.trailText: Even those oblivious to horseracing the rest of the year cannot resist the Grand National. This year however, the National has had the worst possible overture. It has been the build-up not to a festival, but a funeral: yesterday Aintree claimed its fifth horse in two days. It seems a cruel kind of madness to keep going with an event which ends in so much pain, so often.
fields.body:
Even those oblivious to horseracing the rest of the year cannot resist the Grand National. As its name suggests, it is one of that handful of British sporting occasions which serve as a collective moment in the life of the nation. Along with the Cup Final and Wimbledon, the Grand National is an event which draws in people who ordinarily have no interest in the sport. Non-betters suddenly fancy a flutter; non-experts start studying the form.

This year however, the National has had the worst possible overture. It has been the build-up not to a festival, but a funeral: yesterday Aintree claimed its fifth horse in two days. The images of fine animals, leaping, falling and finally quivering before death are distressing to all who see them. It seems a cruel kind of madness to keep going with an event which ends in so much pain, so often. Animal rights activists have now ratcheted up their familiar demand for a ban, threatening instead the possibility of prosecution. A group known as Animal Aid suggests a case could be brought under the 1911 Protection of Animals Act.

Such instant responses, fuelled by emotion, are understandable. People feel that for the tape simply to come down this afternoon as if nothing had hap pened would be wrong. For their part, the organisers claim the problem amounts to nothing more than horribly bad luck. Normally, they say, only three in every thousand racehorses are killed. For five to fall in two days is, according to the Jockey Club, an extraordinary rarity, "a statistical blip". Besides, they add, only two of the five met their deaths on the National course itself - a course which has been vastly improved to learn the lessons of previous, fatal years. In this they find an unexpected ally in the RSPCA. When their representative walked the track at Aintree, he was impressed enough to report that "it could not have been in better condition".

The National's organisers will use this verdict to buttress their case. But it may, paradoxically, hinder more than it helps. For no longer can Aintree promise to make future improvements to save horses' lives. They have done all they can - and still five had to be put down. This leaves them open to more fundamental pressure, enabling activists to say that horseracing itself is an inevitably lethal sport. Whatever else happens today, the onus is now on Aintree to ensure that there is never another National year like this one.

fields.headline: Letting the stars shine
fields.standfirst: This week we profile SocGen, which is celebrating the second birthday of its first unit trust.
fields.trailText: This week we profile SocGen, which is celebrating the second birthday of its first unit trust.
fields.body:
SocGen? What's that?

Aka SGAM, it's short for Société Générale Asset Management, the UK fund arm of France's second biggest bank which has assets totalling £300bn. It set up a unit trust arm in 1998.

How many units have been sold?

The public has bought some £420m while institutions have chipped in a further £400m.

How many funds are there?

Five at the moment - UK Income, UK Growth, European, Technology and Japan.

That leaves a lot of gaps.

Yes, planned funds for the next year or so will cover UK Smaller Companies, Far East, the US and global bonds.

What about trackers?

Definitely out. SocGen sells itself on beating the averages.

And ethical funds?

No - but social responsibility issues are creeping up its agenda.

How does SocGen see itself?

Bringing institutional standards to small investors. It claims to be an amalgam of investment skills and marketing know-how.

What do the advisers think?

Still too early for some. Others look at the previous track record of its managers and give it approval.

What's the public perception?

Adverts with moody black photos dominated by Nicola Horlick.

Do you mean the supermum and super fund manager?

The very same. She is Britain's only fund manager who is far better known than the company she works for.

So SocGen works a superstar manager system?

Not at all - it's all down to teamwork.

Come again?

Alright, while Nicola is "prima inter pares" (first among equals) among the two dozen fund managers, her unique crossover from City pages to women's sections brought bucketloads of publicity to a company which was a complete newcomer to the UK unit trust scene. And she runs the UK income fund.

Who are the "pares"?

The "equals" include Peter Seabrook on the UK growth fund, Dino Fuschillo and Stuart Gilmartin on Europe, Jonathan Greig on Japan, and Alan Torry and Chris Godding on technology - they've all been recruited with long, successful records elsewhere.

But what if they get a new attack of wanderlust?

Then they have to abandon their shares and options. The senior staff jointly own the 30% of SGAM not controlled by the French parent. The exact proportion owned by Ms Horlick is a secret, but is probably 5% to 10%.

Do they deserve extra?

So far, the performance has been very good. All the funds have tough targets. They have to beat an index by a fixed amount each year - and that's a lot harder than merely doing better than the majority of rival unit trusts. And three of the five have done so, with one too new to tell - the laggard so far is Nicola's Income Fund.

Why is that?

You try finding shares which combine long-term capital growth with a rising income when all the hot money is going on short-term capital explosions where the word dividend is outside the lexicon.

Which has been the best fund?

Technology has led its sector since launch with a 321% gain and has virtually doubled unit holders' cash over six months.

Isn't technology a bit of an up-and-down situation?

The proper expression is volatility. SocGen realises that the "suspension of reality" stage, when anyone could do well, is over. Now it hopes any tendency to roller-coasterism in the £300m fund will be dampened down by spreading risks. The dot.com content is less than 3% and the rest of the fund is spread across nearly 100 companies. The trick is to find the next "big thing".

What happened to Nicola's bet with Richard Branson?

The check-pullovered Branson bet Nicola that the SocGen growth fund would not beat his All Share tracker by 2% a year for three years.

What's at stake?

£6,000.

And who's winning?

Nicola. Leaving out the initial costs which give Branson a head start, the SocGen fund has gained 32.4% over the first two years compared with 16.7% for the Virgin fund.

Is there a SocGen style - other than the photos on the adverts?

It all comes down to strict research and sector responsibilities. It looks for cash generation, management skills and for companies that can stamp their authority on rivals. And it lets top fund managers manage money - it says too many other groups promote so that fund managers manage people instead.

Is there a website?

Try www.sgam.co.uk but while you can look and download a form, you can't yet buy. However, the firm does accept phoned Isa purchase orders.

What's SocGen's unique selling proposition?

Adding value with style and consistency - then packaging these for the small unit trust investor.

fields.headline: Turning screw on poor
fields.standfirst: A group specialising in high-risk borrowers is under attack for continuing to treat its clients harshly. Richard Colbey reports
fields.trailText: A group specialising in high-risk borrowers is under attack for continuing to treat its clients harshly.
fields.body:
Controversial home loans group City Mortgage Corporation is still treating some borrowers harshly despite a 1998 agreement with the Office of Fair Trading to remove unfair penalties from its loan contracts.

The group, which specialised in loans to those with credit rating difficulties, faced customer anger over high interest rates and "fines" when a payment was late. This followed the setting up of a high-profile customer protest group, the National Association of Mortgage Victims, which has attracted some 1,500 members.

Subsequently a complicated chain of transactions led to a management buyout of the company, now called Igroup. Although Igroup, 49% owned by Royal Bank of Scotland following the management buyout, is still supposedly subject to that undertaking, the case of Trevor and Susan Reeves, who live in Suffolk, highlights the way the company continues to treat many of its poorer borrowers.

In 1989 the Reeves borrowed £6,000 from Homestead Financing, subsequently taken over by CMC. This was a mortgage secured against their house. They got into difficulties, but in 1995 thought they had reached agreement. Mr Reeves, who has worked in horse racing all his life, arranged to pay back £200 per month over 17 months to cover the arrears and regular payments. These payments, made directly from the Reeves' wages, brought the total paid under the agreement to nearly £14,000. After all the money had been paid CMC claimed that the Reeves owed another £19,000.

Reluctantly, the Reeves continued making payments, but the sum claimed grew to £25,000 by July 1999. They stopped paying and CMC tried to get possession of their home. When the case was heard in November 1999, the judge said he had "considerable disquiet" about the claim and adjourned for the Reeves to seek legal advice. The Racing Post newspaper took up their case and the company said that it is "reviewing the case". The company's claim seems to have grown as a consequence of increases in interest rates it charged under the mortgage - which bore no relation to base rates. These reached nearly 20% at a time when most lenders were charging around 7%.

Had the Reeves' mortgage been granted after July 1995, CMC's shenanigans would almost certainly have fallen foul of the Unfair Terms in Consumer Contracts Regulations. If the company does pursue the case, it could well fall foul of the Consumer Credit Act 1974 which makes "extortionate credit agreements" unenforceable. This argument has led to claims brought by J&J Securities, a company run by David Johnson who has been involved with CMC and Igroup, being thrown out of court when they sought to recover even higher rates of interest. Despite the continuing involvement of Mr Johnson, a spokesman insisted Igroup is a completely separate business.

CMC specialised in non-status loans, on which lenders quite properly charge a higher rate of interest because the chances of default are higher. However, where the rates approach three times the normal figure and the loan is secured anyway, this justification is unlikely to be accepted. The company also relies on terms that supposedly entitle it to levy charges whenever borrowers fall into arrears.

Almost all mortgage agreements enable lenders to recover legitimate expenses, particularly legal fees. However, where the fees amount to a punishment for being in arrears, rather than a genuine appraisal of costs, they are regarded as penalty clauses, which are not recoverable. Many of the sums added to the Reeves' account are completely indefensible. A sum of £95 is charged for swearing an affidavit, while the usual fee is around £5, and £157 is added for a meaningless, "account assessment". These, a spokesman claimed, were acceptable because the companies "operate a policy of complete transparency". This seems to mean making charges, however outrageous, is acceptable if they were expressed in the mortgage agreement even though most borrowers would not read, let alone understand it.

In the Reeves' case the 1995 repayment agreement will probably see off CMC should it pursue the case any further. If the company insists on levying outrageous charges against borrowers who have not entered into a specific repayment agreement, it will take a test case to check their validity. Those facing such claims should contact RBS's Edinburgh head office as it may have a moderating influence.

National Association of Mortgage Victims (01889-507394).

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

webTitle: Never mind the price, just feel the quality

fields.headline: Never mind the price, just feel the quality
fields.standfirst: They seemed to be little more than last year's passing fad but fine hand-woven pasminas are avidly collected, says Stewart Dalby
fields.trailText: They seemed to be little more than last year's passing fad but fine hand-woven pasminas are avidly collected.
fields.body:
Christie's, South Kensington, describes itself as the world's leading textile auctioneer, with four sales a year exclusively devoted to Oriental and Islamic costumes and textiles. When I saw that the first sale of this year on Wednesday April 12 is Perfect Pashminas, I thought this must be a case of slamming the stable door after the horse has bolted.

Pashmina shawls enjoyed a curious and it now seems short-lived revival over the past two years. Around May of 1998 articles started to appear in fashion magazines and national newspapers saying pashminas were the must-have fashion items. Everyone seemed to have them, even the Queen.

I know something about shawls because my wife was in the business. Ours were from Nepal. A friend in Kathmandu was buying them at the factory gate for £64. We were selling them for £106 so it was £25 to her and £25 to us. It was like one of those Tupperware operations where friends sold to friends, only we did it at the office and a little on the internet.

When we started, the cheapest to be found seemed to be at Harrods, and they were £300. It was a nice little earner for a while. Then, around September of last year, fashion gurus decreed that pashminas were definitely passé and ponchos were the thing.

Ponchos do not appear to have taken off in quite the same way. But pashminas seemed to die the death. By Christmas we felt we could not give them away. Moreover, during the boom everybody and their mother seemed to pile in - they advertised in village magazines, in mail order catalogues, everywhere. Even Marks & Spencer started undercutting us, blast them. They sold theirs at £80. Try as we did to explain that ours were superior to those at Marks it was to no avail.

And this really is the point. A pashmina is not just a pashmina; there is a vast range of quality and craftsmanship and, accordingly, price.

Pashmina is part of the fur of the mountain goat. In Nepal the mountain goat is known as "chyangra". And pashmina is the soft downy layer around the neck and chest that protects the goat from the harsh mountain climate. This downy layer is the finest quality. It is covered by longer hair which, in contrast, is fairly coarse.

The higher up the mountain the finer the pashmina becomes as the goat needs to grow more. Our shawls were made from goats grazing at 8,000 ft but the best is to be found from goats at 14,000 ft. The test of a really good pashmina shawl is said to be whether it can be drawn through a wedding ring.

Pat Frost, who is organising the Christies's sale, relates a story of how someone tried to import goats to France and start a pashmina business. He failed because the climate was too mild. There is also the craftmanship. Pat Frost says the sale at Christie's is of antique pashminas.

Fine hand-woven shawls have been made in Kashmir since the 17th century. With traditional Indian motifs they could take as long as 18 months to make. One devotee was said to be Napoleon's wife, Empress Josephine. She had such a passion for them that Napoleon, apparently, had to chide her for spending too much.

During the first part of the 19th century, the shawl trade in Europe was flourishing. The fashion for diaphanous dresses with short sleeves, made from materials such as muslin, meant that the shawl was a necessary accessory for warmth. Also, the introduction of the crinoline, with its exaggerated shape, made wearing heavy coats and capes difficult. Hence the shawl was everywhere until the mid 19th century.

At the auction there are a number of 19th and early 20th century shawls. Prices do start at around £100, but they range up to several thousands of pounds. Colours are important. A square ivory pashmina, the border embroidered with blue arabesques, is estimated at £250 to £300, while a long shawl of scarlet pashmina carries an estimate of £500 to £600.

At the more expensive end a doruka (double-sided) shawl, woven and embroidered with diagonal waves of flowers on hot pink, celadon and green grounds, is priced at £6,000 to £7,000. A long jamawar shawl, dating from circa 1845-50, is expected to fetch £2,000 to £3,000.

Pat Frost says there is strong interest in these shawls, not just from one-off buyers wanting to one to wear but from a solid core of people who collect them. They hold their price or do rather better than this if kept as family heirlooms and not worn to death, according to Pat Frost.

 For further information telephone Christie's South Kensington, 020-7581-7611.

With traditional Indian motifs they could take as long as 18 months to make. One devotee was said to be Napoleon's wife, Empress Josephine. She had such a passion for them that Napoleon, apparently, had to chide her for spending too much. During the first part of the 19th century, the shawl trade in Europe was flourishing. The fashion for diaphanous dresses with short sleeves, made from materials such as muslin, meant that the shawl was a necessary accessory for warmth. Also, the introduction of the crinoline, with its exaggerated shape, made wearing heavy coats and capes difficult. Hence the shawl was everywhere until the mid 19th century. At the auction there are a number of 19th and early 20th century shawls. Prices do start at around £100, but they range up to several thousands of pounds. Colours are important. A square ivory pashmina, the border embroidered with blue arabesques, is estimated at £250 to £300, while a long shawl of scarlet pashmina carries an estimate of £500 to £600. At the more expensive end a doruka (double-sided) shawl, woven and embroidered with diagonal waves of flowers on hot pink, celadon and green grounds, is priced at £6,000 to £7,000. A long jamawar shawl, dating from circa 1845-50, is expected to fetch £2,000 to £3,000. Pat Frost says there is strong interest in these shawls, not just from one-off buyers wanting to one to wear but from a solid core of people who collect them. They hold their price or do rather better than this if kept as family heirlooms and not worn to death, according to Pat Frost.  For further information telephone Christie's South Kensington, 020-7581-7611.

webTitle: Top gear! A bike that takes  the hike out of any old trip

fields.headline: Top gear! A bike that takes  the hike out of any old trip
fields.standfirst: Take them on the train, ride them to work and store them under your desk. Richard Nelsson hears good reports on the little folder
fields.trailText: For years folding bikes have been regarded as a bit of a joke - small wheeled contraptions that appear to be more of a gimmick than a serious mode of transport. Despite this image, however, their popularity has been steadily growing.
fields.body:
For years folding bikes have been regarded as a bit of a joke - small wheeled contraptions that appear to be more of a gimmick than a serious mode of transport.

Despite this image, however, their popularity has been steadily growing with more than 4,000 new bikes being sold in the UK each year. No longer are they the hard to ride, slow to fold contraptions of yesteryear. Instead, they're sophisticated pieces of engineering that can compete on all levels with conventional bicycles.

One of their biggest attractions is that they're part of an inter-modal solution to commuting problems. Most rail operators allow folding bikes to be carried free of charge and without restrictions, so you can cycle to the railway station, fold up the bike, travel by train and then ride to work at the other end.

Mike Hessey, from the Folding Society, says: "Once you get to work, the bike can be stored under the desk so avoiding the risk of theft and there's no heavy lock to carry. They take up a minimum of room in the house and can easily be transported in a car. There are some users, though, who are simply attracted by the sheer ingeniousness of the folding bike's design."

The basic principle behind the bike is that all the parts which stick out - wheels, handlebars and saddle - fold into the centre around the chain. This results in a package the size of large briefcase and which weighs around 12kg. Most designs take an average of 30 seconds or less to assemble (after practice) with another minute or so to fit into the carrying bag.

Unfortunately, this level of engineering does not come cheap. Prices start at around £300 for a basic model and a design classic can rise to more than £4,000. Cheaper bikes can be picked up at warehouses and by mail order for £100, but these are often very heavy with unreliable folding mechanisms. There is also the price of the carry bag or case to consider which is essential if you are planning to travel by plane.

The dominant name in the UK folding bike market is Brompton Cycles which has been operating since the early 80s. Its bikes are claimed to be not only the easiest to fold but also to fold up into the smallest size, due in part to the 16 inch wheels.

Its top of the range machine is the T5 (£613 from Avon Valley Cyclery) which not only has 5-speed hub gears but also dynamo lights, good suspension and a rear rack which can carry loads with ease. This rack then acts as a platform for the bike to stand on, while small wheels allow it to be pulled along like a suitcase.

The cheapest Brompton is the L3 (£341) which has three gears and is a good choice where weight and price are priorities. Accessories are available such as a carrying bag and naturally a folding pedal (£33) which makes the folded size 8 cm narrower. Only one folding pedal is required as the other is hidden by the compressed bike.

Brompton may be the popular choice but plenty of other makes are available. From Germany there are Birdy bikes made by Riese und Muller. These are lighter than the Brompton and come with full suspension, although when folded are bulkier and take slightly longer to assemble. However, some devotees say they ride more like rigid conventional bikes. The cheapest Birdy is the Red (£700) which weighs only 10.5kg while prices rise to £1,300 for the 9-speed Black model. One of the cheapest folding bikes on the UK market is the Brilliant Micro-lite which sells for £279. These bikes fold up into a package.

A different concept is offered by the Strida 2 (£335) made by Roland Plastics. The bike consists of three lightweight aluminium tubes which are arranged into a triangle. Instead of folding, the three tubes are brought into line with the wheels, clipping together to form what is described as a wheeled stick. This is pulled rather than carried and the whole process takes only 10 seconds to execute.

With this machine there is no chance of getting oil on your clothes as there is a drive belt instead of a greasy chain and the bike is said to be corrosion free. This simple one-gear machine is aimed at commuters rather than tourers, but if you're after a bike that stands out it's for you.

There again some in the small-wheeled bike world would say that that accolade belongs to Alex Moulton Bicycles. It is debatable as to whether they should be considered alongside folding bikes as they separate into two parts.

However, Moultons are ideal for transporting by car and are easy to store. The Land Rover model (£900), part of the All Purpose Bicycle (APB) range, has 20inch wheels, front and rear suspension and 21 gears. It is in fact a versatile "urban assault" bike capable of withstanding the potholes in city streets or off-road trails. Moultons are designed primarily for touring, though, and they're renowned for their big, versatile luggage-carrying capacity as well as providing a comfortable ride even over long distances.

When you buy a Moulton you pay for the innovative engineering design and this is no more apparent than in the New Series. Launched in 1998 it was the culmination of 40 years endeavour by Dr Alex Moulton to design a bike, "more pleasurable to have and more effective to use", than any other. It has been described as having jewel-like perfection and prices for this 17 inch wheeled bike start at £3,700. For true enthusiasts only.

webTitle: Gas works village is off the back burner

fields.headline: Gas works village is off the back burner
fields.standfirst: The Greenwich Millennium project embodies the high ideal of creating a truly mixed community. Elizabeth Langton reports
fields.trailText: The Greenwich Millennium project embodies the high ideal of creating a truly mixed community.
fields.body:
A controversial development that aims to set the trend for housing of the future has finally taken off after months of delay, including the resignation of the architects.

When it's finished, the Greenwich Millennium Village in south-east London, will include 1,400 new homes, a fifth of which will be shared ownership or affordable housing units. Some will be built using flexible interior walls that can be altered as residents' needs change.

For John Prescott, who cut the ribbon on the visitor centre, the project has become his "Dome". The deputy prime minister has taken a keen interest in the ex-gasworks next to the Thames. The land was cleaned up by government regeneration agency English Partnerships.

Countryside Properties, Taylor Woodrow Capital Developments and English Partnerships joined forces to create a 30-acre village. The master plan for the site was drawn-up by Swedish architect Ralph Erskine. "This is no ordinary development," he says. "But a true expression of the ideals of respect for human dignity, equality and freedom we foster in our democratic society."

Despite the high-minded ideals, potential residents will find, in practice, that the scheme is about reproducing the kind of communities that spring up around London town squares. The pedestrian-friendly layout will discourage car use - all parking and cycle storage will be out of sight and the car parks will only be accessible from the perimeter roads, says Ross Hammond, the Millennium Village project director.

The village centre, within five minutes walk of all the homes, will have no hidden corners. Garden squares will be well-lit and secured at night; public spaces will be overlooked by windows, balconies, terraces and bays. Two-bedroom apartments are on sale at £230,000 and the first 200 were sold almost immediately.

But the journey to the launch of the first show flats has been far from smooth. Last summer architects Hunt Thompson Associates resigned after criticising the design for not being visionary enough. There were also rumours of rows over where the development's housing association properties should be sited. Soaring house prices and a shortage of affordable accommodation for those on modest incomes mean local authorities have called upon developers to include social housing in private developments to create "mixed tenure" communities.

In the draft planning guidance launched last month, Mr Prescott said housing must be more affordable. He said the government would allow councils "to secure a proportion of affordable housing in larger housing developments - both in urban and rural areas. This will benefit single people, low-income families and key workers such as nurses, teachers and others."

Poor housing cheek-by-jowl with affluent homes can lead to tensions. Back in the 80s, when the docklands transformation began, many locals condemned the "yuppies" moving on to their turf. And it was hard not to sympathise with people crammed into social housing only a stone's throw from spacious apartments with porterage and river views.

Experts believe the way forward is fully integrated communities rather than ghettos. Research on mixed tenure estates carried out by the think-tank Demos found most residents say mixing tenures does not cause significant problems. Among owners, a third thought it had created difficulties, while a quarter thought it had brought benefits. Mixing owner-occupiers and renters on the same streets appeared to make people happier.

Mr Hammond says the Millennium Village will include 266 affordable homes dotted about the development. There will be three types of tenure: renting, shared-ownership and flexible tenure, where owners can reduce or increase the proportion of the property they own.

Most affordable homes will be managed by the Moat Housing Association. Nick Cook, development director, says they will be offered to local people who need homes including those in temporary accommodation and public sector workers, such as teachers and nurses.

He believes the best way to create sustainable communities from scratch is to ensure everyone has access to the same shops, schools and leisure facilities in the scheme. Then it's up to the residents to make their community a success.

webTitle: Forget Armani, now there's an armada

fields.headline: Forget Armani, now there's an armada
fields.standfirst: Companies keen to exploit the weakness of the likes of Marks & Spencer are hitting our shores. Spanish journalist Monica Artigas reports
fields.trailText: Companies keen to exploit the weakness of the likes of Marks & Spencer are hitting our shores.
fields.body:
Britain's traditional high street clothes retailers will face tough competition from brash new specialist rivals for the "foreseeable future", according to an analysis by Verdict Research. The latest study concludes that: "The UK clothing market has changed, fundamentally and for ever. The womenswear market is no longer viable in its present form." It adds that for too long consumers have been offered "uninspired and bland ranges".

The report says Marks & Spencer's market share of womenswear has fallen from 16.1% to 13.5% and menswear from 13.9% to 12.3% in the past year. But while Verdict singled out M&S as the most dramatic case, it said the entire sector was facing a crisis.

"Too many retailers are offering uninspired and bland ranges and consumers are shopping less for clothes as a consequence," says the report. And if this were not enough, the competition is coming from Spanish rag trade upstarts, who have built a sizeable bridgehead in the UK textile sector. The last time a major Spanish offensive to grab a slice of British commerce was launched in 1588, the attack was rebuffed. However, 412 years later they are winning the battle.

Spanish retailer Mango's first store in London turns over around £345,000 a month and is expecting to pull in more than £4m a year. At present Mango employs 140 people in the UK. The label has five branches here, all opened since 1998, with two new shops joining the Mango brigade this spring, one in London's Regent Street, and another in Kent. And Mango is not alone. This is just the vanguard of a powerful Spanish textile armada closing in on GAP, Next, C&A and even the mighty Marks & Sparks.

Around 200 people are employed in the UK by Zara, another Spanish textile outfit. Two new Zara branches are set to hit the high streets before May, one in Reading and the other in Kensington High Street, London. Meanwhile, Camper, a Spanish footwear firm from Majorca, put 105,000 pairs of shoes on British feet in 1999. The firm has three branches in London and more than 236 strategic outlets in department stores such as Liberty and Selfridges.

Not to be left behind, Armand Basi, a classy Spanish brand best known for providing wardrobes for the James Bond films, has opened a shop in Conduit Street, and supplies 70 British retailers in Britain. Armand Basi lists Kevin Spacey and Noel Gallagher among its clients.

Moreover, some Spanish brands - Dicktons, Mascaro, Snipe, Luis Civit - are also boosting their appeal to British tastes. For instance, the Custo-Barcelona T-shirt brand, which last year dressed Julia Roberts with a colourful top in Notting Hill, has since caught the eyes of Selfridges' customers.

"The breakthrough of Mango and Zara has been a turning point in the British fashion market," says Consuelo Gonzalez, manager of the Consumer Goods Department of the Spanish Institute for Foreign Trade in London. "Since then, retailers interested in Spanish fashion and textile companies that want to launch in Britain have increased. The success of Mango and Zara was foreseeable. They are fashionable and dynamic with aggressive pricing policies.

"They refresh their lines every two weeks, so the young woman or teenager who likes shopping every Saturday to find something new is sorted," he adds. Spanish clothing firms see the UK market as their entry into the international arena. Lorenzo Fluxa, founder and president of Camper, says: "The UK, and London, are one of the best international European platforms."

Exports are now outpacing home sales. In 1996, the turnover of Mango shops in Spain was £71m and from overseas shops £39.62m. In 1999, turnover in Spain was £154m, but sales from Mango's shops abroad was £270m. Zara's exports have jumped from 25% to 46% in two years.

The coming of this rag trade armada is good news for job creation. Spanish textile companies are seeking shop assistants, window-stylists, store designers and IT systems experts. They all say the same thing: "Young, bright company seeks..."

Useful links:

www.custo-barcelona.com

www.mango.es

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: The world is waking up to the crucial links between governance and sustainable development.
fields.body:
The world is waking up to the crucial links between governance and sustainable development. The latest confirmation came the same day we heard the news that the wave-piercing catamaran Team Philips had broken up. That evening, I was in the audience as EU Commissioner Chris Patten gave the first of the 2000 Reith Lectures, whose theme is sustainable development. He warned of a looming crisis in governance, with major economic, social and ecological implications, and underscored the role business must play in sustainable development.

As he did so, I spotted a link between the Team Philips disaster and the sustainability challenges business now faces. Not, perhaps, the most obvious link. Yes, the catamaran's revolutionary form reflects the use of computer-aided design and hi-tech carbon fibres. So Team Philips could be seen as a symbol of the much-vaunted New Economy, which may yet prove unexpectedly fragile. But a different link sprang to mind, to do with measuring corporate performance and progress.

In his Respect for the Earth lecture, Patten encouraged non governmental organisations (NGOs) to collaborate with business to solve the world's problems. Fine, but few in the NGO sector have much respect for corporations. So how do we build a degree of mutual confidence? One answer is to develop credible measures of corporate progress. But that's easier said than done. If you are in a catamaran bowling along at 40 knots, you know you are making progress. And if a hull has snapped off further progress is unlikely. Luckily, companies now have new and more sensitive measures to assess their environmental progress.

Business in the Environment has just launched its fourth Index of Corporate Environmental Engagement and Performance. BP Amoco CEO Sir John Browne, who gives the third Reith lecture this year, finds his company in fourth position. Prince Charles, who hosts the final lecture, notes that some companies are making real headway. He adds: "If environmental performance is going to be a source of competitive advantage - as it should be - we all need to be able to compare the way companies perform."

All true, but John Browne and other corporate chieftains face another problem. It may help to show that they are making headway against the triple bottom line, but try telling that to financial analysts. Most just don't get it. Then, as we wallowed around wondering how to build the business case for sustainability to the point where it would convert the most recalcitrant chief financial officer, help appeared from an unlikely quarter.

A new value creation index from Ernst & Young and Wharton business school appears in the magazine Forbes ASAP. The results are stunning. Research on factors making companies more valuable shows environmental performance in fifth place. It trails innovation and the ability to attract talented employees, but comes ahead of brand investment, application of technology and customer satisfaction.

The Team Philips wreck originally caught my eye because of our own Trimaran project, focusing on how boards handle the triple bottom line. For those of us confronting financial analysts on the sustainable development front, the Forbes ASAP news was like waking and finding that the shattered hull was just a bad dream.

 John Elkington is chairman of strategy consultants SustainAbility (web-site: www.sustainability.co.uk). The Reith Lectures will be broadcast on both Radio 4 (from 12 April) and the BBC World Service (from 16 April).

BP Amoco CEO Sir John Browne, who gives the third Reith lecture this year, finds his company in fourth position. Prince Charles, who hosts the final lecture, notes that some companies are making real headway. He adds: "If environmental performance is going to be a source of competitive advantage - as it should be - we all need to be able to compare the way companies perform." All true, but John Browne and other corporate chieftains face another problem. It may help to show that they are making headway against the triple bottom line, but try telling that to financial analysts. Most just don't get it. Then, as we wallowed around wondering how to build the business case for sustainability to the point where it would convert the most recalcitrant chief financial officer, help appeared from an unlikely quarter. A new value creation index from Ernst & Young and Wharton business school appears in the magazine Forbes ASAP. The results are stunning. Research on factors making companies more valuable shows environmental performance in fifth place. It trails innovation and the ability to attract talented employees, but comes ahead of brand investment, application of technology and customer satisfaction. The Team Philips wreck originally caught my eye because of our own Trimaran project, focusing on how boards handle the triple bottom line. For those of us confronting financial analysts on the sustainable development front, the Forbes ASAP news was like waking and finding that the shattered hull was just a bad dream.  John Elkington is chairman of strategy consultants SustainAbility (web-site: www.sustainability.co.uk). The Reith Lectures will be broadcast on both Radio 4 (from 12 April) and the BBC World Service (from 16 April).

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: Marco Rochat Head of technology (Europe, Middle East and Africa) at PricewaterhouseCoopers
fields.trailText: Marco Rochat Head of technology (Europe, Middle East and Africa) at PricewaterhouseCoopers.
fields.body:
When did you first become a manager?

At 29, in 1982, I took charge of the Pricewaterhouse office in Bologna.

What has been your best moment in management?

When things go the way I intended, with people believing in what they are doing.

Which was your greatest mistake?

There are lots of mistakes, the key thing is to remember them so that, hopefully, I won't repeat them.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

People who don't do what they say they will.

Does your organisation have a glass ceiling?

Not at all. The Global Technology Industry Group of PricewaterhouseCoopers promotes the entrepreneurial spirit and initiative, so I am confident that such barriers are non-existent.

What management wisdom is most overrated?

Globalisation is the current buzz word, but first you need to identify the right business model for your company and tailor it to local needs, otherwise it's just globalony.

What one lesson would you pass on to young managers?

To be a team player and not be afraid of changing a strategy or decision if it's not working.

Which management guru do you believe in?

My father who opened the first Coopers office in Milan, in 1957.

Who is your management hero?

There are many, mainly in the technology industry as in some sense they are pioneers. Bill Gates is one of them.

Who is your favourite politician?

I do not particularly care about politicians, but I would name Bill Clinton for what he has done for the US economy and the world peace process.

Do you think European executives are overpaid?

No, but mentalities and measurement systems should be changed to ensure that good performers are rewarded accordingly.

Apart from your family, what else makes you happiest in life?

To see people around me enjoying what they do, learning from it and coming to me for advice - professional and personal.

What annoys you most?

When people tell me, "no, I cannot do it" before I've even finished asking.

How do you relax?

I enjoy building models with wood and playing with radio-controlled cars and planes.

What was your last cultural experience?

It was more a spiritual experience, when I visited the Vatican and had the honour of being blessed by the Pope.

What is your favourite city?

New York, in short doses, otherwise Geneva where we currently live.

What is your greatest regret?

Not to have continued my career as a grand-prix driver.

What will be the big business issue of the next decade?

To handle the effects of change that fast-evolving technology brings.

What would you really like to have been?

The mind behind the internet!

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText: Reading the Duwayne Brooks interview (Free At Last? April 1) filled me with anger and disappointment, at least with a minority of police officers. Wake up: you are taking the respect of the police force with you. Concentrate, instead, on those who pose a genuine threat to the public and the law. Then we may all see you as the reliable figures whom at one time I would never have doubted.
fields.body:
Reading the Duwayne Brooks interview (Free At Last? April 1) filled me with anger and disappointment, at least with a minority of police officers. Wake up: you are taking the respect of the police force with you. Concentrate, instead, on those who pose a genuine threat to the public and the law. Then we may all see you as the reliable figures whom at one time I would never have doubted.

Duwayne Brooks has experienced victimisation that most of us could never imagine. It doesn't matter that interviewers find him arrogant or hard to understand. What matters is his experiences of British society, and the quality of life that he is entitled to in the future. I hope that will be one without victimisation.
A Boyce
London SE14

Free At Last? is the best piece of journalism I can remember reading, Simon Hattenstone has done Duwayne Brooks proud.
Suzanna Hamilton
zan.h@virgin.net

Duwayne Brooks has a greater tolerance than the majority of this country, even though he has been the victim of far more intolerance than most. It is a shame, then, that your reporter mistakes confidence for arrogance. When you have suffered as Brooks has, it is inevitable that you would be proud of what you have achieved in the face of that suffering. He has been condemned by the police and, at least partly, by the Lawrence family. Please don't add to it.
Nick Posford
London WC1

Duwayne Brooks's difficulties with the police are akin to those experienced by many other black Londoners who are not in his situation. To a certain degree, I could not relate to him, as I have not had such encounters myself. However, I do know that the black English community has no confidence in the police, and a similar lack of confidence in the mainstream churches and the ingrained classist attitudes against black English people. These institutions are not just institutionally racist; they are also institutionally nationalist. The battle between the black and white English communities continues.
Jason Young
Anglo-Caribbean Productions
London SW17

Joanna Blythman's article about school vouchers on food was excellent (Food, April 1). However, she did not mention another disadvantage of the system - the environmental aspect. Isn't it about time that crisp and biscuit manufacturers created bags that can be recycled or are biodegradable?
Ruth Fisher
Luton, Beds

The head of my local school has a solution to the voucher problem. She tells parents, 'Either you can spend £1,000 on crisps and we can spend hours counting the packets, or we can just pass the hat round. I know which I'd like you to do, but it's up to you.' Result? The parents cough up the money.
Mary Whiting
London NW11

'My own advice was to steer clear initially of "personal" journalism, unless they had some truly unusual and interesting personal experience to report' (Alexander Chancellor, April 1). Such as looking after a fish? Please tell me that this was just an awful April Fool.
Kevin Metchear
Manchester

fields.headline: Learning to love London
fields.standfirst: "I suppose flies must to and fro across the Atlantic every day. They don't need tickets. Like us, it may have disembarked at Heathrow"
fields.trailText: Alexander Chancellor: "I suppose flies must to and fro across the Atlantic every day. They don't need tickets. Like us, it may have disembarked at Heathrow"
fields.body:
There was a fly buzzing around in the aeroplane when I woke up during my flight back to London from New York. I don't think I have ever noticed a fly on an aeroplane before, but I suppose many flies must to and fro across the Atlantic every day. There is nothing to stop them doing so. They don't need tickets. They have no problems with immigration or security. They are the most undetectable of stowaways. I fell asleep and never saw the fly again but, like the rest of us, it may have disembarked at Heathrow. Or it may have stayed on board for the return flight. I don't know.

In fact, I know almost nothing about flies. I don't even know whether they live long enough to make two trans-Atlantic flights, or whether the cabin pressure affects their health, or whether they have any idea what they are doing. But I like to imagine that the fly had decided to come to Britain for a purpose. Perhaps it wanted to escape the buzz in New York. Flies are associated with buzz - in fact, one cannot easily imagine them without it - but perhaps this was an unusual fly, just seeking a new, less stressful life in Terminal 4.

My homecoming after a month in New York was a comforting experience, even though London was in every superficial respect more disagreeable. In New York, the weather was perfect. The sky was cloudless, spring was springing and a gentle breeze was blowing. Central Park at the weekend was full of cheerful strollers and skateboarders, happy couples pushing their children in prams, happy divorced fathers with children on their shoulders, teaching them to count, and happy old people in wheelchairs taking the sun. There was even a group of active old people with "volunteers" printed on their jackets, laughing and chatting together as they swept leaves from the paths.

London, by contrast, was cold and overcast. The drive from Heathrow into London was as dull as the drive into Manhattan from Kennedy Airport is exciting when the New York skyline comes into view. The people in London looked as downcast as the weather. The laughter in the pub was loud, jarring and false. One might easily have wanted to get on the next plane back. But there is something about London that New York cannot match. Despite all the efforts of the British media to make it seem "cool" and buzzy and competitive, London remains resolutely unselfconscious about itself. New Yorkers spend much of their time thinking how lucky they are to be New Yorkers, citizens of a great metropolis. Londoners are hardly aware of being Londoners. They just happen to live in London.

It is of no more than passing interest to them that the elected symbol of the French Republic, the "Marianne" model Laetita Casta, has taken up residence in Covent Garden, or that hundreds of thousands of continental Europeans have come here to enjoy not only the lower rates of income tax, but also London's incomparable cultural delights. They just get on with their lives as if they were living anywhere. That is why London is really "cool" and why New York, for all its astonishing glamour, is actually a little bit provincial.

One true Londoner who loved London was Bruce Bernard, the art critic and picture editor, whose death last week has cast a shadow over my homecoming. He had a passionate interest in art and photography, which naturally made him love New York, too, but he would never have been comfortable or successful there. He was, in his way, a brilliant man, and one of uncompromising integrity, but he could never have fitted into the New York scene. He was often gloomy and cross, had no interest in money, always travelled by bus or tube and frequently lost his most precious possessions on them. He was thoroughly disorganised, and it would be impossible to imagine him in a limousine.

A few years ago, Bruce flew to New York to see a big exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of his close friend Lucian Freud, the artist. He travelled with one thousand dollars in cash, which was immediately stolen from him on arrival. He then went to the exhibition and stood for hours beside a full-length portrait of himself to see if any of the visitors noted the resemblance. They didn't. Then he came home, perfectly content with the experience. He was about as un-New York as you can be.

On a separate point, I must apologise to readers who wrote to me while I was away asking how to purchase a Grenadier firelighter. I did not see their letters until my return. Since it is still cold, maybe they will not have lost interest. I must warn them that it is rather expensive - £120, plus £6.95 p&p - but it is obtainable by sending a cheque for this amount to Magpies, Annesbrook, Moynalty, Kells, Co Meath, Ireland.

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: www.Schwabb.com
fields.body:
Dreaming of a carnal weekend in Paris with Migraine Alan, I asked Patrick to give me a trim on Friday. I was too busy following the Nasdaq and the Dow Jones in www.Schwabb.com on my laptop to pay attention, but Patrick seemed even more febrile than usual.

'There you are,' he hissed eventually. I looked up and was aghast. I looked like David Beckham! He'd shorn me bald! By then, he was incoherent. A Hewlett-Packard scanner he'd bought from www.Action.com had only ever worked in fits and then died. Everybody at Hewlett-Packard and Action had been hyper-polite on the phone, but the scanner was just past the 30-day guarantee for software, so it wasn't a question of mere telephone advice. 'There's only these voices on the phone and they just want you to go away . . . I wish I had gone to a shop with real people: "I bought this here, and it doesn't work"; "Yes, sir, of course". The world as it used to be . . . Internet fanatics like you put me in this mess . . . Serves you right . . . I hate you.'

Much as I love the net, people who don't know their serial from their parallel ports shouldn't buy equipment from e-dealers, but I was running out of time for a hellraiser. Alan would be arriving in 20 minutes! I fled. At home, I looked at myself in the mirror and wept. Still, my body is fabulous; I shed my clothes for reassurance.

The bell rang. Forget Paris, I thought, wrapped my head in a chiffon scarf (www.liberty-of-london.com) and opened the door. 'Take me,' I whispered. 'Sign here,' said the helmeted courier sternly. I tore open the envelope. 'I'm sorry, but I hate Europe (www.euro-sceptic.org). Can we do Bognor next week instead? Alan.'

gorgeoustanya @hotmail.com

fields.headline: Eating out
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort is cheered to discover a Chinese(ish) restaurant that he can bank on
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort is cheered to discover a Chinese(ish) restaurant that he can bank on
fields.body:
There's cool, and cool; cool and wicked cool, way cool, pukka cool. The Orient is cool and way cool, but possibly not wicked cool. The interior is cool to the point of chilly - it was almost impossible to tell where the walls ended and the grey day beyond the windows began. But, as Neoprene and I discussed the situation, it became sort of meditative and elegant. There is nothing to distract the eye, aside from a battery of modishly decked-out waiters and one or two rather less modish diners. Horizontal lines blurred. Surfaces stretched to infinity. We were locked in a kind of Zen state: timeless, placeless but not appetite-less.

The Orient is the smart end of a vast eating development, the China House, on Piccadilly. The building used to be a bank, and has the proportions and once-intimidatory grandeur of that self-important institution. Downstairs is a fast-food, noodle-style operation, which sits with gaudy cheek inside the heavy neo-classical pomposity of the old banking hall, as if the messenger boy had moved into the manager's office. I am told that the food is not bad at all, and clearly in a different price range from that of the minimalist decor/maximalist price of the 22-carat dining room upstairs.

You reach this by way of a side entrance guarded by a young man in a heavy coat, and by a lift for one-and-a-half people or by some sinuous stairs. The arrangements don't make it easy for would-be gastro-enthusiasts to make their way to the Orient. Perhaps the purpose is to create a touch of secretive elitism. Whatever, as my daughter would say in that peculiarly dismissive tone of voice, it is, in my view, worth making the effort.

Don't go expecting classic Chinese food, or authentic this and that. The primary cooking influences may be Chinese, but the presentation - and sometimes the structure of dishes - owes more to Japan. It's not quite fully-blown Asian fusion (a description that can be given to Singaporean food, anyway), but the eye for presentation adds a welcome dimension to the traditional, rather rough-and-ready dishing techniques associated with Chinese food. Plates come in different sizes and shapes, but all are a dazzling white, which helps to point up the brilliance of the colours of the carefully individualised dishes.

For example, Neoprene wanted to investigate the dim sum lunch, one of the fixed price (£19.50) variations in the Express Lunch section. It came all together on a large, square dish. A neat stack of noodles held centre stage, down each side of which were ranged a selection of raviolis, tiny pies, char-siu buns like the tops of whiter-than-white medium-sized mushrooms, and those floppy pancakes made of rice flour. It was an arrangement that gave pause for pleasure even before she started eating. Still, it's one thing to seduce the eye, quite another to dazzle a picky palate, and few come pickier than Neoprene's.

However, there was very little with which she could find fault, and a great deal that she found to praise, which she did at regular intervals as titbit after titbit vanished from the ends of her chopsticks. The little pies were absolutely oustanding, the pastry light and perfectly textured somewhere between crumb and flake, with each filling cleanly differentiated. The steamed dumplings - prawn, pork, vegetable and black fungus, scallop and pork - were precisely flavoured, delicately spiced or herbed, and fresh as you like. The char siu buns could be demolished in one bite, that curious combination of sweet, areated dough and spiced filling unusually subtle and allusive. And there were plenty of noodles to fill up any odd corners. The only criticism that Neoprene offered was that you couldn't afford to hang around with this kind of arrangement, because the elements cooled down fairly rapidly and a cool scallop or prawn dumpling is not so appetising as a hot one, while a stone-cold rice flour roll is hardly edible at all.

I, meanwhile, was wandering through the à la carte menu, making merry with Confucius salad and salt-and-pepper squid - a cold and a hot first course - followed by spicy bean curd lamb, with some garlic aubergine and steamed jasmine rice as makeweights. The use of dipping sauces - green chilli, red chilli and yellow mustard - in sexy little bowls to liven up the squid was a typical judicious, Japanese-effect touch. The salad, which was made up largely of precisely crunchy bean sprouts combined with finely-shredded cooked mushrooms, was wonderfully light, clean and refreshing. The lamb had been cut into discs and had an extraordinary texture. I could not decide whether it had been caused by the marinade or by mincing it finely, then compressing it again. Either way, it and its sauce boomed with flavour, made fresh for each mouthful by a thoughtful addition of choi sum. Thick sticks of aubergine, cooked but not floppy, were made to dance a lively fandango by the clever addition of chilli.

So carried away were we that we stuck in for a hopelessly un-Asian pudding apiece: tamarind sticky- toffee pudding for me, pear tarte tatin for Neoprene. The pudding chef had let his or her decorative instincts really rip on these, each plate an artful construct of blobs, slashes, swirls and bits of decoration, but this could not take away the fact that these were top-notch puddings in which the secondary ingredients (and the blobs, slashes and swirls) made perfectly judged contributions to the whole.

The bill was £93.10, which puts the Orient comfortably above your average Chinatown diner. Strip out the booze (a bottle of nicely-suited Provençal rosé at a stiffish £21), water and coffee, and it comes down to £65.65. Although charging almost £5 for the choi sum and the aubergine is pushing it a bit, the overall sum isn't unfair for hugely intelligent and accomplished cooking.
