Downstairs is a fast-food, noodle-style operation, which sits with gaudy cheek inside the heavy neo-classical pomposity of the old banking hall, as if the messenger boy had moved into the manager's office. I am told that the food is not bad at all, and clearly in a different price range from that of the minimalist decor/maximalist price of the 22-carat dining room upstairs. You reach this by way of a side entrance guarded by a young man in a heavy coat, and by a lift for one-and-a-half people or by some sinuous stairs. The arrangements don't make it easy for would-be gastro-enthusiasts to make their way to the Orient. Perhaps the purpose is to create a touch of secretive elitism. Whatever, as my daughter would say in that peculiarly dismissive tone of voice, it is, in my view, worth making the effort. Don't go expecting classic Chinese food, or authentic this and that. The primary cooking influences may be Chinese, but the presentation - and sometimes the structure of dishes - owes more to Japan. It's not quite fully-blown Asian fusion (a description that can be given to Singaporean food, anyway), but the eye for presentation adds a welcome dimension to the traditional, rather rough-and-ready dishing techniques associated with Chinese food. Plates come in different sizes and shapes, but all are a dazzling white, which helps to point up the brilliance of the colours of the carefully individualised dishes. For example, Neoprene wanted to investigate the dim sum lunch, one of the fixed price (£19.50) variations in the Express Lunch section. It came all together on a large, square dish. A neat stack of noodles held centre stage, down each side of which were ranged a selection of raviolis, tiny pies, char-siu buns like the tops of whiter-than-white medium-sized mushrooms, and those floppy pancakes made of rice flour. It was an arrangement that gave pause for pleasure even before she started eating. Still, it's one thing to seduce the eye, quite another to dazzle a picky palate, and few come pickier than Neoprene's. However, there was very little with which she could find fault, and a great deal that she found to praise, which she did at regular intervals as titbit after titbit vanished from the ends of her chopsticks. The little pies were absolutely oustanding, the pastry light and perfectly textured somewhere between crumb and flake, with each filling cleanly differentiated. The steamed dumplings - prawn, pork, vegetable and black fungus, scallop and pork - were precisely flavoured, delicately spiced or herbed, and fresh as you like. The char siu buns could be demolished in one bite, that curious combination of sweet, areated dough and spiced filling unusually subtle and allusive. And there were plenty of noodles to fill up any odd corners. The only criticism that Neoprene offered was that you couldn't afford to hang around with this kind of arrangement, because the elements cooled down fairly rapidly and a cool scallop or prawn dumpling is not so appetising as a hot one, while a stone-cold rice flour roll is hardly edible at all. I, meanwhile, was wandering through the à la carte menu, making merry with Confucius salad and salt-and-pepper squid - a cold and a hot first course - followed by spicy bean curd lamb, with some garlic aubergine and steamed jasmine rice as makeweights. The use of dipping sauces - green chilli, red chilli and yellow mustard - in sexy little bowls to liven up the squid was a typical judicious, Japanese-effect touch. The salad, which was made up largely of precisely crunchy bean sprouts combined with finely-shredded cooked mushrooms, was wonderfully light, clean and refreshing. The lamb had been cut into discs and had an extraordinary texture. I could not decide whether it had been caused by the marinade or by mincing it finely, then compressing it again. Either way, it and its sauce boomed with flavour, made fresh for each mouthful by a thoughtful addition of choi sum. Thick sticks of aubergine, cooked but not floppy, were made to dance a lively fandango by the clever addition of chilli. So carried away were we that we stuck in for a hopelessly un-Asian pudding apiece: tamarind sticky- toffee pudding for me, pear tarte tatin for Neoprene. The pudding chef had let his or her decorative instincts really rip on these, each plate an artful construct of blobs, slashes, swirls and bits of decoration, but this could not take away the fact that these were top-notch puddings in which the secondary ingredients (and the blobs, slashes and swirls) made perfectly judged contributions to the whole. The bill was £93.10, which puts the Orient comfortably above your average Chinatown diner. Strip out the booze (a bottle of nicely-suited Provençal rosé at a stiffish £21), water and coffee, and it comes down to £65.65. Although charging almost £5 for the choi sum and the aubergine is pushing it a bit, the overall sum isn't unfair for hugely intelligent and accomplished cooking.

fields.headline: Why worry?
fields.standfirst: Look on the bright side: everyone worries. In fact, we're designed that way. The thing is, we  can  do something about it. David Newnham finds out what.
fields.trailText: Look on the bright side: everyone worries. In fact, we're designed that way. The thing is, we  can  do something about it. David Newnham finds out what.
fields.body:
The Fulani of Mali have a picturesque creation myth. The Fulani live and die by dairy farming. Not surprisingly, therefore, they believe that the world began as a great globule of milk. Then the god Doondari descended, and from the milk he created stone. In due course, the stone created iron, the iron created fire, the fire created water and the water created air. When this chain reaction was complete and the five elements were in place, Doondari came down a second time and shaped the elements into people.

But the people proved to be proud. So Doondari created blindness, and blindness defeated the people. When blindness itself became proud, Doondari created sleep, and sleep defeated blindness. And when sleep in turn became too proud, Doondari created worry. And worry defeated sleep.

Worry. Like breathing and eating, it is something that all humans do. The Fulani will have their own word for it. But they'll do it in exactly the same way as people in Birmingham. Our word comes from the Old Frisian wergia , meaning "to kill". Deep into the 17th century, to worry a person or an animal was to strangle them; to seize them by the throat with one's teeth, to tear and lacerate them, and to shake the life out of them. As time went by and the word matured, it was left to dogs to keep up this vicious sort of worrying, usually with sheep, while we more sophisticated creatures graduated to figurative worrying by means of hostile and menacing speech, employed repeatedly and over prolonged periods.

It was this dogged persistence that soon became the hallmark of worrying. Victims would be plagued and pestered with reiterated demands and worn down by repeated attacks. By and by, people began to speak in terms of worrying away at intractable problems, coming at those problems again and again, until they had whittled them down to nothing.

And so the scene was set for a kind of linguistic crossover in which the worrier became the worried, and the worried became the worry. For it was now possible for a person to lie in bed at night, worrying away at life's problems in the hope of defeating them by daybreak, and at the same time to be worried by those problems. To be beset by worries. To be doubly a worrier. No wonder it keeps us awake in our beds.

I need help. I cannot fall asleep at night. I've tried doctors' medications, OTC piles, everything, but nothing works. When I lie down in bed, I cannot stop my mind from thinking. Even good things that happen, I just can't turn it off. I feel sleepy at night, but once I'm in the bed, there goes the brain, thinking about anything and everything. Like I said, I've seen doctors, with no results. I went to a sleep clinic, but they only wanted to study me while I was sleeping. That's not my problem! It's getting to sleep. Anyone that can help me, please! Several times it's almost come to either I get to sleep or get the gun. I'm desperate. I need help.
Message posted to the SleepNet insomnia bulletin board by John D at 11.57pm, September 4, 1998

What John needs, perhaps, is a good book. Something like Stop Worrying: Understand Your Anxiety And Banish It Forever! by Frank J Bruno. Or 365 Bible Promises For People Who Worry (A Little Or A Lot), by Alice Chapin. Or The Worrywart's Companion: Twenty-One Ways To Soothe Yourself And Worry Smart, by Dr Beverly Potter. Perhaps this is the one. Worry: Controlling It And Using It Wisely, by Edward M Hallowell.

Hallowell is a senior lecturer at Harvard Medical School and a founder-director of a centre for cognitive and emotional health. He's been worrying away at worry for years. Worry, he says, is what we humans are good at. It's our thing. "To create worry," he says, "humans elongate fear with anticipation and memory, expand it in imagination and fuel it with emotion. The uniquely human mental process called worrying depends upon having a brain that can reason, remember, reflect, feel, and imagine. Only humans have a brain big enough to do this simultaneously and do it well."

Of course there's humans and there's humans, and there's worrying and there's worrying. Healthy worry he describes as "the root of planning". At the other extreme is full-blown paranoia. A worrying disposition may be tied up with a diagnosable condition such as depression, attention deficit disorder or generalised anxiety disorder. And some people may indeed be born worriers, genetically wired to worry themselves sick.

But even they can retrain their brains into new patterns, says Hallowell. It's a question of breaking out of the cycle and moving on. He recommends "connectedness" - opening up to other people, to other ideas, and to our spiritual sides. Sometimes medication and psychotherapy are required. Other times, exercise will do it - or yoga, or a change of diet. And some people, he reckons, just need to get good insurance.

In a matter of seconds the body is transformed. To prepare for exertion, blood pressure and heart rate rocket; the liver pours out glucose and calls up fat reserves to be processed for energy; the circulatory system diverts blood from nonessential functions, such as digestion, to the brain and muscles. This is precisely what you need if your goal is to survive the next 10 minutes.
Description of flight-or-fight syndrome, Time/Life

We all know about stress. We've all heard of flight-or-fight syndrome. In the past two decades, it has received more attention than any other human condition. But although worry may lead to stress, and via stress to indigestion, ulcers, a depressed immune system and, ultimately, death, it is of itself a rather different animal. Webster's medical dictionary defines worry as "a mental distress or agitation resulting from concern, usually for something impending or anticipated". Dr Carole Clarke, a clinical psychologist, has pinned it down more precisely. Worry, he says, is the mental counterpart of anxiety. We worry about things we fear may happen at another time, or which we fear are happening now, but in another place. It is "a way - a poor one - to try to control the future or events and other people at a distance".

Too bad that worry often ends up controlling us. But we can master it, says Clarke. And if we can control our conscious worrying, then we can also affect the reservoir of anxiety that our worry has left behind in our unconscious. The quickest way of doing this is to control what he calls "self-talk".

Self-talk, he says, is the perpetual conversation we have with ourselves. "We all have ongoing internal dialogues about concerns, hopes, plans, decisions and so forth, and we can easily observe what we're saying to ourselves, how we're saying it, when we're saying it and what are our perspectives, intentions and directions. Worry involves a great deal of self-talk. Controlling worry can be easily accomplished by intentionally intervening in that internal dialogue.

"Usually, when we worry, we have conversations with ourselves about distressing things we anticipate happening." The key word here, says Clarke, is "anticipate", because the worry is about something that hasn't happened and may or may not happen. "Worry is always about something imaginary. Something that doesn't yet exist. Worry, in fact, is the process of becoming distressed about the non-existent. Put in that perspective, it seems rather silly and useless.

"When you are worried about something, you are having distressing conversations with yourself about things you imagine might happen or be happening outside your observation. Because you are literally worried about nothing - these events are in your mind, not in your real, physical environment - there is nothing you can do about the objects of your worry. You are stuck. You are helpless. You can't do anything about nothing."

But it's possible, says Clarke, to intervene in these internal dialogues as if one were an outside, objective mediator. "You can transform these dialogues into useful and productive activities that allay the fears you feel and break the useless cycle of mental 'awful'-ising."

The first thing to do to stop the "awful"-ising is to apply thought-stopping, says Clarke. "Simply say 'Stop' in your mind. Mentally shout it, if necessary. Whenever you find yourself worrying, stop the dialogue this way immediately. This may sound too easy, but it really works."

The next step is to replace the worry dialogue with a practical dialogue. "The events you are anticipating really might occur, and you can't waste your time stuck in the worry cycle. You have to plan your most probable effective responses to the most probable future events. You have to determine if there is anything you can do right now to prevent or modify those events. Talk to yourself about what probably will happen and what you can do about it."

According to legend, Guatemalan children used to tell one worry to each doll when they went to bed at night and then placed the dolls under their pillows. In the morning the dolls had taken their worries away. Each worry doll we make is a sign of our sorrows for the 140,000 dead and disappeared in Guatemala. The dolls symbolise our united stand - with the students of Guatemala - to demand accountability. For each worry doll you and others make, commit to taking an action on behalf of those who suffered the human-rights violations during the Guatemala Civil War. MATERIALS: Wooden Doll Pins, Popsicle or Craft Sticks, Hot Glue Gun or School Glue, Masking Tape, Scissors, Markers, Yarn...
Amnesty International USA, Make A Worry Doll campaign

Julia Cole, an agony aunt and a counsellor with Relate, is convinced that action is the key to conquering worry. And over the years, she has worked out a neat strategy for ending the cycle of anxiety. You don't need popsicles or glue guns, leotards or rowing machines to try her method. Just a pen and a sheet of paper.

"Some worries are essential," says Cole. "They are spurs to action. But some people become obsessive worriers. They just can't get things out of their brain. And quite often, it's the lack of action that's the problem. They find themselves worrying because they don't know what action to take, and that creates a vicious circle." So she tells clients to select a day at random and write out a list of all the worries that come to them. At end of the day, they should divide those worries into three categories.

"Category One consists of the things that you can't personally change - global or political events, say. Category Two are things that you can change, such as asking your partner or children to come home on time. And in Category Three, you put the things that you can change but don't really want to because you're actually quite happy with the status quo.

"The next stage is to look at Category One and ask yourself if there is anything at all that you could do to allay those worries. For instance, let's say you're worried about the greenhouse effect, or children not having enough to eat in Africa. You might decide to join Greenpeace or put some money in an envelope for Africa. All right, so it's probably a drop in the ocean, but it's an action, and it might help those worries not to loom so large.

"In Category Two, take action on things you can positively change. And if they don't change, then you need to review the situation after a week, say, and in the meantime, stop worrying about it and stop letting the stress build up inside you. As for Category 3 worries, well, you have to allow yourself a sense of perspective. If you've eaten two chocolate bars today, it probably isn't a good idea to eat a third, but it's not the end of the world.

"However, if you find that things get stuck in one category, then try to move them into an action phase. Always try to do something. If you can't, well that's life. But if you can, it will help you. It will disarm the worry - make it less powerful. And it will prevent that circling which compulsive and obsessive worriers often talk about."

Writing things down - it's a tried and tested formula. Sherlock Holmes swore by it. Research in Germany, says Cole, has shown that people with painful arthritis suffered less if they wrote down how they were feeling each day. And if you keep a diary, she says, "you can always look at next year and see how this year's worries just turned to dust".

Like Clarke, Cole believes that worry is often a way of attempting to control events and people. "It's the worrying - the planning and thinking about what will happen, that actually allows the worrier to have a kind of odd control over their life, because they assume and pre-empt. For some worriers, it's almost a protection against life.

"A worrier will say to you, well, if I do A, B will occur, if I do B, C will occur. It's almost as if they're playing a game, and it's often about a desire to control and a fear that if they speak up against the boss who's been harassing them, say, they will be giving some control to the boss. While they're still worrying about it, in a strange kind of way, they're still in control. They can say, well this and this will happen. They can plan it in their mind like a map. Whereas if they speak up, the boss might react in any one of 10 ways."

For you dream you are crossing the Channel, and tossing about in a steamer from Harwich Which is something between a large bathing machine and a very small second-class carriage. And you're giving a treat (penny ice and cold meat) to a party of friends and relations. They're a ravenous horde, and they all came on board at Sloane Square and South Kensington Stations. And bound on that journey you find your attorney (who started that morning from Devon); He's a bit undersized, and you don't feel surprised when he tells you he's only eleven...
When You're Lying Awake, from Iolanthe, by WS Gilbert

If worry is, in Carole Clarke's words, "the mental counterpart of anxiety", then anxiety is fundamental to human life, says Lisa Miller, chair of the Child and Family Department at the Tavistock Clinic. "The human condition is an anxious one," she says. "It's something that goes right back to the absolute beginning of life.

"When a baby is born - well, you can imagine what the difference is between being all curled up inside your mother, plugged into somebody else's system. Suddenly, out you come, and at once you are flooded with anxiety. What is this place, for Christ's sake? We have more brain cells functioning then than at any other time, so a baby is intelligent - brilliantly, brilliantly intelligent, but totally uninformed. It has everything to learn. And it has to tolerate a high degree of anxiety."

In infancy - in the time before active worrying kicks in - a good deal of that raw anxiety is tolerated for us by our parents. "That is why looking after a new baby is a very anxious procedure," says Miller. "There are lots of rational reasons why you might be anxious. But really what you're getting from an infant is a complete blast of primitive anxiety which you then have to take on the chin. You have to absorb it - and, if possible, not return too much of it to the infant."

But as the child grows up, how well it manages life often depends on how well it manages anxiety, says Miller. This is partly a question of "how well your subconscious is crunching away and dealing with it without troubling you", but partly a question of how we cope with it mentally. "The child has to learn to think. Our method of dealing with anxiety is to apply our minds.

"What we have to think about is either the anxiety-provoking things that are happening to us out there, or the anxiety-provoking feelings we get. All sorts of feelings can provoke anxiety. People can become frightfully anxious if they're overwhelmed by strong, uncontrollable feelings of unwelcome anger or jealousy or envy, especially if they don't know what the hell is afflicting them. And that can produce again this sort of raw anxiety that's undiagnosable. Anxiety is more tolerable if you know what you're anxious about. Sometimes we need complex, sophisticated ways of understanding what's bothering us. But the worst sort of anxiety is when you don't know why you're anxious. The more you're able to stop with any anxiety-making thought, hold on to it and give it a whirl mentally, the more you'll be able to process the anxiety. The less it will just be overcoming you."

Language, it seems, is a double-edged sword. On the one hand, it equips us to deal with anxiety better than any dumb animal. But, on the other hand, it enables our minds to range backwards and forwards in time - to anticipate the future or cogitate on the past. To worry.

The impact of Antarctic commercial tourism on the long-term breeding and viability of populations of native animals, such as penguins and seals, is unclear. The project involves newly developed unique techniques for remote monitoring of penguin heart rate (using a dummy egg, equipped with an infra-red sensor to monitor blood flow). This system has recently been tested in the Antarctic and preliminary results indicate that incubating birds may experience significant transient heart-rate changes upon encroachment by human visitors.
Project report, the Centre for Biological and Medical Systems, Imperial College

While one group of scientists at Imperial College place fibreglass eggs under anxious penguins, in another department, Professor Igor Aleksander is exploring the very nature of consciousness, and using computers to simulate the brain's neural networks. Aleksander now believes that worry is a central function of consciousness: an integral part of neural activity.

"Modern neuro-physiological theories about how our brain creates consciousness suggest that it does so in the kind of detail in which we imagine things," says Aleksander. "I can sit here and work out how I'm going to get to Sussex this evening. I can visualise South Ken station and how I'm going to buy my ticket. Now all of that involves a sort of inner visual sense which is there even while I'm talking to you and looking at my computer or the book in front of me. But these inner sensors are very directly related to neural activity in our heads, and I think the penny's beginning to drop that we don't have a kind of peculiar homunculus inside us that's looking at the activity of our neurons, but that it actually is the activity of our neurons. And the same goes for worry.

"And so if I listen to the radio and someone says Victoria Station is shut down, I start worrying about how the hell I'm going to get to Sussex. And that worry expresses itself in the inability to cause my neurons to fire in a way that solves the problem for me. The business of going through, vision by vision, as to how I'm going to solve a problem suddenly gets blocked, and I don't know where I'm going to go to next. And that sets off some anxiety neurons, and I sense that viscerally.

"I think it was Darwin's idea that worries are visceral. It feels like you've got a pain in your stomach. But that's because the neurons that are involved in assessing pains in your stomach are actually firing in this process. Worry is a physical happening. And it can cause you to have an ulcer if it goes too far."

Aleksander is confident that other conscious creatures must experience worry. "Maybe not in exactly the same way as we do, and maybe they can't express their worries. But have you never seen a dog worry or a cat worry? Of course they do. Whether an amoeba worries, I don't know. Certainly other creatures worry.

And a computer? "If you take the definition of a computer as the kind of thing you do your writing on - a general purpose machine which in its own right doesn't do anything - then no. You can't say it worries when it can't find some internet address. A computer will simply start looking at all its options until it finds one, but it doesn't have a visceral worry that causes it to solve its problems. Whereas a neural computer or a neural simulation of the brain might. I am trying to do some work on emotions in general where this visceral representation actually happens.

"We use computers to try to emulate the way in which neural systems of the brain work. When I do work on emotion, I create a virtual machine on a computer - a machine that's a bit like my brain. And the virtual machine can, in fact, display worry. Otherwise I couldn't do research on worry inside a computer."

If you never had a worry stone, now is your chance to experience something truly addicting! If you had a worry stone as a child, now is your chance to re-live those memories. These uncommon worry stones are made out of a material called rainbow obsidian. Rainbow obsidian ranks a hardness of 6 on the Moh's scale (10 being a diamond), making it strong enough to handle your concerns. Polished to a brilliant luster, the Executive Worry Stone, as we have named it, has subtle streaks of natural color that are visible as you turn your stone in bright light. In an assortment of freeform shapes, the Executive Worry Stone will fit snugly in your hand while your thumb works out your frustrations and concerns in a safe way. Want a cigarette but want to quit? Grab your Executive Worry Stone. Just get screamed at by your boss for no reason? Grab your Executive Worry Stone. Kids driving you over the edge? Grab your Executive Worry Stone. Made in Mexico, this item is available in limited quantities at a special price...
Advertisement by Exotic Imports on www.exoticimports.com

The computer on your desktop may not have the wherewithal to worry. But one day soon, it might be able to straighten out its owner more effectively than all the beads and dolls and pebbles in the world. It's happening already in a small way. Dr Judy Proudfoot and a team at the Institute of Psychiatry have just got together with Ultramind, a company specialising in interactive healthcare programmes, to produce Beating The Blues. What it offers is a glimpse of the future.

Beating The Blues consists of six CD-ROMs, and is designed to be operated under supervision in GPs' surgeries, where it is currently undergoing trials. "There is a shortage of about 1,000 psychologists and properly qualified cognitive behaviour therapists in the country," says Proudfoot, "and waiting lists can be up to two years. So the idea is that, when a GP diagnoses anxiety and/or depression, the patient is referred to the computer instead of being given pills or put on a waiting list."

The programme consists of eight sessions - one session a week - with activities and tasks to complete in between. And it uses a combination of TV documentary-type case studies and interactive therapeutic activities that encourage patients to apply the techniques to their everyday situations.

"They are cognitive therapy techniques," says Proudfoot. "So it's analysing and challenging their thinking, looking at their behaviour and their deeply held beliefs, and helping them to tap into their thinking and see whether it's distorted. It's a huge programme, and it's not just for people with clinical worrying. It could be for someone who goes to their doctor and says 'I'm distressed' or 'I'm stressed'. And we've got a module in there on sleep management.

"Studies show that some patients actually prefer it to face-to-face therapy, because they can see the therapist as judgmental. And computer-based programmes in the US have been shown to be as effective as face-to-face therapy. I chose to locate this in GP surgeries because I wanted to put more sophisticated techniques in it and I wanted that minimal clinical supervision. If there are problems, the GP can take steps to give further support. But there is certainly other stuff happening that patients will be able to use at home, and on the internet as well. It's not too far away."

But will it take more than cyber-shrinks to keep our rambling brains in check? According to the Fulani of Mali, worry defeated sleep. But the matter didn't end there. For worry itself became too proud, and so Doondari created death to defeat him. Ultimately, of course, death got out of hand as well. He always does. And when that happened, Doondari knew he had to put in another personal appearance. He descended for the third time, and he came as Gueno the Eternal One. And Gueno defeated death

 Extracts from Worry - And How Not To reproduced by permission of CS Clarke, PhD. The full text is available on The Performance Resources Page, www.superperformance.com. Worry: Controlling It And Using It Wisely, by Edward M Hallowell, is published by Pantheon Books, and is available from amazon.com at $18.20. For information on Beating The Blues, write to the Institute of Psychiatry, Department of Psychology, De Crespigny Park, Denmark Hill, London SE5 8AF.

A worrying disposition may be tied up with a diagnosable condition such as depression, attention deficit disorder or generalised anxiety disorder. And some people may indeed be born worriers, genetically wired to worry themselves sick. But even they can retrain their brains into new patterns, says Hallowell. It's a question of breaking out of the cycle and moving on. He recommends "connectedness" - opening up to other people, to other ideas, and to our spiritual sides. Sometimes medication and psychotherapy are required. Other times, exercise will do it - or yoga, or a change of diet. And some people, he reckons, just need to get good insurance. In a matter of seconds the body is transformed. To prepare for exertion, blood pressure and heart rate rocket; the liver pours out glucose and calls up fat reserves to be processed for energy; the circulatory system diverts blood from nonessential functions, such as digestion, to the brain and muscles. This is precisely what you need if your goal is to survive the next 10 minutes. Description of flight-or-fight syndrome, Time/Life We all know about stress. We've all heard of flight-or-fight syndrome. In the past two decades, it has received more attention than any other human condition. But although worry may lead to stress, and via stress to indigestion, ulcers, a depressed immune system and, ultimately, death, it is of itself a rather different animal. Webster's medical dictionary defines worry as "a mental distress or agitation resulting from concern, usually for something impending or anticipated". Dr Carole Clarke, a clinical psychologist, has pinned it down more precisely. Worry, he says, is the mental counterpart of anxiety. We worry about things we fear may happen at another time, or which we fear are happening now, but in another place. It is "a way - a poor one - to try to control the future or events and other people at a distance". Too bad that worry often ends up controlling us. But we can master it, says Clarke. And if we can control our conscious worrying, then we can also affect the reservoir of anxiety that our worry has left behind in our unconscious. The quickest way of doing this is to control what he calls "self-talk". Self-talk, he says, is the perpetual conversation we have with ourselves. "We all have ongoing internal dialogues about concerns, hopes, plans, decisions and so forth, and we can easily observe what we're saying to ourselves, how we're saying it, when we're saying it and what are our perspectives, intentions and directions. Worry involves a great deal of self-talk. Controlling worry can be easily accomplished by intentionally intervening in that internal dialogue. "Usually, when we worry, we have conversations with ourselves about distressing things we anticipate happening." The key word here, says Clarke, is "anticipate", because the worry is about something that hasn't happened and may or may not happen. "Worry is always about something imaginary. Something that doesn't yet exist. Worry, in fact, is the process of becoming distressed about the non-existent. Put in that perspective, it seems rather silly and useless. "When you are worried about something, you are having distressing conversations with yourself about things you imagine might happen or be happening outside your observation. Because you are literally worried about nothing - these events are in your mind, not in your real, physical environment - there is nothing you can do about the objects of your worry. You are stuck. You are helpless. You can't do anything about nothing." But it's possible, says Clarke, to intervene in these internal dialogues as if one were an outside, objective mediator. "You can transform these dialogues into useful and productive activities that allay the fears you feel and break the useless cycle of mental 'awful'-ising." The first thing to do to stop the "awful"-ising is to apply thought-stopping, says Clarke. "Simply say 'Stop' in your mind. Mentally shout it, if necessary. Whenever you find yourself worrying, stop the dialogue this way immediately. This may sound too easy, but it really works." The next step is to replace the worry dialogue with a practical dialogue. "The events you are anticipating really might occur, and you can't waste your time stuck in the worry cycle. You have to plan your most probable effective responses to the most probable future events. You have to determine if there is anything you can do right now to prevent or modify those events. Talk to yourself about what probably will happen and what you can do about it." According to legend, Guatemalan children used to tell one worry to each doll when they went to bed at night and then placed the dolls under their pillows. In the morning the dolls had taken their worries away. Each worry doll we make is a sign of our sorrows for the 140,000 dead and disappeared in Guatemala. The dolls symbolise our united stand - with the students of Guatemala - to demand accountability. For each worry doll you and others make, commit to taking an action on behalf of those who suffered the human-rights violations during the Guatemala Civil War. MATERIALS: Wooden Doll Pins, Popsicle or Craft Sticks, Hot Glue Gun or School Glue, Masking Tape, Scissors, Markers, Yarn... Amnesty International USA, Make A Worry Doll campaign Julia Cole, an agony aunt and a counsellor with Relate, is convinced that action is the key to conquering worry. And over the years, she has worked out a neat strategy for ending the cycle of anxiety. You don't need popsicles or glue guns, leotards or rowing machines to try her method. Just a pen and a sheet of paper. "Some worries are essential," says Cole. "They are spurs to action. But some people become obsessive worriers. They just can't get things out of their brain. And quite often, it's the lack of action that's the problem. They find themselves worrying because they don't know what action to take, and that creates a vicious circle." So she tells clients to select a day at random and write out a list of all the worries that come to them. At end of the day, they should divide those worries into three categories. "Category One consists of the things that you can't personally change - global or political events, say. Category Two are things that you can change, such as asking your partner or children to come home on time. And in Category Three, you put the things that you can change but don't really want to because you're actually quite happy with the status quo. "The next stage is to look at Category One and ask yourself if there is anything at all that you could do to allay those worries. For instance, let's say you're worried about the greenhouse effect, or children not having enough to eat in Africa. You might decide to join Greenpeace or put some money in an envelope for Africa. All right, so it's probably a drop in the ocean, but it's an action, and it might help those worries not to loom so large. "In Category Two, take action on things you can positively change. And if they don't change, then you need to review the situation after a week, say, and in the meantime, stop worrying about it and stop letting the stress build up inside you. As for Category 3 worries, well, you have to allow yourself a sense of perspective. If you've eaten two chocolate bars today, it probably isn't a good idea to eat a third, but it's not the end of the world. "However, if you find that things get stuck in one category, then try to move them into an action phase. Always try to do something. If you can't, well that's life. But if you can, it will help you. It will disarm the worry - make it less powerful. And it will prevent that circling which compulsive and obsessive worriers often talk about." Writing things down - it's a tried and tested formula. Sherlock Holmes swore by it. Research in Germany, says Cole, has shown that people with painful arthritis suffered less if they wrote down how they were feeling each day. And if you keep a diary, she says, "you can always look at next year and see how this year's worries just turned to dust". Like Clarke, Cole believes that worry is often a way of attempting to control events and people. "It's the worrying - the planning and thinking about what will happen, that actually allows the worrier to have a kind of odd control over their life, because they assume and pre-empt. For some worriers, it's almost a protection against life. "A worrier will say to you, well, if I do A, B will occur, if I do B, C will occur. It's almost as if they're playing a game, and it's often about a desire to control and a fear that if they speak up against the boss who's been harassing them, say, they will be giving some control to the boss. While they're still worrying about it, in a strange kind of way, they're still in control. They can say, well this and this will happen. They can plan it in their mind like a map. Whereas if they speak up, the boss might react in any one of 10 ways." For you dream you are crossing the Channel, and tossing about in a steamer from Harwich Which is something between a large bathing machine and a very small second-class carriage. And you're giving a treat (penny ice and cold meat) to a party of friends and relations. They're a ravenous horde, and they all came on board at Sloane Square and South Kensington Stations. And bound on that journey you find your attorney (who started that morning from Devon); He's a bit undersized, and you don't feel surprised when he tells you he's only eleven... When You're Lying Awake, from Iolanthe, by WS Gilbert If worry is, in Carole Clarke's words, "the mental counterpart of anxiety", then anxiety is fundamental to human life, says Lisa Miller, chair of the Child and Family Department at the Tavistock Clinic. "The human condition is an anxious one," she says. "It's something that goes right back to the absolute beginning of life. "When a baby is born - well, you can imagine what the difference is between being all curled up inside your mother, plugged into somebody else's system. Suddenly, out you come, and at once you are flooded with anxiety. What is this place, for Christ's sake? We have more brain cells functioning then than at any other time, so a baby is intelligent - brilliantly, brilliantly intelligent, but totally uninformed. It has everything to learn. And it has to tolerate a high degree of anxiety." In infancy - in the time before active worrying kicks in - a good deal of that raw anxiety is tolerated for us by our parents. "That is why looking after a new baby is a very anxious procedure," says Miller. "There are lots of rational reasons why you might be anxious. But really what you're getting from an infant is a complete blast of primitive anxiety which you then have to take on the chin. You have to absorb it - and, if possible, not return too much of it to the infant." But as the child grows up, how well it manages life often depends on how well it manages anxiety, says Miller. This is partly a question of "how well your subconscious is crunching away and dealing with it without troubling you", but partly a question of how we cope with it mentally. "The child has to learn to think. Our method of dealing with anxiety is to apply our minds. "What we have to think about is either the anxiety-provoking things that are happening to us out there, or the anxiety-provoking feelings we get. All sorts of feelings can provoke anxiety. People can become frightfully anxious if they're overwhelmed by strong, uncontrollable feelings of unwelcome anger or jealousy or envy, especially if they don't know what the hell is afflicting them. And that can produce again this sort of raw anxiety that's undiagnosable. Anxiety is more tolerable if you know what you're anxious about. Sometimes we need complex, sophisticated ways of understanding what's bothering us. But the worst sort of anxiety is when you don't know why you're anxious. The more you're able to stop with any anxiety-making thought, hold on to it and give it a whirl mentally, the more you'll be able to process the anxiety. The less it will just be overcoming you." Language, it seems, is a double-edged sword. On the one hand, it equips us to deal with anxiety better than any dumb animal. But, on the other hand, it enables our minds to range backwards and forwards in time - to anticipate the future or cogitate on the past. To worry. The impact of Antarctic commercial tourism on the long-term breeding and viability of populations of native animals, such as penguins and seals, is unclear. The project involves newly developed unique techniques for remote monitoring of penguin heart rate (using a dummy egg, equipped with an infra-red sensor to monitor blood flow). This system has recently been tested in the Antarctic and preliminary results indicate that incubating birds may experience significant transient heart-rate changes upon encroachment by human visitors. Project report, the Centre for Biological and Medical Systems, Imperial College While one group of scientists at Imperial College place fibreglass eggs under anxious penguins, in another department, Professor Igor Aleksander is exploring the very nature of consciousness, and using computers to simulate the brain's neural networks. Aleksander now believes that worry is a central function of consciousness: an integral part of neural activity. "Modern neuro-physiological theories about how our brain creates consciousness suggest that it does so in the kind of detail in which we imagine things," says Aleksander. "I can sit here and work out how I'm going to get to Sussex this evening. I can visualise South Ken station and how I'm going to buy my ticket. Now all of that involves a sort of inner visual sense which is there even while I'm talking to you and looking at my computer or the book in front of me. But these inner sensors are very directly related to neural activity in our heads, and I think the penny's beginning to drop that we don't have a kind of peculiar homunculus inside us that's looking at the activity of our neurons, but that it actually is the activity of our neurons. And the same goes for worry. "And so if I listen to the radio and someone says Victoria Station is shut down, I start worrying about how the hell I'm going to get to Sussex. And that worry expresses itself in the inability to cause my neurons to fire in a way that solves the problem for me. The business of going through, vision by vision, as to how I'm going to solve a problem suddenly gets blocked, and I don't know where I'm going to go to next. And that sets off some anxiety neurons, and I sense that viscerally. "I think it was Darwin's idea that worries are visceral. It feels like you've got a pain in your stomach. But that's because the neurons that are involved in assessing pains in your stomach are actually firing in this process. Worry is a physical happening. And it can cause you to have an ulcer if it goes too far." Aleksander is confident that other conscious creatures must experience worry. "Maybe not in exactly the same way as we do, and maybe they can't express their worries. But have you never seen a dog worry or a cat worry? Of course they do. Whether an amoeba worries, I don't know. Certainly other creatures worry. And a computer? "If you take the definition of a computer as the kind of thing you do your writing on - a general purpose machine which in its own right doesn't do anything - then no. You can't say it worries when it can't find some internet address. A computer will simply start looking at all its options until it finds one, but it doesn't have a visceral worry that causes it to solve its problems. Whereas a neural computer or a neural simulation of the brain might. I am trying to do some work on emotions in general where this visceral representation actually happens. "We use computers to try to emulate the way in which neural systems of the brain work. When I do work on emotion, I create a virtual machine on a computer - a machine that's a bit like my brain. And the virtual machine can, in fact, display worry. Otherwise I couldn't do research on worry inside a computer." If you never had a worry stone, now is your chance to experience something truly addicting! If you had a worry stone as a child, now is your chance to re-live those memories. These uncommon worry stones are made out of a material called rainbow obsidian. Rainbow obsidian ranks a hardness of 6 on the Moh's scale (10 being a diamond), making it strong enough to handle your concerns. Polished to a brilliant luster, the Executive Worry Stone, as we have named it, has subtle streaks of natural color that are visible as you turn your stone in bright light. In an assortment of freeform shapes, the Executive Worry Stone will fit snugly in your hand while your thumb works out your frustrations and concerns in a safe way. Want a cigarette but want to quit? Grab your Executive Worry Stone. Just get screamed at by your boss for no reason? Grab your Executive Worry Stone. Kids driving you over the edge? Grab your Executive Worry Stone. Made in Mexico, this item is available in limited quantities at a special price... Advertisement by Exotic Imports on www.exoticimports.com The computer on your desktop may not have the wherewithal to worry. But one day soon, it might be able to straighten out its owner more effectively than all the beads and dolls and pebbles in the world. It's happening already in a small way. Dr Judy Proudfoot and a team at the Institute of Psychiatry have just got together with Ultramind, a company specialising in interactive healthcare programmes, to produce Beating The Blues. What it offers is a glimpse of the future. Beating The Blues consists of six CD-ROMs, and is designed to be operated under supervision in GPs' surgeries, where it is currently undergoing trials. "There is a shortage of about 1,000 psychologists and properly qualified cognitive behaviour therapists in the country," says Proudfoot, "and waiting lists can be up to two years. So the idea is that, when a GP diagnoses anxiety and/or depression, the patient is referred to the computer instead of being given pills or put on a waiting list." The programme consists of eight sessions - one session a week - with activities and tasks to complete in between. And it uses a combination of TV documentary-type case studies and interactive therapeutic activities that encourage patients to apply the techniques to their everyday situations. "They are cognitive therapy techniques," says Proudfoot. "So it's analysing and challenging their thinking, looking at their behaviour and their deeply held beliefs, and helping them to tap into their thinking and see whether it's distorted. It's a huge programme, and it's not just for people with clinical worrying. It could be for someone who goes to their doctor and says 'I'm distressed' or 'I'm stressed'. And we've got a module in there on sleep management. "Studies show that some patients actually prefer it to face-to-face therapy, because they can see the therapist as judgmental. And computer-based programmes in the US have been shown to be as effective as face-to-face therapy. I chose to locate this in GP surgeries because I wanted to put more sophisticated techniques in it and I wanted that minimal clinical supervision. If there are problems, the GP can take steps to give further support. But there is certainly other stuff happening that patients will be able to use at home, and on the internet as well. It's not too far away." But will it take more than cyber-shrinks to keep our rambling brains in check? According to the Fulani of Mali, worry defeated sleep. But the matter didn't end there. For worry itself became too proud, and so Doondari created death to defeat him. Ultimately, of course, death got out of hand as well. He always does. And when that happened, Doondari knew he had to put in another personal appearance. He descended for the third time, and he came as Gueno the Eternal One. And Gueno defeated death  Extracts from Worry - And How Not To reproduced by permission of CS Clarke, PhD. The full text is available on The Performance Resources Page, www.superperformance.com. Worry: Controlling It And Using It Wisely, by Edward M Hallowell, is published by Pantheon Books, and is available from amazon.com at $18.20. For information on Beating The Blues, write to the Institute of Psychiatry, Department of Psychology, De Crespigny Park, Denmark Hill, London SE5 8AF.

fields.headline: High fidelity
fields.standfirst: A penthouse is the ultimate glamorous address, the perfect excuse for never coming down to earth. Julia Bueno discovers what life is like with your head in the clouds.
fields.trailText: A penthouse is the ultimate glamorous address, the perfect excuse for never coming down to earth. Julia Bueno discovers what life is like with your head in the clouds.
fields.body:
Whether you're a sensible investor or the dizziest of fashion victims, image is all-important for a home. But while a flat, say, can have associations with urban deprivation and tenement squalor, "penthouse" will always have the quality mark. Not for this classy number the indignity of being rebranded as an "apartment" - or in some inaccurate cases "loft". Its very name is a byword for exclusivity, its position closest to heaven among its peers. And you'll never get to sail past it in the lift, on your way, presumably, to higher things; it is, literally and emotionally, the tops.

But this is to get too hung up on the penthouse image. They are very nice places to live, too - as Justin Warshaw, a family law barrister, well knows. He is one of the lucky few to enjoy a life above the roofs of central London. His two-bedroom penthouse, near the throng of Oxford Street, was built in 1970 above six other flats. The freehold for all of them is owned by St Paul's church, which is situated, in part, on the ground floor. This makes the Church of England an incongruous landlord for a property that was the one-time home of the silky-smooth pop singer, David Essex.

The flat has retained most of its original, space-saving, Modernist features that pervaded the style of the time. The lift opens its doors to the "soft" living space, where the sleeping, washing and eating takes place. Oak sliding doors conceal the small bedrooms and bathrooms from the open-plan remainder, sharpening the focus on the four generously proportioned windows. But the impressive view from here is a mere taster of what awaits skywards up the spiral stairs.

Effectively, this is a huge, glass, rectangular box sitting in the centre of the roof. In it, Warshaw fulfilled his dream of constructing an impressively stocked bar that could compete with any small Soho joint. Here, it is possible to prepare a Martini while contemplating an all-round view of the capital. Like the countryside changing with the seasons, this urban vista will have evolved down the years. The Palace of Westminster and Highgate Hill were always there, as was the Post Office Tower. Today, though, there are additions such as Canary Wharf and the London Eye. "I often have to get up very early to prepare my briefs for the day, which is my favourite time to come up here and work," says Warshaw. "At the moment, the sun creeps up behind the London Eye, casting a fantastic light over the east of London."

Warshaw's girlfriend, Stephanie Marshall, spends a lot of her time at the flat, and agrees that this is the best part of living high: "It is amazing to see how the light changes in the sky over such a short time, and how the weather patterns emerge. Sometimes, you can see huge grey cumulus clouds in one corner of the sky, while the other corner is bright and sunny."

A few miles north of the West End, and with a spectacular view of these busy streets, is the home of Shimon Cohen and Jessica Blair. Their flat sits above only two others but, being on top of Hampstead hill, it gives them the exclusivity of elevated living that they were after. Having acquired a taste for the lofts of New York, where Blair used to live, the couple were keen to find somewhere that was genuinely urban, yet provided a peaceful oasis from everything that goes with it.

By a stroke of luck, they stumbled across a property with 2,500 sq ft to make into whatever they wanted. The two of them are keen cooks, so they concentrated on a custom-made galley kitchen that lets them both use it at the same time without getting in each other's way.

Either side of the workspace, a series of glass doors opens on to a decked roof terrace, extending the kitchen's otherwise narrow width. And, while one end sits among the foliage of Hampstead Heath woods, the other offers a spectacular view that, on a good day, can stretch to Southend.

Cohen says that it is the synthesis of nature with the urban fabric that makes this the perfect home. "It takes me less than 20 minutes to get into work in the City, yet it's like being in a tree-house up here - it is so quiet. When I was getting dressed for New Year's Eve, I had the television on. I stopped to watch the London Eye before I realised how crazy I was - I only had to step outside to see it live."

While Cohen and Blair can enjoy nature by dint of fortunate topography, interior architect Fiona Naylor has a garden in the sky. She and her family live in a penthouse flat in Clerkenwell, east London, which Naylor, when pregnant with her first child, Max, now six, set about creating from the top floor and roof of BP's old print works. Integral to her design was the rooftop glass pavilion, which is circled by 3,500 sq ft of decked roof garden. "I love seeing the change in the seasons. I used to live in a basement flat, so I would miss it. Living up here allows you to be more aware of the environment than you otherwise would be. It's absolutely wonderful to get the full brunt of the weather, especially when the rain lashes down."

It is also a great space from which to enjoy the view of some famous London landmarks. To the east, the narrow tower of the deconsecrated St Luke's church in Old Street pokes above the skyline. This inspired Naylor to choose muted, stone colours for the flat. St Paul's cathedral is out there somewhere as well, obscured by a housing block. "I did not want any solid barriers to break up the view, so the garden is designed to break the wind and provide an edge," says Naylor. "This means only the hardier types of plants, such as the bamboo, can survive. But I also have a seasonal herb garden, eucalyptus, willow, and a 20ft silver birch."

With the added details of a small pond and hidden sand-pit for Max and his younger brother, Felix, 15 months, the terrace has an oddly terrestrial feel. "Max and his friends can run around and play as if they were in any garden," Naylor explains; "although Max now has an impressive knowledge of the various types of aeroplanes."

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck keeps up with the Joneses
fields.body:
This is a unique occurrence in the history of this column. It is concerned exclusively with the wines of a single Australian, a Victorian vigneron situated in an unusually purposeful spot for vines called the Pyrenees - a piece of titular romance of the sort that always strikes the traveller not only as incongruous but fraudulent. However, it is to our advantage, not to mention Mr David Jones's, who grows the grapes, that these Pyrenees bear little relation to their European eponym.

The soil and the climate in Jones's Pyrenean vineyard, called Dalwhinnie, are patently remarkable, though these facts in themselves - the so-called terroir of his vineyard - are not the sole reasons for the stunning excellence of his wines. For, on the same terroir and cheek by jowl with Jones's vines are those of the more famous Taltarni estate, the significant glumness of whose wines (bubblies apart) compared with Dalwhinnie's complex palette counters the arguments of the terroirists, who worship the French concept of vinous real-estate values. This claims that wine is an expression of a vineyard site, rather than a creation of fallible humankind. It is, of course, how a site is managed and its grapes pressed that are more important than the site itself, for it can express nothing without human intervention.

I tasted Jones's wines in the vineyard on a day of such clement and clear-skied warmth that I felt it expedient, before I declared my admiration, to taste them again in more leaden-weathered London. This I have now done, courtesy of shippers Justerini & Brooks. My opinions have not altered. Dalwhinnie wines are among the most concentrated yet unpretentious to emerge from that tantalising landmass called Australia, combining grace with pungency. And, since they are not outrageously expensive though they are in short supply, I felt it essential to bring them to your attention. You can buy the wine by the bottle from J&B shops in London and Edinburgh (at 61 St James s Street, London SW1 and 45 George Street, respectively) or J&B will deliver two cases or more for free, or a single case for a £9 surcharge. There are two telephone numbers - that for London is 020-7493 8721; for Edinburgh it's 0131-226 4202.

There are two cabernets, the 1998 (18 points out of 20, £22 the bottle, £264 the case, 85 cases available), and the 1997 (17 points, £17 the bottle, £204 the case, 50 cases available). The latter wine is the more alcoholic (14% as against a more lenient 12.5%), and it also displays more ripeness, darker fruit, more spice; it is like a significant left-bank chteau of a miraculous year. The 1998 has a minerally, almost minty, subtlety to its aroma, is immensely smooth yet characterful, and has graceful poise. In both wines, the tannins are lip-smackingly high class. So, what do they possess that a five-quid Chilean cannot, or what a £30 Medoc can only pray for? Intensity without clottedness; finesse with weighted presence.

There are three shirazes, all rating 17 points: a 1995 (£19.83 the bottle, £238 the case, 10 cases available), a 1997 (£17 the bottle, £204 the case, 45 cases available) and a 1998 (£19.83 the bottle, £238 the case, 80 cases available). The 1995 is vibrantly mature, marvellously tannic and, if not quite mountainous in personality, can be said to possess ruggedness. The 1997 has a hint of eucalyptus on the bouquet, striking tannins and marvellously alert, virile fruit, smooth, hinting at violets, textured like crèpe-de-chine. The 1998 is somewhat more soupily savoury in construction and is, to me, the very essence of a fine, fully-tanned Aussie shiraz. The ratings indicate that I found it difficult to choose between these three, but forced to nominate one I d go for the cheapest - not on the grounds of cost, mind.

Finally, there are two Jones chardonnays: a 1997 (14 points, £14 the bottle, £168 the case, 25 cases available) and a 1998 (17 points, £17.50 the bottle, £210 the case, 55 cases available). The 1998, finely built and lithe, has an elegant and soft Burgundian vegetality, and a creamy, soft fruit/hard fruit complexion. The 1997, though slightly less gripping, develops fast in the glass and has an oxidative fatness. Superplonks? Maybe not, but indulge me just this once.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Green genie: avocado
fields.trailText: Green genie: avocado
fields.body:
The subject
Persea americana and close relations; Central American native; strange fruit. Formerly an exotic rarity. Currently as ubiquitous as paper. Which is what the fruit can taste like if you buy the wrong stuff.

The basics
Why are avocados strange? Well, they contain serious quantities of fat - 20%-30%. The name comes from an Aztec word meaning 'butter from the wood' (according to one source) or 'testicle' (according to another). You decide. They do not ripen if they're left on the tree. And they lose sugar in the course of ripening. More prosaically, they grow in warm, humid climates; there are more than 500 varieties, or cultivars; Israel is a big supplier to you and me.

The details
We can buy avocados all year round, but some are the pits. Undisputed all-time champion and hero: the Hass variety, born in California in 1926, with purplish, thick, knobbly skin. Buy no other. There is an old idea that you can keep a cut avocado from browning (it's caused by enzymes) by sticking the seed back in. This is avo-nonsense. Rubbing with lemon juice will slow the rate of browning, but not stop it. Smart solution: eat the whole thing right now . Avo-curiosity: at fast-food joints in Chile, avocado purée is served from pump-action tubs alongside mayo and ketchup. Avo-curiosity: American football fans ate more than 16 million avocados on Super Bowl Sunday. Most was in the form of guacamole, the greatest avocado dish by a margin of some miles. Bosom buddies: tomato, onion, lemon, chilli. Avo-mania website: www.avocado.org, cyberhome of the California Avocado Commission.

Where to buy
Anywhere. Finish nature's work by ripening in a paper bag, unrefrigerated. Sign of success: it feels squishy. And remember: an unripe avocado tastes almost as good as a rechargeable battery.

The easy way out
Order a hot dog in Chile.

fields.headline: False confidence
fields.standfirst: Claims that salmonella in eggs is a thing of the past are a bit premature, says Joanna Blythman
fields.trailText: Claims that salmonella in eggs is a thing of the past are a bit premature, says Joanna Blythman
fields.body:
Eggs have had something of a millennium make- over. While demonstrating how to make a caesar salad dressing on BBC2's Food And Drink recently, chef/presenter Antony Worrall Thompson gleefully incorporated a raw egg into the mix, passing on the good "news" that ,"since January 1, we no longer have to worry about salmonella bacteria in eggs, as from that date the Lion Quality Mark guarantees salmonella-free eggs".

For its part, the Egg Information Service, the public-relations wing of the British Egg Industry Council (BEIC), hailed its vaccination programme as "a new dawn for British eggs", with massive adverts in the national press, though these stopped short of declaring that vaccination equals salmonella-free eggs. The problem is that other people might jump to that conclusion. This slight reserve apart, BEIC chairman, Andrew Parker, felt confident enough about this techno-fix for the industry's once intractable salmonella problem to offer the following assurance: "Although no food can ever be 100% safe, we believe that Lion Quality eggs are now among the safest in the world - if not the safest." Not content with that grandiose claim, the egg industry is singlehandedly taking the credit for the noticeable decline in cases of Salmonella enteriditis PT4 over the past two years, attributing it to the gradual introduction of the vaccine.

It all sounds so reassuring. But, according to Dr Richard North, the highly-respected public-health consultant and leading authority on food poisoning, "these claims encourage a false level of confidence in British eggs". The first loose end that doesn't quite fit the BEIC's "new dawn for eggs" plot is the fact that, although the vaccine may have a temporary efficacy against systemic, internal infection of hens with Salmonella enteriditis , it is wholly ineffective against surface contamination of the shell, which is the most common form of contamination encountered. The next thing to bear in mind is that invasive pathogens such as Salmonella enteriditis are cyclical in nature, with roughly a 10-year lifespan. The problem with UK eggs was first identified in 1988, so it may well be that the recent decline in poisoning cases simply reflects the natural cycle of that particular outbreak. Alternatively, there's the possibility that the drop in the number of cases reflects hygiene improvements that have been made by the broiler chicken (chicken meat) industry, and not by egg producers at all. It's hard to be sure, especially when Public Health Laboratory Service figures record only the total number of Salmonella enteriditis cases, and do not distinguish between those caused by table birds and eggs.

Let's not forget about the poor old egg-laying hen, either. She now has to put up with yet another vaccination to add to the already comprehensive list of 13 different shots that she may already require to fortify her against the diseases endemic to the intensive battery-cage system that produces some 84% of the UK's eggs. "This latest vaccine is yet another perfect example of drugs and veterinary treatments that prop up a cruel and unsustainable system of egg production" says Philip Lymbery of Compassion in World Farming.

Nor do vaccines address the great unspoken egg industry scandal in the disparity between egg production and consumption. While egg production is steady throughout the year, consumption is not. The peaks for egg sales are Christmas and Easter, while they nosedive in January. However, as producers are not allowed to store or refrigerate their eggs when demand slackens, says Dr North, they either have to comply with the law and lose money or find ruses with which to perpetrate the myth that their eggs are fresher than they really are. (Two years ago, I reported how two leading producers had been prosecuted for altering the date stamp on their eggs.) To overcome this potential loop-hole, Dr North supports the implementation of a marketing law that would allow only fresh eggs to be sold as Grade 1 and older eggs as Grade 2, making them clearly destined for recipes in which the eggs are well-cooked. This, North believes, would encourage producers to be more honest. In the meantime, it pays to be suspicious of the egg that may have been hanging around a bit, despite its notional "lay" date. The older your egg is, from whatever source, the more likely it is to poison you, since Salmonella enteriditis multiplies rapidly with age. A fresh salmonella-infected egg may not make you ill (unless you are old, infirm or have a compromised immune system), but that same egg a fortnight on might very well do so.

So, whatever the season, if you fancy a proper aïoli, say, or an authentic tiramisu, please buy the freshest eggs you can find and eat them that day or the next. And if it's a real mayonnaise you're after, stick to Mrs Beeton's sage household advice: make sure it contains a hefty shot of vinegar to inhibit anything nasty lurking in the eggs.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Antonio Carluccio
fields.trailText: Antonio Carluccio
fields.body:
Antonio Carluccio was born in 1937 on the Amalfi coast, the son of a station master, and moved to Britain in 1975. He was runner-up in the 1985 Sunday Times cook of the year competition, and now owns the Neal Street Restaurant and Carluccio's Caff in London. He has had his own TV series and written books, most recently Antonio Carluccio's Vegetables. He is married and lives in London and Hampshire.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
A plate of steaming risotto topped with freshly-shaven white truffle.

What is your greatest fear?
Ignorance and hypocrisy, the cause of most conflicts.

With which historical figure do you most identify?
Guglielmo Marconi, the founder of instant communication.

Which living person do you most admire?
Gorbachev, unsung hero - he single-handedly scrapped communism.

What has been your most embarrassing moment?
Saying to Her Royal Highness, Princess Margaret, that I knew her brother, meaning His Royal Highness, Prince of Wales. She was highly amused.

What is your greatest extravagance?
Buying one kilo of Beluga Caviar.

What objects do you always carry?
Swiss army knife and a Ronson lighter.

What makes you depressed?
The inability of humans to discover that they are destroying themselves.

What is your favourite smell?
White truffles, roses, fresh-baked bread.

What is your favourite building?
An igloo is the perfect house.

What is your favourite journey?
To the woods in search of funghi.

Should the Royal Family be scrapped?
What is the alternative?

What or who is the greatest love of your life?
My dog, Jan, who delighted 13 years of my life.

Which person do you most despise?
Drug and arms dealers because they're the lowest in the scale of morality.

What is your greatest regret?
To have given up active sport too early.

When and where were you happiest?
My childhood spent in Italy, living in a railway station.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
An English butler.

What would your motto be?
Live a good life without harm to oneself or to others.

What keeps you awake at night?
Full moon and writing books.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
If you want to be successful you have to work at it.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: stalking sense
fields.standfirst: 'Prepare to flee as I can hear Aunt puffing up the stairs again. She's my stalker'
fields.trailText: 'Prepare to flee as I can hear Aunt puffing up the stairs again. She's my stalker'
fields.body:
Dulcie! I've just rrread in this magazine that vitamin C gives you hearrrt disease!" Aunt stricken, like someone who's just discovered their husband has been cheating on them for years. "Oh well," I quip airily, "that means the Virgos are all going to die off, leaving the world in a terrible mess." Mustn't let the aunt see my concern. She panics easily. I blame her old childhood rhyme, The Campbells Are Coming, now a sinister Downing Street mantra.

Suddenly realise that Easter is almost upon us and decide to do something lastminute.com. Log on to their website but encounter strange difficulties in my attempts to secure exquisite flat in Siena overlooking the Campo for £200 a week. Nothing in Siena at all, in fact, so log off in disgust. Tempted to start my own travel company. Themed celebrity breaks with a dash of the unexpected. On Safari with Mystic Meg in Cardiff. Last Tango in Leicester with Delia Smith and John Redwood. Learn to waterski with the Archbishop of Canterbury. I am wasted on unemployment, wasted.

Aunt stalks up behind me. "And St John's Worrrrt rrraises your blood prrressurrre !" Assure aunt that St John was bound to have high blood pressure, tangling with dancing girls and having his head cut off after that quiet, ascetic life he'd been leading in the wilderness. Aunt purses lips and stalks off. She doesn't like it when I take liberties with the saints.

"Mum!" Harriet arrives at my elbow. "I'm being stalked by this bloke on the internet, his name's Roberto and he lives in San Diego and he's always like bothering me, yeah? And saying like really weird pervy things." Henry is also being stalked - by his ex-girlfriend, Holly. She delivers, by hand, a long letter to him every night. Henry doesn't read them. He just chucks them under his bed. Still, he has decided to revive his laddish rugby life. He still hasn't done any revision, but at least he is out of the house.

I am tempted to sneak into his room and just glance at one of the Holly letters, just to make sure she's not stark staring bonkers in a homicidal way like Glenn Close in Fatal Attraction. I just knew she was going to rear up out of that bath, even though she'd looked properly drowned for ages. It was such a relief when the wife shot her.

"Never mind, darling," I soothe my frazzled teen, "San Diego is a long way away."

"But I, like, gave him my address. I'm really really sorry, I didn't mean to. He tricked me."

"How old is he?"

"He says he's 18." Hmmmm. At least it's cured Harriet of her addiction to the internet. This supernatural soliciting cannot be good. "I'm sick of chat anyway." Chat, here, is a virtual experience with people one would cross the road to avoid if one saw them coming down the street.

"Don't worry, Harriet. If the worst comes to the worst we can always move house."

"I don't see why we should move house just because of him! I hate stalkers and if he dares to come over here I want you to kill him." Agree cheerfully, then prepare to flee as I can hear Aunt puffing up the stairs again. She is my stalker.

"Echinacea!" she cries - halfway between Eureka and Abracadabra. She has identified a plant that has only benign properties, and is happy again.

Everybody has a stalker but me - except for the brooding presence of my pupil Gabrielle. Even as I idly surf the net I am aware that I ought to be marking her essay on Romeo and Juliet, and that tomorrow evening her shadow will fall across my threshold. There is something about her which paralyses me. Instead of wit and enlightenment, all I can offer is fumble and mumble. I just hope she's not listening. In fact, I'm sure she's not.

This thought cheers me up, and I am halfway through counting a few other blessings when the phone rings. It is Elaine, ex-Spouse's other ex-wife. "I want to talk to you, Dulcie," she says, with deadly composure. "I want to meet you for a face-to-face. I think it's time you knew about all the affairs Gordon had while he was married to you - not counting me, of course." Enquire if Thursday will be convenient.
