Chat, here, is a virtual experience with people one would cross the road to avoid if one saw them coming down the street. "Don't worry, Harriet. If the worst comes to the worst we can always move house." "I don't see why we should move house just because of him! I hate stalkers and if he dares to come over here I want you to kill him." Agree cheerfully, then prepare to flee as I can hear Aunt puffing up the stairs again. She is my stalker. "Echinacea!" she cries - halfway between Eureka and Abracadabra. She has identified a plant that has only benign properties, and is happy again. Everybody has a stalker but me - except for the brooding presence of my pupil Gabrielle. Even as I idly surf the net I am aware that I ought to be marking her essay on Romeo and Juliet, and that tomorrow evening her shadow will fall across my threshold. There is something about her which paralyses me. Instead of wit and enlightenment, all I can offer is fumble and mumble. I just hope she's not listening. In fact, I'm sure she's not. This thought cheers me up, and I am halfway through counting a few other blessings when the phone rings. It is Elaine, ex-Spouse's other ex-wife. "I want to talk to you, Dulcie," she says, with deadly composure. "I want to meet you for a face-to-face. I think it's time you knew about all the affairs Gordon had while he was married to you - not counting me, of course." Enquire if Thursday will be convenient.

fields.headline: Comfort of strangers
fields.standfirst: Is your display let down by dull shrubs? Help is at hand - in the form of a clematis. Christopher Lloyd hails a cheery hero
fields.trailText: Is your display let down by dull shrubs? Help is at hand - in the form of a clematis. Christopher Lloyd hails a cheery hero
fields.body:
One of the most delightful conceits for evolving a happily integrated garden is to encourage clematis and other climbers to mantle shrubs that might otherwise look a bit dull in their off-season. This will allow you to grow more clematis than would otherwise be possible if you confined them to walls and fences. It is the way clematis grow in nature, we rightly reassure ourselves, and if shade at the roots is what they most like then their hosts will automatically provide it.

All this is true, but we also need to remember that no garden situation is static. If we plant with the idea of good-neighbourliness, the chances are that one of the protagonists will try to get the better of the other. It all looks charming at the time, but at the end of the season we may discover that murder has been committed.

So a correspondent asks me for a solution where a clematis has flourished but, in one season, has killed or maimed a rhamnus, a choysia and two roses. She tries to close every easy escape that I might resort to in my reply. "There are only so many tripods, posts and vertical supports that one can accommodate in a garden," she protests. And if I suggest she should grow large-flowered clematis as being less vigorous than the Viticella types, well, she prefers the latter, thank you very much. So do I. They have a far longer flowering season than the earlier, large-flowered hybrids, and have a more natural habit of growth.

But as to there being limited scope for posts and vertical supports, I don't see it. An upright post takes up virtually no lateral space at all, and it makes use of vertical space that would otherwise go to waste. The ideal is to cut later-flowering clematis hard back at the end of the season, and to tie or train its new shoots to the post in the following year. This will take all the clematis's weight, but if there is a nearby shrub over which it can negligently fling the odd vine, a delightful picture will result without any damage being done. For the rest, you'll have a column of blossom up your post and everyone will be happy.

If you do allow a clematis to grow over a shrub, you must ensure that it is the right clematis - that is, not too enveloping and creative of darkness beneath it; and that it is the right sort of shrub - in other words, one that is of stiff habit and able to stand added weight on top of it without collapsing.

An ideal example for a number of years in my garden has been of Clematis * triternata 'Rubromarginata' growing over the top of Mahonia * media 'Buckland'. The mahonia, which flowers in December, has a very strong, chunky framework because, every three years or so, I lop it back all over (right now is the ideal moment) to prevent it from becoming leggy and, in my eyes, ungainly. It breaks freely from the bare wood so exposed, and its flowering next winter is unaffected.

The clematis is a hybrid between white C. flammula , whose delicious airborne scent it inherits, and purple C. viticella . There are purple margins to a pale-centred flower. It is extremely prolific in its July-August season, but without producing very much foliage. So, as soon as it has flowered, by the end of August, we cut back all that flowered growth and the mahonia is freed for the next nine months.

No vertical post is involved in this case. But in another, I have the June to July-flowering Viticella hybrid 'Etoile Violette' growing up a fairly short chestnut pole - short because the clematis is quite near to the front of a mixed border. It got there by accident, I have to admit, its roots being in some old potting soil with which we topped the border up. At the time, we didn't realise that a living clematis was being included, but we soon did, and we didn't like to discourage it. Well, it grew with a vengeance and killed a couple of daisy bushes, Olearia * scilloniensis , before we appreciated that the situation was critical and provided the post.

Next door is an extremely strong and stiff Hybrid Tea rose, the pink 'Paul McCartney', alias 'The McCartney Rose', alias 'Meizeli'. Some of the clematis strays harmlessly on to that and, as the clematis itself is purple with a white eye, the team works excellently. The July-flowering 'Perle d'Azur' is one of the best summer-flowering, near-blue clematis around, but it has tremendously long internodes that give it a rangy habit. It is quite a heavyweight. 'Prince Charles' is far shorter-jointed and less consuming of space. Its flowers are of the same colouring, but a lot smaller - however, as is always the case, size is compensated for by the numbers of blooms produced.

So here we have a prolific clematis of moderate growth and I grow it over the clear pink-flowered Hebe 'Watson's Pink'. Thanks to mild winters, this is 6ft high. Its texture is rather soft, but it copes well and the two colours are charming together. I daresay the situation will have to be reviewed - I fancy that the hebe would benefit from a hard cut-back itself - but we constantly need to adjust. Nothing tragic about that.

As for growing something through my own enormous yet by no means stiff Mexican orange, Choisya ternata , to pep it up after its May flowering, I have Berberidopsis corallina , an evergreen climber with pendant clusters of rich-red flowers in summer. It is not easily pleased, but seems to respond to heavy mulching. If it succeeds in smothering my 50-year-old choisya, I'll join in its triumph.

webTitle: Hillary takes lead in NY senate race

fields.headline: Hillary takes lead in NY senate race
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Hillary Clinton has surged ahead of the mayor of New York, Rudolph Giuliani, for the first time in their race for a senate seat, according to an opinion poll.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton has surged ahead of the mayor of New York, Rudolph Giuliani, for the first time in their race for a senate seat, according to an opinion poll.

The change in her fortune looks like the result of a voters' backlash against Mr Guiliani's gung-ho endorsement of the New York police department's shooting tactics.

After several months in which she seemed incapable of capturing the political initiative from the normally popular Mr Guiliani, Mrs Clinton has a 49% to 41% lead, having trailed her Republican rival by two points as recently as mid-February.

When undecided voters were pressed to reveal which way they were leaning, her lead in the poll for the New York Times and CBS News increased to 52-42%.

Mrs Clinton, who is trying to become the first wife of a US president to win elective office, probably owes the lead less to her efforts than to a dramatic collapse of Mr Giuliani's approval ratings since the latest shooting of an unarmed black suspect by a New York police officer.

A Haitian-born American, Patrick Dorismond, was shot dead in a struggle with a plainclothes drugs squad officer on March 16. It is the most recent in a succession of high-profile killings by NYPD officers.

The following day Mr Giuliani released Dorismond's extensive arrest record and said in a series of interviews that the dead man was "no altar boy"and his behaviour had contributed to his killing.

In the new poll, one third of voters - including 15% of Republicans - said Mr Giuliani's handling of the shooting had made them less inclined to vote for him in the senate elections in November.

In an effort to turn round his recent slump, Mr Giuliani has persuaded the failed Republican presidential contender John McCain to campaign with him this week. He appeared in a new Giuliani television commercial, first broadcast yesterday, which stressed the mayor's "tolerance, truthfulness and humanity".

fields.headline: How to ramble
fields.trailText: One of the unintended consequences of the cutbacks in rail services has been the relentless rise in rambling. When there are few trains around to spot, dull people start walking around aimlessly and inevitably start rambling
fields.body:
One of the unintended consequences of the cutbacks in rail services has been the relentless rise in rambling. When there are few trains around to spot, dull people start walking around aimlessly and inevitably start rambling. Ramblers carry boiled sweets in flavours so repulsive that you'd rather eat your own leg in an emergency situation. They wear hi-tech anoraks that withdraw the heat and moisture from their bodies and release them into the noses of other ramblers. Ramblers have big boots. This is to stop them falling over when they've had the second pint of real ale at the end of their epic four-mile ramble.

Ramblers go around in packs, and are always led by a man or woman with a beard and big knobbly stick. He's known as Ramblo. Ramblers keep maps in Perspex holders (so they won't get soaked by all the moisture being extracted from their bodies). With these maps and their compasses, they can work out that they're 300 yards from the car park.

Ramblers engage in conversation when they walk, and it's no surprise that they tend to ramble when they do so. In any pack of ramblers, you'll have someone who knows a bit about birds, someone who knows a bit about plants and someone who knows a bit about soils. The upshot of this is you cannot move five yards without one of them piping up with a half-hour lecture on the fascinating Kimmeridge clays that everyone's big boots are currently sinking into.

Ramblers love unspoilt countryside, and sometimes you can spot great packs of brightly-coloured ramblers grinding through the country getting the maximum enjoyment from it. Ramblers think that the best way of seeing the country is to walk directly behind some achingly dull cagouled idiot for six hours.

You can always tell a rambler because they've dressed for the Himalayas. They're the ones carrying the emergency bivouac, Primus stove and distress flares on the Thames towpath. Long-distance paths do a great service to society by keeping ramblers in remote parts of the country for extended periods and well away from normal people.

The right to roam would be so much more palatable if you could guarantee that the first person to traipse across your lawn wouldn't be a rambler. No one likes people rambling when they're talking, so why should we put up with it when people start walking? If you want to get somewhere, fine, but for Pete's sake don't ramble. Ramblers should be hunted by horse and hound. That would get them moving.

fields.headline: Para dies in training accident
fields.trailText: Police were yesterday investigating the death of an 18-year old recruit to the Parachute Regiment who was crushed by an armoured personnel carrier during an exercise on Salisbury Plain.
fields.body:
Police were yesterday investigating the death of an 18-year old recruit to the Parachute Regiment who was crushed by an armoured personnel carrier during an exercise on Salisbury Plain.

Christopher France died instantly from severe head injuries. Another private, 24-year-old Daniel Snell, suffered minor injuries in the accident on Thursday.

A Ministry of Defence spokesman said yesterday: "A full investigation into the accident is being undertaken by the civil police and the military." He said no further details of the incident would be released until Wiltshire police had completed its inquiries.

The MoD said that exercises were designed to simulate as far as possible situations soldiers would expect to experience in military operations, but insisted that safety was a primary concern.

 The law lords have dismissed a compensation claim by Sergeant Trevor Walker of the Royal Engineers who lost a leg after a Serb tank fired a shell at the UN camp where he was based in Bosnia.

They said his injuries were a result of military action rather than a criminal act.

webTitle: Red letter day for blind piranha

fields.headline: Red letter day for blind piranha
fields.trailText: Nasher the blind piranha may not be as threatening as she used to be but yesterday she became a legend at the age of 24.
fields.body:
Nasher the blind piranha may not be as threatening as she used to be but yesterday she became a legend at the age of 24.

Staff at the Bolton Aquarium, Greater Manchester, decorated her tank with party poppers and balloons and sang happy birthday to her as she swam around unaware that she was probably the oldest piranha in the world.

The 11-inch red bellied piranha joined the aquarium when she was a few weeks old and has been there longer than any members of staff.

She has a cataract in one eye and lost sight in the other 15 years ago after being attacked by the rest of the shoal in a dispute over spawning territory. "Piranhas have razor-sharp teeth and just one bite does a lot of damage," said her keeper, Pete Liptrot. "A shoal of 1,000 could devour a whole person in minutes."

Nasher, who originates from the Amazon basin, has outlived the nine other piranhas introduced to the aquarium in the 1970s and now lives among a shoal of small fish, too blind to catch them. "If she was younger she would have made a meal of them," Mr Liptrot said. She survives on a diet of smelt from the local fish market.

webTitle: Pay boost for special need teachers

fields.headline: Pay boost for special need teachers
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Thousands of special needs teachers who work in mainstream schools are in line for salary rises of at least £1,000, after a court ruling in favour of three members of the National Union of Teachers.
fields.body:
Thousands of special needs teachers who work in mainstream schools are in line for salary rises of at least £1,000, after a court ruling in favour of three members of the National Union of Teachers.

Durham county court ruled that special needs teachers who used their skills mainly in teaching pupils who were integrated into mainstream classes were entitled to the extra pay .

The NUT, which brought the case, said school governing bodies were taking advantage of the government's policy of including pupils with special needs in mainstream classes to cut costs, by not giving the teachers additional pay increments to which they were entitled.

The three teachers, who were all employed at Deerness Valley comprehensive, in Durham, challenged their school governors and local authority over their right to extra pay.

The court took the view that although each of the three teachers was working alongside a mainstream teacher, it was not necessary, as the school and local authority argued, to establish that more than 50% of their time was actually spent teaching pupils whose needs had been recognised through the issue of statements.

Two of the teachers involved, Ann Mawson and Catherine Haddon, are still employed by the school and were each awarded £12,723 in back pay.

The third teacher, Denise Hardy, was made redundant by the school in 1998. She was awarded £9,735 in back pay.

The NUT said it did not know the total number of special needs teachers in the country who would use the ruling to demand rises from their employers, but it amounted to thousands.

fields.headline: Turbines beat goose deadline
fields.trailText: Work on Britain's biggest wind generation turbines, which was threatened with suspension because it was being carried out near the home of a rare species of goose, was completed one day ahead of schedule yesterday - as the birds' breeding season began.
fields.body:
Work on Britain's biggest wind generation turbines, which was threatened with suspension because it was being carried out near the home of a rare species of goose, was completed one day ahead of schedule yesterday - as the birds' breeding season began.

Red-throated divers were spotted preparing to nest around Burgar Hill, Orkney, as the blades of two wind turbines - one 210ft high, the other 197ft - spun there for the first time.

The birds, known as rain geese, could have brought the £2m project to an abrupt halt. Permission was granted for the 3.5 megawatt turbines - which will generate electricity for more than 2,000 homes - as long as they were completed before the breeding season began.

"We've been checking each day to make sure the birds are OK and we saw them in full display - neck stretching and dashing across the water," said Keith Fairclough, of the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds."It looks, touch wood, as if they haven't been put off by the operation and are preparing to nest."

Britain is believed to have around 1,500 pairs of red-throated divers, most nesting in remote areas of Scotland.

fields.headline: Chef gets £10,000 for sacking
fields.trailText: Celebrity chef Phil Vickery was yesterday awarded £10,000 compensation for being unfairly sacked from his job at a five-star hotel.
fields.body:
Celebrity chef Phil Vickery was yesterday awarded £10,000 compensation for being unfairly sacked from his job at a five-star hotel.

Mr Vickery, star of TV's Ready Steady Cook, was sacked from his £60,000 a year job at the Castle Hotel in Taunton for working on the show, then presented by his lover Fern Britton, while he was supposed to be on sick leave.

He also took Miss Britton on a romantic long weekend to Venice and charged the £1,444 cost to his expenses.

An employment tribunal at Exeter ruled that Mr Vickery's sacking was unfair and that his contract of employment had been broken but he was told he must repay the cost of the Venice trip and a £2,915 interest-free loan.

He said he later retracted his resignation but was offered a severance package.

fields.headline: Candyfloss painkiller a world first
fields.trailText: A painkiller which melts in the mouth by mimicking fairground candyfloss made its world debut in British pharmacies yesterday.
fields.body:
A painkiller which melts in the mouth by mimicking fairground candyfloss made its world debut in British pharmacies yesterday.

Instead of being swallowed with water, the pills, which have been developed by Boots Healthcare International and a US partner, are designed to dissolve instantly in the mouth.

Each tablet contains thousands of microspheres containing the pain-relieving drug ibuprofen. The microspheres, which are each smaller than a pinhead, are held in a matrix of finely spun sugar.

The lemon-flavoured pills are being marketed as Nurofen Meltlets. William Cotton, managing director of the Boots subsidiary Crookes Healthcare, which is distributing them, said: "Pop them in your mouth and they dissolve on the tongue. You don't need water to help you swallow them and they have a pleasant lemon taste.

"This is a genuine revolution in drug administration. It is the first tablet of its kind available anywhere in the world. Nurofen is already Europe's fastest growing over the counter medicine and we are sure that Nurofen Meltlets will be a major success."

webTitle: Strange but true: our lives on record

fields.headline: Strange but true: our lives on record
fields.standfirst: Official detritus of a rich and fascinating past goes on display
fields.trailText: There are strange neighbours at the public record office in Kew: Dick Turpin and Queen Victoria, Jack the Ripper and Shakespeare, Robin Hood and Elton John.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
There are strange neighbours at the public record office in Kew: Dick Turpin and Queen Victoria, Jack the Ripper and Shakespeare, Robin Hood and Elton John.

A new visitor centre, to be opened by the lord chancellor next week, will display for the first time some of the most unexpected and precious items among the 96 miles of records covering 1,000 years of British history.

Some of the oddest things in the collection - such as the spikes on which the Cato Street Conspirators planned, in 1820, to impale members of the cabinet - lie side by side with the treasures: Magna Carta, the Domesday Book, and the solid gold 16th century seal of Francis I of France, which entered the public records attached to a "treaty of perpetual peace" signed with Henry VIII, an agreement that lasted all of six months.

Shakespeare's will of 1616, which famously left Anne Hathaway his "second best bed", has a case of its own. Only half a dozen Shakespeare signatures regarded as genuine have survived, and three are on this will.

Nearby there is an extremely dull looking piece of officialese: a deed poll recording that on December 8 1971 a young man called Reginald Kenneth Dwight changed his name to Elton Hercules John. The rest is pop history.

Every member of staff had nominations from the huge collection: it was left to the curator, Tracy Borman, to choose just 40 objects for the opening exhibition. She slipped in some personal favourites, including a census return of 1851. A woman called Victoria is listed as living at Buckingham Palace: under occupation it gives "queen", but under "relation to head of household" some brave official has filled in "wife".

Ms Borman, a Tudor historian by training, wanted to include the record of Anne Boleyn's trial, but the huge volume was too big for any case. Instead there is a fond, friendly, casual letter which cost another queen's head: Catherine Howard's letter in 1541 hoping that Thomas Culpepper was feeling better. It was taken as proof of adultery. Culpepper was hanged and quartered in December, Catherine's head rolled two months later, and Henry VIII moved on to his sixth and last wife.

A long, tedious 14th century manuscript is an account of porters' wages for the king's chamber, for November 1324. One of them, being paid off with 20 days wages because for some unstated reason he could no longer work, was a certain "Robyn Hod", his departure from the royal service possibly marking the start of a new career in Sherwood forest.

An equally dull document masks another figure famous in stories and ballads: the indictment, for stealing "a black mare worth three pounds and a filly foal worth twenty shillings" is of one "John Palmer, alias Richard Turpin." The highwayman, having cheated the law for years, hanged for £4 of horseflesh.

The old public record office, in its shabby Victorian splendour in Chancery Lane, Holborn, had a small museum. None of the treasures has been on display since the move to Kew in the 1990s, because the planned new museum was dropped as building costs spiralled. The new exhibition space will be open, free, every day from Monday to Saturday.

Some documents have never been displayed before, such as a letter - in an elegant, educated hand - sent to the Central News Agency on September 25 1888, which may have been by Jack the Ripper and sparked a flood of fake letters to the newspapers and police.

There is only one notable absentee: the public records rat is out on loan to the Royal Armouries for its millennium exhibition at the Tower of London. The mummified rat was found among the files in the 19th century, and was judged to have devoured so many documents that it warranted inclusion in the public records: it was solemnly given its own record number and filed. "We are looking forward to his return," Ms Borman said. "He will certainly go straight into the exhibition."

fields.headline: Roger Cook sues paper
fields.trailText: The investigative TV reporter Roger Cook is to sue the News of the World for libel after the newspaper claimed he had faked some of his shows.
fields.body:
The investigative TV reporter Roger Cook is to sue the News of the World for libel after the newspaper claimed he had faked some of his shows.

Mr Cook's lawyers served a writ on News Group Newspapers last night, claiming damages over a series of articles published since February. The articles alleged that several editions of the Cook Report were faked, and that Mr Cook bungled the investigations.

A spokeswoman for the paper refused to comment as it had not yet seen the writ.

Mr Cook's show, made by Carlton for ITV, has developed a reputation for hard-hitting stories. But the News of the World has claimed that viewers were duped by faked scenes. Mr Cook is seeking aggravated damages, and an injunction to prevent any repeat of the claims.

fields.headline: Inquest verdict challenge fails
fields.trailText: A man whose millionaire friend was found dead in his fume-filled car in an apparent suicide failed yesterday in his high court attempt to overturn a coroner's verdict of unlawful killing.
fields.body:
A man whose millionaire friend was found dead in his fume-filled car in an apparent suicide failed yesterday in his high court attempt to overturn a coroner's verdict of unlawful killing.

John Hart, 40, who stood to inherit £1.4m from his friend and neighbour Lawrence Dabbs after his death, claimed that the inquest was "fundamentally flawed" and had turned into a criminal trial.

Mr Dabbs, 74, was found dead in September 1996 at his home in Ilkeston, Derbyshire. In a will written only a month before his death, the widower left £1.4m, the bulk of his estate, to Mr Hart, a law student from Marlpool, Heanor.

But Mr Hart is still fighting for his share of the will in the face of opposition from Mr Dabbs's relatives, who are challenging the validity of the will in the high court.

The judge heard that Mr Hart - who was arrested in connection with the death, although the case against him was subsequently dropped - had been "ostracised" since the inquest verdict.

Mr Justice Newman dismissed Mr Hart's challenge to the verdict of unlawful killing returned by a coroner's jury in July 1998 after a 22-day inquest.

He rejected claims that the inquest had been allowed to "degenerate into a criminal trial" and allegations that Derbyshire police had taken part in the inquest to gather evidence for a possible prosecution - "a forbidden purpose" under the law.

The judge also rejected claims that the Derby and South Derbyshire coroner, Peter Ashworth, had "in effect been complicit in an abuse of the inquest proceeding". He was satisfied the coroner had carried out a "scrupulously fair" inquiry.

The high court heard that the crown prosecution service decided before the inquest there was not enough evidence to prosecute anyone over Mr Dabbs's death.

The judge ruled that contacts Mr Ashworth had with CPS officials before the inquest were "harmless".

Mr Hart, who was not in court to hear the ruling, was ordered to pay legal costs estimated to exceed £100,000, should he inherit substantial sums from Mr Dabbs's will.

An application by Mr Hart for leave to appeal to the court of appeal was adjourned.

fields.headline: School benefits from neglected painting
fields.trailText: For more than 45 years, schoolchildren barely gave the painting a second glance as they filed past it on their way to classes.
fields.body:
For more than 45 years, schoolchildren barely gave the painting a second glance as they filed past it on their way to classes.

But the picture which has hung, virtually ignored and gathering dust, in the entrance to Llantarnum comprehensive at Cymbryn, near Newport in South Wales, since 1954 has turned out to be the school's saviour.

The work, by Victorian artist George Dunlop Leslie, is expected to fetch up to £250,000 when it is auctioned by Sotheby's in London in June - enough to build eight brick classrooms to replace leaky mobile ones.

The painting, Daughters of Eve, showing three girls pausing to pick apples while hanging out laundry, was bought for 300 guineas by the school's architect, Colin Jones, in 1954.

Using the last few hundred pounds of the school's £250,000 building budget, he bought the painting and an antique oak table from a nearby colliery estate, Llanfair Grange, "to relieve the severity of the modern design".

David Kitchen, headteacher at the 1,350-pupil comprehensive, said yesterday: "Over the years the painting became just part of the furniture and nobody took any notice of it.

"It was only when the hall was redecorated and the picture taken down that we realised how spectacular it was in natural light. The colours are beautiful.

"After getting an idea of its value from Sotheby's we decided it would not be appropriate to put it back on the wall."

The 73ins by 39ins painting, which will be replaced by a reproduction, was painted by Leslie (1835-1921) in 1883, probably at his house near Wallingford on the Thames. It was exhibited at the Royal Academy.

webTitle: Dyke race pledge on BBC jobs

fields.headline: Dyke race pledge on BBC jobs
fields.standfirst: Special report on the future of the BBC at www.newsunlimited.co.uk/BBC
fields.trailText: The BBC's director general, Greg Dyke, pledged yesterday to increase the number of employees from ethnic minorities to 10% of his workforce by 2003, and to double the number of managers from diverse backgrounds in the same time.
fields.body:
The BBC's director general, Greg Dyke, pledged yesterday to increase the number of employees from ethnic minorities to 10% of his workforce by 2003, and to double the number of managers from diverse backgrounds in the same time.

Mr Dyke made the task the "acid test" of his tenure at the BBC, saying the corporation had a "moral duty" to reflect the diversity of 21st century Britain.

"From Marks & Spencer right through to the Metropolitan police you find institutions which have been slow to react to modern Britain and as a result have had problems," he told the race in the media awards at the Savoy hotel in London yesterday.

"The BBC is no different. The BBC changed a lot in the 90s, but I would argue that the world has changed much faster and so we have to change more." As the British Broadcasting Corporation, it had to reflect the changing nature of Britishness, he said. It had almost a moral duty to do so because every household funds the BBC through the licence fee, he added.

Mr Dyke said that the BBC was no longer the preserve of the "public school, Oxford-educated chap", and joked that was just as well for him.

He praised advances made by his predecessor, Lord Birt, whose reforms ensured 8% of the workforce is now made up of people from ethnic minorities. Last month, Mr Dyke appointed a head of diversity at the BBC, Linda Mitchell.

He made the target of doubling the number of managers a key aim - at present, only 2% of the corporation's managers were from ethnic minorities, he said.

Mr Dyke, who worked as a race relations officer for Wandsworth borough council as a young man, said: "We need a new vision, and central to that vision is that the BBC must serve Britain's broad and diverse population. The great danger for any broadcaster is to let your audience get ahead of you in ideas and attitudes. And I believe that in the area of race there is real evidence that one important part of our audience, the young, are already well ahead of us."

At the awards, the Granada film The Murder of Stephen Lawrence shared the best TV drama honour with Channel 4's production Nightshift. Stephen's parents, Neville and Doreen, attended the event.

Meera Syal, the writer and star of the BBC television comedy series Goodness Gracious Me, was named media personality of the year.

More than 300 entries were submitted for this year's awards, organised by the Commission for Racial Equality to recognise excellence in coverage of race relations issues.

webTitle: Business gives Greenham a positive spin

fields.headline: Business gives Greenham a positive spin
fields.standfirst: Common once famous for cruise missiles and peace camps now welcomes its visitors with chardonnay
fields.trailText: Today the fence comes down. For decades thousands of unannounced visitors to Greenham Common had to make their own arrangements: they tunnelled, climbed over the perimeter fence, or brought bolt cutters to cut their way in. Now anyone may drive past the former guard post, admire the monumental new sculpture by the late Michael Kenny, and have some marinaded lamb and a nice glass of chardonnay in the arts centre wine bar.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Today the fence comes down. For decades thousands of unannounced visitors to Greenham Common had to make their own arrangements: they tunnelled, climbed over the perimeter fence, or brought bolt cutters to cut their way in. Now anyone may drive past the former guard post, admire the monumental new sculpture by the late Michael Kenny, and have some marinaded lamb and a nice glass of chardonnay in the arts centre wine bar.

The entire perimeter fence around the former United States air base is coming down, returning hundreds of acres of Berkshire heathland to the people.

It is almost 10 years since the cruise missiles left. The gates, home to women's peace camps for 18 years, are now gone as well.

The base buildings are flourishing as a business park, with 90% of the space let. A gigantic aircraft hangar is full of jam, another offers ballroom dancing, and firms storing secure documents will lease the armoury and the command centre built to withstand nuclear blast.

Most of the runway has been ground up and sold as aggregate for the Newbury bypass, but the millionth ton is being crushed into a cube, a bizarre feature for the planned visitor centre. The centre will be in the watchtower which once kept a wary eye on the cruise missile convoys coming in, the bombers taking off. Astonishingly frequently the watchers saw military police converging on the chanting slogan-spraying protesters who had made it to the heart of the most secure air base in Britain, dancing their defiance on the roofs of the nuclear silos.

The cross of concrete where the two runways met will stay as a permanent memorial. Nearby the last bomb on Greenham Common is lying in a heap of gravel - a battered dummy, made as a welding training exercise by soldiers. It will also go to the visitor centre.

"You could not have a name with a more calamitous resonance than Greenham Common," Stuart Tagg said. "Our challenge is to turn it around and make something positive of it."

The positive is that he is chief executive of the only business park whose name is familiar all over the world.

The history of Greenham Common can be traced in hundreds of court actions, taken against the protesters, or by them. The common was bought by the local council as a public recreation area, and almost instantly requisitioned by the Ministry of Defence in 1939. After the war it was briefly returned, then requisitioned again in the dawn of the cold war. The council eventually reluctantly sold, under threat of compulsory purchase. In the 1980s the cruise missiles arrived, and the common became an international focus of anti-nuclear protests.

The missiles were gradually pulled out in the years after the December 1987 disarmament treaty between the Soviet Union and the US, and in 1992 the common was declared to be militarily redundant.

On the eve of the new millennium, after 18 years, a party was held formally ending the women's peace camp.

The Greenham Common Trust, established by the council and local business interests, bought the land for £7m, and immediately sold the open land, 750 acres - considerably larger than the original common - back to the council for £1.

The trust has promised a work of art for every new building, as the tatty old military buildings are gradually replaced. The first piece of public sculpture has already arrived, Broken Symmetry, the last major work by Michael Kenny.

The artist chose his own site for the circular platform and angular uprights, in steel and Kilkenny limestone, with great care.

The finished sculpture was delivered in sections by truck some months ago. When local builders began to assemble it they came back to the trust in consternation - something was wrong, they said, they could not make the pieces fit together according to the sculptor's minutely detailed drawings.

After some frantic telephone calls between Ireland and Greenham Common it emerged that they had the wrong stones. They were hastily reconsigned to the Imperial War Museum, and their own sculpture arrived by the next ferry.

The flat roof of the command centre may now become an observation platform where visitors can look out over a remarkably unspoiled landscape.

Increasingly rare heathland flowers and plants have flourished in the shadow of the cruise missiles.

Deer, badgers and hawks are regularly seen, and any visitor will see the new wave of trespassers, with an equally cavalier attitude to fencing and "keep out" notices - the common's ever increasing rabbit colony.

Astonishingly frequently the watchers saw military police converging on the chanting slogan-spraying protesters who had made it to the heart of the most secure air base in Britain, dancing their defiance on the roofs of the nuclear silos. The cross of concrete where the two runways met will stay as a permanent memorial. Nearby the last bomb on Greenham Common is lying in a heap of gravel - a battered dummy, made as a welding training exercise by soldiers. It will also go to the visitor centre. "You could not have a name with a more calamitous resonance than Greenham Common," Stuart Tagg said. "Our challenge is to turn it around and make something positive of it." The positive is that he is chief executive of the only business park whose name is familiar all over the world. The history of Greenham Common can be traced in hundreds of court actions, taken against the protesters, or by them. The common was bought by the local council as a public recreation area, and almost instantly requisitioned by the Ministry of Defence in 1939. After the war it was briefly returned, then requisitioned again in the dawn of the cold war. The council eventually reluctantly sold, under threat of compulsory purchase. In the 1980s the cruise missiles arrived, and the common became an international focus of anti-nuclear protests. The missiles were gradually pulled out in the years after the December 1987 disarmament treaty between the Soviet Union and the US, and in 1992 the common was declared to be militarily redundant. On the eve of the new millennium, after 18 years, a party was held formally ending the women's peace camp. The Greenham Common Trust, established by the council and local business interests, bought the land for £7m, and immediately sold the open land, 750 acres - considerably larger than the original common - back to the council for £1. The trust has promised a work of art for every new building, as the tatty old military buildings are gradually replaced. The first piece of public sculpture has already arrived, Broken Symmetry, the last major work by Michael Kenny. The artist chose his own site for the circular platform and angular uprights, in steel and Kilkenny limestone, with great care. The finished sculpture was delivered in sections by truck some months ago. When local builders began to assemble it they came back to the trust in consternation - something was wrong, they said, they could not make the pieces fit together according to the sculptor's minutely detailed drawings. After some frantic telephone calls between Ireland and Greenham Common it emerged that they had the wrong stones. They were hastily reconsigned to the Imperial War Museum, and their own sculpture arrived by the next ferry. The flat roof of the command centre may now become an observation platform where visitors can look out over a remarkably unspoiled landscape. Increasingly rare heathland flowers and plants have flourished in the shadow of the cruise missiles. Deer, badgers and hawks are regularly seen, and any visitor will see the new wave of trespassers, with an equally cavalier attitude to fencing and "keep out" notices - the common's ever increasing rabbit colony.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Beatle attack: man bailed
fields.body:
Beatle attack: man bailed

The man accused of attempting to murder the former Beatle George Harrison, 56, and his wife Olivia, 51, at their mansion in Henley-on-Thames, Oxfordshire, last December was bailed to a psychiatric unit by Oxford magistrates yesterday. Michael Abram, 33, from Huyton, Liverpool, will be held at a medium secure unit. He will appear at Oxford crown court on May 12.

Footballer cleared

The former Northern Ireland footballer Derek Dougan was cleared at Wolverhampton crown court yesterday of assaulting an American Vietnam war veteran with a pool cue.

Dougan, of Codsall, Staffordshire, was found not guilty of causing actual bodily harm to former US pilot Eylande Mason, 57, last July at the home of Dougan's former girlfriend, Patricia Thompson, in Wolverhampton. He had already been cleared of aggravated assault and aggravated burglary.

Rower ends Pacific attempt

A rower has abandoned his attempt to cross the Pacific, it emerged yesterday, after 250 days at sea.

Andrew Halsey, 42, from Camden, north London, was picked up by a Korean ship. He set off from California last July, and aimed to row 7,000 miles to Australia in seven months. But bad weather meant that although he rowed 6,000 miles, 4,000 of them were in the wrong direction.

Queen objects to phone mast

The Queen has objected to a 20 metre mobile phone mast disguised as a tree being put up near Windsor Castle, in Berkshire.

In a letter to council planners, one of her aides described the fake fir tree proposed by Vodaphone for a roundabout near the Long Walk in Windsor Great Park as 'ridiculous'.

webTitle: Drugs detective cleared of accepting bribes

fields.headline: Drugs detective cleared of accepting bribes
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The former deputy head of the Merseyside drugs squad was yesterday cleared at Carlisle crown court of accepting bribes from a drug dealer.
fields.body:
The former deputy head of the Merseyside drugs squad was yesterday cleared at Carlisle crown court of accepting bribes from a drug dealer.

Detective Chief Inspector Tony Doyle, 49, was accused of taking bribes from Lee Whittaker, 26, in return for favours and information about police operations.

A jury had failed to reach a verdict on the same charges last autumn.

DCI Doyle now faces a police disciplinary hearing relating to the case.

The jury heard that DCI Doyle insisted his meetings with Mr Whittaker were conducted on a professional level as Mr Whittaker was a registered police informant.

The jury heard that anti-corruption squad officers had tapped into DCI Doyle's phone at the Marsh Lane police station in Bootle after receiving a tip-off from a colleague who became concerned about his relationship with Mr Whittaker.

webTitle: Kenneth Noye: the day I killed

fields.headline: Kenneth Noye: the day I killed
fields.standfirst: Man who died in violent fight was the aggressor, Old Bailey told
fields.trailText: Kenneth Noye admitted stabbing a police officer and being jailed for his part in the Brink's-Mat golden bullion robbery as he began an audacious defence yesterday to the charge that he murdered Stephen Cameron four years ago in a road-rage attack.
fields.body:
Kenneth Noye admitted stabbing a police officer and being jailed for his part in the Brink's-Mat golden bullion robbery as he began an audacious defence yesterday to the charge that he murdered Stephen Cameron four years ago in a road-rage attack.

Noye spoke of his involvement in one of the country's most notorious crimes to explain to an Old Bailey jury that he fled to Spain because he feared he would not receive a fair trial, even though he was adamant that he had not murdered Cameron during a ferocious fight at the Swanley interchange of the M25.

Speaking in a low, gruff voice, Noye blamed Cameron for flying at him in a "wild rage" after a simple misunderstanding. Noye said the 21-year-old had shouted at him: "I will kill you" and ignored several pleas to calm down.

Noye, 52, described how he staved off Cameron by pulling a 4in lock knife from the pocket of his jeans, one that he kept there because he said he was in constant fear of his life. But the younger man was out of control and had charged at him again, punching and kicking him to a point where Noye said he was exhausted and believed Cameron would seize the knife from him.

Violent

Only then, Noye told the jury, did he stab him. "I thought if he catches me again, then I'm out. He will take the knife and definitely use it on me. So I struck out with the knife. I can't remember exactly how I done it, but I accept it was twice."

Far from being a violent man, Noye said he could not fight. "I've never hurt anyone. I've never hurt an animal."

He had left the UK the following day because, he said: "The police detest me. I would never get a fair trial here."

Stephen Batten QC, defending Noye, told the jury his client was acquitted in December 1985 of the murder of DC John Fordham, an undercover officer Noye stabbed when he found him hiding in the garden of his home in West Kingsdown, Kent. Fordham was wearing a balaclava and camouflage. As in this case, Noye pleaded self-defence. Noye also admitted being sentenced to 14 years for dishonestly handling gold stolen during the Brink's-Mat gold bullion robbery at Heathrow airport in 1983.

His four and a half hours in the witness box on the seventh day of the trial held court two of the Old Bailey spellbound. Wearing blue trousers, a light blue shirt and a grey cardigan, Noye's walk from the dock to the stand took him within feet of Stephen Cameron's parents, Ken and Toni, who gripped each other's hands as the man accused of murdering their son swore an oath on the Bible.

Noye said he left home on Sunday May 19 1996 to drive to a pub in Chislehurst to have a drink with friends. On the way, he saw a red Rascal van but said he did not remember "cutting up" the vehicle, as the prosecution claimed. He thought he recognised the driver, Danielle Cable, as a woman he met in a nightclub with his friend Mickey Taylor.

When the van started flashing its lights at the next set of traffic lights, he got out. The moment he saw the couple he realised it was a case of mistaken identity, but Cameron, the passenger in the van, had got out to confront him, the court heard.

"I said, 'Sorry mate, I thought you were someone else.' He just started. I said, 'Sorry,' and he said: 'You will be, you C-U-N-T - I will kill you.' As he came at me, I see his face, and I knew I was in trouble.

"I have done nothing. Nothing. I have not antagonised or done anything."

Noye said he came close to being run over by a lorry as Cameron kicked and pushed him into the road. Another "full- frontal" blow knocked him to his knees and left him clinging to the bumper of his Land Rover Discovery, he said.

Noye said he tried to get away, but Cameron "came up behind me and done me in the back". At that point, he reached for the knife. "He was facing me. I said, 'Don't come near me, you nutcase.' I was holding [the knife] outstretched. He stood there for a second or two. His girlfriend got out of the van and said, 'Don't go near him.' That just fired him up. He came straight at me. The fight started again. He has punched me and given a few kicks and then I said, 'Hold up, hold up.' He's telling me he's going to kill me. He was in a completely wild rage. He grabbed me and started smashing me in the face. I was trying to get back, to get away from him.

Shaking

"I cannot fight, I was worn out. I didn't have nothing left. I thought, I cannot take much more and no one has tried to stop the fight. So I struck out."

Noye said he drove off wondering "why a person would fight like that".

He told the jury: "I was shaking. I had a bloody face. I was just devastated."

When he returned home that afternoon, his wife, Brenda, asked him what had happened. "She has seen my face. I said, 'I have been in a fight.' She was not too happy. She said 'I've heard. It was on the news. The chap's dead.' "

Later that evening, Noye decided to flee the country after discussing his predicament with a friend, whom he refused to name in court. "If I go down the police station, I knew myself what would happen," Noye said. "I would never be believed, I would never get a fair trial. All those witness statements would, without a shadow of doubt, have been tainted against me."

The unnamed associate took Noye's car and the knife and said, "Leave them with me." Neither has ever been found.

Mr Batten turned to Noye's background, asking him what he felt about the press coverage of the Fordham case.

"It was absolutely scandalous. There's no other word for it."

Noye said he had been taken to court "like a monkey in a box" and that jurors who had been told they could not befriend officers who were protecting them were spotted "laughing and joking" during trips to Marks & Spencer.

After his release from prison in 1994, he said he had feared being "fitted up" by the police and being kidnapped by criminals who believed that he knew where three tonnes of missing Brink's-Mat gold had been hidden.

"They [the police] thought I had it," Noye told the jury.

He told how a close friend, Nicky Whiting, had been kidnapped and stabbed to death in mysterious circumstances, even though he had had nothing to do with the bullion robbery. "I was in fear of my life from two sources. The police definitely detested me and I had it in my mind that they would pull in a villain who had done something really serious and would get them to do something to me."

There had been occasions when he felt the police were after him, the court heard.

An American who had approached him while they were serving time in prison asked him whether he would swap gold for cocaine. Noye said: "His name was John O'Boyle. I found out later he was working for the FBI."

Noye said the fear of reprisals made him carry a knife.

During cross-examination Julian Bevan QC reminded Noye that he told a Spanish extradition hearing he had not been at the scene of the stabbing.

"That, of course, was a total lie on your part?" Noye replied: "Yes."

Mr Bevan added: "Since then you have completely changed tack and you put forward a defence of self-defence?" Noye said: "Well, that is true."

When asked how he came to have a false passport under the name of Green, Noye said: "I bought it off a mate of mine. When he came out to Spain, he brought it with him."

Asked how he had financed his life on the run, Noye said he did not need funds from the UK. "I had money in Spain. As much as I wanted. I'd been doing deals previously."

The trial was adjourned until Monday.

'I didn't want to fight. I can't fight. I was forced into it'

Noye on the stabbing of Stephen Cameron "I didn't want to fight. I can't fight. I was forced into something that I did not want to do."

Noye on violence "I said to my sons from when they were little, if you ever get into a fight, just walk away. You are not being a coward. You never know what will happen."

Noye said he carried a knife because he thought it was legal "I would have preferred a stun gun or CS canister but they are illegal. A stun gun would have been much better really."

Asked why he had registered his car in a false name, Noye said: "I didn't want anyone to know where I lived. I didn't want anyone to know what cars I drove."

During cross-examination, Julian Bevan QC, prosecuting, described how Noye had denied being at the scene at all during extradition hearings in Spain.

"That, of course, was a total lie on your part?"

Noye: "Yes."

Mr Bevan: "Which you told to help your cause at that time?"

Noye: "Yes."

Mr Bevan: "Since then, of course, you have completely changed tack and put forward a defence of self-defence?"

Noye: "Well, that is true."

Mr Bevan: "You thought nothing of telling the Spanish court a complete lie to help your position?"

Noye: "Yes."

Mr Bevan: "So if you hadn't been found by the police in Spain you were never going to come back?"

Noye: "Yes."

Mr Bevan: "And face some responsibility, as you had, leaving the parents of this boy totally ignorant?"

Noye: "Yes, they would have been."

On the stabbing Mr Bevan: "Mr Noye, the truth is that so far as this incident is concerned you became angry with that young man and deliberately stabbed him, didn't you?"

Noye: "No, I am quite a placid man. I did not do that. It is not true."

Mr Bevan: "And you ran away in fear, not fear of not having a fair trial, you ran away in fear of the truth emerging from all the people at that junction?"

Noye: "Well, the truth has emerged."

webTitle: Turk admits stabbing murdered Leeds fan

fields.headline: Turk admits stabbing murdered Leeds fan
fields.standfirst: Knife believed to have been used in killing found at home of one of 13 Galatasaray supporters arrested
fields.trailText: One of 13 Turks arrested in Istanbul has confessed to stabbing Leeds United fan Christopher Loftus, whose body is expected to be flown to Britain today with that of fellow victim Kevin Speight.
fields.byline: Rory Carroll  in Istanbul and Martin Wainwright
fields.body:
One of 13 Turks arrested in Istanbul has confessed to stabbing Leeds United fan Christopher Loftus, whose body is expected to be flown to Britain today with that of fellow victim Kevin Speight.

Police named the man as Ali Umit Demir, a kebab cafe worker. He was held in an overnight raid at his home where a knife, thought to have been used in the killing, was also found, before being paraded before the media in Istanbul yesterday.

The two fans died after violence in Istanbul on Wednesday night before Leeds' Uefa Cup semi-final match against Galatasaray.

Another man is understood to have confessed to stabbing an English fan before throwing a knife into a rubbish bin. Two other suspects, including a youth identified from TV clips and nicknamed "the Arab", are being hunted in connection with the violence in Taksim Square.

Demir is expected to face murder charges over the weekend after being identified in a line-up by Leeds fans injured in the fighting. They described him as smartly dressed at the time of the attack, which took place after a chase past a fortified police post in the bar and nightclub area.

Two of the arrested group, who must be released by Monday unless police are granted an extension by a judge, were described as friends but there is no suggestion that they formed part of an organised gang of Galatasaray supporters. The Turkish media continued to blame English fans for provoking the violence by being drunk and belligerent.

It was suggested that many had mixed the powerful local spirit raki with beer instead of the usual water. Bar owners in Taksim Square said a glass had been broken in a Turkish youth's face and that drunken approaches had been made to local women.

Leeds fans returning home disputed the claims but there was little hard evidence of how harmless swagger on both sides had got so quickly out of hand. Most of the Leeds supporters directed their fire at police treatment at Istanbul airport and the disrespect shown to the dead by Turkish fans at Galatasaray's Ali Sami Yen stadium.

Ian Williamson, the fan shown in widely published pictures kneeling in the street while a Turkish youth grabbed his hair, said the situation had been confused. Visting Elland Road after arriving back from Istanbul early yesterday, he said: "We went out to watch football and got people being stabbed instead."

West Yorkshire police said security arrangements for the return leg at Elland Road on April 20 were under constant review, with potential troublemakers under scrutiny. Leeds' small Turkish community placed a large spray of flowers on the growing mound of tributes at the ground, where United's team came out in the early afternoon to read the hundreds of messages and place their own wreath.

Friends of Mr Loftus, who was 37, single and a fibre-optics engineer, and Mr Speight, 40, who was married with two young children and ran the Bay Horse pub in Farsley, Leeds, reacted angrily to claims on a Galatasaray website that they were known troublemakers. Mark Jackson, who knew both victims, said: "To my knowledge neither had convictions relating to football hooliganism. This is just propaganda."

Suggestions that the second leg of the cup tie should be played outside Leeds were downplayed by the club and the Labour MP for Leeds Central, Hilary Benn. He said: "The whole community will want the opportunity to do what they went to Turkey in expectation of doing - which was to support their team and to be able to do so safely."

The Turkish embassy in London said last night that it had received death threats and abusive calls since the attack.

Two other suspects, including a youth identified from TV clips and nicknamed "the Arab", are being hunted in connection with the violence in Taksim Square. Demir is expected to face murder charges over the weekend after being identified in a line-up by Leeds fans injured in the fighting. They described him as smartly dressed at the time of the attack, which took place after a chase past a fortified police post in the bar and nightclub area. Two of the arrested group, who must be released by Monday unless police are granted an extension by a judge, were described as friends but there is no suggestion that they formed part of an organised gang of Galatasaray supporters. The Turkish media continued to blame English fans for provoking the violence by being drunk and belligerent. It was suggested that many had mixed the powerful local spirit raki with beer instead of the usual water. Bar owners in Taksim Square said a glass had been broken in a Turkish youth's face and that drunken approaches had been made to local women. Leeds fans returning home disputed the claims but there was little hard evidence of how harmless swagger on both sides had got so quickly out of hand. Most of the Leeds supporters directed their fire at police treatment at Istanbul airport and the disrespect shown to the dead by Turkish fans at Galatasaray's Ali Sami Yen stadium. Ian Williamson, the fan shown in widely published pictures kneeling in the street while a Turkish youth grabbed his hair, said the situation had been confused. Visting Elland Road after arriving back from Istanbul early yesterday, he said: "We went out to watch football and got people being stabbed instead." West Yorkshire police said security arrangements for the return leg at Elland Road on April 20 were under constant review, with potential troublemakers under scrutiny. Leeds' small Turkish community placed a large spray of flowers on the growing mound of tributes at the ground, where United's team came out in the early afternoon to read the hundreds of messages and place their own wreath. Friends of Mr Loftus, who was 37, single and a fibre-optics engineer, and Mr Speight, 40, who was married with two young children and ran the Bay Horse pub in Farsley, Leeds, reacted angrily to claims on a Galatasaray website that they were known troublemakers. Mark Jackson, who knew both victims, said: "To my knowledge neither had convictions relating to football hooliganism. This is just propaganda." Suggestions that the second leg of the cup tie should be played outside Leeds were downplayed by the club and the Labour MP for Leeds Central, Hilary Benn. He said: "The whole community will want the opportunity to do what they went to Turkey in expectation of doing - which was to support their team and to be able to do so safely." The Turkish embassy in London said last night that it had received death threats and abusive calls since the attack.

webTitle: Judge warns on rape law change

fields.headline: Judge warns on rape law change
fields.trailText: The controversy over whether the rape law should be reformed to bring more rapists to justice was reopened yesterday when a senior judge warned that pressures for change could risk imprisoning innocent men.
fields.body:
The controversy over whether the rape law should be reformed to bring more rapists to justice was reopened yesterday when a senior judge warned that pressures for change could risk imprisoning innocent men.

His comments came as he freed a man who spent 15 years in jail for a rape which "almost certainly never happened at all".

Roy Burnett, 56, was jailed for life in 1986 after a jury accepted evidence from a 20-year-old nurse that she had been raped and seriously assaulted. But yesterday three judges quashed his conviction and accepted that the woman had probably faked her own injuries and fabricated the allegations.

Lord Justice Judge said the papers in the "profoundly disturbing case" had been sent to the director of public prosecutions for a decision on whether the woman should be prosecuted.

The judge, sitting in London with Mr Justice Wright and Mrs Justice Rafferty, said: "If nothing else, this case provides a salutary reminder that an allegation of rape is not always true and that the man against whom it is made is not necessarily guilty.

"It should serve to ensure that proper safeguards against the wrongful conviction of innocent individuals are preserved. If so, then, although of no comfort whatever to Mr Burnett, something positive will have been salvaged from this disaster."

The judge said a re-examination of the evidence given at the Old Bailey in1986 revealed many inconsistencies in the woman's various accounts of what happened and her description of her alleged assailant.

Mr Burnett always protested his innocence but had no grounds for an appeal until 1998, when the Metropolitan police decided to re-open his case after the woman made a false allegation of rape to Devon police.

Yesterday it emerged that she had made more than a dozen complaints to Devon police in the last three years, covering a range of allegations from a snatched handbag to threats to kill.

Mr Burnett's conviction was quashed just days after ministers received the report of a government steering group on sex offences which recommended that the definition of rape should be changed from sex without consent to sex without "free agreement". The idea is to make it harder for an accused to get off in cases where his defence is that the woman was willing to have sex or he honestly believed she was willing.

The steering group's proposals would not affect cases where the defence is that the incident is totally fabricated. One QC said yesterday that he believed the abolition of the requirement in sex cases for judges to warn that it was dangerous to convict on the accuser's word alone - repealed after a campaign by women's groups - could lead to more wrongful convictions.

Another QC, Anthony Scrivener, thought cases like Mr Burnett's could happen because the law was reluctant to allow investigation into the complainant's mental state.

Michel Massih, the QC who won the acquittal of the London University student Austen Donellan on charges of raping a fellow student who was drunk, warned against making any changes to rape law.

Mr Massih, who has represented several men who later proved to have been falsely accused, added: "It's a very hard slog to obtain materials to enable us to fight these cases." In one case his client was in custody for two years before "purely by luck we managed to obtain a letter disclosing the woman had made multiple allegations of rape".

webTitle: Toddlers signed up for computer courses

fields.headline: Toddlers signed up for computer courses
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A private tutorial college yesterday provoked controversy by announcing that it is to offer computer skills courses for children as young as 18 months old.
fields.body:
A private tutorial college yesterday provoked controversy by announcing that it is to offer computer skills courses for children as young as 18 months old.

Ryde College, Watford, said the one-hour courses were to satisfy demand from parents. It has developed a reputation for coaching very young children through GCSE and A-level examinations, and holds the record for the youngest GCSE pass in information technology - by a six-year old.

The college is to offer lessons for two age groups: 18 months to two and a half, and two and a half to three and a half. The college ruled out the prospect of rows of babies lined up in front of banks of computers, saying they would not be exposed to a screen for more than 10 minutes at a time.

Courses will teach them how to use a keyboard and a mouse, with other activities involving hand-eye coordination, sound, shape and colour recognition, and simple vocabulary exercises.

Children between two and three will be helped to develop reading and writing skills using a word processor and learn very basic computer programming.

Mike Ryde, the college's managing director, rejected criticism that such courses were inappropriate for children of this age. He said: "Education should start at home, and if skills are taught to children in a structured but fun manner, they are capable of learning and achieving so much at a very early age."

But David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said: "This is hot-housing at its very worst. Parents ought to be very wary of anything like this, and it should have a health warning attached."

webTitle: Managing on a pension - 'but it's not living'

fields.headline: Managing on a pension - 'but it's not living'
fields.standfirst: Lord Falconer reckons he could survive on the state payout. His neighbour, Joyce Bennett, disagrees
fields.trailText: Lord Falconer reckons he could survive on the state payout. His neighbour, Joyce Bennett, disagrees
fields.body:
Baron Falconer of Thornton and Joyce Bennett are unlikely neighbours. They live 500 yards apart in the heart of Islington, north London, but materially they might as well be on different planets.

Lord Falconer, 49, Cabinet Office minister and close friend of Tony Blair, receives a an annual salary of £80,367 and lives in a magnificent four-storey house worth more than £1m, the fruit of more than 20 successful years at the bar.

Mrs Bennett lives just around the corner in a neat, modern council block and gets by on a state pension of £82.54 a week, something her neighbour last week declined to try.

On a visit to a day care centre in Southampton intended to publicise the minimum income guarantee (a government commitment that no pensioner should have to live on less than £78 a week) the minister told a retired dinner lady that he thought he could survive for a week on her pension.

The reaction was swift and damning. The National Pensioners Convention called his comments insensitive and insulting and, along with Age Concern, challenged the minister to try. He declined. Social security minister Jeff Rooker yesterday admitted he could not live on a state pension. Asked by a TV interviewer if he could live on it, the minister responsible for pensions said: "No I couldn't and I wouldn't dream of trying."

Meagre increase

The Falconer challenge was not the government's last embarrassment over pensions last week.

On Monday evening 41 Labour MPs backed a rebel motion to restore the link between pensions and earnings (they are currently calculated on the basis of inflation) severed 20 years ago by Margaret Thatcher. The motion was defeated but the revolt signalled profound discontent on the backbenches at the meagre annual increase in the pension; from Monday pensioners will receive an extra 75p a week, a 1.1% increase.

Unlike Lord Falconer, Mrs Bennett has no choice but to manage on the pension. Widowed four years ago, she is unimpressed by her neighbour's comments."He doesn't know what he's talking about. He wants a kick up the backside. What will 75p buy? It's paltry, it barely buys you a loaf of bread."

While Mrs Bennett is scathing about the increase she is certain to make it stretch as far as possible. Like the 4m pensioners who depend on state benefits, she is expert at making ends meet. "I'm not a tight person but I'm careful," she said. "I have to think before I spend. I can manage but I can't throw it about. We all have to wait and see what we can afford."

After deductions for rent and council tax, both of which are subsidised by the local authority, the TV licence (only over-75s get a free licence), and bills, Mrs Bennett is left with around £10 a day. It is less than it sounds in Falconer's Islington, where the battle for the grey pound is not fiercely fought.

The Salvation Army store on Upper Street looks increasingly out of place amid the interiors shops, boutiques and bars, and while you can buy a cafe latte on every other corner, you will not find a cup of tea under 80p.

In a typical week Mrs Bennett shops almost every day. She says it's important to get out if you are on your own. At the local Sainsbury's she refuses to compromise on food, ignoring the lower shelves stacked with own brand economy items. "I'd rather buy one nice piece of meat than two rubbishy things," she said.

She can be a little selective at the supermarket thanks in part to a day centre for older people run by Age Concern. Open five days a week the Sotheby Mews centre in Highbury is a haven for around 400 people. Staffed by two boundlessly patient full-time staff and a band of volunteers, the centre offers social contact, advice, subsidised meals, preventative healthcare, adult education and a range of activities.

Mrs Bennett visits twice a week to enjoy the company of her peers and a two-course lunch for just £1.85. On Mondays there is bingo, and on Fridays a quiz. Best of all though is the company. "I like being able to eat with my friends. They do a lovely dinner and if I didn't go there I'd be making another meal on my own."

Loneliness

Away from the club Mrs Bennett staves off loneliness by watching television, and satisfying her appetite for books and puzzles. A stack of crossword books sit beside her armchair, and she is motoring through the sequel to Gone With the Wind. Once again, Sotheby Mews allows her to stretch her budget. She buys books at the club for 25p and takes them back when they are finished to be sold on.

By careful management Mrs Bennett can afford the occasional extravagance. She has been saving for two years to take her daughter to the The King and I and she has taken two holidays, coach trips to Scotland and Cornwall, in four years.

Joyce Bennett copes with dignity in sometimes difficult circumstances, and she has the help and support of her daughter and son-in-law, with whom she spends a lot of her weekends.

According to Joe Lewis, another neighbour of Lord Falconer and a representative of the NPC, millions of pensioners do not enjoy the safety net of family or savings. While the pension allows people to get by, it is little help when the roof leaks, the carpet wears or the boiler breaks.

"Of course Lord Falconer could survive for a week on a pension, but he should try doing it week in, week out. Instead of providing for a modest, dignified way of life paid for by those who can afford it ... we are offering people little more than poor relief."

Mrs Bennett agrees that her illustrious neighbour missed the point: "Anyone could manage on a pension, but that's all it is, managing. You can't afford to really live."

fields.headline: Internet's 'potential for evil'
fields.trailText: The wonders of the internet could be leading us towards a "soulless society", according to the Archbishop of York.
fields.body:
The wonders of the internet could be leading us towards a "soulless society", according to the Archbishop of York.

David Hope warned that over-reliance on the new technology could rob us of our ability to socially interact and even went as far as to say the net has the "potential for evil".

Dr Hope writing in the Easter edition of Conservatism, the journal of the Conservative Christian Fellowship, said: "I fear that we are becoming a nation which simply sits in front of a television screen and orders its lives at the press of a button or a mouse."

The archbishop warned that the developments of the net were not neccesarily positive. "Like all these developments there is that which has the potential for good, and that which has the potential for evil."

Dr Hope is not the first senior clergyman to issue warnings about the new technology. In February George Carey, Archbishop of Canterbury, made similar comments. "Clearly access to information and the ability to tap resources not otherwise available can be a potent tool of empowerment. But it can also be exclusive and isolating," he said.
