fields.headline: Out-classed
fields.standfirst: Blair realises Labour is an anachronism. There just aren't enough poor people
fields.trailText: Ever since Tony Blair became Labour leader, his detractors have said that he is a cynical operator, a media-manipulator, a brilliant tactician with no real strategic vision or goal. All of which is the precise opposite of the truth. As every month reveals, Blair is a most incompetent political tactician, whose government has been a series of presentational disasters, and seen one long line of bungled balls-ups, from Scotland to Wales, London to Longbridge.
fields.body:
Ever since Tony Blair became Labour leader, his detractors have said that he is a cynical operator, a media-manipulator, a brilliant tactician with no real strategic vision or goal. All of which is the precise opposite of the truth. As every month reveals, Blair is a most incompetent political tactician, whose government has been a series of presentational disasters, and seen one long line of bungled balls-ups, from Scotland to Wales, London to Longbridge.

And yet Blair clearly does have a large long-term strategy. He mentioned it in a riveting aside in his interview this week with Robert Harris in the American magazine, Talk. More significant than (though related to) his indiscreet hints about a Lib Dem alliance was his confirmation that the great goal of Blairism is "to take class out of British politics" - which is to say, to undo the work of the past century and discard everything the Labour party once stood for.

Until the late 19th century, British party politics were not divided by class, or at least not by the class of have and have-not, bourgeois and proletarian. Tories and Whigs had their origins in the religious and dynastic conflicts of the 17th century, and their later differences were barely ideological. To Hazlitt in the 1820s, Whigs and Tories were two stagecoaches splashing each other with mud, but heading to the same destination by the same road.

The Tories may have been the party of gentry and Church, hostile to radical bourgeois manufacturers. But Whigs were no less aristocratic than Tories, far from it. Even after Whigs, Radicals and Peelites coalesced awkwardly into the Liberal party in 1859, most of the dukes and other grandees remained within this coalition. Gladstone had at least as many great country houses to stay in as his Tory opponents.

The historic rupture came in 1886, with home rule as the proximate cause that saw almost all the Whigs deserting, but there were deeper causes for this rift than Ireland. After 1886, if not by then, the two parties were plainly divided on class lines for the first time. Although there were patriotic working-class Tories - the "angels in marble" Disraeli had descried - the Conservatives and Liberals were increasingly separated by a horizontal class line.

Some saw this and were dismayed. Lord Salisbury, who became Tory premier in 1886, had already been alarmed by the nature of the Liberal victory in the 1880 general election, which "may be the beginning of a serious war of classes". Then in 1894, the distinctly conservative Lord Rosebery complained to his colleague Sir William Harcourt about "the cleavage of classes" in politics. Rosebery became Liberal prime minister that year, albeit as a distinctly unradical Whig who was uneasy about leading a purely plebeian party. He disliked this class basis of party politics as much as Salisbury, or Blair.

"You are too late," Harcourt replied perceptively. "The horizontal division of party was bound to come as a consequence of household suffrage. The thin end of the wedge was inserted, and the cleavage is growing day by day." In other words, once the mass of the people were admitted to the franchise, the day of two great political estates of the realm, divided vertically by policy rather then horizontally by class, was finished.

Even Harcourt didn't know the half of it. He did not foresee how this cleavage was to doom the Liberals, though if he had looked harder at his own party he would have known that, although receptive to the Nonconformist lower middle class, it had been foolishly unwelcoming to the newly politicised working class.

And so the cleavage of classes was taken a step further in February 1900 with the formation of the Labour representation committee, to become the Labour party in 1906. Then and later, its raison d'etre was often misunderstood by left and right alike. Labour had been created quite simply for class reasons - to allow proletarian politicians to become the voice of their class - rather than to espouse any doctrine. Labour was born in order to follow the principle Keir Hardie set out in 1903: "When acting in the House of Commons, they should be neither socialists, Liberals, nor Tories, but a Labour party".

There was an uneasy alliance between leftwing pressure groups and a mass working-class movement: bodies like the Social Democratic Federation, the ILP and the Fabians were socialist but tiny, the unions were huge but not socialist. However, as Hardie suggested, the Labour party was defined first and foremost by class and not ideology.

From its first substantial showing at the 1906 election to its first government in 1924 to its landslide in 1945, Labour was destined to replace the Liberals, in a way which seemed to serve the Tories' interests. This is what Blair means when he regularly laments the split in progressive politics which, as he believes, allowed the Conservatives to dominate the 20th century. It is what he wants to remedy by embracing the Lib Dems, a progressive alliance to dominate the 21st century.

Or as he puts it in his Talk interview: "I think it's a fantastic thing that you get people who are in business, who are middle class, and comfortably off, who will support the Labour party today, and I see nothing wrong in it at all. It was always a terrible constraint on the Labour party, to be seen as representing one class of people."

No doubt the turn of phrase will make old Labour grimace, but he has a point. When he talks about removing class from politics, it has largely removed itself. For all New Labour's gratingly mawkish rhetoric and the intellectual vacuity of the "third way," the prime minister has grasped one great truth: that the sort of society which produced the Labour party no longer exists.

The poor always we have with us, but 100 years years ago "the poor" were most of the British people, and they aren't any more. Now the poor are a minority, to help whom the majority, and not just the rich, must pay taxes. The old industrial working class on whose behalf Labour was called into being grows smaller every year.

Indeed, it very nearly follows from Blair's analysis that the creation of the Labour party was a terrible mistake - an opinion Blair barely disguises. He treated Labour's centenary in February rather like the 100th birthday of a senile, incontinent and unloved granny. It was time for her to fondle her telegram from the Queen, and get ready for the undertaker.

Altogether, Blair's diagnosis that "actually existing Labour" has long outlived any purpose it may ever have had, and his prognosis that the future lies with class-free centrism, are coherent enough. Whether his party was quite bargaining for this when it chose him as leader is another matter.

To Hazlitt in the 1820s, Whigs and Tories were two stagecoaches splashing each other with mud, but heading to the same destination by the same road. The Tories may have been the party of gentry and Church, hostile to radical bourgeois manufacturers. But Whigs were no less aristocratic than Tories, far from it. Even after Whigs, Radicals and Peelites coalesced awkwardly into the Liberal party in 1859, most of the dukes and other grandees remained within this coalition. Gladstone had at least as many great country houses to stay in as his Tory opponents. The historic rupture came in 1886, with home rule as the proximate cause that saw almost all the Whigs deserting, but there were deeper causes for this rift than Ireland. After 1886, if not by then, the two parties were plainly divided on class lines for the first time. Although there were patriotic working-class Tories - the "angels in marble" Disraeli had descried - the Conservatives and Liberals were increasingly separated by a horizontal class line. Some saw this and were dismayed. Lord Salisbury, who became Tory premier in 1886, had already been alarmed by the nature of the Liberal victory in the 1880 general election, which "may be the beginning of a serious war of classes". Then in 1894, the distinctly conservative Lord Rosebery complained to his colleague Sir William Harcourt about "the cleavage of classes" in politics. Rosebery became Liberal prime minister that year, albeit as a distinctly unradical Whig who was uneasy about leading a purely plebeian party. He disliked this class basis of party politics as much as Salisbury, or Blair. "You are too late," Harcourt replied perceptively. "The horizontal division of party was bound to come as a consequence of household suffrage. The thin end of the wedge was inserted, and the cleavage is growing day by day." In other words, once the mass of the people were admitted to the franchise, the day of two great political estates of the realm, divided vertically by policy rather then horizontally by class, was finished. Even Harcourt didn't know the half of it. He did not foresee how this cleavage was to doom the Liberals, though if he had looked harder at his own party he would have known that, although receptive to the Nonconformist lower middle class, it had been foolishly unwelcoming to the newly politicised working class. And so the cleavage of classes was taken a step further in February 1900 with the formation of the Labour representation committee, to become the Labour party in 1906. Then and later, its raison d'etre was often misunderstood by left and right alike. Labour had been created quite simply for class reasons - to allow proletarian politicians to become the voice of their class - rather than to espouse any doctrine. Labour was born in order to follow the principle Keir Hardie set out in 1903: "When acting in the House of Commons, they should be neither socialists, Liberals, nor Tories, but a Labour party". There was an uneasy alliance between leftwing pressure groups and a mass working-class movement: bodies like the Social Democratic Federation, the ILP and the Fabians were socialist but tiny, the unions were huge but not socialist. However, as Hardie suggested, the Labour party was defined first and foremost by class and not ideology. From its first substantial showing at the 1906 election to its first government in 1924 to its landslide in 1945, Labour was destined to replace the Liberals, in a way which seemed to serve the Tories' interests. This is what Blair means when he regularly laments the split in progressive politics which, as he believes, allowed the Conservatives to dominate the 20th century. It is what he wants to remedy by embracing the Lib Dems, a progressive alliance to dominate the 21st century. Or as he puts it in his Talk interview: "I think it's a fantastic thing that you get people who are in business, who are middle class, and comfortably off, who will support the Labour party today, and I see nothing wrong in it at all. It was always a terrible constraint on the Labour party, to be seen as representing one class of people." No doubt the turn of phrase will make old Labour grimace, but he has a point. When he talks about removing class from politics, it has largely removed itself. For all New Labour's gratingly mawkish rhetoric and the intellectual vacuity of the "third way," the prime minister has grasped one great truth: that the sort of society which produced the Labour party no longer exists. The poor always we have with us, but 100 years years ago "the poor" were most of the British people, and they aren't any more. Now the poor are a minority, to help whom the majority, and not just the rich, must pay taxes. The old industrial working class on whose behalf Labour was called into being grows smaller every year. Indeed, it very nearly follows from Blair's analysis that the creation of the Labour party was a terrible mistake - an opinion Blair barely disguises. He treated Labour's centenary in February rather like the 100th birthday of a senile, incontinent and unloved granny. It was time for her to fondle her telegram from the Queen, and get ready for the undertaker. Altogether, Blair's diagnosis that "actually existing Labour" has long outlived any purpose it may ever have had, and his prognosis that the future lies with class-free centrism, are coherent enough. Whether his party was quite bargaining for this when it chose him as leader is another matter.

fields.headline: Kosovo, twinned with Ulster
fields.standfirst: The country may be different but the job's similar.  Owen Bowcott  talks to RUC officers working in Kosovo, who find that only the intensity of the enmity is different
fields.trailText: The country may be different but the job's similar. Owen Bowcott talks to RUC officers working in Kosovo, who find that only the intensity of the enmity is different
fields.body:
The fractured, urban landscape of Mitrovice bears more than a passing resemblance to Londonderry at the height of the Troubles. Communities torn apart by political hatred are divided by a swift-flowing river; isolated minorities depend on the 24-hour vigilance of military patrols for their lives. Barbed wire coils spool across closed roads.

Look closer and the similarities grow stronger. Both places today have officers from the Royal Ulster Constabulary in their distinctive green uniforms on the streets. Kosovo and Northern Ireland might as well be twins; provinces whose violent disputes date back to the Middle Ages and refuse to settle.

Of all the police contingents sent to restore civil order in the Balkans, the RUC is among the most experienced at combating terrorism and the type of slow-burn conflict which flares up into mass confrontations. Sixty officers have been sent already and the United Nations Mission In Kosovo (UNMIK), short of police and recognising their expertise, has requested more. Extra detectives are needed to investigate the weekly random ethnic killings.

The transfer of officers from Magherafelt to Mitrovice, from Portadown to Pristina, as well as throwing up close political parallels, casts fresh light on the durability of sectarian hatred. "Violence kicks off very quickly," warns an RUC sergeant on patrol in Serb-dominated northern Mitrovice. "You get instant crowds." He points out the old police station, crumpled into slabs of broken concrete by US Tomahawk cruise missiles a year ago. "There were 14 Serb police killed in there. Five bodies are still inside. You have to admire the precision: the only building touched in an estate of flats."

Children gather, eager for attention. They carry crude toy guns fashioned from wood and chase over the debris. "It looks like the early days in Belfast or Londonderry, back in 1969, when troops stood around braziers at street corners and were welcomed at first."

Even at this distance during an IRA ceasefire the Troubles cast a long shadow. The sergeant is reluctant to be named for fear of becoming a target for republicans at a future date. In Belfast, the risk depends on how identifiable your name is and where you live. Here he lives in mixed flats north of the River Ibar. "There are four Albanians in the building. They have received phone calls telling them to leave."

Out on patrol the US flag attracts most venom from the Serbs; the Union Jack less. "I was explaining to a woman we're from Northern Ireland," says Peter Bates, an RUC man who normally works on Belfast's notorious Shankill Road. "She said she liked Ireland because it gives Britain a bad time."

But RUC officers were attacked with their Albanian translator by a crowd of 70 ethnic Serbs who chanted:"Go back to London," and, bizarrely, "Go back to Sussex,". A French tank extracted them.

Life is cheap in Kosovo, and so is military equipment. "A grenade cost 25 deutschmarks, rocket launchers a little more," says the sergeant. "AK47s are only 20 deutschmarks." Weapons often turn up in deserted houses. Like those abandoned by the IRA, they can be booby-trapped with explosives.

Sergeant Ronnie Agnew, from Belfast but now attached to UNMIK's central criminal investigation Unit examining war graves, always checks for devices. The lesson has been hard won. Republicans had a craze for booby-trapping everything, he says. "They left a Playboy magazine by a road in South Armagh, hoping a soldier would pick it up. It killed a local guy."

The switch to Kosovo for many of them has been a welcome respite from Stormont's intractable politics, though one officer's locker bore a sign declaring: "Support the RUC against the name change" - in reference to the Patten report proposal to rename the force. The RUC contingent arrived in November amid power cuts, water shortages and sub-zero temperatures. Kosovo is a high plateau, ringed by snow-topped mountains. There is no lush spring; winter fades directly into dusty summer heat. Piles of abandoned possessions and litter blow through the landscape.

In Ulster, there was always a popular Unionist prejudice that you could spot a Protestant farm because it was tidier. In Kosovo, both an RUC and British army officer earnestly assured me that Serb farms were "neater" - as we passed the charred skeletons of houses, mostly burnt-out out by Serb forces.

Mitrovice's guarded bridges, across which Kfor tries to return evicted Albanians, have also been the battleground for an embarrassing dispute between a senior RUC officer and the French army. Inspector John Adams, formerly deputy commander of UNMIK police in the town, was relieved of his duties in Mitrovice last month. The tall rugby enthusiast from Antrim with 21 years of service, appears to have been the victim of diplomatic expedience.

His forthright criticism of what he saw as French military incompetence is based on the security orthodoxy of Northern Ireland - allowing police primacy and giving the military a supporting role. He is not alone in his views: ethnic Albanians see French troops as pro-Serb, blaming them for failing to make arrests.

Adams wanted to develop the kind of intelligence-led policing which proved successful at intercepting many attacks by republican and loyalist paramilitaries. He was keen for the French to use more translators. He was openly critical of their disregard for sites of crimes where forensic examination might yield clues. "Our police officers are capable of so much," says Adams, now back in Pristina. "With the Greenjackets, who had just done a tour of duty in Northern Ireland, we had a great relationship. It's unfortunate it doesn't work in northern Mitrovice".

The fact that the need for international concensus over Kosovo has produced a United Nations administration of uneven qualities is an open secret. Mukesh Kapila, who oversees the department of international development's £110 million budget for the province, admitted in Pristina last week: "In theory UNMIK should work but we have cobbled together an alliance and often the common denominator is the lowest."

Most of the RUC contingent are in the British sector around Pristina under the command of Superintendent John Middlemiss, the deputy head of CID in Belfast. "There will be an international police presence here for many years," he suggests. "There was very little infrastructure, no court system, a backlog of crimes and few detention places in Pristina." Those arrested for arms possession are being released and told to come to court later.

What do Kosovars feel about being policed by the RUC and other foreign forces? Ardian Arifaj, of the province's Koha Dittore newspaper, says the relief of being liberated will guarantee a welcome for a long time. "But the police must arrest war criminals as soon as they can," he adds. "Otherwise people will get frustrated and lose their trust in the internationals, which will be difficult to regain."

Across Kosovo, every Serb Orthodox church has an armoured car parked outside protecting it from revenge attacks by ethnic Albanians. Ekrem Dardhishta, a former Kosovo Liberation Army officer now with the Kosovo Peace Corps, insists: "We have nothing against Kfor, nor their protection for these monuments". But he adds: "You cannot have good feelings about these monuments. Because of them tragedies happened. It's too early to forget what they [the Serbs] did to us."

Milan Jankovic, a Serb who rarely leaves his home in Kosovo Polje these days because of the killings, is in an area heavily patrolled by the RUC and Kfor troops. "If they were not here," he says, "there would be no Serbs left." Most of his neighbours have already fled to Serbia.

Blind sectarian hatred is obviously not new tomost of the officers from Northern Ireland. Its intensity, however, is on a different scale. For Sgt Ronnie Agnew, excavating mass graves and uncovering evidence of particulary gruesome murders, there is a tinge of nostalgia for the familiarity, even integrity, of the Northern Ireland conflict. Recently he came across a pair of severed hands preserved in a deep freeze."No matter how bad some terrorist organisations were [in Northern Ireland]", he says, "there were some kind of rules. But over here it's ruthless." Proof, perhaps, that even after the Shankill Butcher murders and the IRA's no-warnings bombs, that memories can heal with time?

webTitle: One stop pop and knickers shop

fields.headline: One stop pop and knickers shop
fields.trailText: Lost in music
fields.body:
With the music industry close to crisis point, the phrase "CD burning system" is ripe for misunderstanding, evoking a modern version of the Disco Sucks bonfire. The Chemistry system in the Oxford Circus, London, branch of Top Shop in fact features the UK's first make-your-own-CD kiosks, but I'm tempted to visit it with a sack of Stereophonics recordings, asking for directions to the inferno.

Chemistry's CD pods look like HMV's listening posts, but are surrounded by underwear instead of records (next week: greengrocers with electronic scrabble booths). The idea, clearly, is this: you've bought a new vest, and you want something to listen to when you get home and try it on. The choice features 150 songs split into five categories - indie, dance, R&B, chart and specialist - from which you select 10 tracks. Hand in your list, pay £14.99 at the counter, and, after half an hour (during which you should have purchased at least six more vests), collect your personal CD. "The perfect balance between ultimate consumer choice and retail," apparently.

Post-WWW brainwashing, marketing execs have realised that the music-buying public is a sucker for being sold the same thing in different formats, provided it's accompanied by an irritating buzzword ("burning" is already becoming the new "MP3").

The delusion here is that the CD burning kiosk gives you autonomy and the opportunity to encapsulate your personality in music. My own CD, for example, tells me that my only reference point to James Brown is a diabolical drum'n'dross remix, that I once had an embarrassing penchant for Move Any Mountain by the Shamen, that, if really pushed, I can just about stand the yuppie banshee music of Bjork, and... oh,that's it. Well, gee, thanks: feel just brimming over with self-esteem for that. I thought I might be able to find something in the "specialist" category, but it seems Top Shop define specialist as "not quite mind-numbing chart-dance, not quite anaesthetised R&B, but somewhere in between, preferably with a lyric about rubbing up against girls' bottoms".

Top Shop plans to expand its choice of tracks in the next few months, but the lack of variety, the idea that the tiny island of chart pop is the apogee of taste, isn't even the main problem. The major insults are that Chemistry a) doesn't realise that great cover art, flawed songs and imperfections are a major part of the process of learning to treasure an album, b) thinks that a plain CD with a computer print-out tracklisting is a match for a lovingly compiled tape, and c) has a subtext telling us what lazy, unimaginative humans we all are, and attempting to turn us into anal retentives living in perfect, minimalist environments requiring no physical or mental exertion.

Before you check out Chemistry, ask yourself what the real drag is. Getting up off the sofa to skip a duff track on an otherwise brilliant album? Treasure-hunting through a box of forgotten vinyl in a charity shop? Spending a couple of hours agonising over what to put on My Best TDK C90 Ever? Or having your favourite songs dictated to you by a clothes shop?

fields.headline: A Bridlington splash
fields.standfirst: David Hockney  never meant his holiday snapshots to be seen as art. But there's still much to admire, says  Jonathan Jones
fields.trailText: David Hockney never meant his holiday snapshots to be seen as art. But there's still much to admire, says Jonathan Jones
fields.body:
David Hockney is our great artist of leisure. He focuses on the iconography of modern relaxation - showers, swimming pools, pets - just as the French impressionists painted picnics, boating parties and beer halls.

We see the light and space of California through Hockney's paintings: a perfect eggshell-blue sky; tall, straight palms; the explosion of a diver hitting a swimming pool. Now here's the dirty, drizzling half-sunshine of a British seaside resort caught in his casual holiday snaps. In one picture a woman holds off the rain with an umbrella while her husband, in orange and black leisurewear, pushes the pram. In another an elderly couple on a white bench, their backs to us, stare at the sea and a little boy looks our way.

These are just some casual photos Hockney took on one of his visits to Yorkshire to see friends and family; in one of them you can see the artist himself, in long white shorts, reflected in a window as he stands outdoors attempting to photograph people indoors. The pictures could be a mocking pendant to the high Californian pastorale of A Bigger Splash. A Bit of Rain, perhaps. Here's a woman with her coat over her head. There are three lads - up to no good, I'll be bound. In place of the blue pool you have the sea, grey and far too cold to dive into. Bridlington is a nice, middle-class place. There are seafront villas with blooming gardens. It's out of one of these gardens that most of the pictures appear to have been taken, as Hockney surveyed the life of the resort with a friendly eye.

These pictures are not "art". The painter gave the roll of film to a friend as a souvenir; now an anonymous vendor is selling it through a Scarborough auction house. Hockney's family are said to be fuming. There is something pathetic in the urge to market an artist's ephemera, without his permission, as an "original Hockney". On the other hand, these are original Hockneys. He is an artist who uses the camera, and these are his photos.

Photography has been fundamental to the way Hockney paints. His most famous paintings were made partly by copying photographs, a technique he uses to give painting a diary-like quality. He recently enthused to the New Yorker about his late friend Andy Warhol's use of photography. Warhol made portraits from Polaroids and photobooth passport shots, valuing photography as a casual picture-making machine.

Hockney also used the camera in his classic paintings of the late 60s and early 70s to combine the monumentality of a big canvas with the emotional texture of a domestic snapshot. The paintings are private photographs turned into public art and record a time when he was moving permanently to California, missing old friends. Jack Hazan's documentary of this period, A Bigger Splash, shows a series of snaps being taken of Hockney's former lover, Peter; we see how these mementos are transformed into something weighty and lyrical as the film follows the painting of Hockney's 1971 Portrait of an Artist (Pool with Two Figures). A similar photographic process lies behind his Portrait of Mr and Mrs Clark and Percy from the same year, currently in a display of his work at Tate Britain.

The point about Hockney is that he is more straightforwardly emotional than almost any other contemporary artist. He paints people and places with the same naturalness as when any of us take holiday snapshots of friends and family. Newspaper reports have stressed the amateurism of Hockney's Bridlington photos, as if it were humiliating. But his holiday snaps are not embarrassing at all. They are a small but authentic example of what makes him our most lovable artist.

 David Hockney's photos can be seen between 10am and noon today at David Duggleby auctioneers in Scarborough, where they will be auctioned on Monday. Details: 01723-507111.

These pictures are not "art". The painter gave the roll of film to a friend as a souvenir; now an anonymous vendor is selling it through a Scarborough auction house. Hockney's family are said to be fuming. There is something pathetic in the urge to market an artist's ephemera, without his permission, as an "original Hockney". On the other hand, these are original Hockneys. He is an artist who uses the camera, and these are his photos. Photography has been fundamental to the way Hockney paints. His most famous paintings were made partly by copying photographs, a technique he uses to give painting a diary-like quality. He recently enthused to the New Yorker about his late friend Andy Warhol's use of photography. Warhol made portraits from Polaroids and photobooth passport shots, valuing photography as a casual picture-making machine. Hockney also used the camera in his classic paintings of the late 60s and early 70s to combine the monumentality of a big canvas with the emotional texture of a domestic snapshot. The paintings are private photographs turned into public art and record a time when he was moving permanently to California, missing old friends. Jack Hazan's documentary of this period, A Bigger Splash, shows a series of snaps being taken of Hockney's former lover, Peter; we see how these mementos are transformed into something weighty and lyrical as the film follows the painting of Hockney's 1971 Portrait of an Artist (Pool with Two Figures). A similar photographic process lies behind his Portrait of Mr and Mrs Clark and Percy from the same year, currently in a display of his work at Tate Britain. The point about Hockney is that he is more straightforwardly emotional than almost any other contemporary artist. He paints people and places with the same naturalness as when any of us take holiday snapshots of friends and family. Newspaper reports have stressed the amateurism of Hockney's Bridlington photos, as if it were humiliating. But his holiday snaps are not embarrassing at all. They are a small but authentic example of what makes him our most lovable artist.  David Hockney's photos can be seen between 10am and noon today at David Duggleby auctioneers in Scarborough, where they will be auctioned on Monday. Details: 01723-507111.

fields.headline: Thrills without frills
fields.standfirst: Simple is best for Pat Metheny, says  John Fordham
fields.trailText: Simple is best for Pat Metheny, says John Fordham
fields.body:
He no longer looks bashful when he climbs on stage, but everything else about Pat Metheny is familiar from the last 25 years. There's the same jeans and rock-star thicket, and the same fluent musicality that took him through an unbroken two-hour set at the Kendal Leisure Centre as if he were gently jogging.

This is probably Metheny's favourite incarnation, as no-frills soloist in a jazz band, rather than special-effects artist in the stadium-fusion entourage that periodically tours his greatest hits. A brilliant bebop improviser whose curiosity extends to Ornette Coleman and the foothills of free music, Metheny is a spontaneous musician usually trapped in an unspontaneous marketing niche. This show represented the way he sounds off the leash.

The repertoire embraced both Metheny's excellent new Trio 99-00 disc, which also features Bill Stewart on drums and Larry Grenadier on bass, and a slice of Metheny's easygoing, open-spaces composing since the late 70s. The band opened with one of Trio 99-00's standouts, the loping Soul Cowboy. Metheny warmed up with a long solo of bop-blues licks, as if to blow the routine materials out of his system. On What Do You Want, Stewart, the most creatively pushing of drummers, revealed the influence he has lately had on Metheny's phrasing with a thunder of bass-drum patterns. On bass, Grenadier's solos are phrased like songs, and his time is immaculate.

Into the Dream, a solo for Metheny's 42-string hybrid guitar, was pretty but florid. An atypical abstract-jazz noise blast was greeted enthusiastically by the audience: maybe that's a sign that Metheny's soft lyricism has bored not only him but his faithful as well. This is Pat Metheny at his freewheeling best: it's how jazz fans want to hear him, and may even build a new audience.

 Pat Metheny plays the Barbican, London (0171-638 8891), tonight, then tours to Leicester and Birmingham.

fields.headline: Frightfully good form
fields.standfirst: Cut your handicap in the dinner-party stakes with an ear for nuance
fields.trailText: Cut your handicap in the dinner-party stakes with an ear for nuance
fields.body:
A country that pulses with an obsession with horses and makes of social engagement a measurable art is bound to come up with a phrase that unites the two. It may seem an old England I'm talking about (especially to New World-slanged urbanites), but its Ascot-imaged language lives on. "Being on good form" is the phrase I am thinking of, which I encountered among slightly older friends soon after I moved to London. It was an early linguistic hint that the English, whom I thought I knew from having gone to school here (I did O-levels, for God's sake! did they teach me nothing?) were a stranger breed than I'd realised.

"How's Richard?" "He's on very good form at the moment." The line, delivered as a breezy, affectionate assessment, made it seem to me that the question I thought I was asking ("how is the man? healthy? happy? suicidal?") provoked a subtly different answer: he is performing well, thank you. Although the phrase included within it some sense that Richard was in good spirits, the image it brought to mind was Richard at the races. Richard? Ah, yes. On his last outing, he ran fast, and with spirit.

Americans are notoriously interested in each other's interior states. "How are you feeling?" is a common way for friends to check in on each other, but even "How are you doing?", though it sounds more outward-looking - doing suggests activity - is a broad question that inherently asks for a self-assessment from the inside. It implies "How is your life?"

To think otherwise requires an interesting realignment of values - learning to reflect less on state of mind than on state of social grace. If, in my shuttling back and forth between the two countries and languages, I have not yet picked up "She's on good form" to report on my nearest or dearest, it doesn't mean I haven't been struck by the corollary self-doubt: was I on good form, the other night? Have I ever been "on good form"?

The question comes up most pressingly in social gatherings, of which the dinner party is, for a certain class, the key ritual. Here, being on good form means telling good stories, making people laugh, swimming in the swift current of collective conversation. This is what the English are good at, and what they enjoy. Americans prize different social skills: the capacity to discuss an issue, pursue an argument, reveal oneself. (As Edmund White noted: "For an American, a confidence is an ice-breaker and we describe our grandmother's suicide with the same desire to appear amiable that a European employs in commenting on the unseasonably warm weather".)

If you master the dinner partying art, you will earn an even happier accolade: you will be considered "good value". This phrase, which I have heard friends use to describe acquaintances when trying to calculate the balance of guests for a dinner - "Should we invite the art librarian?" "Oh yes, she's good value" - takes social life out of the stable and into the market place. It exposes the harrowing, though no doubt accurate, fact that eating and drinking together create a social economy, and the place you take in that economy will depend on how others assess your performance.

I am sure a Marxist could do something elegant with this - create a nifty, critical diagram. For me, the phrase triggered an uncomfortable string of associations. If you were "good value" you'd obviously be worth asking back; you'd be a smart social investment; you'd earn good returns. Who doesn't like a bargain? Who doesn't feel stiffed when they've overpaid? That porcini risotto we cooked, your hosts might think while watching you fail to wreck the table with laughter; that turbot roasted in salt! And for what?

What I naively, Americanly, thought of simply as "getting together with friends" was clearly far more complicated - a transaction on which books might somewhere be kept. For a paranoid outsider, such language leads inexorably to wondering what happens to the unlucky ones who don't measure up in this economy. If your value plummets, are you consigned to the scrap heap of social history? If your social form proves unreliable, will you be let out to pasture?

Then again, maybe I have this all wrong. Friends dropped me a note about their beautiful newborn, whom I'd recently visited. Young Sonia was described, with glowing parental pride, as being "on very good form". Presumably this had less to do with Sonia's ability to regale a dinner table than with the good news that she was feeding well, sleeping through the night, and not crying too much. In which case, my performance anxiety is misplaced; that much I am sure I can manage.

fields.headline: The last word on   Age
fields.standfirst: Growing old is a bad habit which a busy man has no time to form -   André Maurois
fields.trailText: Growing old is a bad habit which a busy man has no time to form - André Maurois
fields.body:
One is so used to seeing irrationality prevail that it comes as a surprise, and a welcome one, to see the opposite. Reports this week show that a number of leading companies, including supermarkets and B&Q, have begun to employ older people. One of the banks is rehiring retired managers because of a skill shortage, and some companies, like BT, are planning to raise their compulsory retirement age to 70.

Anti-ageism campaigners, in welcoming these developments, say that the point is choice: there are many who do not wish to retire, at least at the now young age of 60 or 65; and there is much evidence that retirement is as bad for individual health as it is for the future pensions burden of the country.

Some, of course, yearn to give up the daily tie of work, either to pursue their own avocations, or - a scarcely comprehensible desire - to put their feet up once and for all. No doubt the victories over challenges and the feeling that one is productive and valued that go so far to make life worth living can be supplied by hobbies; but hobbies have to be good to compare to a role in the real thing.

The Romans of classical antiquity saw retirement and value as linked, on the principle of "seniores priores"; the respect due to experience gave it a front seat at the counsels of state. Even if it is true, as La Rochefoucauld observed, that "old men like to give good advice to console themselves for no longer being able to set bad examples", it is nevertheless useful to a society to have the fruits of experience available if required.

The Chinese take this to an extreme; in their gerontocracy no one under 75 is regarded as yet fit for power. They think time induces perspective, as exemplified by Zhou En Lai's celebrated comment on the French Revolution; when asked whether he thought it had been a good thing; he said (after a deliberative pause): "It's too soon to say".

The fashion in recent times has been for the young to hold centre stage, as if they were the only important form of human being. The main reason is that advertisers know the young have beliefs they are prepared to back with money, chief among them that everyone else is having fun, and that if they are to have fun too they must go somewhere smoky and noisy and wear the same clothes as all the others there. They therefore flock to clubs or Ibiza in search of stupefaction by a combination of decibels, drink and drugs, and mock their elders for flinching from the scene.

They do not see that "nobody loves life as much as the old do", as Sophocles remarked, and that accumulated years confer wisdom of the kind possessed by the old bull in the fable (which goes: a young bull sees that the gate into the next field, full of cows, is open. In delight he says to the old bull, "Look! The gate's open! Let's rush down there and mount a few!" To which the old bull replies, "No; let's go down there slowly, and mount them all.")

There is, incidentally, no such thing as "middle age". This is the period of life allegedly defined by the exchange of geometries between your broad mind and narrow waist, or when, as Franklin Adams observed, you are too young to take up bowls but too old to rush up to the net. Some people are born old, and some die young in their nineties: it is entirely a matter of attitude, which, as the Stoics long ago pointed out, is something wholly at your own command. What happens as the years pass is that folly somewhat abates, and the bank balance improves; on both counts, getting older is a desirable activity.

There is much false propaganda about age. "Age has a good mind and sorry shanks," said Aretino, confusing the ability to run for a bus with good health and the right kinds of vigour. Most of the saws and sayings that apply to age, making it a concoction of trembling limbs and forgetfulness, are drawn from a time when people were old at 40. A person must now be at least double that to have the honour of being properly old. And honour it is: "Life is a country that the old have seen, and lived in", said Joseph Joubert; "those who have yet to travel through it can only learn the way from them."

fields.headline: Letter: Charles Ford
fields.trailText: Frank Bealey writes: I first met Charles Ford (Obituary, March 27) at the London School of Economics in 1946. His main preoccupation was to prevent the resurgence of Oswald Mosley, understandable because he had grown up in Dalston Road, Hackney, on the route of British Union of Fascist marches.
fields.body:
Frank Bealey writes: I first met Charles Ford (Obituary, March 27) at the London School of Economics in 1946. His main preoccupation was to prevent the resurgence of Oswald Mosley, understandable because he had grown up in Dalston Road, Hackney, on the route of British Union of Fascist marches.

Our friendship was sealed when, in the summer of 1947, we hitch-hiked from Prague to Budapest: some of our journey was on farm tractors. At the Yugoslav embassy in Budapest, we were given our train fares to central Bosnia where, with hundreds of other European students, we helped to build a railway for Tito.

Because of his poor eyesight, Charles had not been called up for military service and had taken a job filing gold bars at the Royal Mint. He told the story of how, applying later for a clerkship at the Czech embassy, he described his occupation as "filing" and was successful. It was a pity that his political ambitions were not fulfilled. He had the capacity for rational argument and a strong reaction to injustice.

fields.headline: Jean Howard
fields.standfirst: The photographer who snapped her partygoing friends, the stars, when Hollywood was a real community
fields.trailText: In these times Hollywood glamour receives unprecedented media attention, but is probably at its lowest actual manifestation, as the life of Jean Howard, who has died aged 89, illustrates.
fields.body:
In these times Hollywood glamour receives unprecedented media attention, but is probably at its lowest actual manifestation, as the life of Jean Howard, who has died aged 89, illustrates.

She was born Ernestine Hill to a travelling salesman and a housewife in the obscure Texas town of Longview. She became a Ziegfeld chorine, a starlet, and the film community's own photographer. She numbered as friends Laurence Olivier, Marlene Dietrich, and Marilyn Monroe, spurned marriage to Hollywood's most powerful studio boss, and lived in a house of legendary splendour.

She mingled with Tyrone Power, Greta Garbo, Humphrey Bogart, Lauren Bacall, Merle Oberon, Cole Porter, Judy Garland, Gary Cooper, Cary Grant, the gangster Bugsy Siegel, and former President John Kennedy. That social life would be impossible today. The stars do not mix socially outside such events as the Oscars; the Palm Springs movie colony no longer exists; and the retinues of bodyguards and courtiers would get in the way.

But as Howard's photographs show in her two books, Jean Howard's Hollywood: A Photo Memoir (1989), and Travels With Cole Porter (1991), there was a time when stars played croquet, frolicked in Raybans on beaches, went on trips, enjoyed parties - where everyone seemed to smoke - dressed up, and danced the tango. They gathered around pianos and sang, and the Conga lines often ended in the swimming pool.

They also attended countless functions at Howard's Spanish-colonial style home in Coldwater Canyon, Beverly Hills, where the fashionable designer Billy Haines created a resplendent conglomeration of deep green walls, tortoise-shell pedestals, Chinese porcelain lamps and a garden room where Judy Garland would sing.

Howard and her husband, agent-producer Charles Feldman, bought it for $18,000 in 1942 and Howard died in it - as Feldman had done in 1968.

Jean Howard was beautiful and decided early to exploit it. A photographer who had discovered several child stars encouraged her, and she changed her surname to his, Mahoney. Her father financed her in fashion shows and beauty contests, and in the late 20s took her to Hollywood for a fortnight - although as a cover for an affair he was having. Then, in 1930, she signed a contract with MGM, considered the "queen of the studios".

The Broadway producer Lorenz Ziegfeld took her to New York, renamed her Jean Howard, and cast her in his Follies shows. She continued playing small film parts, including The Prizefighter And The Lady in 1933, with boxers Max Baer, Jack Dempsey and Primo Carnera. MGM's chief, Louis B Mayer, fell passionately in love with her, proposed marriage and promised to divorce his wife. But Howard rejected him, whereupon he got drunk and tried to throw himself out of a window.

She married Feldman the following year and Mayer, who by then was madly jealous, threatened to end Feldman's career. Feldman survived, producing A Streetcar Named Desire with Marlon Brando in 1951, and becoming the first agent to "package", by supplying the director, stars and other talent - all of them on his books - for a film. In 1948, the couple's stormy upsets led to divorce, but they continued living together, and throwing those legendary parties.

For years Howard had been friendly with Cole Porter's wife Linda, from whom she learned many social skills. After Linda's death, Howard persuaded the songwriter, who was homosexual, to travel with her, and the pictures she took in 1955 and 1956 became her second book. As well as photos of museums and landmarks in Europe, the book was an account of Porter's astonishing extravagance.

Although Howard studied photography at college in Los Angeles, her work, which appeared in Vogue and Life, demonstrated her ability to relax her subjects more than any artistry in portraiture. Her great skill, wrote one critic, was her "talent for friendship with highly accomplished and rather difficult people".

In 1964, she left a Mediterranean cruise in Capri, where she met musician Tony Santoro in a night club. They began living together in Capri and Rome, were married in 1973, and returned to Beverly Hills. He is her only immediate survivor.

Among her many intriguing stories was that of her first meeting with Kennedy. She had hosted a party for him until 4am after the 1960 Democratic convention in Los Angeles, when he was nominated as presidential candidate. While clearing up she heard a scratch at the window, and Kennedy entered, saying he was starving and could find nowhere to eat. Howard made him scrambled eggs after which, she later told a magazine, he kissed her passionately.

What happened next, she said, would be revealed in her autobiography. She never wrote it.

 Jean Howard, Hollywood hostess and photographer, born October 13 1910; died March 20 2000

Her father financed her in fashion shows and beauty contests, and in the late 20s took her to Hollywood for a fortnight - although as a cover for an affair he was having. Then, in 1930, she signed a contract with MGM, considered the "queen of the studios". The Broadway producer Lorenz Ziegfeld took her to New York, renamed her Jean Howard, and cast her in his Follies shows. She continued playing small film parts, including The Prizefighter And The Lady in 1933, with boxers Max Baer, Jack Dempsey and Primo Carnera. MGM's chief, Louis B Mayer, fell passionately in love with her, proposed marriage and promised to divorce his wife. But Howard rejected him, whereupon he got drunk and tried to throw himself out of a window. She married Feldman the following year and Mayer, who by then was madly jealous, threatened to end Feldman's career. Feldman survived, producing A Streetcar Named Desire with Marlon Brando in 1951, and becoming the first agent to "package", by supplying the director, stars and other talent - all of them on his books - for a film. In 1948, the couple's stormy upsets led to divorce, but they continued living together, and throwing those legendary parties. For years Howard had been friendly with Cole Porter's wife Linda, from whom she learned many social skills. After Linda's death, Howard persuaded the songwriter, who was homosexual, to travel with her, and the pictures she took in 1955 and 1956 became her second book. As well as photos of museums and landmarks in Europe, the book was an account of Porter's astonishing extravagance. Although Howard studied photography at college in Los Angeles, her work, which appeared in Vogue and Life, demonstrated her ability to relax her subjects more than any artistry in portraiture. Her great skill, wrote one critic, was her "talent for friendship with highly accomplished and rather difficult people". In 1964, she left a Mediterranean cruise in Capri, where she met musician Tony Santoro in a night club. They began living together in Capri and Rome, were married in 1973, and returned to Beverly Hills. He is her only immediate survivor. Among her many intriguing stories was that of her first meeting with Kennedy. She had hosted a party for him until 4am after the 1960 Democratic convention in Los Angeles, when he was nominated as presidential candidate. While clearing up she heard a scratch at the window, and Kennedy entered, saying he was starving and could find nowhere to eat. Howard made him scrambled eggs after which, she later told a magazine, he kissed her passionately. What happened next, she said, would be revealed in her autobiography. She never wrote it.  Jean Howard, Hollywood hostess and photographer, born October 13 1910; died March 20 2000

fields.headline: Slippery customers
fields.standfirst: Gay outing upsets Turkey's wrestlers
fields.trailText: Competitors in Turkey's annual oil-wrestling competition have banded together to try to stop a group of homosexual admirers coming to watch the event.
fields.body:
Competitors in Turkey's annual oil-wrestling competition have banded together to try to stop a group of homosexual admirers coming to watch the event.

Bears of Turkey, a gay entity that exists on the internet and describes itself as "just a group of guys who try to do something", is advertising a trip to watch the 639th Kirkpinar oil wrestling championships to be held on July 1 and 2 near Turkey's northwestern city of Edirne.

But Alper Yazoglu, chairman of the Traditional Sports Federation, said: "It's immoral. We are trying every way to have this stopped... We shall pass this matter on to the interior, foreign and other ministries to ask for this disgusting business to be stopped."

The sport of oil wrestling dates back to the Turks' exodus from central Asia in the middle ages. Each year, the contestants cover themselves in olive oil and grapple with each other wearing leather trousers.

Putting a hand down the opponent's trousers to get a better grip is a common tactic.

webTitle: Britain warns EU to drop spying debate states over Echelon

fields.headline: Britain warns EU to drop spying debate states over Echelon
fields.trailText: Britain is trying to stifle a European Union debate about its involvement in a US-led economic espionage network by warning its partners that their own secrets could be exposed.
fields.body:
Britain is trying to stifle a European Union debate about its involvement in a US-led economic espionage network by warning its partners that their own secrets could be exposed.

With Portugal planning to raise concerns about the controversial Echelon surveillance system - a network of satellites and listening posts - the government signalled yesterday that EU member states should think carefully before allowing any discussion.

Echelon, set up during the cold war, is reportedly capable of intercepting millions of telephone, fax and email messages. It has come under scrutiny by the European parliament amid allegations that it has been used to spy on European companies.

Britain is worried because the issue has been presented as one in which a choice has to be made between loyalty to the US and European partners - and because intelligence and security matters are normally strictly off-limits for the EU.

"The Portuguese said they wanted a general exchange on interception," a British official said. "But it would need to be a discussion that would cover the issue in the round rather than focusing on just one member state.

"There is no incompatibility between our position as an EU member state and our duty to maintain national security. Others are in the same position."

France, angered by reports that the US used Echelon to beat the European consortium Airbus to a deal with Saudi Arabia, is expected to be quick to grasp the veiled threat.

Britain declared formally last month that any interception of communications carried out by the GCHQ eavesdropping centre was covered by strict legal guidelines, ministerial control and parliamentary oversight.

Fresh efforts are being made to convince sceptics that interception officially justified by the need to "safeguard the nation's economic well-being" does not involve British companies gaining commercial advantage.

Only threats to the supply of energy, commodities and raw materials or attempts to manipulate or undermine the financial markets would justify legal interception, the government says.

Portugal, the current holder of the EU's rotating presidency, announced that it would consider the issue at a meeting of interior ministers next month.

The 626-member parliament will make the unusual move next week of setting up its own ad hoc committee of inquiry, and hold two plenary debates on Echelon in May.

James Woolsey, a former head of the CIA, admitted recently that the US does secretly collect information on European companies. But he insisted that it only targeted firms which violated United Nations sanctions or offered bribes to gain business.

Britain has never denied helping the US operate Echelon satellites and listening posts along with Canada, Australia and New Zealand in an intelligence-sharing pact that dates back to the early days of the cold war.

webTitle: Close call fails to stir Greek voters

fields.headline: Close call fails to stir Greek voters
fields.trailText: At the end of one of the longest general election campaigns in history, Greeks will be faced with a simple choice at the polls tomorrow: re-elect Pasok, which has brought peace with Turkey, or elect the conservative New Democrats, who take a more hawkish stance on relations with Athens's traditional foe.
fields.body:
At the end of one of the longest general election campaigns in history, Greeks will be faced with a simple choice at the polls tomorrow: re-elect Pasok, which has brought peace with Turkey, or elect the conservative New Democrats, who take a more hawkish stance on relations with Athens's traditional foe.

Analysts say it is the only real difference between the two main parties. Under the leadership of Costas Simitis, Pasok, the Socialist party, has buried the left, along with generous patronage and social spending; under Costas Karamanlis, leader of New Democracy, the conservatives have moved centre stage, even courting labour organisations which were once the backbone of Pasok's support.

In the confusion of overlapping agendas the election, called five months early, has been dominated by the sniping between leaders stealing one another's policies.

"People here have realised that in a united Europe it doesn't make a great difference who wins," says Nikos Dimou, author of the best selling The Misfortune to be Greek.

"We are a country that is totally dependent on the EU and, as such, there is very little the national government can do. Greeks are more interested in the Athens stock exchange: it's the only thing left that seems to get their blood boiling."

But with 26 parties competing it will be the closest contest since the restoration of democracy after the collapse of the Colonels' regime in 1974. Up to 13% of the 8.9m electors are still undecided and the polls show the two main contenders neck and neck.

Both big parties were flying in voters from around the globe last night, including migrant workers in Germany and Greeks studying in Britain.

webTitle: Sneaky leak leaves Old Russia at a loss

fields.headline: Sneaky leak leaves Old Russia at a loss
fields.trailText: In the beginning was an officious knock on the padded, triple-locked door, which is supposed to keep out the cold and deter the allegedly ubiquitous thugs. The chaps from the municipal plumbing department had arrived to look for the leak.
fields.body:
In the beginning was an officious knock on the padded, triple-locked door, which is supposed to keep out the cold and deter the allegedly ubiquitous thugs. The chaps from the municipal plumbing department had arrived to look for the leak.

Poor old Lyudmila Filipovna downstairs was getting soaked. She'd managed to call in the plumbing pros, or so she thought, after several days of being fobbed off by the council.

The experts arrived. Three males. Two were meek and silent. The third - the boss - barked orders. He was Mr Angry. He marched into the loo and his face turned greener than the tiles with envy at the comfortable middle-class bathroom.

They did not have a tool between them. One started unscrewing the access hatch to the pipes with a ballpoint before giving up. We gently suggested he might want to borrow a screwdriver.

Mr Angry glowered, then declared that the bathroom was to blame for the distress downstairs."Get it fixed quick. If we have to come back, we'll smash up the bathroom."

Mr Angry is Old Russia, a municipal employee who holds an age-old contract with the state. They pretend to pay him and he pretends to work.

The discovery of westerners living in relative luxury in the Russian block of flats was more than he could bear. Most western professionals in Moscow live in government-run compounds with guards and gardeners, a relic of the Soviet era when they traded KGB surveillance of their comings and goings for a colonial lifestyle.

They are safe havens in the Moscow mayhem, allaying paranoia about rampant criminality somewhere out there beyond the high steel railings, checkpoints and security guards.

But where we live there is no special regime. We are the sole foreigners in a block of 16 flats, at the mercy of the angry men who idle away their days bullying and browbeating the tenants.

What was really bothering Mr Angry was that ordinary Russian bathrooms are built to suit the plumber, not the occupant, with all pipes exposed. Rima, our Armenian landlady, had had the whole place tiled, discreetly encasing the piping. The plumbers were at a loss to locate the leak.

So the "canalisation committee" arrived to have a look. That's the effluent people. No joy. Then came the blokes from the "sanitation committee". They're in charge of water supply. The cold water was turned off. The leak persisted. Then the hot water was turned off. Eureka.

We called in Volodya. He is New Russia - a proper plumber who turns up promptly in overalls and with a tool kit, fixes things, and tidies up behind him.

He is a winner in the New Russia. He has a proper job, reasonably paid. The angry squad, losers in the Russian revolution, hate him for it.

"Did you see the way [Mr Angry] looked at Volodya?" Rima said.

"He can't stand to see someone doing a decent job."

webTitle: One pot meals: how food is meant to be

fields.headline: One pot meals: how food is meant to be
fields.standfirst: One-pot meals aren't just a way to save on the washing up, says Peter Preston. They're a reminder of what food is all about
fields.trailText: One-pot meals aren't just a way to save on the washing up, says Peter Preston. They're a reminder of what food is all about
fields.body:
All for one, and one for all. You don't have to argue the technical virtues of one-pot cooking - the mingling of flavours, the juices sealed in, the tenderness of meat stewed over hours. Nor is there any debate about its extreme, old-fashioned convenience in the hubbub of working lives. Make, leave, forget, serve. But one pot, for me, always betokens something more, wherever you come across it. One pot is the taste of home.

Take a couple of business days in Paris a week or so ago. A succession of elegantly sculpted confections have passed over your plate, and you're desperate for something straightforward. The dish of the day at Les Fous d'en Face (in the Rue de Bourg-Tibourg) is a marmite des p cheurs: just chunks of fish, potatoes and vegetables served in a high, white pot. Perfection. No ingredient competes with another. Everything blends and complements in utter simplicity. It is not, in the very best sense, a restaurant meal at all. You take notes because you know you could do it yourself.

That goes, of course, for all classic one-pot dishes. They aren't art, titillated for effect; they are solid nourishment. They carry with them the image of cast-iron pots steaming on a blackened stove or earthenware dishes bubbling within. They are ladle food. The image, perhaps, is a little out of date. There's a plug-in electric pot for indefinite stewing that lies at the back of my kitchen cupboard and never comes out these days, the ghosts of Morphy and Richards past. You wouldn't be seen dead at a supper party carrying such dated vessels.

But there is also, when you cast around the world, much more to one-pot cooking than beef, beer and carrots. The Japanese have a precise word for it, nabemono , of which the most routine embodiment is sukiyaki. Try it, though, as yosenabe, a wonderful seafood stew, if you get the chance. There's no reason why any of this should sit weightily on the stomach. The freshness of the fish and vegetables cuts right across one pot stereotypes. So it does, too, in a Norwegian version I sometimes make for myself: cod fillets, apples, celery and onions cooked for 30 minutes or so with a little milk.

One style of cooking, though, depends almost entirely on the single pot and the big spoon, and it expands your horizons in the process. The great Creole and Cajun dishes of Louisiana all jump into and out of the pot. Shrimp and ham jambalaya, with celery, green pepper and tomato, the rice thrown in at the end. Creole gumbo, the king of hearty soups, with chicken, crab, shrimp and anything else to hand, as long as you don't forget the okra or, better still, file powder from ground sassafras leaves. Or, more gently, think Oyster Rockefeller casserole with a pile of chopped spinach, and (my personal favourite) a casserole of spinach and crabmeat with shrimps and artichoke hearts.

The moment you begin to roam more widely is the moment you see the possibilities. The heart of one-pot cooking is essentially traditional. Cooking, after all, began with one pot on an open fire. The historic dishes of France are rooted in it. Long hours in the pot turns the toughest, cheapest ingredients tender. They also, in the most natural way, accentuate every taste positive.

Is that a bit out of fashion, though? A tradition that doesn't fit with instant magret from the supermarket or (ultimate horror) tandoori chicken Kiev? There's no doubt that's so. The show has moved on. But it's time, I think, to come back to it. The one pots don't have to be meat and winter vegetables: they can be whipped up in 15 minutes and are as good left for a day as eaten immediately. A most convenient food you can zip up in the morning while the kids eat breakfast and return to with relish at night. A cassoulet or pot au feu can be eaten in stages, as the family, in its various manifestations, drops in through the day because it's starving. That, after all, is the taste and feel and memory of home, wherever you are: a communal gathering, a natural feast in every pot.

webTitle: Peru's leader in tight election battle

fields.headline: Peru's leader in tight election battle
fields.trailText: In his climb to Peru's highest political office, President Alberto Fujimori learned how to play the part of the victorious underdog. But as the son of poor Japanese immigrants, who in previous elections trounced novelist Mario Vargas Llosa and the former UN secretary general, Javier Perez de Cuellar, sets his sights on a third term, he now faces a giant-killer of his own.
fields.body:
In his climb to Peru's highest political office, President Alberto Fujimori learned how to play the part of the victorious underdog. But as the son of poor Japanese immigrants, who in previous elections trounced novelist Mario Vargas Llosa and the former UN secretary general, Javier Perez de Cuellar, sets his sights on a third term, he now faces a giant-killer of his own.

Mr Fujimori's run for a third five-year term, considered a fait accompli until a few weeks ago, has become the toughest political fight of his life, with the emergence of Alejandro Toledo as a serious challenger.

Mr Toledo, a US-educated economist with humble Peruvian roots, moved slightly ahead of his rival in the opinion polls this week, indicating that tomorrow's election will force a second round run-off in June.

The rise of Mr Toledo is all the more remarkable since the race has ben riddled with allegations of campaign sabotage and government-financed harassment of opposition candi dates. International observers have said that "irreversible damage" has been done to the voting process and that the state's control of the media has given Mr Fujimori a huge, unfair advantage.

Mr Toledo, 54, has strong Indian features which makes him popular with Peru's large Indian and mixed-race communities. He started as a shoeshine boy, but escaped poverty by gaining a scholarship to Stanford University in California before becoming an economist for the World Bank.

Analysts believe that the in cumbent president is still the man to beat, although Mr Toledo's supporters are hoping that their candidate can pull off a last-minute victory.

But others, such as the political scientist Fernando Rospigliosi, feel that Peru's political playing field may have been irreversibly skewed since then. "Those who think [Toledo could win] forget something fundamental and decisive," he said. "The 1990 elections were the last ones that were free, clean and competitive in Peru. Today's are not."

webTitle: Editor accuses South African minister of libel

fields.headline: Editor accuses South African minister of libel
fields.trailText: A South African newspaper editor sought to have criminal charges brought against a senior minister in the South African cabinet yesterday as the long-running row about alleged racism in the media erupted once again.
fields.body:
A South African newspaper editor sought to have criminal charges brought against a senior minister in the South African cabinet yesterday as the long-running row about alleged racism in the media erupted once again.

Philip van Niekerk, editor of the Mail & Guardian - a sister publication of the Guardian - asked the human rights commission to launch an inquiry into what he termed a "lie" told to it by the minister of public enterprises, Jeff Radebe.

Mr Radebe delivered a written submission to the commission this week on behalf of the ANC, claiming that Mr Van Niekerk had personally written an attack on the president, Thabo Mbeki, and published it under the name of a black woman reporter to avoid the accusation that he was a racist.

Yesterday the reporter in question, Lizeka Mda - now executive editor of one of the country's biggest daily newspapers, the Star - said in a front page article that the allegation was entirely untrue, that the minister had made no attempt to confirm it with her, and that it was the worst possible insult to her integrity.

Ms Mda dismissed Mr Radebe as less than a "colourless piece of chewing gum stuck to the underside of the dinner table", and said: "What gives one a sinking feeling is that as president of the ANC, Mbeki wrote, or gave his express approval to, that nonsensical document."

A statement issued by the Mail & Guardian on behalf of the editor, management and staff described Mr Radebe's accusation as "in every respect, a gross, defamatory lie".

Demanding that the ANC and minister withdraw it and issue "an unconditional retraction and full apology", the statement said: "It does not become a proud political party, or, for that matter, a minister of state, to lie publicly and with defamatory intent and result."

It said the staff stood by Mr Van Niekerk, "an editor of rare integrity and courage."

Mr Van Niekerk, acting on legal advice, made a formal application to the commission for an inquiry into Mr Radebe's testimony.

Specific provision is made in the enabling legislation for such an inquiry if it is suspected that a witness has made allegations with reckless disregard for the truth: a criminal offence punishable by up to six months' imprisonment.

Other newspapers were quick to rally to the support of the Mail & Guardian. Business Day said in an editorial, headed "Higher order of crassness", that the ANC's submission was "idiocy," and that its characterisation of the South African press was an "offensive" stereotype.

It said that the portrayal of all criticism as racist "looks like an attempt to intimidate the media into halting any criticism of government and, particularly, the president".

Another Johannesburg newspaper, the Citizen, demanded that the minister "retract and apologise" for the charge. Asking why Mr Radebe and the ANC had made no attempt to establish the facts, it said: "In the absence of a plausible answer, we must assume that the allegation was made with malicious intent."

An ANC statement on Thursday night said: "We took an oath before the commission and therefore stand by our written submission."

fields.headline: Four fabulous one-pot recipes
fields.standfirst: Scotch broth, pot au feu, bouillabaisse and boiled beef and carrots with dumplings. Jeremy Lee shares some of his favourite recipes
fields.trailText: Scotch broth, pot au feu, bouillabaisse and boiled beef and carrots with dumplings. Jeremy Lee shares some of his favourite recipes
fields.body:
All recipes serve six.

Scotch broth

As with all traditional fare, the basic idea and ingredients are integral; thereafter it's simply a matter of availability.

1kg lamb scrag end or neck fillet

50g pearl barley, rinsed

2-3 medium carrots

2 medium onions

2 medium potatoes

1 swede

200g baby turnips (if available)

3 leeks

1 small head cabbage

1 bayleaf

1 sprig thyme, tied

Sea salt and milled black pepper

Peel, clean and trim all the vegetables. Cut off any large chunks of fat on the meat. Place the meat in a large, heavy-based pot and cover with water. Bring to a boil, skim off any impurities that rise to the surface, add more water to make up for that lost through evaporation and skimming, return to the boil, then reduce to a simmer. Add the barley.

Cut the vegetables into small cubes, and add to the pot, starting with the carrots and finishing with the leeks and cabbage. Some fresh spring vegetables - new potatoes, peas, broad beans, et al - enhance the dish immeasurably, but these should be added to the pot no more than 20 minutes before serving. Keep skimming any foam that rises to the surface. Let the broth tick away for two hours. It can be served right away, but tastes much better the next day.

Pot au feu

A big choice of meats, I know, so reduce at will, as long as chicken and beef figure.

1.5kg beef shin

500g forequarter flank

500g bladebone

500g rump

500g oxtail

200g rib bones

5 calf marrow bones, in 3cm lengths

500g veal knuckle

500g neck of lamb

1.5kg chicken

2 leeks

4 medium carrots

3 ripe tomatoes

4 sticks celery, heart preferably

3 medium onions

1 fennel bulb

1 parsnip

12 cloves garlic, whole

2 bayleaves

1 small sprig thyme

3 fresh sage leaves

12 black peppercorns

Ask a butcher to prepare and tie the meats as required. If using marrow bones, place them on the bottom of the pan with the meats atop, commencing with the beef cuts. Cover liberally with water, set over a gentle heat, then prepare the vegetables: peel the onions, carrots and parsnip; cut, wash and tie the leeks. All the other vegetables are left whole, to reduce the chances of the stock turning cloudy.

Once the meat is simmering, remove any foam on the surface, then add the vegetables and herbs. Peas, broad beans, green beans, even a truffle, can be added 10-15 minutes before serving. Check the pot from time to time: as each vegetable or meat is done - the chicken, for example, will be cooked before the beef - remove it to a warm dish, and keep moist with ladles of stock. Keep covered. Serve the meats, sliced and portioned, with the vegetables on a big platter, doused with some broth.

Bouillabaisse

Native Mediterranean fish such as rascasse and weaver are vital to the authenticity of this meal, but needs must: a generous selection of fish will make a fine pot, regardless of provenance. Ask the fishmonger to gut, scale and clean the fish (and, if you don't like bones, to fillet them, too).

3kg fish (sea bass, monkfish, hake, bream, red mullet, conger eel, etc)

500g mussels, optional

500g mixed shellfish - lobster or langoustine - or 200g cleaned, sliced squid, optional

3 onions

3 leeks

3 sticks celery

1 head garlic

500g ripe tomatoes

1 fennel bulb

2 bayleaves

1 small sprig thyme, tied

1 heaped tsp saffron

5cm strip orange peel

100ml olive oil

100ml white wine

1.5kg boiling potatoes

For the rouille

3 egg yolks

1 heaped tsp saffron

5 anchovy fillets

2 cloves garlic

1 tsp tomato purée

1 good squeeze lemon juice

5 healthy slugs Tabasco

250ml olive oil

Salt and pepper

For the croutons

1 baguette

2 garlic cloves

Peel and finely chop the onions, fennel, celery, garlic and leeks, cleaning them as you go. In a big pot, heat the oil and fry until the vegetables are soft and lightly coloured. Chop the tomatoes, add to the pot and cook until all the liquid has evaporated. Pour in the wine, tip in the herbs and saffron, and bring to the boil. Pour in water to cover, and return to the boil. If you're using filleted fish, add their bones and skin at this stage. Simmer for 20 minutes, and check the seasoning. Strain the stock and return to the pot. Add the potatoes and, when almost cooked, add the fish. Filleted fish will cook in a few minutes, but whole fish will take 15-20 minutes. Do not overcook. Remove the fish as it cooks to a serving dish. Serve the potatoes alongside or in a separate dish, with rouille in a bowl and croutons in another.

To make the rouille, place all the ingredients except the oil in a food processor and render to a paste. Pour in the oil in a steady stream, stirring all the while; decant into bowl and cover until required. To make the croutons, rub the baguette with garlic until gleaming and sticky. Slice the baguette thinly, lay on a baking tray and drizzle with olive oil. Bake in a moderate oven until golden.

Boiled beef and carrots with dumplings

I like what Dorothy Hartley had to say on the subject of boiled beef. So much so, in fact, that I offer it up intact: 'Slightly salted beef is good for this, and a round of beef is excellent. Take carrots, parsnips, a turnip and a little celery, and onions, and clean and cut up and set to boil in a large pot. Tie the beef securely, and when the vegetables have come to the boil, put it into the broth, and immediately draw it aside from the fire, or lower the heat, so that hereafter the water only simmers. After 20 minutes or so, lift the lid and scum off any "clearing" from the top of the broth, add a little whole pepper, spice, close the lid again, and let it cook till the meat is tender and the vegetables soft. Serve, drained, on a hot dish, with the vegetables separately, and the broth for gravy. Dumplings are always served with boiled beef. Some people also like a white onion sauce.'

For the dumplings

450g self-raising flour

85g unsalted butter

85g suet

2 very fresh eggs

1 small handful picked flat-leaf parsley, chopped

1 pinch sea salt

Put the flour, butter and suet in a bowl, and work into fine crumbs. Add the eggs, salt and parsley, along with a tablespoon of ice-cold water. Mix deftly, as the dough toughens if overworked. Form the dough into small, walnut-sized pieces, then place in a steamer to cook for 20 minutes or so. The dumplings should be served at once, so cook them only when ready to serve the beef

 Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.
