webTitle: Peter Nichols: A voice from the wilderness

fields.headline: Peter Nichols: A voice from the wilderness
fields.standfirst: For two decades he was one of our finest playwrights. Then he fell from favour and found himself out in the cold. Nicholas Wroe on the embittered genius whose first success was inspired by personal tragedy and who now hopes, as his Passion Play is revived, for a new beginning
fields.trailText: For two decades he was one of our finest playwrights. Then he fell from favour and found himself out in the cold. Nicholas Wroe on the embittered genius whose first success was inspired by personal tragedy and who now hopes, as his Passion Play is revived, for a new beginning
fields.body:
In 1981 Peter Nichols won the London Evening Standard best play of the year award for Passion Play, his ingenious and revelatory account of modern mores. It was the fourth time he had won the award - a record - and his position as one of Britain's leading playwrights was assured. But there was no lachrymose and gracious acceptance speech. Instead, Nichols chose to launch into a splenetic rant about members of the cast whose pay demands had ensured the play's short run at the RSC didn't transfer to a commercial west end theatre. How sick he was of accepting awards for plays that had already closed, he fulminated.

It sounds par for the course for a man who is easy to cast as the embittered lost genius of the London stage. Ever since the early 80s, Nichols has found it increasingly difficult to get his plays staged, and now says he doesn't read the newspapers, "not only because they might say something bad about me, but even worse, they might say something good about someone else". His last work to be seen, Blue Murder, was a play about putting on a play and was itself put on in a space called Quakers Friars above the register office in Bristol. As Nichols put it to a friend, "every year at awards ceremonies it seems that my seat gets nearer to the lavatories".

However, Passion Play is due to be restaged this month. Where Pinter fractured and reversed time in Betrayal, his study of infidelity, Nichols's radical approach to the same subject had already blazed a trail in slowing time down. To communicate to the audience the inner thoughts and motivations of the troubled married couple he used a parallel pair of actors - it was a stunning, and at the time groundbreaking, coup de thétre.

Nichols, who has never been short of friends and admirers in the industry, is hoping the Passion Play revival will spark a reassessment of his work. "He is such a theatre man," says Stephen Sondheim, who has known him for 30 years. "Peter was an actor when he started, as were so many of the best playwrights in history. He really knows the stage."

Michael Frayn is also an admirer. "I have been greatly influenced by his work. One of the wonderful things about him as a writer is that he is very dangerous. He doesn't have any of the techniques of self censorship and self preservation that other writers develop. Sometimes he says terrible things that no one else would say that absolutely strike home to one's heart, and sometimes he says things which are embarrassing. But that is part of being a dangerous writer."

The American theatre producer Hal Prince is equally impressed but thinks that Nichols has not played the game: "Maybe he has not been as pragmatic as he might have been. He is one of the best contemporary playwrights your country has produced. I wish he had previously just swallowed some of the guff and saved his generally accurate opinions for himself. There is a certain lunatic courage in how quick he is to express what he feels, and while Peter never sets out to hurt people's feelings, he has never learned not to say what he thinks."

So what is Nichols's best guess as to why, when he has been more productive than ever, only two new works have been staged in the past 13 years? "I've asked that question in private and in public and if I knew the answer I might be a happier person," he says. In 1993 he published a long poem in the Independent, "The Rime Of The Ancient Dramatist", about him accosting the then director of the National Theatre Richard Eyre and haranguing him about his neglect. "This is the fourth play of mine/ You've found your reasons to decline", etc etc.

"I suppose it just comes down to the fact that they don't like my stuff," he says. "When young playwrights ask for advice I always say 'get a friend at court'. Michael Grandage, who is directing Passion Play, is friendly to my stuff, therefore it goes on. In 1990 Richard Eyre and everyone else loved a play of mine called Euphoria that was due to go on at the National. But as soon as the director, Mike Ockrent, dropped out for a film job, the play was stranded. You have to remember that theatres are run by directors."

This theory of directorial discrimination is given added credence in that critics have been generally enthusiastic about his work. "As Edith Evans said about the Russians when people talked about Stalin's tyranny," explains Nichols, "they've always been very nice to me. But I am less concerned about my critical reputation and more with just getting the plays on. I want to see how they work with an audience."

Just how difficult this simple aim has become is starkly illustrated by Nichols's recent calculation that while 41 of his works including adaptations, films and television have been realised, there are now another 40 that have been rejected. These, all lined up in neat box files in the top floor office he has in his Belsize Park home, have a strange ongoing half life as continuing works in progress. He has turned scripts that were not filmed into novels that have not been published. Unseen novels have become plays that have not been staged. "When you think of all the wasted creativity and the wasted time it is appalling," he says.

Why Nichols fell so sharply out of vogue is a complicated tale. Undoubtedly, the transformation of the 70s generation of political playwrights into the 80s establishment played a part, and Nichols's own fractious relationship with the theatre couldn't have helped. But perhaps more importantly there was a strong perception that he had fallen into the classic trap set for successful writers. A fellow playwright says, "You can see it in David Mercer and John Osborne, and perhaps even in Harold Pinter. As you become successful you move away from your class and your subject matter. Your field of vision gets narrower and narrower and in the end your work can become arid and lack the density of earlier pieces." Nichols doesn't agree. "Alan Bennett doesn't have any trouble getting his plays on. I am an autobiographical writer. Just because I am a playwright doesn't mean I don't have a life. If I thought that was the problem don't you think I would have done something to change it?"

The writer Robert Heller has been a long-time friend and thinks Nichols has remained pretty much the same throughout the vicissitudes of his career. "He's melancholic, feels under-appreciated and has a wicked sense of humour," says Heller. "It always seemed a bit absurd to me that he thought he was in competition with other writers. The real competition is with yourself and bugger the others. But maybe he thinks that in comparison to the potential Peter Nichols, the real Peter Nichols has not done as well as he should have done. But he has done bloody well. He might not be in the O'Neill school when history looks back, but he will certainly be at the Rattigan level. And I think Rattigan is very good."

The painter Patrick Hughes is another old friend. "He seems to have made that transition from angry young man to acerbic old man without passing through the gentle uplands of middle age. But he would never be as rude to people as his friend John Osborne was. He is still hilarious, and sort of profound company. He knows things ebb and flow. Particularly in the youth culture, people get passed over and then they get revived. There are very few who are always on the inside track."

Peter Nichols was born in Bristol in 1927, the first child of Richard and Violet Nichols. He has one brother, Geoffrey, five years younger than him. When asked whether he had a happy childhood he replies, "who can say". His father was a "representative in dry saltery" for the Cooperative Society - "he hated being called a grocery salesman" - and they had a car which, in the 1920s, was "pretty classy".

"Essentially, it was a Victorian home," says Nichols. "My father was a Victorian and was non gambling, non smoking and non drinking. I think my grandfather drank and my father used to resent having to fetch his beer when a boy. If any of my plays are really autobiographical then Forget-me-not-Lane - about how we all end up like our parents - is about what tensions there were in that house. But they were extremely decent, self-sacrificing parents who paid for me and my brother to go to grammar school, and I repaid them by total laziness and indifference to learning. I never got a prize or was praised in any way for writing while there."

Nichols said he didn't know what university was when he left school. "I couldn't care less. I wanted to go to Hollywood. I was completely stage-struck. The highlights of my year were the Christmas pantomime and the summer circus. In between I would play with my toy circus and toy pantomime. And I'd go to the cinema and occasionally the theatre and variety shows."

His route in to this theatrical world was unexpected. He was conscripted into the Royal Air Force just as the war was ending. After being turned down by the entertainment corps in India he was accepted in Singapore. "And that's when my education really began." He was in the same troupe as Kenneth Williams, Stanley Baxter and John Schlesinger, who was a conjurer at the time. The experience was turned into his 1977 hit musical and film Privates On Parade, and was strangely echoed later in the sit-com It Ain't Half Hot Mum.

More immediately, it provided a launch pad into the world of legit theatre. When demobbed in 1951 he enrolled at the Bristol Old Vic theatre school and two years later began life as a professional actor. He says he did some pretty good work but didn't get enough jobs. His biggest success was playing Count Dracula in fortnightly rep in Edinburgh, Glasgow and Aberdeen. "My favourite notice said, 'Count Dracula is no longer so fearsome'. But I knew in my heart that acting wasn't the right thing for me."

His father had given him £500, which he spent trying to be an actor and writer. He wrote some plays but didn't submit them because he didn't feel they were good enough. Friends advised him to become a teacher because the long holidays would give him time to write. He got a place in a teacher training college in Hertfordshire and in 1959 made two ambitious new year resolutions; that he would get a play performed and that he would get married. At the time he had no girlfriend and no play.

The play issue was solved when he won a BBC playwriting competition - despite never having seen a television play - for Walk On The Grass, a family comedy. Soon after, Granada screened a second work, Promenade, about a group of young people on a weekend in Brighton. The wife issue was solved after his lung collapsed and he was hospitalised in Bristol. He received a letter from a childhood friend, Thelma Reed, who was also a teacher. She visited him and a few months later, on December 28 1959, they were married.

"I was in hospital when the second television play went on. Granada said they would give me a monitor to watch it in a private ward but the matron wouldn't allow that so I had to see it on a ward television set. Unfortunately there was a cup final on the other station and so I forced everyone to watch this incredibly arty play, which was described as 'pastel-coloured Fellini', so it was a bit awkward."

With his career now taking off they both gave up teaching and moved to Devon. Their first daughter, Abigail, was born soon afterwards. The Nichols had three further children in the next five years. Their daughter Louise is an IT coordinator at a primary school in London, Daniel works with redundant coal miners in South Wales and has written a musical which is being staged in Cardiff shortly, and Catherine is a solicitor in Darlington. They have five grandchildren.

Abigail was born severely brain-damaged and went into hospital on a full-time basis when she was three. She died aged 10. Had they anticipated such a short life expectancy? "Well, we always hoped so. There was nothing we could do for her. Abigail went into hospital just after our third child was born and stayed there the rest of her life. She was always physically very beautiful. She had lovely eyes and her features were very fine. I used to say why me? Why us? But then I thought, why not us?"

Nichols was finding it increasingly difficult to earn a living as a television playwright. Fellow playwright and old Bristol friend Charles Wood lent the couple money, as did Nichols's agent, Peggy Ramsey. "It was all getting a bit of a struggle and then John Boorman, who was working in the features section in BBC Bristol, asked me if I'd like to write this caper film like A Hard Day's Night for the pop band the Dave Clark 5. I said not really, because it looked pretty much like rubbish. 'What would we get out of it?' I asked. John said he would get a Hollywood contract and I'd get the money to write my stage play. And he was right."

The result was A Day In The Death Of Joe Egg, a tragi-comedy about a couple with a severely handicapped child. Michael Blakemore directed it at the Citizens' Theatre in Glasgow after it had been turned down by all the London west end managers. "Peter and I had been very good friends," says Blakemore. "The Nichols stayed at our flat when they were in London and they were with us when the doctor told them how severe Abigail's brain damage was. It was almost a resignation issue for me when it became very contentious with the theatre board. A lot of people thought it was sick comedy but it was a study in how people cope with this kind of disaster. The Nichols coped through humour. It was an awful time for them and it is, of course, the great irony of his life that this catastrophe was the thing that made his name and his fortune."

Nichols says that the money from Joe Egg stopped being, "anything to write home about 10 years ago. But luckily, when we were doing well, my accountant suggested a pension. Three years after they moved to Shropshire, John Osborne became a neighbour and, almost inevitably, the two had a row just before Nichols moved back to London. "But as Mark Twain said when receiving the Légion d'honneur, with John 'that is an honour few escape'." The argument was over who would pay a wine bill. The next day Osborne sent his gardener to Nichols with a note, "full of invective and in which the word 'commonness' was used". The two didn't speak again before Osborne died.

"I was very fond of John, and we have made peace with his wife Helen now," says Nichols. He moved back to London, he says, because "I just got fed up looking at sheep and decided I was a city person. Born: July 31 1927, Bristol.

Married: 1959 Thelma Reed (one son, three daughters, Abigail deceased).

Education: Bristol Grammar School; Bristol Old Vic theatre school 1951-53; Trent Park Teachers College 1958-60.

Occupations: Royal Air Force 1945-49; actor 1953-58; teacher 1958-60.

Some television plays: Walk On The Grass 1959; Promenade 1960; Hearts and Flowers 1970.

Some films: Catch Us If You Can 1965; Georgy Girl 1967; Joe Egg 1971; Privates on Parade1983.

fields.bodyText: In 1981 Peter Nichols won the London Evening Standard best play of the year award for Passion Play, his ingenious and revelatory account of modern mores. It was the fourth time he had won the award - a record - and his position as one of Britain's leading playwrights was assured. But there was no lachrymose and gracious acceptance speech. Instead, Nichols chose to launch into a splenetic rant about members of the cast whose pay demands had ensured the play's short run at the RSC didn't transfer to a commercial west end theatre. How sick he was of accepting awards for plays that had already closed, he fulminated. It sounds par for the course for a man who is easy to cast as the embittered lost genius of the London stage. Ever since the early 80s, Nichols has found it increasingly difficult to get his plays staged, and now says he doesn't read the newspapers, "not only because they might say something bad about me, but even worse, they might say something good about someone else". His last work to be seen, Blue Murder, was a play about putting on a play and was itself put on in a space called Quakers Friars above the register office in Bristol. As Nichols put it to a friend, "every year at awards ceremonies it seems that my seat gets nearer to the lavatories". However, Passion Play is due to be restaged this month. Where Pinter fractured and reversed time in Betrayal, his study of infidelity, Nichols's radical approach to the same subject had already blazed a trail in slowing time down. To communicate to the audience the inner thoughts and motivations of the troubled married couple he used a parallel pair of actors - it was a stunning, and at the time groundbreaking, coup de thétre. Nichols, who has never been short of friends and admirers in the industry, is hoping the Passion Play revival will spark a reassessment of his work. "He is such a theatre man," says Stephen Sondheim, who has known him for 30 years. "Peter was an actor when he started, as were so many of the best playwrights in history. He really knows the stage." Michael Frayn is also an admirer. "I have been greatly influenced by his work. One of the wonderful things about him as a writer is that he is very dangerous. He doesn't have any of the techniques of self censorship and self preservation that other writers develop. Sometimes he says terrible things that no one else would say that absolutely strike home to one's heart, and sometimes he says things which are embarrassing. But that is part of being a dangerous writer." The American theatre producer Hal Prince is equally impressed but thinks that Nichols has not played the game: "Maybe he has not been as pragmatic as he might have been. He is one of the best contemporary playwrights your country has produced. I wish he had previously just swallowed some of the guff and saved his generally accurate opinions for himself. There is a certain lunatic courage in how quick he is to express what he feels, and while Peter never sets out to hurt people's feelings, he has never learned not to say what he thinks." So what is Nichols's best guess as to why, when he has been more productive than ever, only two new works have been staged in the past 13 years? "I've asked that question in private and in public and if I knew the answer I might be a happier person," he says. In 1993 he published a long poem in the Independent, "The Rime Of The Ancient Dramatist", about him accosting the then director of the National Theatre Richard Eyre and haranguing him about his neglect. "This is the fourth play of mine/ You've found your reasons to decline", etc etc. "I suppose it just comes down to the fact that they don't like my stuff," he says. "When young playwrights ask for advice I always say 'get a friend at court'. Michael Grandage, who is directing Passion Play, is friendly to my stuff, therefore it goes on. In 1990 Richard Eyre and everyone else loved a play of mine called Euphoria that was due to go on at the National. But as soon as the director, Mike Ockrent, dropped out for a film job, the play was stranded. You have to remember that theatres are run by directors." This theory of directorial discrimination is given added credence in that critics have been generally enthusiastic about his work. "As Edith Evans said about the Russians when people talked about Stalin's tyranny," explains Nichols, "they've always been very nice to me. But I am less concerned about my critical reputation and more with just getting the plays on. I want to see how they work with an audience." Just how difficult this simple aim has become is starkly illustrated by Nichols's recent calculation that while 41 of his works including adaptations, films and television have been realised, there are now another 40 that have been rejected. These, all lined up in neat box files in the top floor office he has in his Belsize Park home, have a strange ongoing half life as continuing works in progress. He has turned scripts that were not filmed into novels that have not been published. Unseen novels have become plays that have not been staged. "When you think of all the wasted creativity and the wasted time it is appalling," he says. Why Nichols fell so sharply out of vogue is a complicated tale. Undoubtedly, the transformation of the 70s generation of political playwrights into the 80s establishment played a part, and Nichols's own fractious relationship with the theatre couldn't have helped. But perhaps more importantly there was a strong perception that he had fallen into the classic trap set for successful writers. A fellow playwright says, "You can see it in David Mercer and John Osborne, and perhaps even in Harold Pinter. As you become successful you move away from your class and your subject matter. Your field of vision gets narrower and narrower and in the end your work can become arid and lack the density of earlier pieces." Nichols doesn't agree. "Alan Bennett doesn't have any trouble getting his plays on. I am an autobiographical writer. Just because I am a playwright doesn't mean I don't have a life. If I thought that was the problem don't you think I would have done something to change it?" "He's melancholic, feels under-appreciated and has a wicked sense of humour," says Heller. "It always seemed a bit absurd to me that he thought he was in competition with other writers. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Germany bans soccer thugs | Krajisnik denies war crimes | Protest clashes in Kashmir
fields.body:
Germany bans soccer thugs
Germany's upper house of parliament, the Bundesrat, yesterday passed a law to ban known German soccer hooligans from travelling to this summer's Euro 2000 tournament in Belgium and the Netherlands. Four German hooligans were sentenced to jail terms last November for beating a French policeman almost to death during the 1998 World Cup finals.
Reuters, Berlin

Krajisnik denies war crimes

Momcilo Krajisnik, right-hand man to the Bosnian Serb wartime leader Radovan Karadzic, yesterday pleaded not guilty to war crimes charges.

Speaker of the Bosnian Serb parliament during the 1992-95 war, Mr Krajisnik, 55, is charged with genocide, complicity in genocide, crimes against humanity, violations of laws or customs of war, and grave breaches of the Geneva conventions.
Reuters, the Hague

Protest clashes in Kashmir

More than 2,000 people clashed with police in the Indian state of Kashmir yesterday during a protest against the shooting of eight people earlier this week at a demonstration over the killing of five Muslim youths. Witnesses said police fired tear gas shells to disperse the crowd in Srinagar.
Reuters, Srinagar

Russia calls for release of ship

Russia's foreign ministry yesterday demanded the release of a Russian oil tanker being held in the Gulf by the US navy pending analysis of oil samples, officials said.

The Akademik Pustovoit was boarded on Wednesday, said Commander Jeff Gradeck, a spokesman for the US 5th fleet. He declined to speculate on whether the ship was suspected of carrying Iraqi oil in violation of UN sanctions.
AP, Manama

MP sparks 'third sex' row

A Brazilian MP's campaign to make a third set of toilets for gays, lesbians and transvestites compulsory in Brasilia's bars and clubs sparked outrage this week from gay rights groups, which claim the concept violates civil rights.

"This type of project paints homosexuals to be a third sex," said Claudio Nascimento of the Brazilian Gay, Lesbian and Transvestite Organisation.
Reuters, Brasilia

Female Sherpas to climb Everest

The first all-female Sherpa team will leave Katmandu tomorrow in an attempt to scale Mount Everest. The five women are trying to break the domination of male Nepalese mountaineers. Sherpa women have been limited to cooking, cleaning and carrying equipment to lower camps. In 1993 a female Sherpa, Pasang Lhamhu, climbed the peak with a male team, and died on the descent.
AP, Katmandu

webTitle: Impatience tempts volcano refugees into danger

fields.headline: Impatience tempts volcano refugees into danger
fields.standfirst: Japanese evade roadblocks to tend crops and recover valuables
fields.trailText: Refugees from the Mount Usu volcano are slipping into the police-guarded exclusion zone as they begin to doubt expert forecasts of a devastating new eruption.
fields.body:
Refugees from the Mount Usu volcano are slipping into the police-guarded exclusion zone as they begin to doubt expert forecasts of a devastating new eruption.

A week after the relatively minor release of gas and ash last week, the town of Date, three miles from the volcano, resembles a scene from a Godzilla film: television helicopters constantly buzz overhead, military vehicles line the side streets, and thousands of refugees huddle in evacuation centres.

But the new peak that vulcanologists say will soon rise out of the ground in a devastating explosion of molten rock and superheated gas has still to appear, and it is increasingly disputed whether it ever will.

Refugees who fled in terror a week ago are starting to sneak past the police blockades into the danger zone to check their houses, feed their pets and tend their crops.

"It's easy to understand why they return," said Takamachi Kimura, one of the 500 people bedding down in the giant hall of Date's culture centre. "We're fed up with waiting. Nobody knows if this situation will last a month, half a year, or for ever."

Yesterday the volcano was quiet, puffing just the occasional milky white cloud into the otherwise clear blue sky. Approaching its most distant slopes, the only signs of activity were the pungent smell of sulphur dioxide and a layer of brown-grey ash on nearby trees and fields.

It is a far cry from last week, when violent earthquakes rattled homes twice an hour in a terrifying prelude to the eruption on Friday, which sent a plume of gas and ash almost two miles into the air.

But even that failed to impress many refugees, who remember the last eruption in 1978, when Mt Usu belched smoke six miles into the sky and three people were killed.

Residents of Date, Abuta and Sobetsu, the towns that ring the mountain, are arguably more used to such disasters than anyone in Japan, a country with 86 active volcanoes.

The earth in this part of the world is rarely still. Mt Usu blows its top every few decades, throwing up new peaks, such as the 400-metre (1,300ft) Showa Shinzen, which suddenly became a neighbour of Date city in 1942 and 1943.

Rather than inspiring terror, the frequency of volcanic activity seems to have bred familiarity and, in some cases, complacency. Even in Japan, where land is at a premium, there is amazement that the Koya hot spring resort in Abuta was built on an area overlapping Mt Usu's northern slopes.

But the resort owes its existence to a huge eruption in 1910, which opened a channel to a source of hot underground water for the onsen (spas) which attract hundreds of thousands of tourists each year.

What the volcano created it is now taking away. Craters have appeared on the edge of the town and cracks up to 30ft wide have swallowed houses.

Although the tremors have more or less stopped, measurements taken by satellite indicate that the expansion and contraction of the earth is accelerating.

According to Mitsuhiro Nakagawa, a professor at Hokkaido University, these are signs that an underground lava dome will push its way to the surface within the next two weeks.

He said there was a strong danger that such an eruption would produce pyroclastic flows of molten rock, which travel at speeds of more than 60mph, incinerating every thing in their paths. "It is very similar to what happened during the eruption of 1910," he said. "You have to know your history."

Residents are more concerned about economics. Far mers are frustrated at being away from their fields in their most important season. According to one agricultural cooperative, 30%of the crops in the exclusion zone are already ruined and this will rise to 70% by next week. Farmers and fishermen have petitioned the authorities to lift the entry ban.

With the mountain now apparently docile, refugees say they are tempted to return home to pick up valuables - nobody is insured against volcano damage - and bedding to make life more comfortable in the evacuation centres.

"I just want me and the kids to be able to sleep on a proper futon," said Hiroko Ishi, a mother of three, who only had time to grab nappies for her baby when she was evacuated. The family now occupy the space of a few blankets on the hard floor of a gymnasium.

"I'm exhausted, especially mentally. Not knowing how long this will last is extremely stressful."

For the moment, most still accept the validity of the official warnings, not least because they remember the last eruption, when lava stones the size of pingpong balls rained down on Date.

But as the boredom and tension of waiting increase, the most common prayer is for Mt Usu to make up its mind.

"I just wish the volcano would get on with it: either destroy my house or let me go back," said Ken Homata, who works in a hot-spring hotel. "The volcano created our business, but now it just seems to be playing with our existence."

fields.headline: German agents 'helped Moscow'
fields.trailText: German intelligence agents gathered information for Moscow on Chechen guerrillas suspected of being behind a series of bomb attacks on Russian cities last year, a German television station said yesterday.
fields.body:
German intelligence agents gathered information for Moscow on Chechen guerrillas suspected of being behind a series of bomb attacks on Russian cities last year, a German television station said yesterday.

ARD said that German agents provided Moscow with intelligence, primarily on the international links of rebels thought to be responsible for the bombings, which the Russian authorities used to justify the war in Chechnya.

The channel carried an interview with Ernst Uhrlau, the secret service coordinator of the German government, in which he confirmed that Germany was among the countries who had been asked by Moscow to help track down the bombers.

"Three hundred people were killed in those attacks last autumn," Mr Uhrlau told the station.

"A request was made at that point to the Federal Republic, and to other states, to help with intelligence."

ARD said that the head of Germany's foreign intelligence agency, August Hanning, had recently made a trip to Moscow to report on the findings of his agents.

"Anything which indirectly supported or helped launch the war in Chechnya would demand absolute condemnation," Christian Stroebele, a member of parliament for the Greens, told the television station.

webTitle: South African cricket captain accused of match fixing

fields.headline: South African cricket captain accused of match fixing
fields.standfirst: Hansie Cronje accused of match fixing
fields.trailText: South Africa's highly respected cricket captain, Hansie Cronje, was last night accused of match fixing by police in India. Investigators in New Delhi played part of what they said was a taped phone conversation between Cronje and two Indian businessmen. They also released a transcript.
fields.body:
South Africa's highly respected cricket captain, Hansie Cronje, was last night accused of match fixing by police in India. Investigators in New Delhi played part of what they said was a taped phone conversation between Cronje and two Indian businessmen. They also released a transcript.

Also mentioned in the conversation were three other members of the South African side: Herschelle Gibbs, Nicky Boje and Pieter Strydom.

The allegations were vehemently denied by the United Cricket Board of South Africa and Cronje, who has presided over his team's emergence as a formidable cricketing nation. He said last night: "I am stunned. The allegations are com pletely without substance. I have been privileged to play for South Africa since 1992 and I want to assure every South African that I have made a 100% effort to win every match that I have played. It has been an honour to play for South Africa and I would never do anything to let my country down."

A statement released by Ali Bacher, managing director of the South African cricket board, said that the board was convinced the accusations were unfounded, and added: "South African captain Hansie Cronje is a man of enormous integrity and honesty. He and his teammates Nicky Boje, Herschelle Gibbs and Pieter Strydom are emphatic that there is no substance to [the] allegations.

Indian police have registered charges of criminal conspiracy against all four in connection with five one-day matches played during the South Africans' tour of India from March 9-19. India won the series 3-2.

Rajesh Kalra, a wealthy Delhi businessman, has been arrested and remanded in custody, while another businessman, Sanjiv Chawla (also known as Sanjay Chawla), is wanted by police. Some reports in India say he may be in London.

Mr Kalra was arrested in a dawn raid at his home in south Delhi and is to face further questioning today.

Police in the Indian capital said that a tip-off led them to begin taping phone calls made to and by Cronje.

The investigators allege that some of the conversations took place with a caller phoning from abroad ,while others took place in New Delhi.

The South African team stayed at the Taj Palace hotel in New Delhi and it is alleged that Cronje was taped revealing which cricketers would be playing and also making references to payments. The police say that they have 12 tapes in total.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: We very much regret confusing the personal details of the two Leeds United fans killed in Istanbul in our front page story in yesterday's paper. The report should have said that Kevin Speight was landlord of the Bay Horse Inn at Farsley, Leeds, and leaves a wife and two children. The other victim, Christopher Loftus, was a fibre optics engineer and lived with his parents in Burmantofts, Leeds. We wish to apologise to both families.
fields.body:

The report should have said that Kevin Speight was landlord of the Bay Horse Inn at Farsley, Leeds, and leaves a wife and two children. The other victim, Christopher Loftus, was a fibre optics engineer and lived with his parents in Burmantofts, Leeds. We wish to apologise to both families.

In a letter about a planned Royal Society debate on the origins of HIV (No shirking HIV debate, page 25, April 1), doctors Beatrice Hahn and Bette Korber were described by the writer as "leading opponents of the 'cut hunter' theory of origin". In fact, Hahn and Korber's position is supportive of this theory, in that they oppose the notion that the HIV virus sprang from the polio vaccine.

The TV review in yesterday's paper, page 18, G2, was by Matthew Baylis, not Jamie McCallum as the byline wrongly stated.

Weston-super-Mare appeared wrongly, twice, as Western-super-Mare in an article about the titles chosen by peers on page 6, G2, April 4.

The classic Brit awards will take place in the Royal Albert Hall, London, on May 6. An incorrect date was given on page 6, in the music section of the Friday review, yesterday.

webTitle: Highlight Historic tunnel's reopening is climax of £24m programme

fields.headline: Highlight Historic tunnel's reopening is climax of £24m programme
fields.trailText: British Waterways' £24m winter refurbishment programme for Britain's 2,000-mile canal network reaches a historic stage this weekend with reopening of the Islington Tunnel on the Regent's Canal in north London.
fields.body:
British Waterways' £24m winter refurbishment programme for Britain's 2,000-mile canal network reaches a historic stage this weekend with reopening of the Islington Tunnel on the Regent's Canal in north London.

Barhale Construction used a specially designed pontoon (pictured) to provide access to brickwork in the tunnel, which was built in 1820. The pontoon was moved 13 times to cover the tunnel's 875 metre length.

Because of the historic nature of the grade 2 listed structure, the tunnel was lined with new bricks, which had been matched in colour to the originals, rather than receiving the standard repair treatment of sprayed concrete.

The £400,000 work on the tunnel is part of the biggest canal repair programme in BW's history. The government increased the canal repairs budget in February.

More than £12m has been allocated to safety-related work but British Waterways admits that will make a relatively small impact on an £83m backlog of such work.

webTitle: Byers blueprint is hard to credit

fields.headline: Byers blueprint is hard to credit
fields.standfirst: Insolvency reforms attacked
fields.trailText: Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers's recent run of bad luck appeared to continue yesterday when he announced proposals for six-month "quickie" bankruptcies.
fields.body:
Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers's recent run of bad luck appeared to continue yesterday when he announced proposals for six-month "quickie" bankruptcies.

Mr Byers - in common with his predecessor Peter Mandelson - believes permissive bankruptcy laws are one of the pillars of the entrepreneurial miracle in turn of the century America, allowing determined risk-takers to shrug off mistakes and return to the fray, older, wiser and raring to go.

But data yesterday from the insolvency profession suggested Britain's rising trend of personal insolvency has less to do with risk-taking and dynamism than the Department of Trade and Industry imagines, and more to do with reckless, feckless borrowing.

The Association of Business Recovery Professionals - R3, as the repo men style themselves - found 37% of bankruptcies are triggered by consumer debts, up from about 20% 10 years ago, and a fifth of that 37% is related to straightforward credit card debt.

Mr Byers's blueprint allows the courts to discriminate between honest bankrupts, eligible for discharge after six months, and dishonest ones, facing up to 15 years as an undischarged bankrupt, five times the present maximum.

But consumer borrowers may not be dishonest, simply irresponsible. For them, the quickie bankruptcy is, according to R3's Andrew Smith, simply a "get out of jail free card".

Mr Mandelson set Britain on the road to a US-style permissive Chapter 13 bankruptcy regime at the end of 1998, saying the stigma of personal insolvency deterred commercial risk-taking and was one of the factors holding back British economic growth.

Yesterday's proposals have three main features:

 A distinction between honest and dishonest bankrupts.

 An exemption on personal homes for those who have put their own money into a failed business. Up to £20,000 there will be pound-for-pound protection, allowing the bankrupt to retain equity in the home.

 A post-bankruptcy arrangement under which the insolvent person would continue to make payments to creditors. It is not clear whether this would be a condition of the six-month discharge. If it is not, there is no obvious incentive for the bankrupt to agree to such an arrangement.

Mr Byers said: "We must change attitudes. Most businesses fail because of bad luck or a lack of cash. But for too long such people have been tarred with the same brush as the reckless minority whose companies collapse because of fraudulent activity."

The DTI has found fewer than 2% of business failures are attributable to fraud.

But R3 worries that by concentrating on the need to reactivate insolvent entrepreneurs the DTI may be looking through the wrong end of the telescope. Some would-be business folk ought to be stripped of their entrepre neurial illusions as early as possible, according to Mr Smith. "There are people who cannot manage a business."

The £20,000 home-equity exemption also worries him, because 78% of bankrupts have assets of less than £20,000, meaning shielding the bankrupt from creditors will help make those creditors, in turn, bankrupts.

The banks are likely to increase the cost of credit to cover the risks. It is, said R3, "very badly thought through".

The DTI is likely to learn that Britain can have a permissive lending regime or a permissive bankruptcy regime but not both.

Some would-be business folk ought to be stripped of their entrepre neurial illusions as early as possible, according to Mr Smith. "There are people who cannot manage a business." The £20,000 home-equity exemption also worries him, because 78% of bankrupts have assets of less than £20,000, meaning shielding the bankrupt from creditors will help make those creditors, in turn, bankrupts. The banks are likely to increase the cost of credit to cover the risks. It is, said R3, "very badly thought through". The DTI is likely to learn that Britain can have a permissive lending regime or a permissive bankruptcy regime but not both.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Hi-tech fever returned to the London markets with a vengeance, leading to a near 6% jump on the Techmark 100 index and putting the FTSE 100 blue-chip indicator just about back where it was at the beginning of the week.
fields.body:
Hi-tech fever returned to the London markets with a vengeance, leading to a near 6% jump on the Techmark 100 index and putting the FTSE 100 blue-chip indicator just about back where it was at the beginning of the week.

Private investors streamed back into the market, leading to some extraordinary gains in new economy favourites such as Freeserve, up from 423p to 606p, Baltimore Technology, rallying from £75.83 to £85.63, and Geo Interactive, 277p firmer at £19.77.

A little over a month ago, of course, Freeserve was sitting close to £10 and Baltimore has come down from a recent high of £137, while Geo stood at £35 four weeks ago.

The overall mood yesterday was helped by some benign jobs data from the United States, enabling the Footsie to close 118.8 points higher on the day at 6,569.9.

The telecoms sector again played a substantial role pushing the top 100 higher, with heavyweight Vodafone AirTouch up 11p at 355p and BT advancing 27p to £11.27.

Other notable tech gainers included Psion, which recovered 648p to £43.52, and Netbenefit, which jumped from £10.12 to £13. Business software group Kewill Systems surged from £15.09 to £20 as investment banker Warburg Dillon Read reissued a "strong buy" recommendation on the stock. But back in March the stock was trading above £30.

Recruitment consultancy Northern Recruitment crashed 31p to 50p after the company warned that profits would be "substantially" below last year's level - and the finance director, Howard Woolgar, has resigned.

Of yesterday's crop of new issues, Getmapping.com, in which the Queen has a stake, added 5p to 225p, incubator Brainspark closed at 130p against a 125p sale price and Quadranet, spun off from restaurant firm BGR , moved from 26p to 29p.

Meanwhile there was further evidence that even when its computers are working, the stock exchange's order driven trading system can still throw out funny numbers. At the close of play Tarmac was showing a fall of 150p to 435p, but dealers indicated there had been so little trade in the stock that a "rogue" closing price had been created. All other things being equal, the price should bounce back to around 580p on Monday morning.

fields.headline: Rising above the turbulence
fields.trailText: The first scheduled flight by the company which was to become British Airways started with a single-engined DeHavilland biplane carrying one passenger and a cargo of newspapers, Devonshire cream and grouse from London to Paris. The journey took two and a half hours.
fields.body:
The first scheduled flight by the company which was to become British Airways started with a single-engined DeHavilland biplane carrying one passenger and a cargo of newspapers, Devonshire cream and grouse from London to Paris. The journey took two and a half hours.

The company, Aircraft Transport and Travel, was founded by press baron George Holt Thomas towards the end of the first world war.

Just before the war, Holt Thomas, owner of the Daily Graphic, had set up an aircraft production business and taken on Geoffrey de Havilland, the aircraft designer.

He was convinced that there was a future for commercial aviation and even before the war ended, he had campaigned for rules to regulate international flights. AT&T's first scheduled flight, on August 25, 1919, was the first tangible result.

But the public, aware of the high death rate among wartime pilots and the fragility of their planes, were reluctant to embark on long journeys in the air. Planes were still unreliable. One London to Paris flight took two days with the pilot forced to land 33 times en route.

Aviation pioneers struggled, and AT&T eventually went bust, only to rise again as Daimler Airway. But by 1924, the country's four leading airlines, including Daimler and arch rival Handley Page, were forced to merge in the face of subsidised competition from France and Holland. The result was Imperial Airways.

Between the wars, Imperial's planes, except for its luxurious flying boats, flew mainly from the new London airport at Croydon. Its services, initially to continental Europe, were extended during the 1920s and 1930s as far as Egypt, India, South Africa, Singapore, West Africa and Australia.

Its main competitor was a group of smaller air transport companies which had merged and were operating out of Gatwick. In 1939 the government nationalised both groups under a new name, British Overseas Airways Corporation. By the time BOAC was formally incorporated, war had broken out and its planes came under government control.

All its available planes were pressed into service to airlift food and ammunition to troops in France following the fall of Holland, Belgium and Luxembourg. They were also used to evacuate people from the Channel Islands. By 1941 BOAC planes were bringing in urgently needed ball bearings from Sweden. Besieged Malta benefited from night-time supply runs. The war also saw the introduction of BOAC stewardesses. The company estimated that by the end of the war its planes had flown 57m miles, carried 280,000 passengers and more than 23,000 tons of cargo.

One post war legacy was the delivery of Lancaster bombers originally built for the RAF but converted for civil use.

The company ushered in the age of the passenger jet aircraft when it introduced the British-built Comet to its South Africa run in 1952 and later to its transatlantic service. But it suffered a severe setback when its Comets were grounded after two crashed in 1954. Extensive testing showed metal fatigue to be the cause of the crashes.

BOAC merged with British European Airways, and the combined business was named British Airways in 1974. Although beset with financial and industrial problems, BA, together with Air France, launched the first supersonic passenger service in 1976 with Concorde.

The government decided in 1979 to be rid of BA and its problems. It brought in Lord King to return the company to profit and eventual privatisation in 1987.

BA has fought to maintain its image as the nation's flag carrier. But an attempt to emphasise its global role by replacing its distinctive tailplane decoration with artwork from around the world - at a cost of £64m - backfired badly.

That, together with a poor commercial performance, led to the ousting earlier this year of chief executive Bob Ayling. His successor is expected to be appointed shortly. He will find the intensity of competition little changed from the company's early days.

webTitle: That was the week that was

fields.headline: That was the week that was
fields.trailText: Where to begin? A week of high drama and low farce, punctuated by the occasional burst of light comedy. I defy anyone who lived through these five days in the markets to deny that truth is indeed far stranger than fiction.
fields.body:
Where to begin? A week of high drama and low farce, punctuated by the occasional burst of light comedy. I defy anyone who lived through these five days in the markets to deny that truth is indeed far stranger than fiction.

On the global stage Microsoft's Bill Gates plays the part of Macbeth - reviled, feared and, let's be honest, respected in equal measure. It is not yet certain, however, that his corporation will be torn apart in its battle with the US competition authorities.

Mr Gates this week refused to blink in compromise talks intended to resolve the legal dispute about Microsoft's alleged abuse of its dominant position in the desktop software market. It is now down to the US courts to devise a solution to the problem. At the extreme this could involve the enforced break-up of the world's most valuable company. Or rather, the world's most valuable company at the start of the week. A plunge in Microsoft shares triggered by the breakdown of talks relegated Microsoft to second place behind General Electric. The reaction of investors in technology shares in general was blind panic. At its worst on Tuesday the Nasdaq index plunged 14%, accelerating its slide of recent weeks.

On reflection it was both premature for Linux lovers to hail the demise of their bogeyman and plain daft to translate Microsoft's troubles into negative sentiment towards tech stocks as a whole.

Legal filibustering will drag Microsoft's case through the presidential election cycle and beyond - possibly into a more favourable Republican administration. On the other hand, even if it is stuck with savage punishments this is hardly going to derail the technology revolution - Microsoft is just one counter on the global stock exchange.

Investors in Britain logged on to their PCs with some trepidation on Wednesday morning, fearful of the reaction of the market - and tech stocks in particular - to Nasdaq's overnight queasiness. At 3.30pm they were still waiting to begin trading.

As if to prove that technology is not all for the best, the London stock exchange had suffered the most complete system failure in its post-big bang history - and on the last day of the tax year.

Down at the Golden Fleece traders sunk their umpteenth pint and waited for their mobile phones to ring to call them to their work stations. Speculation was rife that the eco-warriors had succeeded in crippling the financial system with a deft bit of industrial sabotage.

The truth was more prosaic, a simple cock-up that took hours to rectify, prompting a witch-hunt for the culprits and calls for compensation from investors and brokers alike. The stock exchange points a finger of blame vaguely in the direction of Anderson Consulting, which runs the system. Anderson declined to comment. The regulators and parliament demanded an inquiry.

Wednesday's events certainly will not have strengthened the exchange's hand in its merger discussions with the Frankfurt exchange, but they are not grounds for scrapping the London trading platform or for heads to roll in a grand but empty ritualistic gesture.

Let's face it, computer systems fail. The test for their managers is whether they are smart enough to learn the lessons involved. As for light relief - just hark at those broking fossils demanding a return to a trading floor. Volunteers to play the Ugly Sisters, anyone?

There were resounding cheers on two City trading floors on Wednesday afternoon - those of German-owned rivals Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Kleinwort Benson. The two parent banks had just called off their merger after a highly publicised spat over the future of DKB. To sell or to close, that was the divisive question.

There were more than two sides to this argument. Dresdner the parent favoured a merger of the two investment banks - effectively a closure of DKB with massive job losses. This was all about "face" in Frankfurt. DKB's staff, needless to say, preferred a sale to a third party.

At Deutsche, head office favoured a sale. Its investment bankers were pretty ambivalent - they knew the boot was on their foot and the "kick me" sign was pinned to the trousers of their DKB rivals.

In the event Dresdner called off the merger and a day later its chairman, Bernhard Walter, did the decent thing and resigned. He had advocated the deal, underestimating the colossal arrogance of Deutsche that, frankly, many could have warned him of. The outcome has been to weaken Dresdner severely, DKB in particular, and Deutsche somewhat.

Thoughts on a role for Walter? The Fool, perhaps.

 Edmond Warner is chief executive of Albert E Sharp Securities

webTitle: Family cuts last tie to Thomson board

fields.headline: Family cuts last tie to Thomson board
fields.trailText: The grandson of the Canadian millionaire who founded Thomson Travel has resigned from the company's board, just days after a hostile £1.3bn bid approach from a German rival, C&N Touristic.
fields.body:
The grandson of the Canadian millionaire who founded Thomson Travel has resigned from the company's board, just days after a hostile £1.3bn bid approach from a German rival, C&N Touristic.

Standing down as a non-executive director, David Thomson insisted that his family was "totally supportive of the company and the steps the new management have taken to grow the value of the business".

Through Woodbridge International, the Thomson family has a 19% stake in the package holidays group.

Woodbridge has said that it is opposed to C&N's 130p-a-share proposed offer.

It is understood that Mr Thompson's departure was designed to avert any possible conflict of interest if the bid overtures become a definite offer.

A Thomson Travel spokesman said: "It puts them at arm's length. It was thought useful to clarify the situation."

The change means there is no family representation on Thomson's board for the first time in its 25-year history.

The business was established by Lord Thomson of Fleet, a Toronto-born businessman who moved to Britain and built up the Thomson Newspapers empire.

During the 1960s, the Thomson media conglomerate included the Times, the Sunday Times, Scotsman and several regional publications.

Lord Thomson diversified into holidays by buying three businesses - Universal Sky Tours, Britannia Airways and Riviera Holidays.

The family kept control of Thomson Travel until the company floated in 1998.

However, since that time the value of the Thomson family's stake in the business has fallen by £60m to £260m due to a series of profits setbacks.

On Thursday Thomson Travel refused an invitation to meet C&N Touristic, a joint venture between Lufthansa airline and retailer Karstadt Quelle. The German firm said it might raise its offer if a friendly deal could be agreed.

webTitle: Double your bonus for staying, says grateful Dresdner

fields.headline: Double your bonus for staying, says grateful Dresdner
fields.trailText: Delighted staff at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson expect lucrative "golden handcuffs" next week as the bank acts to stem a tide of departures. Sporting T-shirts bearing the slogan "I've not been torched" yesterday, Kleinwort's 3,500 investment bankers in the City could be in line for lock-ins worth twice their already hefty bonuses.
fields.body:
Delighted staff at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson expect lucrative "golden handcuffs" next week as the bank acts to stem a tide of departures. Sporting T-shirts bearing the slogan "I've not been torched" yesterday, Kleinwort's 3,500 investment bankers in the City could be in line for lock-ins worth twice their already hefty bonuses.

Most of them had expected to lose their highly paid jobs as a result of the merger between their parent company, Dresdner Bank of Germany, and its rival Deutsche Bank. But they have been given a brief respite by the collapse of the record-breaking deal this week amid bitter recriminations.

"We continue to be green," one said yesterday in a reference to the colour of the bank's logo.

Senior executives are expected to spend the weekend hastily constructing the latest pay deals. It will be the second such round of offers in a month - the first, arranged when the merger was announced in March, failed to prevent the departure of 100 staff including a number of highly regarded bankers.

Kleinwort refused to commment officially yesterday but rivals believe the bank needs to act quickly if it is prevent complete destruction of the business through a mass defection of staff to rivals.

Top executives at Kleinwort are expected to meet their German owners this weekend to try to end the uncertainty. As well as cementing terms of the emergency pay deals, the parties might try to arrange a way for staff to take a stake in the business, senior bankers suggested.

Bernhard Walter - the Dresdner chairman who has fallen on his sword and will leave at the end of the month - moved yesterday to play down speculation that the bank was already in talks with another suitor.

"Whoever wants to speculate can just go on doing that. All I can say is that right now in Germany we have no concrete plans," Mr Walter said, reporting a 60% rise in pre-tax profit to €500m (£310m) for the first two months of the year.

"As for concrete foreign talks, none right now. Takeovers are always possible. They were possible before. They're possible now."

His counterpart at Deutsche, Rolf Breuer, has so far retained his role despite speculation that he too will leave following the collapse of the merger, which was blamed on disagreements over Kleinwort. Mr Breuer originally described the investment bank as a jewel but it later emerged that he was considering selling it.

Dresdner acknowledged yesterday that Kleinwort was the main driver behind its record profits last year of €2.1bn. The investment bank's profits rose by 85% to €954m in 1999, but Dresdner said they were unlikely to be so large this year because of the loyalty payments to staff and a fall in revenues as a result of the uncertainty inside the operation.

Mr Walter, who is to be succeeded by Bernd Fahrholz at the end of the month, said yesterday that he bank would not press ahead with the "fitness" plan it had devised before the merger. He rejected claims that Allianz, a big shareholder in the bank, had forced him into the deal with Deutsche in the first place.

fields.headline: Banker jailed for taking bribes
fields.trailText: The former head of a merchant banking offshoot of HSBC was yesterday jailed by a Hong Kong court for five years, having been convicted of taking bribes two decades ago totalling more than £360,000. Ewan Quayle Launder was ordered to return his payoffs to HSBC.
fields.body:
The former head of a merchant banking offshoot of HSBC was yesterday jailed by a Hong Kong court for five years, having been convicted of taking bribes two decades ago totalling more than £360,000. Ewan Quayle Launder was ordered to return his payoffs to HSBC.

Launder, aged 63, who fought extradition from Britain between 1993 and 1998, was found guilty of taking the money from Hong Kong property group Carrian in October 1980, in return for favourable treatment for major financing deals when he was head of HSBC's Wardley subsidiary.

Carrian collapsed in 1983 with debts of about £700m, amid allegations of widespread corruption in Malaysia and elsewhere.

Launder was convicted last month of accepting the bribes from Carrian boss George Tan. But he was was acquitted of 12 other counts.

In sentencing him yesterday, Judge Gareth Lugan-Mawson in the Court of First Instance called Launder's crimes the worst case of corruption in Hong Kong's private sector, but he gave Launder less than the maximum sentence of seven years, in part because of his previous clean record.

The judge also ordered Launder to repay Wardley's parent, banking company HSBC, the sum he had accepted and barred him from serving as a company director for seven years.

Launder's defence had been that the money was paid because Launder was making investments for the companies, and did not constitute bribes.

George Tan was jailed in 1996 to charges of conspiracy to defraud and was released in 1998.

In the 20 years since Launder's offence, HSBC - which was then known as the Hongkong & Shanghai Banking Corporation - has changed out of all recognition, taking over Britain's Midland Bank and reducing its emphasis on the Far East. Wardley no longer exists in its previous form.

fields.headline: Oxford minnow wins biotech battle
fields.standfirst: High court ruling causes £200m slide in US group's shares
fields.trailText: A tiny Oxford genetics company with five staff yesterday won a high court battle against one of the world's largest biotechnology companies, Affymetrix. The outcome caused a £200m slide in the California-based group's market value.
fields.body:
A tiny Oxford genetics company with five staff yesterday won a high court battle against one of the world's largest biotechnology companies, Affymetrix. The outcome caused a £200m slide in the California-based group's market value.

A judge decided Affymetrix was not entitled to use intellectual property owned by Oxford Gene Technology, a company set up by biology professor Ed Southern.

The technology allows genetic information to be stored on slides or chips. Oxford Gene Technology maintained it was central to Affymetrix's main products, used in the development of gene-based medicines.

Affymetrix immediately said it would appeal. It argued that it bought a licence to the technology from another company, Beckman Coulter, two years ago. OGT claims that if the ruling is upheld the result could destroy Affymetrix.

Chris Shelley of OGT's lawyer, Manches Solicitors, said: "If a company's entire business consists of infringing a patent, you can shut them down."

Affymetrix supplies gene analysis materials to drug development firms. Its main products are called GeneChips, which store DNA in a convenient way for analysis.

Professor Southern claims he invented the array process used to create these. "We cannot allow infringements of our patents to go unchallenged: this would not be fair on others who have willingly entered into licence agreements with us."

OGT plans to apply to a US federal court in October for an injunction restricting Affymetrix's activities. Mr Shelley said: "It may well be that by then OGT and Affymetrix could reach an agreement. But if not it follows as night follows day that an injunction would be the consequence."

Affymetrix's shares, quoted on the hi-tech Nasdaq market, fell 15% on the news. A company spokesman said: "This does not affect the day-to-day running of our business."

OGT is gearing up to commercialise its technology. Last year it recruited former British Biotech research chief Andrew Millar as its chief executive. Dr Millar caused a collapse in British Biotech's shares by exposing the management's over-optimistic strategy.

OGT vowed to press home its win. Prof Southern said: "Affymetrix was offered a licence on reasonable terms but tried to improve its position by entering into a complex series of arrangements with one of our licensees. We challenged their actions in the courts and I am pleased that our position was upheld."

However, Affymetrix said it would fight on. Its spokesman said: "We have over 70 US patents covering all aspects of array technology."

Affymetrix shares have been volatile following recent remarks by President Clinton about gene patenting.

webTitle: Radio win for Evans and MacKenzie

fields.headline: Radio win for Evans and MacKenzie
fields.trailText: Kelvin MacKenzie and Chris Evans, two of British radio's more colourful entrepreneurs, yesterday combined to win the second digital "multiplex" licence in London, which will support eight new stations.
fields.body:
Kelvin MacKenzie and Chris Evans, two of British radio's more colourful entrepreneurs, yesterday combined to win the second digital "multiplex" licence in London, which will support eight new stations.

Mr MacKenzie's Wireless Group owns 42.5% of the winning consortium Switchdigital, with Ginger Media Group holding 10%.

This was the second time Switchdigital had tried for one of the licences, which are awarded by the Radio Authority, after losing out to a Capital Radio/Emap joint venture in the contest for the first London multiplex last September.

The Switchdigital consortium has already agreed to broadcast Jazz FM, an easy listening station provided by Saga Radio, a soul station from Virgin and a Ministry of Sound dance station, spun out of the south London nightclub which has become a burgeoning business empire.

The other investors include US media group Clear Channel with 42.5% and Charles Dunstone's Carphone Warehouse, which will push the new digital radio sets, with a 5% interest.

Mr MacKenzie, who last week disclosed plans to float the Wireless Group, said digital radio was a long-term investment. "In the end it's the future of our industry. You can't just say you don't believe in it, because everything will be digital, from photography to television to radio. I've heard all the arguments against it but then I heard all the arguments against it in TV and digital is rocketing."

Digital radio transmits CD-quality sound and can also support data services such as traffic information But the take-off has so far been stalled by the prohibitive cost of the special radios needed to receive the signal. A Technics set on sale in Dixons costs £499.

Switchdigital saw off competition for the multiplex from a Border TV/Chrysalis consortium and a second between Scottish Radio Holdings, GWR and Guardian Media Group.

A third London multiplex will be contested although timing has yet to be announced. Other channels on the Switchdigital multiplex include a traffic and travel news station and an adult contemporary music station. The Wireless Group will run two of the stations, one devoted to speech and another to classic rock and sport.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: 221B Baker St to be sold | Leicester fails to play game | News Corp in digital link-up
fields.body:
221B Baker St to be sold

Sherlock Holmes's latterday landlord, Abbey National, is putting the great detective's home on the market - along with the rest of its £460m property portfolio. Holmes's London flat, at 221B Baker Street, was as much a figment of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's imagination as both Holmes and his sidekick Dr Watson. But when the Abbey National building society built its art deco headquarters at 200 Baker Street in 1932, it started receiving mail addressed to Holmes's flat. It promptly assumed responsibility for 221B, and appointed a member of staff to handle the detective's correspondence. Now Abbey National, converted to a bank, wants to realise the value of its property portfolio - possibly through a stock market flotation or trade sale.

Leicester fails to play game

Football club Leicester City yesterday failed to reflect the sound performance of its players when it turned a £1.03m loss in its first six months last year into a £3.38m loss in the six months to January 31. The fall came despite a rise in sales from £13.2m to £14.8m. However, operating profit before exceptional charges and player transfers provided some cheer. The club cut an £823,000 loss in the first half of 1999 to a £31,000 loss in the last six months.

Pound blamed as 255 jobs go

South African-owned Alloy Wheels International has blamed the strong pound and east European competition for its decision to close a factory in Cardiff with the loss of 255 jobs. The factory, which makes alloy wheels for the motor industry, is to close in July. There will also be job losses at the firm's tool-making division in nearby Taffs Well. The company said its staff had made dramatic improvements in productivity but it was unable to compete against cheap imports.

News Corp in digital link-up

Rupert Murdoch's News Corp and French conglomerate Vivendi confirmed yesterday that they are discussing plans to combine digital operations. News Corp is believed to be keen to split off its digital interests into a separate company, named Platco, which would involve Vivendi's Map internet joint venture with Vodafone AirTouch. Observers said News Corp may trade a minority interest for participation in Map and an agreement to include Vivendi's 25% stake in BSkyB in News Corp's digital venture. The venture will also include Mr Murdoch's Star TV, Sky Latin America and Foxtel.

M&S telecoms joint venture

Marks and Spencer Ventures, the e-commerce investment arm of the retail chain, yesterday entered into a three-year strategic partnership with Talkcast Corp to jointly develop and market telecoms and digital products and services for M&S customers. M&S Ventures will take a minority stake in Talkcast, which will offer the services through in-store promotions, mailshots, and website links. The first product is to be launched by the autumn, and the groups aim to attract 1m users in two years.

webTitle: How to raise your market value

fields.headline: How to raise your market value
fields.trailText: An estimated 12.5m people in the UK now own shares, and stockbrokers have seen the volume of private trades double within months as investors scrambled to buy - and sell - fashionable technology shares.
fields.body:
An estimated 12.5m people in the UK now own shares, and stockbrokers have seen the volume of private trades double within months as investors scrambled to buy - and sell - fashionable technology shares.

Yet despite this frenzied activity most people's portfolios are haphazard collections, assembled without much thought or discipline. Typically they might hold privatisation stocks like BT or BG, a few hundred shares in a couple of demutualised buildings societies like Halifax or Woolwich, a UK growth or index-tracking trust and a smattering of more speculative dot.com companies.

Against the background of volatile share prices, target=_new>MoneyUnlimited, the personal finance website of the Guardian, is offering a free tutorial all this week on how to buy shares and build a balanced portfolio. From trackers to Isas to portfolio management, we'll show you how to increase your market value.

webTitle: Border TV in talks with suitors

fields.headline: Border TV in talks with suitors
fields.trailText: Border Television said yesterday talks were continuing with a number of parties about rival offers for the group as it published its defence against the hostile bid from Scottish Radio Holdings.
fields.body:
Border Television said yesterday talks were continuing with a number of parties about rival offers for the group as it published its defence against the hostile bid from Scottish Radio Holdings.

Radio groups including Capital, Chrysalis, Scottish Media Group and Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group are understood to have approached Border in the four weeks since Scottish Radio made its offer. Guardian Media Group has also shown an interest.

Paul Corley, Border's chief executive, declined to comment on which parties might be involved but said talks continued "which may or may not lead to anything". That statement appeared to run against previous insistence that the group would retain its independence.

The Scottish Radio offer of 10 new shares for every 17 Border units values Border at 926p a share with a cash alternative of £10.25.

Border's defence maintains that Scottish Radio failed to recognise the "significant value" in the group. Richard Findlay, Scottish Radio's chief executive, said he saw nothing in the defence document to alter his view that the £110m offer was "full and fair".

webTitle: Licence auction expected to pass £20bn mark

fields.headline: Licence auction expected to pass £20bn mark
fields.trailText: Bidders took a breather yesterday in the auction for Britain's third generation mobile phone licences, but analysts predicted that the sum raised could top £20bn next week.
fields.body:
Bidders took a breather yesterday in the auction for Britain's third generation mobile phone licences, but analysts predicted that the sum raised could top £20bn next week.

Action was suspended at the request of the Spanish group Telefonica, which is thought to be considering whether to withdraw. Bids had reached £14.3bn on Thursday.

Observers expect further frenetic activity from Monday. Telecoms analyst James Ross of ABN Amro said: "I think there will be another couple of days of hard slugging before we get people withdrawing."

He believes the government could end up with a £22bn windfall for the five licences on offer - including £5bn for licence A, which is reserved for a new entrant to the market.

The licences cover new telecoms technology which will allow users to access the internet on their handsets, downloading music, pictures and email.

There are three serious contenders left in the race for licence A: NTL, the US group WorldCom and Canadian company TIW.

TIW was considered an outsider until yesterday, when it emerged that it has backing from the Hong Kong-based conglomerate Hutchison Whampoa. TIW confirmed it had con ducted "negotiations with Hutchison for financial and commercial support" for its UK operations. Hutchison has a strong track record in telecoms.

Mr Ross said there was still a case to be made for valuing the new licence at £5bn but added: "The risk profile of the thing working out is becoming rather worrying."

Another analyst agreed that the bidding war was likely to pass the £20bn mark: "I can definitely see it getting up to the 20s but I can't see it going much higher than that."

However, he said: "We're all clutching at straws - it's very difficult to call. It's a vicious circle for operators - they just have to have one of these."

Vodafone AirTouch has made the highest offer so far, pledging £3.63bn for licence B. It wants to expand its network, buying more capacity to increase its customer base.

BT Cellnet, Orange and One2One are all still in the chase - they are concerned that failure to secure a licence could cause a slump in their stock market values.
