webTitle: Big boss, big fees and big trouble

fields.headline: Big boss, big fees and big trouble
fields.standfirst: John Varley, head of retail financial services, Barclays
fields.trailText: John Varley, head of retail financial services, Barclays
fields.body:
John Varley has been left to take the flak. Tall and elegant, he is the solitary voice explaining the brutal closure of 171 Barclays branches. There is no sign of Matt Barrett, the multimillionaire chief executive of the "big bank for the big world", who stands to make amounts in a performance-related pay deal that would make even the fattest of the fat cats weep.

Such is the confusion about the fiendishly complicated structure of the package that even top remuneration experts cannot agree on the possible rewards for the top bosses at the bank: £30m, or 36 times salary, is a possible payout for Barrett; for Varley the figure might be £15m.

Bad timing
While revelations about potential pay deals never come at a good time for companies, for Barclays the timing could not have been worse. It left the 300 year-old bank, which is in the throes of cutting 6,000 jobs in the UK, ending the week with controversy over the pay deals after spending the early part fending off calls from the environment minister, Chris Mullin, for bank customers to vote with their feet because of the branch closures.

A clumsily-timed advertising drive proclaiming the benefits of the bank's size only made matters worse. Barclays refuses to confirm just how many millions its executives stand to make and pay is one thing Varley, the chief executive of Barclays retail financial services operations, really does not want to talk about. Fresh from a public grilling by John Humphrys, the veteran presenter of BBC Radio 4's Today Programme, Varley will only say: "I think being profitable is a good thing. I'm not apologetic for the profits Barclays makes."

Insiders, meanwhile, insist the plan is yet to have shareholder approval and could actually pay out nothing at all. For the record, however, Varley's pay rose last year by 60% to £627,000, while Barrett took home £1.3m for his first three months of work.

Zurich gnomes
The bank, Varley argues, offers good employment prospects for staff, good service to customers and much-demanded rewards for all-important shareholders. "Who owns Barclays? It's not 12 gnomes in Zurich. It's pensioners, your grandmother and mine," he says, adding that many of his 48,000 employees in the UK also own shares. "They watch [how] they perform," he says.

Without the branch closures - welcomed by the City when they were announced last year - Barclays might end up "in a grave like Rover or NatWest". This is why he will make "an apology for the inconvenience" to customers but not for the closures themselves. "This industry is going through a seismic change. When industry goes through changes you've got to to be at the front and that's something that can be uncomfortable," he says. The changes are those sweeping through every aspect of life brought about by changing patterns of work and the development of the internet. Rural communities and deprived areas are not being hit just by bank branch closures but by the end of local pubs and corner shops.

In 63 of the 171 locations in which Barclays is shutting branches, it is already the last bank on the local high street - a fact which has prompted criticism from the City that the bank has been too slow to cut its costs in an attempt to boost its returns to shareholders. To Varley, the fact that the bank is the last in some towns and villages is an indication of its commitment to the areas.

He insists that the bank has made alternative arrangements for customers through the post office network - in a deal signed at the eleventh hour - and also in 50% of cases there is another branch within three miles. He argues that customers want to use the bank in a different way than in the past - to pay gas bills at 9.30pm, say, or check their balance at 2am.

The bank claims to have more customers banking on the internet than any other, with 750,000, and says that another 20,000 registered last week alone. Even after the branch closures Barclays insists that it will still have more branches than any of its rivals - other than Lloyds TSB, with 1,729. "That's more than twice Nationwide, and three times Tesco, and both claim to have national coverage," says Varley.

Under scrutiny
The timing of the closures is not helped either by the fact that banks, always the people's enemy, are under unprecedented scrutiny as a result of the government's Cruickshank review. If Varley harbours any regrets about the decision to close all the branches on a single day while rivals have eased their closure programmes by doing them in dribs and drabs, he refuses to admit to them. A solicitor by training, this is not his first brush with controversy.

The issue of charging customers for withdrawing money from cash machines was raised by Barclays when it infuriated its competitors by altering the way it structured its charges. While customers had been paying to take cash out of machines for years, Barclays ended up receiving the brunt of the criticism for its proposed charges.

Described as extremely intelligent - he has a first class degree in history - and always polite, Varley's business last year generated £1.7bn of the £2.4bn profits the bank made last year. When he took on this role two years ago on April Fool's Day - which incidentally is also his birthday - he was cited as the heir apparent to the then chief executive, Martin Taylor. Much water has passed under the bridge since then, with Taylor flouncing out after a boardroom row and leaving the bank with a lengthy search for another chief executive. The first choice left after just one day in the job because of a health complaint, with Barrett eventually taking the helm in October.

Ambitious fantasy
Varley admits he harbours ambitions for the "fantastic job" but says he can learn from his new boss, Matt Barrett. He is rumoured to have been a strong candidate for the role during last year's extended search and it is unclear whether his 18-year marriage to Carolyn Pease, a member of one of the Quaker families which founded the bank, would be a help or a hindrance to achieve that goal.

Fiercely protective of his private life, he first joined the bank in 1982, working at the now defunct BZW investment bank and the asset management operation before moving to his current role and joining the board. His CV makes a reference to his mysterious one year's absence from BZW, the troublesome operation which was another source of reputation-battering stuff for the bank and ultimately the root of Taylor's sudden departure. Despite criticism relating to the timing of the £15m "brand building exercise", Varley is unrepentant about the new advertising campaign - unusual by banking standards, hinged as it is on the the idea that Barclays is big.

He highlights ambitions for the bank outside the UK, particularly in mainland Europe, and is an advocate of the view that in the coming years there will be so many mergers and takeovers that only a handful of major banks will survive. Unsurprisingly, he believes Barclays will be one of them. "The Barclays brand is one of the great financial industry brands of the world," he says. But for now the bank's attentions are likely to be closer to home as it tries to defuse the controversy.

Adverse publicity
Varley is full of praise for the employees in the Barclays branches around the country who, he admits, are having a "quite a difficult time because of the adverse publicity". He insists that the bank can now claw back its credibility after the torrent of bad news and damage to its reputation. "We want to move on," he says. But the major investors who are beginning to express concern about the risk of further damage to the accident-prone bank's reputational risk will not be willing to wait long.
fields.bodyText: John Varley has been left to take the flak. Tall and elegant, he is the solitary voice explaining the brutal closure of 171 Barclays branches. There is no sign of Matt Barrett, the multimillionaire chief executive of the "big bank for the big world", who stands to make amounts in a performance-related pay deal that would make even the fattest of the fat cats weep. Such is the confusion about the fiendishly complicated structure of the package that even top remuneration experts cannot agree on the possible rewards for the top bosses at the bank: £30m, or 36 times salary, is a possible payout for Barrett; for Varley the figure might be £15m. Bad timing While revelations about potential pay deals never come at a good time for companies, for Barclays the timing could not have been worse. It left the 300 year-old bank, which is in the throes of cutting 6,000 jobs in the UK, ending the week with controversy over the pay deals after spending the early part fending off calls from the environment minister, Chris Mullin, for bank customers to vote with their feet because of the branch closures. A clumsily-timed advertising drive proclaiming the benefits of the bank's size only made matters worse. Barclays refuses to confirm just how many millions its executives stand to make and pay is one thing Varley, the chief executive of Barclays retail financial services operations, really does not want to talk about. Fresh from a public grilling by John Humphrys, the veteran presenter of BBC Radio 4's Today Programme, Varley will only say: "I think being profitable is a good thing. I'm not apologetic for the profits Barclays makes." Insiders, meanwhile, insist the plan is yet to have shareholder approval and could actually pay out nothing at all. For the record, however, Varley's pay rose last year by 60% to £627,000, while Barrett took home £1.3m for his first three months of work. Zurich gnomes The bank, Varley argues, offers good employment prospects for staff, good service to customers and much-demanded rewards for all-important shareholders. "Who owns Barclays? It's not 12 gnomes in Zurich. It's pensioners, your grandmother and mine," he says, adding that many of his 48,000 employees in the UK also own shares. "They watch [how] they perform," he says. Without the branch closures - welcomed by the City when they were announced last year - Barclays might end up "in a grave like Rover or NatWest". This is why he will make "an apology for the inconvenience" to customers but not for the closures themselves. "This industry is going through a seismic change. When industry goes through changes you've got to to be at the front and that's something that can be uncomfortable," he says. The changes are those sweeping through every aspect of life brought about by changing patterns of work and the development of the internet. Rural communities and deprived areas are not being hit just by bank branch closures but by the end of local pubs and corner shops. In 63 of the 171 locations in which Barclays is shutting branches, it is already the last bank on the local high street - a fact which has prompted criticism from the City that the bank has been too slow to cut its costs in an attempt to boost its returns to shareholders. To Varley, the fact that the bank is the last in some towns and villages is an indication of its commitment to the areas. He insists that the bank has made alternative arrangements for customers through the post office network - in a deal signed at the eleventh hour - and also in 50% of cases there is another branch within three miles. He argues that customers want to use the bank in a different way than in the past - to pay gas bills at 9.30pm, say, or check their balance at 2am. The bank claims to have more customers banking on the internet than any other, with 750,000, and says that another 20,000 registered last week alone. Even after the branch closures Barclays insists that it will still have more branches than any of its rivals - other than Lloyds TSB, with 1,729. "That's more than twice Nationwide, and three times Tesco, and both claim to have national coverage," says Varley. Under scrutiny The timing of the closures is not helped either by the fact that banks, always the people's enemy, are under unprecedented scrutiny as a result of the government's Cruickshank review. If Varley harbours any regrets about the decision to close all the branches on a single day while rivals have eased their closure programmes by doing them in dribs and drabs, he refuses to admit to them. A solicitor by training, this is not his first brush with controversy. The issue of charging customers for withdrawing money from cash machines was raised by Barclays when it infuriated its competitors by altering the way it structured its charges. While customers had been paying to take cash out of machines for years, Barclays ended up receiving the brunt of the criticism for its proposed charges. Described as extremely intelligent - he has a first class degree in history - and always polite, Varley's business last year generated £1.7bn of the £2.4bn profits the bank made last year. When he took on this role two years ago on April Fool's Day - which incidentally is also his birthday - he was cited as the heir apparent to the then chief executive, Martin Taylor. Much water has passed under the bridge since then, with Taylor flouncing out after a boardroom row and leaving the bank with a lengthy search for another chief executive. The first choice left after just one day in the job because of a health complaint, with Barrett eventually taking the helm in October. Ambitious fantasy Varley admits he harbours ambitions for the "fantastic job" but says he can learn from his new boss, Matt Barrett. He is rumoured to have been a strong candidate for the role during last year's extended search and it is unclear whether his 18-year marriage to Carolyn Pease, a member of one of the Quaker families which founded the bank, would be a help or a hindrance to achieve that goal. Fiercely protective of his private life, he first joined the bank in 1982, working at the now defunct BZW investment bank and the asset management operation before moving to his current role and joining the board. His CV makes a reference to his mysterious one year's absence from BZW, the troublesome operation which was another source of reputation-battering stuff for the bank and ultimately the root of Taylor's sudden departure. Despite criticism relating to the timing of the £15m "brand building exercise", Varley is unrepentant about the new advertising campaign - unusual by banking standards, hinged as it is on the the idea that Barclays is big. He highlights ambitions for the bank outside the UK, particularly in mainland Europe, and is an advocate of the view that in the coming years there will be so many mergers and takeovers that only a handful of major banks will survive. Unsurprisingly, he believes Barclays will be one of them. "The Barclays brand is one of the great financial industry brands of the world," he says. But for now the bank's attentions are likely to be closer to home as it tries to defuse the controversy. Adverse publicity Varley is full of praise for the employees in the Barclays branches around the country who, he admits, are having a "quite a difficult time because of the adverse publicity". He insists that the bank can now claw back its credibility after the torrent of bad news and damage to its reputation. "We want to move on," he says. But the major investors who are beginning to express concern about the risk of further damage to the accident-prone bank's reputational risk will not be willing to wait long.

fields.headline: Legal challenge could open floodgates
fields.trailText: A professional endowment trader is threatening to take Norwich Union to court over the big cuts in with profits bonus rates it announced earlier this year. It cut its key 25-year endowment return by 8.7%. and also slashed payouts on other policies.
fields.body:
A professional endowment trader is threatening to take Norwich Union to court over the big cuts in with profits bonus rates it announced earlier this year. It cut its key 25-year endowment return by 8.7%. and also slashed payouts on other policies.

Peter Barrett of Endowment Investments, based in Maidenhead, Berks, is angry because a policy he bought suddenly slumped in value. He says: "I have several policies, some for myself and some in my role as a professional policy trader. But they have all fallen in value and I want compensation."

In a letter to Norwich Union chief executive Richard Harvey, Mr Barrett asks for £1,490 for "the direct loss and expense" in connection with a policy he had bought. If Mr Harvey turns him down, he says he will sue.

He started negotiating for the policy in question last November and agreed on £7,400. This value, he says, took in a potential bonus cut in January. "But the fall was far tougher than anyone imagined," he says. "I calculated the original maturity value at £69,026 and now my arithmetic suggests £61,659. And while the market value, a sum that allows for a profit to the dealer, was £8,681, it has now fallen to £6,717 or less than I paid for it. Falls in other Norwich Union policies were not so severe," he claims.

Norwich Union says: "Against a wider background in recent years of lower interest rates and low inflation, our view of the longer-term investment outlook led us to further adjust annual bonus levels."

Mr Barrett is refusing to back down. "I'm determined to have Norwich Union discuss this in front of a judge. If I win, it will open floodgates."
